translation2.4: Results favored cephalosporins over penicillin.
translation2.5: The risk of treatment failure for bacterial strep throat is 2 times higher for oral penicillin antibiotics than for cephalosporins antibiotics.

1000139.Title: Clozapine versus perphenazine: the value of the biochemical mode of action of neuroleptics in predicting their therapeutic activity

abstract.1: The chemical structure of a neuroleptic does not relaibly predict the exact profile of its therapeutic action.
abstract.2: We considered the question whether the biochemical action of a neuroleptic, and specifically the ratio between DA-receptor block and NA-receptor block, might have a higher predictive value in this respect.
abstract.3: In this context we carried out a double-blind study of the therapeutic value of clozapine and perphenazine in acute psychoses of varying symptomatology and aetiology.
abstract.4: There are strong indications that clozapine has only a slight inhibitory effect on transmission in central DA-ergic neurons, but markedly inhibits transmission in central NA-ergic neurons, and that the reverse applies to perphenazine.
abstract.5: In view of these data we expected perphenazine to be a stronger antipsychotic and a weaker sedative than clozapine, and vice versa.
abstract.6: The plausibility of this hypothesis was demonstrated.
abstract.7: Partly also on the basis of earlier research, we concluded that the biochemical action of a neuroleptic is a more faithful predictor of its therapeutic action profile than the chemical structure.

translation1.1: The chemical structure (arrangement of chemical bonds between atoms in a molecule) of drugs used to treat psychotic disorders does not reliably predict how well the treatment works.
translation1.2: We looked into whether the biological and chemical changes made to the body by a drug to treat psychotic disorders might better predict how well the treatment works.
translation1.3: We did a study of how well antipsychotics clozapine and perphenazine treat short-term impaired relationships with reality with varying symptoms and causes.
translation1.4: Data suggest that clozapine and perphenazine have opposite effects on two types of neurons or brain cells.
translation1.5: We thought that perphenazine would be a stronger drug to treat impaired relationships with reality and a weaker sedative than clozapine, and vice versa.
translation1.6: This assumption proved reasonable.
translation1.7: Partly based on earlier research, we concluded that the biological and chemical changes to the body made by a drug used to treat psychotic disorders better predicts how well the treatment works than the arrangement of chemical bonds between atoms in a molecule.

13667001.Title: Clinical indications and toxicity of prolonged perphenazine therapy

abstract.1: CLINICAL experience with tranquilizers has shown the need for prolonged therapy for chronic neurotic and psychotic disorders.
abstract.2: Since phenothiazine derivatives such as perphenazine are being employed in this manner and since there have been rare reports of jaundice and leukopenia associated with its administration, questions about a potential deleterious effect of this drug on the liver and blood have to be answered.

translation1.1: Use of tranquilizers on patients has shown the need for long-term treatment of long-term neurotic and pyschotic mental disorders.
translation1.2: Because antipsychotic drugs like perphenazine are being used to treat long-term mental disorders and there have been rare cases of yellowing of the skin and a decrease in disease-fighting cells in the blood of people who take it, we must figure out whether this drug harms the liver and blood.

33099901.Title: Adding perphenazine to increase effectiveness of standard glioblastoma chemoirradiation

abstract.1: In the effort to improve treatment effectiveness in glioblastoma, this short note reviewed collected data on the pathophysiology of glioblastoma with particular reference to intersections with the pharmacology of perphenazine.
abstract.2: That study identified five areas of potentially beneficial intersection.
abstract.3: Data showed seemingly 5 independent perphenazine attributes of benefit to glioblastoma treatment - i) blocking dopamine receptor 2, ii) reducing centrifugal migration of subventricular zone cells by blocking dopamine receptor 3, iii) blocking serotonin receptor 7, iv) activation of protein phosphatase 2, and v) nausea reduction.
abstract.4: Perphenazine is fully compatible with current chemoirradiation protocols and with the commonly used ancillary medicines used in clinical practice during the course of glioblastoma.
abstract.5: All these attributes argue for a trial of perphenazine's addition to current standard treatment with temozolomide and irradiation.
abstract.6: The subventricular zone seeds the brain with mutated cells that become recurrent glioblastoma after centrifugal migration.
abstract.7: The current paper shows how perphenazine might reduce that contribution.
abstract.8: Perphenazine is an old, generic, cheap, phenothiazine antipsychotic drug that has been in continuous clinical use worldwide since the 1950's.
abstract.9: Clinical experience and research data over these decades have shown perphenazine to be well-tolerated in psychiatric populations, in normals, and in non-psychiatric, medically ill populations for whom perphenazine is used to reduce nausea.
abstract.10: For now (Summer, 2020) the nature of glioblastoma requires a polypharmacy approach until/unless a core feature and means to address it can be identified in the future.
abstract.11: Conclusions: Perphenazine possesses a remarkable constellation of attributes that recommend its use in GB treatment.

translation1.1: To improve how well treatment for glioblastoma, a type of brain cancer, works, we looked at studies on the disease-related processes associated with glioblastoma and their interaction with how the antipsychotic perphenazine affects the body.
translation1.2: That study found five areas of possibly helpful interaction.
translation1.3: Studies showed 5 independent qualities of perphenazine that might help treat glioblastoma, including changing how cells grow and move and reducing nausea.
translation1.4: Perphenazine can be taken with current chemotherapy and radiation treatments and with commonly prescribed glioblastoma drugs.
translation1.5: These qualities suggest the addition of perphenazine to current chemotherapy and radiation treatment should be studied.
translation1.6: Part of the brain sends out damaged cells that become recurring glioblastoma after they move outward.
translation1.7: This paper shows how perphenazine might decrease this activity.
translation1.8: Perphenazine is an old, generic, cheap drug used to treat psychotic disorders worldwide since the 1950s.
translation1.9: Studies over time have shown perphenazine does not cause many side effects in normal people, people with mental illness, and ill people taking perphenazine to reduce nausea.
translation1.10: As of Summer 2020, glioblastoma requires multiple drugs to treat it until and unless it is better understood and a single treatment drug is found.
translation1.11: We conclude that perphenazine has many qualities that suggest its use in treating glioblastoma.

translation2.1: To try improving treatment in glioblastoma (a brain cancer), this work collected data on the cancer's symptoms and traits along with references to perphenazine (an anti-psychotic medication).
translation2.2: This study found five areas of possibly beneficial treatment.
translation2.3: 5 perphenazine attributes of benefit to glioblastoma treatment include blocking two target sites for chemical messengers, reducing movement of specific cells, activating certain enzymes, and reducing nausea.
translation2.4: Perphenazine works with current chemradiotherapy and common medicines used to treat glioblastoma.
translation2.5: Perphenzaine attributes argue for a trial to add it to current standard treatment with temozolomide (an anti-cancer drug) and irradiation.
translation2.6: A specific brain region seeds the brain with mutated cells that become reappearing gliobastoma after outward movement.
translation2.7: The current work shows how perphenazine may reduce this outward growing brain cancer.
translation2.8: Perphenazine is an old, common, cheap antipsychotic drug used clinically worldwide since the 1950's.
translation2.9: Perphenzaine has been well-tolerated in psychiatric groups, in healthy groups, and in non-psychiatric but medically ill groups who use perphenazine to reduce nausea.
translation2.10: For now (Summer, 2020), glioblastoma needs a multi-drug approach until a core treatment can be identified.
translation2.11: Perphenazine has many attributes that recommend its use in glioblastoma treatment.

abstract.1: Background: Perphenazine is an old phenothiazine antipsychotic with a potency similar to haloperidol.
abstract.2: It has been used for many years and is popular in the northern European countries and Japan.
abstract.3: Objectives: To examine the clinical effects and safety of perphenazine for those with schizophrenia and schizophrenia-like psychoses.
abstract.4: Authors' conclusions: Although perphenazine has been used in randomised trials for more than 50 years, incomplete reporting and the variety of comparators used make it impossible to draw clear conclusions.
abstract.5: All data for the main outcomes in this review were of very low quality evidence.
abstract.6: At best we can say that perphenazine showed similar effects and adverse events as several of the other antipsychotic drugs.
abstract.7: Since perphenazine is a relatively inexpensive and frequently used compound, further trials are justified to clarify the properties of this classical antipsychotic drug.

translation1.1: Perphenazine is an old drug used to treat psychotic disorders with strength similar to haloperidol, another drug to treat psychotic disorders.
translation1.2: Perphenazine has been used for many years and is popular in the northern European countries and Japan.
translation1.3: We aimed to look at the effects and safety of perphenazine in people with schizophrenia (a reality-distorting mental illness) and schizophrenia-like disorders.
translation1.4: We conclude that although perphenazine has been used for more than 50 years, incomplete results and the variety of drugs used to compare perphenazine to make it impossible to make clear judgements.
translation1.5: The results used in this review were not reliable.
translation1.6: The most we can say is that perphenazine had similar results and side effects as many other drugs used to treat psychotic disorders.
translation1.7: Because perphenazine is a cheap and often used drug, more studies are needed to fully understand the drug's properties.

25290157.Title: Perphenazine versus low-potency first-generation antipsychotic drugs for schizophrenia

abstract.1: Background: Antipsychotic drugs are the core treatment for schizophrenia.
abstract.2: Treatment guidelines state that there is no difference in efficacy between the various first-generation antipsychotics, however, low-potency first-generation antipsychotic drugs are sometimes perceived as less efficacious than high-potency first-generation compounds by clinicians, and they also seem to differ in their side effects.
abstract.3: Authors' conclusions: The results do not show a superiority in efficacy of high-potency perphenazine compared with low-potency first-generation antipsychotics.
abstract.4: There is some evidence that perphenazine is more likely to cause akathisia and less likely to cause severe toxicity, but most adverse effect results were equivocal.
abstract.5: The number of studies as well as the quality of studies is low, with quality of evidence for the main outcomes ranging from moderate to very low, so more randomised evidence would be needed for conclusions to be made.

translation1.1: Drugs used to treat psychotic disorders are the main treatment for schizophrenia (a reality-distorting mental illness).
translation1.2: Treatment recommendations say there is no difference in treatment effect among older drugs used to treat psychotic disorders. However, doctors sometimes think older drugs with lower strength used to treat psychotic disorders do not work as well as older drugs with higher strength, and they also seem to have different side effects.
translation1.3: We conclude that the results do not show that the antipsychotic perphenazine with its higher strength works better than older antipsychotics with lower strength.
translation1.4: Some evidence exists that perphenazine is more likely to cause restlessness and less likely to cause drug toxicity in the bloodstream requiring hospitalization, but most side effects were the same.
translation1.5: More evidence is needed to make judgements, as the number and quality of studies is low with medium- to very low-quality results.

32527541.Title: Repurposing of antipsychotics perphenazine for the treatment of endometrial cancer

abstract.1: Endometrial cancer (EC) is one of the most common and fatal gynecological cancers worldwide, but there is no effective treatment for the EC patients of progesterone resistance.
abstract.2: Repurposing of existing drugs is a good strategy to discover new candidate drugs.
abstract.3: In this text, perphenazine (PPZ), approved for psychosis therapy, was identified as a potential agent for the treatment of both progesterone sensitive and resistant endometrial cancer for the first time.
abstract.4: Specifically, perphenazine exhibited good cell proliferation inhibition in Ishikawa (ISK) and KLE cell lines according to the CCK-8 assay and colony formation assay.
abstract.5: It also reduced the cell migration of ISK and KLE cell lines in the light of the transwell migration assay.
abstract.6: Annexin-V/PI double staining assay suggested that perphenazine could effectively induce ISK and KLE cell apoptosis.
abstract.7: Moreover, results of western blot assay indicated perphenazine obviously inhibited the phosphorylation of Akt.
abstract.8: Delightedly, PPZ also could significantly attenuate xenograft tumor growth at both 3 mg/kg and 15 mg/kg in mice without influencing the body weights.

translation1.1: Endometrial cancer (EC), cancer of the lining of the uterus, is one of the most common and deadly cancers of the female reproductive system worldwide, but there is no working treatment for EC patients who do not respond to progesterone, a hormone.
translation1.2: Trying drugs used for other things is a good way to find new ways to treat conditions.
translation1.3: Perphenazine, used to treat psychotic disorders, might treat people with endometrial cancer who are both sensitive to and resistant to progesterone.
translation1.4: Perphenazine reduced growth of certain cancer-causing endometrial cells based on common lab tests.
translation1.5: Tests showed perphenazine also reduced movement of certain cancer-causing endometrial cells.
translation1.6: Tests suggest that perphenazine could kill certain cancer-causing endometrial cells.
translation1.8: Perphenazine also could reduce tumor growth in mice without affecting body weight.

translation2.1: Endometrial (outer womb) cancer (EC) is a common, fatal female-related cancer worldwide, but there is no treatment for EC patients of progesterone (specific female hormone) resistance.
translation2.2: Adapting current drugs is useful to discover new candidate drugs.
translation2.3: In this text, perphenazine (PPZ), used for psychosis, may treat patients with both progesterone sensitive and resistant outer womb cancer.
translation2.4: Perphenazine (an anti-psychotic) blocked cell growth in two, outer womb cancer cell groups.
translation2.6: Perphenazine could effectively cause controlled cell death in two, outer womb cancer cell groups.
translation2.7: Also, perphenazine could block phosphorylation of Akt, which activates the Akt enzyme which monitors cell growth.
translation2.8: Delightedly, perphenazine could weaken cancer growth from a different-species organ transplant in mice at various doses without affecting body weight.

16034865.Title: Depot perphenazine decanoate and enanthate for schizophrenia

abstract.1: Background: Antipsychotic drugs are usually given orally but compliance with medication given by this route may be difficult to quantify.
abstract.2: The development of depot injections in the 1960s gave rise to extensive use of depots as a means of long-term maintenance treatment.
abstract.3: Perphenazine decanoate and enanthate are depot antipsychotics that belong to the phenothiazine family and have a piperazine ethanol side chain.
abstract.4: Objectives: To assess the effects of depot perphenazine decanoate and enanthate versus placebo, oral antipsychotics and other depot antipsychotic preparations for people with schizophrenia in terms of clinical, social and economic outcomes.
abstract.5: Authors' conclusions: Depot perphenazine is in clinical use in the Nordic countries, Belgium, Portugal and the Netherlands.
abstract.6: At a conservative estimate, a quarter of a million people suffer from schizophrenia in those countries and could be treated with depot perphenazine.
abstract.7: The total number of participants in the four trials with useful data is 313.
abstract.8: None of the studies observed the effects of oral versus depot antipsychotic drugs.
abstract.9: Until well conducted and reported randomised trials are undertaken clinicians will be in doubt as to the effects of perphenazine depots and people with schizophrenia should exercise their own judgement or ask to be randomised.

translation1.1: Drugs used to treat psychotic disorders are usually given by mouth, but it is hard to measure if people take the drugs as instructed.
translation1.2: Slow-releasing shots, created in the 1960s, became popular as long-term treatment to keep conditions stable.
translation1.3: Perphenazine decanoate and enanthate are slow-release shots used to treat psychotic disorders.
translation1.4: We aimed to measure the medical, social, and economic effects of slow-releasing perphenazine decanoate and enanthate shots compared to no treatment, drugs used to treat psychotic disorders by mouth, and other slow-releasing shots used to treat psychotic disorders for people with schizophrenia (a reality-distorting mental illness).
translation1.5: We state that slow-releasing perphenazine shots are used in Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden, Belgium, Portugal, and the Netherlands.
translation1.6: At least 250,000 people have schizophrenia in these countries and could be given slow-releasing perphenazine shots.
translation1.7: The four trials with useful results had 313 total people.
translation1.8: None of the studies compared the effects of antipsychotics taken by mouth to a slow-releasing shot.
translation1.9: People with schizophrenia should use their own judgement until more studies are done and doctors know the effects of slow-release perphenazine shots.

33449568.Title: Oral Perphenazine 8 mg: A Low-Cost, Efficacious Antiemetic Option

abstract.1: We have found oral perphenazine 8 mg (OP8) useful as follows: (1) as a nonsedating antiemetic; (2) as a preventative measure similar to the antihistamine promethazine against ketamine-induced psychotomimetic effects; and (3) as a safe single-dose drug (only 1.3 extrapyramidal events per 10,000 patients receiving 4–8 mg oral dose, with all events easily treated).
abstract.2: Additionally, we evaluated the efficacy of single-dose OP8 to a single 40 mg dose of aprepitant given preoperatively in colorectal surgery patients at our academic center within an enhanced recovery protocol, which was designed to mitigate opioid utilization, reduce Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting (PONV), and optimize patient recovery.
abstract.3: In this retrospective study, no differences were noted in antiemetic requirement on postoperative days 0 and 1 between patients receiving OP8 versus aprepitant.
abstract.4: As enhanced recovery protocols become more widespread and continue to be applied to other surgical specialties, effective PONV prevention is imperative for improving patient outcomes.
abstract.5: OP8 deserves to be properly evaluated (by clinical study, and/or in routine clinical practice) as a part of a cost-effective multimodal enhanced recovery strategy.

translation1.1: Perphenazine 8 mg (OP8) can be taken by mouth for the following uses: (1) as a nonsedating drug to prevent nausea and vomiting; (2) like promethazine, an antihistamine (allergy drug) , to prevent psychotic symptoms caused by ketamine (a pain relief drug); and (3) as a safe one-dose drug.
translation1.2: We also rated the success of one-dose OP8 compared to one 40 mg dose of aprepitant, used to prevent nausea and vomiting, given to people before rectum, anus, and colon operations in our center with guidelines designed to help people recover more quickly from surgery, reduce opioid use, and reduce nausea and vomiting after surgery.
translation1.3: In this study, we saw no differences in nausea and vomiting prevention on the same day of surgery and one day after surgery between patients who got OP8 versus aprepitant.
translation1.4: As guidelines to help people recover more quickly from surgery become more widespread and used for other surgeries, successfully preventing nausea and vomiting after surgery is key to improving patient results.
translation1.5: OP8 should be studied as part of a cost-effective, multi-process way to help people recover more quickly from surgery.

20739894.Title: Efficacy of perphenazine to prevent postoperative nausea and vomiting: a quantitative systematic review

abstract.1: Background and objective: despite the introduction of newer antiemetics in the prevention of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), perphenazine is recommended in current guidelines, as the concept of multimodal management of PONV in high-risk patients requires more than two drugs to be combined.
abstract.2: The aim of this quantitative systematic review was to assess the efficacy and safety of perphenazine in the prophylaxis of PONV in adults and children.
abstract.3: Results: eleven trials published between 1965 and 1999 including a total of 2081 participants fulfilled the inclusion criteria and were further analysed.
abstract.4: In children, perphenazine 0.07 mg kg was effective in preventing vomiting (RR, 0.31; 95% CI, 0.18-0.54), whereas in adults, a dose of about 5 mg was effective for the prevention of PONV (RR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.37-0.67).
abstract.5: When compared with established newer drugs, for example, ondansetron, dexamethasone or droperidol, no significant differences were observed in the pooled analysis with limited data.
abstract.6: Reporting of adverse events was poor.
abstract.7: Transient sedation was reported in three eligible trials (RR, 0.9; 95% CI, 0.40-2.05).
abstract.8: Conclusion: there is evidence that perphenazine is effective in the prevention of PONV in children and adults without serious adverse effects compared with placebo.

translation1.1: Even though there are newer drugs to prevent nausea and vomiting after surgery, current guidelines recommend the drug perphenazine. A multi-process way to prevent nausea and vomiting in high-risk patients requires using more than two drugs.
translation1.2: We aimed to rate the success and safety of perphenazine in prevention of nausea and vomiting in adults and children.
translation1.3: We looked at eleven studies published between 1965 and 1999 with a total of 2081 people.
translation1.4: Perphenazine 0.07 mg kg and 5 mg prevented nausea and vomiting in children and adults, respectively.
translation1.5: We saw no big differences compared to newer drugs like ondansetron, dexamethasone or droperidol in studies with limited results.
translation1.6: Side effects were not well reported.
translation1.7: Short-term sedation occurred in three studies.
translation1.8: Studies show that perphenazine prevents nausea and vomiting in children and adults without serious side effects compared to sham treatment.

translation2.1: Despite newer anti-nausea drugs, perphenazine (an anti-psychotic) is still used in multimodal treatment of nausea and vomiting post-operation in high-risk patients that need two or more drugs.
translation2.2: This work measures the success and safety of perphenazine in preventing post-operation nausea and vomiting.
translation2.3: Eleven trials published between 1965 and 1999 included 2081 total participats for analysis.
translation2.4: In children, 0.07 mg kg of perphenzaine prevented vomiting while 5 mg prevented post-operation nausea and vomiting in adults.
translation2.5: Compared to newer anti-nausea and -vomiting drugs, no differences were observed.
translation2.6: Reporting of harmful events was poor.
translation2.7: Three trials reported temporary sedation or a calming effect.
translation2.8: Perphenazine may be effective in preventing post-operation nausea and vomiting in children and adults without serious harmful effects.

24242756.Title: Glioblastoma treatment using perphenazine to block the subventricular zone's tumor trophic functions

abstract.1: We present here a potential new treatment adjunct for glioblastoma.
abstract.2: Building on murine studies, a series of papers appeared recently showing that therapeutic irradiation of the ipsilateral subventricular zone (SVZ) retards growth of more peripherally growing cortical glioblastomas in humans, suggesting a tumor trophic function for the SVZ.
abstract.3: Further studies showed that SVZ cells migrate out towards a peripheral glioblastoma.
abstract.4: Dopamine signaling through D3 subtype receptor indirectly drives this centrifugal migration in humans.
abstract.5: Since psychiatry has several drugs with good D3 blocking attributes, such as fluphenazine, or perphenazine, we suggest that adding one of these D3 blocking drugs to current standard treatment of resection followed by temozolomide and irradiation might prolong survival by depriving glioblastoma of the trophic functions previously subserved by dopaminergic signaling on SVZ cells.

translation1.1: We look at a possible new treatment to add to standard treatment for glioblastoma, a type of brain cancer.
translation1.2: Based on mouse studies, several recent studies showed that radiation of the part of the brain where brain cells are made reduces growth of some glioblastomas in humans, suggesting this part of the brain might play a role in fueling brain tumors.
translation1.3: More studies showed cells from the part of the brain where brain cells are made move outward toward a glioblastoma.
translation1.4: Certain molecule signaling causes this cell movement.
translation1.5: Because many mental health drugs block molecule signaling, such as fluphenazine, or perphenazine, we suggest adding one of these drugs to the current standard treatment of surgery followed by chemotherapy and radiation to possibly increase survival time by cutting off fuel to the glioblastoma.

9.question: How to dislodge meat from throat?

7698623.Title: Management of foreign bodies of the upper gastrointestinal tract: update

abstract.1: Management of 242 foreign bodies of the upper gastrointestinal tract are reported.
abstract.2: Thirty-nine were in the pharynx, 181 in the esophagus, 19 in the stomach, and 3 in the small bowel.
abstract.3: The flexible panendoscope was used 211 times (87.2%) to manage these foreign bodies, while the rigid esophagoscope was used 12 times (5.0%).
abstract.4: Two hundred thirty-nine foreign bodies (98.8%) were successfully managed endoscopically.
abstract.5: The surgery rate was 0.4%.
abstract.6: There was no morbidity or mortality.
abstract.7: Twenty-five percent of the cases were done under general endotracheal anesthesia.
abstract.8: Coins in the esophagus are removed promptly if in the cervical or mid esophagus, and within 12 hours if in the distal esophagus.
abstract.9: Once in the stomach, they will usually pass without difficulty.
abstract.10: Meat impaction resulting in an obstructed esophagus is an urgent problem and the bolus should be removed within hours.
abstract.11: Sharp and pointed foreign bodies can be very difficult to manage.
abstract.12: Dry runs with a reproduction of the foreign body are essential to successful removal.
abstract.13: Button batteries lodged in the esophagus represent an emergency and should be removed without delay.
abstract.14: Once in the stomach, they will usually pass through the gastrointestinal tract without difficulty.
abstract.15: The forward-viewing flexible panendoscope has become the instrument of choice in managing foreign bodies in most tertiary medical centers as well as in the community hospitals.

translation1.1: We reported removal of 242 objects that shouldn't be eaten which were stuck in the mouth, throat, esophagus, stomach, and upper part of the small intestine.
translation1.2: Thirty-nine objects that shouldn't be eaten were located in the throat, 181 in the esophagus, 19 in the stomach, and 3 in the small intestine.
translation1.3: A flexible, telescoping tube with a camera was used 211 times (87.2%) to treat these objects, while the stiff, inflexible tube with a camera was used 12 times (5.0%).
translation1.4: Two hundred thirty-nine objects that shouldn't be eaten (98.8%) were successfully removed by putting a long, thin tube directly into the body.
translation1.5: 0.4% of people had surgery to remove the object that shouldn't be eaten.
translation1.6: Nobody had an illness or died.
translation1.7: Twenty-five percent of the cases required people to be put in a sleep-like state with a breathing tube.
translation1.8: Coins in the esophagus are removed quickly if they are in the uppermost or mid esophagus, and within 12 hours if in the lower esophagus.
translation1.9: If coins makes it to the stomach, they are usually passed easily.
translation1.10: Meat that gets stuck and blocks the esophagus is an urgent problem, and the blockage should be removed within hours.
translation1.11: Sharp and pointed objects can be hard to remove.
translation1.12: Practicing with a similar object is very important.
translation1.13: Button batteries in the esophagus are an emergency and should be removed immediately.
translation1.14: If button batteries make it to the stomach, they are usually passed easily.
translation1.15: A new kind of flexible, telescoping tube with a camera has become the tool to treat objects that shouldn't be eaten in most specialized medical centers and community hospitals.

15228825.Title: Management of foreign bodies in the esophagus

abstract.1: Objective: To evaluate management of foreign bodies in the upper gastrointestinal tract.
abstract.2: Patients and methods: A total of 103 patients with history of foreign body ingestion were included in this study.
abstract.3: X-ray neck and rigid oesophagoscopy was carried out in all patients for diagnosis and removal of foreign bodies.
abstract.4: A structured questionnaire was designed to record all information.
abstract.5: Results: Dysphagia (92%) and tenderness in neck (60%) were the most common clinical features.
abstract.6: Majority (89%) patients had come to the hospital within 24 hours.
abstract.7: X-ray of the neck (lateral view) was the most useful investigation with presence of air in the esophagus being a significant finding.
abstract.8: Post-cricoid region was the site of impaction of foreign bodies in 84% of the subjects.
abstract.9: The procedure of esophagoscopy was successful in 90 patients (97%) and failed in 3 patients (3%).
abstract.10: Coins were the most common foreign bodies (60%), followed by meat related foreign bodies (22.5%) and dentures in 5% cases.
abstract.11: Complications occurred in 18% patients and were more common in adults (37.1%) compared to children (8.8%).
abstract.12: The most serious complication was pneumomediastinum.
abstract.13: Maximum complications occurred with dentures (80%) and bone chips (42%).
abstract.14: Conclusion: Foreign body in the esophagus is a serious condition and early removal by rigid esophagoscopy is recommended which is a safe and effective procedure.

translation1.1: Our objective is to rate treatment of objects that shouldn't be eaten found in the mouth, throat, esophagus, stomach, and upper part of the small intestine.
translation1.2: We included 103 patients who ate objects that shouldn't be eaten.
translation1.3: Neck x-rays and a procedure that uses a stiff, inflexible tube with a camera were done to diagnose and remove the objects that shouldn't be eaten.
translation1.4: We recorded all information using a questionnaire.
translation1.5: Trouble swallowing (92%) and soreness in neck (60%) were the most common symptoms.
translation1.6: Most of the patients (89%) had come to the hospital within 24 hours.
translation1.7: X-rays of the side of the neck helped the most with air in the esophagus being an important finding.
translation1.8: The part of the throat that allows food to pass into the esophagus was where objects that shouldn't be eaten got stuck in 84% of people.
translation1.9: Using a flexible tube with a camera worked in 90 patients (97%) and didn't work in 3 patients (3%).
translation1.10: Coins were swallowed most often (60%), followed by meat (22.5%) and dentures (5%).
translation1.11: Complications happened in 18% of patients and were more common in adults (37.1%) compared to children (8.8%).
translation1.12: The most serious complication was air in the center of the chest.
translation1.13: People who swallowed dentures (80%) and bone chips (42%) had the most complications.
translation1.14: We concluded that objects in the esophagus that shouldn't be eaten are a serious condition and early removal by inserting a flexible tube with a camera is safe and works.

translation2.1: The objective is to rate treatment of foreign objects stuck in the upper digestive tract.
translation2.2: 103 patients that swallowed foreign objects were examined.
translation2.3: X-ray neck and esophagus checks were carried out in all patients for identifying and removing foreign objects.
translation2.4: A structured questionnaire was created to record all information.
translation2.5: Difficulty swallowing (92%) and neck tenderness (60%) were the most common medical attributes.
translation2.6: Most (89%) patients came to the hospital within 24 hours.
translation2.7: Neck x-rays (from the side) were the most useful scan, showing presence of air in the esophagus as an important finding.
translation2.8: A specific site near the bottom of the throat was the site of stuck foreign objects in 84% of patients.
translation2.9: Inserting a tube with a viewing lens into the esophagus worked in 90 patients (97%) and failed in 3 patients (3%).
translation2.10: Coins were the most common foreign objects (60%), followed by meat-related substances (22.5%) and dentures (5%).
translation2.11: Issues occured in 18% of patients and were more common in adults (37.1%) compared to children (8.8%).
translation2.12: The most serious issue was air trapped in the area between the lungs.
translation2.13: Serious issues occured with dentures (80%) and bone chips (42%).
translation2.14: Foreign objects in the esophagus is serious and early removal with esophagus checks, which are safe and effective, is recommended.

30454775.Title: Foreign Bodies of the Ear, Nose and Throat

abstract.1: Foreign bodies to the ear, nose, and throat often can be managed in the emergency department, particularly if the patient offers a history consistent with foreign body and is calm and compliant with the examination and removal attempts.
abstract.2: Tips for success include analgesia, adequate visualization, immobilization of the patient's head, dexterity and experience level of the provider, and minimizing attempts at removal.
abstract.3: It is critical to recognize the risks involved with certain retained objects (button batteries or sharp objects) and when to call a consultant to help facilitate safe, successful removal of objects to the ear, nose, and throat.

translation1.1: Objects that shouldn't be found in the ear, nose, and throat can be removed in the emergency room, especially if the information the patient provides lines up with an object that shouldn't be in the body and the patient is calm and agreeable with the exam and efforts to remove the object.
translation1.2: Tips for success include painkillers, the ability to see the object, keeping the patient's head still, skill and experience of the doctor, and removing the object with the least number of tries.
translation1.3: It is very important to realize the risks involved with certain objects (button batteries or sharp objects) and when to call a specialist to help ensure safe, successful removal of objects to the ear, nose, and throat.

31195771.Title: Removal of ear, nose and throat foreign bodies: A review

abstract.1: Background: Patients with foreign bodies in their ear, nose or throat typically present to general practitioners.
abstract.2: The safe and timely removal of foreign bodies ensures good patient outcomes and limits complications.
abstract.3: Objectives: The aim of this paper is to outline common foreign objects and review the associated anatomy that may make removal difficult.
abstract.4: A description of instruments and indications for use is provided, along with circumstances where specialist referral is warranted.
abstract.5: Discussion: The use of appropriate techniques for removal of foreign bodies reduces the complications of removal and associated distress, and limits the number of cases that require surgical input.

translation1.1: People with objects in their ear, nose or throat that shouldn't be there usually go to general doctors.
translation1.2: The safe and quick removal of objects that shouldn't be swallowed provides good results and reduces complications.
translation1.3: We aimed to list common objects that shouldn't be swallowed and look at the parts of the body that may make removing them hard.
translation1.4: We described tools and how to use them, along with times when a specialist should see the patient.
translation1.5: Using the right ways to remove objects that shouldn't be swallowed lowers the complications of removal and possible pain, and reduces the cases that require surgery.

32686966.Title: Clinical diagnosis and treatment of throat foreign bodies under video laryngoscopy

abstract.1: Objective: This study was designed to explore the clinical application of video laryngoscopy in the diagnosis and treatment of throat foreign bodies (FBs).
abstract.2: Method: In total, 1572 patients diagnosed with throat FBs at the Department of Otolaryngology of Nanjing Drum Tower Hospital were retrospectively analysed.
abstract.3: The covariables collected were the time from FB ingestion to admission, age, sex, duration of admission, and site of impaction.
abstract.4: Result: The most common FBs were fish bones, which accounted for 1446 (91.98%) of 1572 FBs.
abstract.5: Among all 1572 FBs, 1004 (63.87%) were successfully removed by video laryngoscopy without complications.
abstract.6: A shorter duration of admission was associated with a higher diagnostic rate under video laryngoscopy.
abstract.7: The diagnostic rate of sharp FBs was significantly higher than that of non-sharp FBs.
abstract.8: The most common sites of throat FBs were the tongue root (42.29%), epiglottic vallecula (19.40%), tonsil (18.21%), and piriform fossa (10.65%).
abstract.9: Conclusion: Video laryngoscopy is a powerful tool for the diagnosis and treatment of throat FBs, allowing for identification of rare locations of FBs as well as refractory FBs.

translation1.1: The study aimed to look at the use of a camera on the tip of a curved blade to diagnose and remove objects in the throat that shouldn’t be eaten.
translation1.2: We studied 1572 people who had objects in the throat that shouldn't be eaten.
translation1.3: We wrote down the time between eating the object and coming to the hospital, age, gender, how long the patient was in the hospital, and where the object was stuck.
translation1.4: The most common objects stuck were fish bones, which made up 1446 (91.98%) of 1572 objects.
translation1.5: Among all 1572 objects, 1004 (63.87%) were successfully removed using a camera on the tip of a curved blade without problems.
translation1.6: When a camera on the tip of a curved blade was used to diagnose the object, people left the hospital sooner.
translation1.7: Diagnosing sharp objects was higher than that of non-sharp objects.
translation1.8: The most common place that objects were stuck in the throat were the far back and bottom of the tongue (42.29%), the space between the back of the tongue and the windpipe entrance (19.40%), the tonsil (18.21%), and the bottom of the throat (10.65%).
translation1.9: We conclude that using a camera on the tip of a curved blade is a strong tool for the diagnosis and removal of objects in the throat that shouldn't be eaten, allowing for the finding of uncommon locations of objects and of objects not easily removed.

translation2.1: This work explored the use of video viewing of the voice box with a small device to identify and treat throat foreign bodies (FBs) or substances.
translation2.2: 1572 total patients with throat foreign substances at the Department of Otolarynology of Nanjing Drum Tower Hospital were analysed.
translation2.3: Time from foreign substance consumption to hospital admission, age, sex, duration of admission, and site of blockage were measured.
translation2.4: The most common foreign substance was fish bones, seen in  91.98% of patients.
translation2.5: Among all 1572 foreign substances, 1004 (63.87%) were removed by video throat treatment with a small device without issues.
translation2.6: A shorter hospital stay was linked to higher identification rate by video viewing of the voice box with a small device.
translation2.7: The identification rate of sharp foreign substances was higher than that of non-sharp ones.
translation2.8: The most common sites of throat foreign substances were areas near the tonsil and bottom of the tongue and throat.
translation2.9: Video viewing of the voice box with a small device is powerful for identifying and treating throat foreign substances. It allows identification of rare locations of foreign substances and stubborn ones.

17990843.Title: Foreign bodies in the ear, nose, and throat

abstract.1: Foreign bodies in the ear, nose, and throat are occasionally seen in family medicine, usually in children.
abstract.2: The most common foreign bodies are food, plastic toys, and small household items.
abstract.3: Diagnosis is often delayed because the causative event is usually unobserved, the symptoms are nonspecific, and patients often are misdiagnosed initially.
abstract.4: Most ear and nose foreign bodies can be removed by a skilled physician in the office with minimal risk of complications.
abstract.5: Common removal methods include use of forceps, water irrigation, and suction catheter.
abstract.6: Pharyngeal or tracheal foreign bodies are medical emergencies requiring surgical consultation.
abstract.7: Radiography results are often normal.
abstract.8: Flexible or rigid endoscopy usually is required to confirm the diagnosis and to remove the foreign body.
abstract.9: Physicians need to have a high index of suspicion for foreign bodies in children with unexplained upper airway symptoms.
abstract.10: It is important to understand the anatomy and the indications for subspecialist referral.
abstract.11: The evidence is inadequate to make strong recommendations for specific removal techniques.

translation1.1: Objects that shouldn't be in the ear, nose, and throat are sometimes seen by family doctors, usually in children.
translation1.2: The most common objects are food, plastic toys, and small household items.
translation1.3: Diagnosis is often late because the event that caused the object to get stuck wasn't seen, the symptoms are vague, and people often are diagnosed incorrectly at first.
translation1.4: Most objects stuck in the ear and nose can be removed by a skilled doctor in the office with low risk of other problems.
translation1.5: Common methods to remove the object include the use of forceps, flushing with water, and using a long, flexible suction tube.
translation1.6: Objects stuck in the throat or windpipe are emergencies and considered for surgery.
translation1.7: X-rays are often normal.
translation1.8: Flexible or stiff tubes with cameras are usually needed to make sure the diagnosis is correct and to remove the object.
translation1.9: Doctors need to have a good reason to think there might be an object stuck in children with unexplained upper airway symptoms.
translation1.10: It is important to understand the body’s structure and reasons to refer to a subspecialist.
translation1.11: The available information is not enough to make strong recommendations for specific ways to remove objects.

abstract.1: Dysphagia is common but may be underreported.
abstract.2: Specific symptoms, rather than their perceived location, should guide the initial evaluation and imaging.
abstract.3: Obstructive symptoms that seem to originate in the throat or neck may actually be caused by distal esophageal lesions.
abstract.4: Oropharyngeal dysphagia manifests as difficulty initiating swallowing, coughing, choking, or aspiration, and it is most commonly caused by chronic neurologic conditions such as stroke, Parkinson disease, or dementia.
abstract.5: Symptoms should be thoroughly evaluated because of the risk of aspiration.
abstract.6: Patients with esophageal dysphagia may report a sensation of food getting stuck after swallowing.
abstract.7: This condition is most commonly caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease and functional esophageal disorders.
abstract.8: Eosinophilic esophagitis is triggered by food allergens and is increasingly prevalent; esophageal biopsies should be performed to make the diagnosis.
abstract.9: Esophageal motility disorders such as achalasia are relatively rare and may be overdiagnosed.
abstract.10: Opioid-induced esophageal dysfunction is becoming more common.
abstract.11: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is recommended for the initial evaluation of esophageal dysphagia, with barium esophagography as an adjunct.
abstract.12: Esophageal cancer and other serious conditions have a low prevalence, and testing in low-risk patients may be deferred while a four-week trial of acid-suppressing therapy is undertaken.
abstract.13: Many frail older adults with progressive neurologic disease have significant but unrecognized dysphagia, which significantly increases their risk of aspiration pneumonia and malnourishment.
abstract.14: In these patients, the diagnosis of dysphagia should prompt a discussion about goals of care before potentially harmful interventions are considered.
abstract.15: Speech-language pathologists and other specialists, in collaboration with family physicians, can provide structured assessments and make appropriate recommendations for safe swallowing, palliative care, or rehabilitation.

translation1.1: Trouble swallowing is common but may be underreported.
translation1.2: Specific symptoms, not the area where they are thought to come from, should guide the first exam and visual tests.
translation1.3: Symptoms of difficulty breathing that seem to come from the throat or neck may actually be caused by damage in the lower esophagus.
translation1.4: Difficulty swallowing that happens in the mouth or the throat shows up as difficulty starting swallowing, coughing, choking, or something entering the airway or lungs by accident. It is most often caused by long-term brain conditions such as stroke, Parkinson's, or memory, language, and thinking loss.
translation1.5: Symptoms should be looked at closely due to the risk of something entering the airway or lungs by accident.
translation1.6: People with problems that happen during swallowing may describe a feeling of food getting stuck after swallowing.
translation1.7: Problems that happen during swallowing is most often caused by stomach-related reflux diseases and disorders of the esophagus with symptoms like heartburn and chest pain.
translation1.8: A long-term allergic condition of the esophagus is set off by food allergens and is more and more common. To diagnose this condition, a small part of the esophagus should be removed for examination.
translation1.9: Dysfunction of the esophagus that causes difficulty swallowing such as a disorder in which your esophagus is unable to move food and liquids down into your stomach are pretty rare and may be overdiagnosed.
translation1.10: Dysfunction of the esophagus caused by opioids is becoming more common.
translation1.11: Using a flexible tube with a camera to look at the esophagus, stomach and part of the small intestine is used to look at difficulty swallowing that happens in the mouth and throat, together with barium and X-rays.
translation1.12: Cancer of the esophagus and other serious conditions are not common, and low-risk people may take acid reducers for 4 weeks before undergoing testing.
translation1.13: Many weak older adults with progressive deterioration in functioning have serious but unseen difficulty swallowing, which really increases their risk of pneumonia (lung infection) caused by something entering the airway or lungs by accident and risk of lacking nutrients in the body.
translation1.14: In these people, the diagnosis of difficulty breathing should lead to a conversation about what is important to the person before suggesting possibly harmful treatments.
translation1.15: People who treat communication and swallowing disorders and other specialists, working with family doctors, can evaluate and make suggestions for safe swallowing, care for people living with a serious illness, or rehab.

abstract.1: Most swallowing problems can be treated, although the treatment depends on the type of dysphagia.
abstract.2: A multidisciplinary team of surgeons, phoniatrists, and speech-language therapists is necessary to develop the appropriate treatment strategy.
abstract.3: A thorough medical history, clinical investigation of the swallowing muscles, and fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing with foods of different consistencies help to decide whether swallowing exercises alone are sufficient, or whether an additional pharmacologic or surgical treatment is needed to prevent aspiration, malnutrition, and dehydration.

translation1.1: Most swallowing problems can be fixed, although the treatment depends on the type of trouble swallowing.
translation1.2: A team of surgeons, doctors who treat organs involved in speech production, and people who treat communication and swallowing disorders is needed to figure out the best treatment.
translation1.3: Information provided by the patient, examination of the swallowing muscles, and using a flexible tube with a camera to see swallowing of different foods help decide whether swallowing exercises are enough, or whether drugs or surgery are also needed to prevent something entering the airway or lungs by accident, prevent a lack of nutrients in the body, and prevent a lack of fluid in the body.

translation2.1: Most swallowing problems can be treated, but the treatment depends on the type of swallowing difficulty.
translation2.2: A multi-type team of surgeons, speech-related organ specialists, and speech-language therapists is needed to create appropriate treatment.
translation2.3: A clear medical history, swallowing muscle examination, and monitoring with small devices of swallowing of food with various textures help decide if swallowing exercises alone or additional drug or surgical treatment is needed to prevent breathing, eating, and hydration issues.

32773454.Title: ACG Clinical Guidelines: Diagnosis and Management of Achalasia

abstract.1: Achalasia is an esophageal motility disorder characterized by aberrant peristalsis and insufficient relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter.
abstract.2: Patients most commonly present with dysphagia to solids and liquids, regurgitation, and occasional chest pain with or without weight loss.
abstract.3: High-resolution manometry has identified 3 subtypes of achalasia distinguished by pressurization and contraction patterns.
abstract.4: Endoscopic findings of retained saliva with puckering of the gastroesophageal junction or esophagram findings of a dilated esophagus with bird beaking are important diagnostic clues.
abstract.5: In this American College of Gastroenterology guideline, we used the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation process to provide clinical guidance on how best to diagnose and treat patients with achalasia.

translation1.1: Achalasia describes a disorder in which your esophagus is unable to move food and liquids down into your stomach.
translation1.2: People often have difficulty swallowing solids and liquids, spitting up undigested or partially digested food from the stomach, and occasional chest pain with or without weight loss.
translation1.3: Measuring the strength and muscle coordination of your esophagus when you swallow led to the finding of 3 subtypes of achalasia that have different pressure and contraction patterns.
translation1.4: A lot of saliva and puckering where the esophagus is connected to the stomach, seen using a flexible tube with a camera, or a widened esophagus and narrowing where the esophagus is connected to the stomach, that looks like a bird's beak, found by X-raying the esophagus suggest achalasia.
translation1.5: In this guideline, we used a popular method to guide doctors on how best to diagnose and treat people with achalasia.

25328387.Title: Effects of aural stimulation with capsaicin ointment on swallowing function in elderly patients with non-obstructive dysphagia

abstract.1: Objective: In the present study, an attempt was made to examine the effects of aural stimulation with ointment containing capsaicin on swallowing function in order to develop a novel and safe treatment for non-obstructive dysphagia in elderly patients.
abstract.2: Patients and methods: The present study included 26 elderly patients with non-obstructive dysphagia.
abstract.3: Ointment containing 0.025% capsaicin (0.5 g) was applied to the external auditory canal with a cotton swab under otoscope only once or once a day for 7 days before swallowing of a bolus of colored water (3 mL), which was recorded by transnasal videoendoscopy and evaluated according to the endoscopic swallowing score.
abstract.4: Results: After a single application of 0.025% capsaicin ointment to the right external auditory canal, the endoscopic swallowing score was significantly decreased, and this effect lasted for 60 minutes.
abstract.5: After repeated applications of the ointment to each external auditory canal alternatively once a day for 7 days, the endoscopic swallowing score decreased significantly in patients with more severe non-obstructive dysphagia.
abstract.6: Of the eight tube-fed patients of this group, three began direct swallowing exercises using jelly, which subsequently restored their oral food intake.
abstract.7: Conclusion: These findings suggest that stimulation of the external auditory canal with ointment containing capsaicin improves swallowing function in elderly patients with non-obstructive dysphagia.
abstract.8: By the same mechanism used by angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors to induce cough reflex, which has been shown to prevent aspiration pneumonia, aural stimulation with capsaicin may reduce the incidence of aspiration pneumonia in dysphagia patients via Arnold's ear-cough reflex stimulation.

translation1.1: We looked at the effects of rubbing an ointment with capsaicin, found in different types of hot peppers, on the ears to improve swallowing function and create a new and safe treatment for old people who have the sensation of food stuck in the esophagus without physical blockage.
translation1.2: We looked at 26 old people who had the sensation of food stuck in the esophagus without physical blockage.
translation1.3: We used a Q-tip to put ointment with 0.025% capsaicin (0.5 g) in the ear only once or once a day for 7 days before drinking 3 mL of colored water, which was recorded using a flexible tube with a camera and rated using a common test that measures how well one swallows.
translation1.4: After putting 0.025% capsaicin ointment to the right ear, the common swallowing test showed less difficulty swallowing. This effect lasted for one hour.
translation1.5: After putting the ointment on alternating ears once a day for 7 days, the common swallowing test showed less difficulty swallowing in people with more serious sensations of food stuck in the esophagus without physical blockage.
translation1.6: Of the eight people fed with tubes in this group, three began direct swallowing exercises using jelly, which then returned their ability to eat food by mouth.
translation1.7: We concluded that putting ointment with capsaicin on the ear improves swallowing function in old people who have the sensation of food stuck in the esophagus without physical blockage.
translation1.8: In the same way as other methods to stimulate the cough reflex, putting capsaicin on the ears may decrease how often people with difficulty swallowing develop pneumonia, caused by something entering the airway or lungs by accident, through a cough reflex stimulated by a nerve.

10.question: I have a cut on my arm and my fingers are sweating and i feel pain in my fingers. What can i do to stop the pain?

abstract.1: The local, systemic, and referred causes of finger pain are generally recognizable by historical features and physical examination findings, although radiographs and laboratory evaluation are often required to support the diagnostic impression.
abstract.2: Most minor traumatic causes of finger pain require only conservative management, including immobilization followed by exercise.
abstract.3: Infectious causes of finger pain include cellulitis, tendinitis, paronychia, felon, and infectious emboli, which generally require antibiotics with or without drainage.
abstract.4: Certain patients with finger pain resulting from infection should be referred to a hand surgeon.
abstract.5: Vascular and ischemic causes of finger pain represent true emergencies, because tissue viability is dependent on prompt intervention.
abstract.6: Whereas any sensory neuropathy may present with finger pain, carpal tunnel syndrome is among the most common.
abstract.7: Systemic rheumatic disease, such as rheumatoid arthritis or vasculitis, may begin with finger pain.
abstract.8: In addition, such pain may be the first manifestation of a serious systemic illness, as in hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy.
abstract.9: Reflex sympathetic dystrophy is an example of referred pain, presumably by way of neural mechanisms.
abstract.10: Certain infectious, traumatic, and ischemic causes of finger pain must be diagnosed promptly to avoid significant morbidity; depending upon the cause of the symptoms, referral to a hand surgeon, rheumatologist, or neurologist may be appropriate.
abstract.11: Symptomatic and functional improvement may also be hastened by the input of an occupational therapist.

translation1.1: The causes of finger pain can usually be found by learning about the duration and severity of the problem and doing a physical examination. However, x-rays and lab tests are often used to identify the cause of the pain.
translation1.2: Most minor traumatic injuries that cause finger pain only need non-invasive (no surgery) therapy, such as resting followed by exercise.
translation1.3: Finger pain caused by an infection (germs that build in the body causing illness) usually require medicines that fight bacteria called antibiotics. A process called drainage that removes extra fluid from a wound is sometimes used with antibiotics.
translation1.4: Sometimes patients with finger pain from an infection will see a hand surgeon.
translation1.5: Limited or no blood flow to or through the tissues in the finger can cause finger pain, are signs of a true emergency, and require immediate attention to prevent more damage to the tissues.
translation1.6: Patients with nerve damage may have finger pain. Carpal tunnel syndrome (pain or tingling in the hand or arm caused by a pinched wrist nerve) is a common example of pain caused by nerve damage.
translation1.7: Diseases that can cause your immune system to attack your joints, muscles, bones and organs (called systemic rheumatic diseases) can begin with finger pain.
translation1.8: In addition, finger pain may be the first sign of a more serious illness, such as in hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy (a rare disease with irritation around the bone and enlarged fingertips).
translation1.9: Reflex sympathetic dystrophy (a disease causing long-lasting pain in one or more limbs) is an example of when an injury in one part to the body causes pain in a different part of the body.
translation1.10: Certain infections, traumatic injuries, and blood flow problems that cause finger pain must be identified quickly to prevent long-term or more serious damage. In some cases, going to a hand surgeon, a rheumatologist (doctor who treats arthritis and other joint, muscle, and bone diseases), or a neurologist (brain and nerve doctor) is needed.
translation1.11: Progress in reducing pain and improving movement in the finger may come faster with the help of an occupational therapist, people who help patients with injuries, illnesses, and disabilities build or restore their abilities to do everyday tasks in life.

translation2.1: Causes of finger pain are usually recognizable by past characteristics and findings from a physical checkup. However, radiographs (images created usually by x-rays) and other lab tests are usually required to support the identification.
translation2.2: Most minor causes of finger pain need only mild treatment, like restraining the finger from moving and exercise.
translation2.3: Causes of finger pain from bacteria include cellulitis (a bacterial skin infection), tendinitis (an irritation of the tendon), paronychia (a bacterial nail infection), felon (a bacterial fingertip infection), and emboli (a blood vessel blockage). These causes generally require antibacterials alomg with or without fluid drainage of the finger.
translation2.4: Some patients with finger pain from bacteria should be sent to a hand surgeon.
translation2.5: Causes of finger pain related to blood vessels represent real emergencies that depend on quick treatment.
translation2.6: When any nerve damage leads to finger pain, a pinched nerve in the wrist is usually the most common.
translation2.7: Full-body autoimmune diseases (diseases in which infection-preventing cells attack healthy cells), which may cause joint pain or irritation in the blood vessels, might start with finger pain.
translation2.8: Also, finger pain may be the first sign of a serious full-body illness, as in hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy, a rare disease with irritation around the bone and joints and enlarged fingertips.
translation2.9: Reflex sympathetic dystrophy (a disease causing long-lasting limb pain) is an example of pain felt in an area away from its source, possibly by nerve signaling issues.
translation2.10: Some bacteria-related, injury-related, and blood vessel-related causes of finger pain must be checked quickly to avoid serious harm. Depending on the cause, help from a hand surgeon, rheumatologist (a doctor who treats musculoskeletal issues), or neurologist (a doctor who treats nerve-related issues) may be needed.
translation2.11: Recovery may be quickened with occupational therapists that help patients perform everyday activities.

29184745.Title: Solving Hand/Finger Pain Problems with the Pencil Test and Relative Motion Splinting

abstract.1: When patients present with acute or chronic hand and/or finger pain after an injury, try placing a pencil first over and then under the proximal phalanx of the finger that is generating the pain.
abstract.2: Ask the patient to flex and extend the fingers several times.
abstract.3: Putting the affected metacarpal phalangeal (MP) joint more relatively flexed or extended than the other MP joints will often take away the pain with active movement with the pencil in place.
abstract.4: When this happens, our hand therapist builds a relative motion splint that simulates the effect of the pencil.
abstract.5: These are very functional splints that patients wear 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
abstract.6: Most people can work with these splints on.

translation1.1: When a patient has sudden or ongoing hand and/or finger pain after an injury, a hand therapist may place a pencil over and under the first bone of the finger (that starts at the base from the hand) that is causing the pain.
translation1.2: The doctor will then ask the patient to flex and extend the fingers several times.
translation1.3: Putting the first knuckle (the joint where the finger connects with the hand) in a more flexed and extended position than the other knuckles will often take away the pain with active movement when the pencil is in place.
translation1.4: The hand therapist will then build a relative motion splint (a piece of sturdy material to support injured bones and allow some movement) that will have the same effect of the pencil.
translation1.5: These types of splints support initial movement and can be worn 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
translation1.6: Most people can work with these splints on.

21493175.Title: Stellate ganglion blockade (SGB) for refractory index finger pain - a case report

abstract.1: Objective: To identify through case study the presentation and possible pathophysiological cause of complex regional pain syndrome and its preferential response to stellate ganglion blockade.
abstract.2: Setting: Complex regional pain syndrome can occur in an extremity after minor injury, fracture, surgery, peripheral nerve insult or spontaneously and is characterised by spontaneous pain, changes in skin temperature and colour, oedema, and motor disturbances.
abstract.3: Pathophysiology is likely to involve peripheral and central components and neurological and inflammatory elements.
abstract.4: There is no consistent approach to treatment with a wide variety of specialists involved.
abstract.5: Diagnosis can be difficult, with over-diagnosis resulting from undue emphasis placed upon pain disproportionate to an inciting event despite the absence of other symptoms or under-diagnosed when subtle symptoms are not recognised.
abstract.6: The International Association for the Study of Pain supports the use of sympathetic blocks to reduce sympathetic nervous system overactivity and relieve complex regional pain symptoms.
abstract.7: Educational reviews promote stellate ganglion blockade as beneficial.
abstract.8: Three blocks were given at 8, 10 and 13 months after the initial injury under local anaesthesia and sterile conditions.
abstract.9: Physiotherapeutic input was delivered under block conditions to maximise joint and tissue mobility and facilitate restoration of function.
abstract.10: Conclusion: This case demonstrates the need for practitioners from all disciplines to be able to identify the clinical characteristics of complex regional pain syndrome to instigate immediate treatment and supports the notion that stellate ganglion blockade is preferable to upper limb intravenous regional anaesthetic block for refractory index finger pain associated with complex regional pain syndrome.

translation1.1: The objective of this case report (a summary of an individual patient's symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment) is to identify the sign or symptoms and causes of complex regional pain syndrome (a form of ongoing pain that affects the arm or leg) and if a pain treatment called stellate ganglion blockade (an injection of medication into nerves at the front of the neck that can relieve pain) has any effect on the pain.
translation1.2: Complex regional pain syndrome can occur in the arms or legs after a minor injury, fracture, surgery, or nerve damage. It appears as sudden, random pain, changes in skin temperatures and color, swelling in ankles, feet or legs, and uncontrollable movements in the body.
translation1.3: Disease-related physical changes are likely to involve outer and central parts, nerve-related elements, and inflammatory elements, the body's natural response to injury or infection.
translation1.4: There is no consistent approach to treatment with a wide variety of specialists involved.
translation1.5: Diagnosis can be difficult. Sometimes it is over-diagnosed (diagnosis of a medical condition that would never have caused any symptoms or problems) from too much attention on the pain even though other symptoms are not present. Sometimes it can be under-diagnosed (diagnosed less often than its occurrence) when less obvious symptioms are not recognized.
translation1.6: A professional medical association for the study of pain supports the kind of pain block used in stellate ganglion blockade to reduce sensory nerves and relieve pain sympoms.
translation1.7: Educational reviews promote stellate ganglion blockade as beneficial.
translation1.8: Three blocks (injections) were given at 8, 10 and 13 months after the initial injury under local anaesthesia and clean conditions.
translation1.9: Physical therapy was provided after the patient received an injection to allow more movement of the joint and tissues and to help restore use of the injured finger.
translation1.10: This case shows that healthcare providers need to be able to identify clinical signs of complex regional pain syndrome to start treatment immediately. It also shows that stellate ganglion blockade is a preferable method to an IV of local anaesthetic (one-time injection of medicine that numbs a small area of the body) in the upper arm to help finger pain associated with complex regional pain syndrome.

24610977.Title: Low level laser therapy (lllt) for chronic joint pain of the elbow, wrist and fingers

abstract.1: Background and aims: In previous studies, we successfully applied Low Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in patients with non-specific chronic pain of the shoulder joint and lower back.
abstract.2: The purpose of the present study was to assess the effectiveness of LLLT for chronic joint pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.
abstract.3: Subjects and methods: Nine male and 15 female patients with chronic joint pain of the elbow, wrist, or fingers, who were treated at the rehabilitation outpatient clinic at our hospital from April, 2007 to March, 2009 were enrolled in the study.
abstract.4: We used a 1000 mW semiconductor laser device.
abstract.5: Each tender point and three points around it were irradiated with laser energy.
abstract.6: Each point was irradiated twice for 20 s per treatment, giving a total of three minutes for all 4 points.
abstract.7: Patients visited the clinic twice a week, and were evaluated after four weeks of treatment.
abstract.8: Pain was evaluated with a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS).
abstract.9: Statistical analysis of the VAS scores after laser irradiation was performed with Wilcoxon's signed rank sum test, using SPSS Ver.17.
abstract.10: Results: All VAS scores were totaled and statistically analyzed.
abstract.11: The average VAS score before irradiation was 59.2±12.9, and 33.1±12.2 after the irradiation, showing a significant improvement in VAS score (p<0.001) after treatment.
abstract.12: The treatment effect lasted for about one and a half days in the case of wrist pain, epicondylitis lateralis (tennis elbow), and carpal tunnel syndrome.
abstract.13: In other pain entities, it lasted for about three to fifteen hours.
abstract.14: No change in the range of motion (ROM) was seen in any of the 24 subjects.
abstract.15: Conclusion: We concluded that LLLT at the wavelength and parameters used in the present study was effective for chronic pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.

translation1.1: To treat patients with chronic shoulder and low back pain, previous studies have successfully used a treatment called low level laser therapy (LLLT), a laser light used at a low level and applied to the skin of the body to reduce pain or inflammation and help heal wounds, tissues, and nerves.
translation1.2: The purpose of this current study is to find out if LLLT also helps patients with chronic joint pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.
translation1.3: This study included 9 male and 15 female patients with chronic joint pain in the elbow, wrist, or fingers.
translation1.5: The tender point (specific area of pain) and three points surrounding the pain were exposed to the LLLT therapy light.
translation1.6: Each area was exposed two times for 20 seconds per treatment, giving a total of three minutes for all 4 points.
translation1.7: Patients visited the clinic twice a week, and were evaluated after 4 weeks of treatment with LLLT (laser therapy).
translation1.8: A tool called the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) was used to measure pain by asking patients to report how intense their pain is on a scale.
translation1.9: The study analyzed VAS scores (how patients described their pain) after they received the LLLT laser treatment.
translation1.10: All VAS scores that document pain intensity were totaled and analyzed.
translation1.11: There was significant improvement in how much pain patients felt after they received the treatment.
translation1.12: The effect of the laser treatment lasted for about one and half days for patients with wrist pain, tennis elbow, and carpal tunnel syndrome (pinched nerve in the wrist).
translation1.13: In patients with other types of pain, the effect lasted for about 3-15 hours.
translation1.14: There was no change in how far patients could move or stretch the injured part of the body after the treatment.
translation1.15: This study found that low level laser therapy was helpful for chronic pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.

translation2.1: In previous studies, we used Low Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), therapy with applying light on the body's surface, in patients with non-specific, long-lasting pain of the shoulder joint and lower back.
translation2.2: This work measures the success of this specific light therapy for lasting joint pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.
translation2.3: Nine male and fifteen female patients with long-lasting joint pain of the elbow, wrist, or fingers were treated at our hospital's recovery clinic from April, 2007 to March, 2009. These patients were employed in the study.
translation2.7: Patients visited the clinic twice a week and were checked after four weeks of treatment.
translation2.8: Pain was measured with a specific pain scale.
translation2.11: The average pain score noticeably improved after treatment.
translation2.12: The treatment effect lasted for about one and a half days regarding wrist pain, tennis elbow, and carpal tunnel syndrome, which involves pinched nerves in the wrist.
translation2.13: In other pain types, the treatment effect lasted for about three to fifteen hours.
translation2.14: No change in the range of motion was seen in any of the 24 patients.
translation2.15: LLLT at the settings used in this study was useful for long-lasting pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.

32100225.Title: Injection Techniques for Common Chronic Pain Conditions of the Hand: A Comprehensive Review

abstract.1: This compilation presents a comprehensive review of the literature on common chronic pain conditions of the hand.
abstract.2: It briefly presents these common conditions with their biological background, diagnosis, and common management options.
abstract.3: It then presents and compares the latest literature available for injection techniques to treat these diagnoses and compares the available evidence.
abstract.4: Results: Hand pain is a common condition with 9.7% prevalence in men and 21.6% in women and can cause significant morbidity and disability.
abstract.5: It also carries a significant cost to the individuals and the healthcare system, totaling in $4 billion dollars in 2003.
abstract.6: Injection therapy is an alternative when conservative treatment fails.
abstract.7: Osteoarthritis is the most common chronic hand pain syndrome and affects about 16% of the population.
abstract.8: Its mechanism is largely mechanic, and as such, there is controversy if steroid injections are of benefit.
abstract.9: Hyaluronic acid (HA) appears to provide substantial relief of pain and may increase functionality.
abstract.10: More studies of HA are required to make a definite judgment on its efficacy.
abstract.11: Similarly, steroid ganglion cyst injection may confer little benefit.
abstract.12: Carpal tunnel syndrome is a compressive neuropathy, and only temporarily relieved with injection therapy.
abstract.13: US-guidance provides significant improvement and, while severe cases may still require surgery, can provide a valuable bridge therapy to surgery when conservative treatment fails.
abstract.14: Similar bridging treatments and increased efficacy under US-guidance are effective for stenosing tenosynovitis ("trigger finger"), though, interestingly, inflammatory background is associated with decreased effect in this case.
abstract.15: When the etiology of the pain is inflammatory, such as in RA, corticosteroid (CS) injections provide significant pain relief and increased functionality.
abstract.16: They do not, however, change the course of disease (unlike DMARDs).
abstract.17: Another such example is De-Quervain tenosynovitis that sees good benefit from CS injections, and an increased efficacy with US-guidance, and similarly are CS injections for gout.
abstract.18: For Raynaud's phenomenon, Botox injections have encouraging results, but more studies are needed to determine safety and efficacy, as well as the possible difference in effect between primary and secondary Raynaud's.
abstract.19: Conclusions: Chronic hand pain is a prevalent and serious condition and can cause significant morbidity and disability and interferes with independence and activities of daily living.
abstract.20: Conservative treatment remains the first line of treatment; however, when first-line treatments fail, steroid injections can usually provide benefit.
abstract.21: In some cases, Hyaluronic acid or Botox may also be beneficial.
abstract.22: US-guidance is increasing in hand injection and almost ubiquitously provides safer, more effective injections.
abstract.23: Hand surgery remains the alternative for refractory pain.

translation1.1: This report presents a thorough review of the literature on common chronic pain conditions of the hand.
translation1.2: It briefly presents common conditions with their biological background, diagnosis, and common options to treat and manage pain.
translation1.3: The report also shows and compares the latest literature available for injection methods to treat these diagnoses and compares the available evidence.
translation1.4: Hand pain is a common condition occuring in 9.7% of men and 21.6% of women and can cause significant illness and disability.
translation1.5: It is also costly to the individuals and the healthcare system, totaling in $4 billion dollars in 2003.
translation1.6: Injection therapy (a treatment that involves inserting a needle into the skin to deliver medicine and reduce pain) is an option when other non-surgical treatments fail.
