translation1.6: The remaining 3 virus culture studies evaluated patients with severe or critical COVID-19 illness. COVID-19 was isolated up to 32 days in one of these studies.
translation1.7: Two studies identified immunocompromised patients (patients with decreased immune function) from whom COIVD-19 was able to be isolated from for up to 20 days.
translation1.8: For both contact tracing or spreading studies, when exposure occurred more than five days after symptoms were apparent, there was no evidence of COVID-19 spreading.
translation1.9: The authors concluded that COVID-19 patients with mild to moderate symptoms are unlikely to spread the virus to others beyond 10 days of symptoms.
translation1.10: However, studies have shown that patients with severe to critical symptoms, or those who are immunocompromised, may spread the virus for longer periods of time.

33176093.Title: SARS-CoV-2 Transmission among Marine Recruits during Quarantine

abstract.1: Background: The efficacy of public health measures to control the transmission of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) has not been well studied in young adults.
abstract.2: Methods: We investigated SARS-CoV-2 infections among U.S. Marine Corps recruits who underwent a 2-week quarantine at home followed by a second supervised 2-week quarantine at a closed college campus that involved mask wearing, social distancing, and daily temperature and symptom monitoring.
abstract.3: Study volunteers were tested for SARS-CoV-2 by means of quantitative polymerase-chain-reaction (qPCR) assay of nares swab specimens obtained between the time of arrival and the second day of supervised quarantine and on days 7 and 14.
abstract.4: Recruits who did not volunteer for the study underwent qPCR testing only on day 14, at the end of the quarantine period.
abstract.5: We performed phylogenetic analysis of viral genomes obtained from infected study volunteers to identify clusters and to assess the epidemiologic features of infections.
abstract.6: Results: A total of 1848 recruits volunteered to participate in the study; within 2 days after arrival on campus, 16 (0.9%) tested positive for SARS-CoV-2, 15 of whom were asymptomatic.
abstract.7: An additional 35 participants (1.9%) tested positive on day 7 or on day 14.
abstract.8: Five of the 51 participants (9.8%) who tested positive at any time had symptoms in the week before a positive qPCR test.
abstract.9: Of the recruits who declined to participate in the study, 26 (1.7%) of the 1554 recruits with available qPCR results tested positive on day 14.
abstract.10: No SARS-CoV-2 infections were identified through clinical qPCR testing performed as a result of daily symptom monitoring.
abstract.11: Analysis of 36 SARS-CoV-2 genomes obtained from 32 participants revealed six transmission clusters among 18 participants.
abstract.12: Epidemiologic analysis supported multiple local transmission events, including transmission between roommates and among recruits within the same platoon.
abstract.13: Conclusions: Among Marine Corps recruits, approximately 2% who had previously had negative results for SARS-CoV-2 at the beginning of supervised quarantine, and less than 2% of recruits with unknown previous status, tested positive by day 14.
abstract.14: Most recruits who tested positive were asymptomatic, and no infections were detected through daily symptom monitoring.
abstract.15: Transmission clusters occurred within platoons.

translation1.1: The strength of current public health measures to prevent the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), or COVID-19 (a viral respiratory disease), has not been well studied in young adults.
translation1.2: The authors investigated COVID-19 infections amongst U.S. Marine Corps recruits. These recruits underwent a two-week quarantine )or isolation) within their personal homes before participating in a second two-week quarantine. The second quarantine was supervised at a closed college campus where recruits wore masks, practiced social distancing, and received daily temperature and symptoms monitoring.
translation1.3: Participants in the study were tested for COVID-19 by using nose swabs taken between the time of arrival and the second day of supervised quarantine. A second COVID-19 test run with nose swab samples was conducted on days 7 and 14.
translation1.4: Marine recruits who did not want to participate in the study only received one COVID-19 test on day 14 (the final day of supervised quarantine).
translation1.5: To identify clusters of unique COVID-19 cases and to better understand how the virus affects public health, the researchers studied the genetic makeup of COVID-19 within samples from the nose swabs.
translation1.6: In total, 1848 recruits volunteered to participate in the study. Within the first two days of supervised quarantine, 16 recruits tested positive for (or had) COVID-19. Fifteen of the 16 positive cases did not show symptoms of illness.
translation1.7: An additional 35 participants tested positive on day 7 or on day 14.
translation1.8: Fifty-one participants tested positive at any time. Five of these patients had symptoms before their COVID-19 test returned positive.
translation1.9: Of the recruits who declined to participate in the study, 26 of the 1554 recruits with available COVID-19 test results were positive on day 14.
translation1.10: No COVID-19 infections were identified through clinical testing performed as a result of daily symptom monitoring.
translation1.11: The evaluation of the genetic makeup of the virus identified six spreading clusters among 18 participants.
translation1.12: Tracing of the virus transmission identified several spreading events, including between roommates and among recruits within the same platoon.
translation1.13: The authors concluded that among the recruits, around 2% of those who had tested negative for (or did not have) COVID-19 on day 1 of supervised quarantine, along with 2% of those with unknown previous status, tested positive by day 14.
translation1.14: Most recruits who tested positive showed no signs of illness. No infections were detected through daily symptom monitoring.
translation1.15: Spreading clusters occurred within platoons.

translation2.1: The effectiveness of public health policies to control the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which is a viral breathing-related disease, has not been well studied in young adults.
translation2.2: We checked SARS-CoV-2 infections in U.S. Marine Corps recruits who had a 2-week quarantine or isolation at home. They then had a second supervised 2-week quarantine at a closed college campus with mask wearing, social distancing from others, and daily temperature and symptom checks.
translation2.3: Study volunteers were tested for SARS-CoV-2 by swabs obtained between the time of arrival and second day of supervised isolation and on days 7 and 14.
translation2.4: Recruits who did not volunteer had testing only on day 14, at the end of the isolation period.
translation2.6: 1848 recruits participated in the study. Within 2 days after arrival on campus, 16 (0.9%) tested positive for or had SARS-CoV-2, 15 of whom showed no symptoms.
translation2.7: Another 35 participants (1.9%) tested positive or had SARS-CoV-2 on day 7 or day 14.
translation2.8: Five of the 51 participants (9.8%) who tested positive at all had symptoms in the week before a positive test.
translation2.9: Of those who decline to participate in the study, 26 (1.7%) of the 1554 recruits with test results tested positive on day 14.
translation2.10: No SARS-CoV-2 infections were detected by clinical testing performed for daily symptom checks.
translation2.11: Analyzing 36 sets of genetic data from 32 participants showed 6 disease-spreading clusters among 18 participants.
translation2.12: Analysis notes multiple disease-spreading events, including spreading between roommates and among recruits in the same military group.
translation2.13: Among Marine Corps recruits, around 2% with past test results detecting no SARS-CoV-2 at the beginning of supervised isolation, and less than 2% of recruits of unknown status previously, had results detecting SARS-CoV-2 by day 14.
translation2.14: Most recruits with positive tests had no symptoms. No infections were detected from daily symptom checks.
translation2.15: Disease-spreading clusters occurred within military groups.

32594116.Title: Distribution of Transmission Potential During Nonsevere COVID-19 Illness

abstract.1: Background: Patients recovering from coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) often continue to test positive for the causative virus by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) even after clinical recovery, thereby complicating return-to-work plans.
abstract.2: The purpose of this study was to evaluate transmission potential of COVID-19 by examining viral load with respect to time.
abstract.3: Methods: Health care personnel (HCP) at Cleveland Clinic diagnosed with COVID-19, who recovered without needing hospitalization, were identified.
abstract.4: Threshold cycles (Ct) for positive PCR tests were obtained and viral loads calculated.
abstract.5: The association of viral load with days since symptom onset was examined in a multivariable regression model, which was reduced by stepwise backward selection to only keep variables significant at a level of .05.
abstract.6: Viral loads by day since symptom onset were predicted using the model and transmission potential evaluated by examination of a viral load-time curve.
abstract.7: Results: Over 6 weeks, 230 HCP had 528 tests performed.
abstract.8: Viral loads declined by orders of magnitude within a few days of symptom onset.
abstract.9: The only variable significantly associated with viral load was time since onset of symptoms.
abstract.10: Of the area under the curve (AUC) spanning symptom onset to 30 days, 96.9% lay within the first 7 days, and 99.7% within 10 days.
abstract.11: Findings were very similar when validated using split-sample and 10-fold cross-validation.
abstract.12: Conclusions: Among patients with nonsevere COVID-19, viral loads in upper respiratory specimens peak by 2 or 3 days from symptom onset and decrease rapidly thereafter.
abstract.13: The vast majority of the viral load-time AUC lies within 10 days of symptom onset.

translation1.1: Patients recovering from COVID-19 (a viral respiratory disease) oftentimes continue to test positive for (or have) the virus. This can make "return to work" plans difficult.
translation1.2: The goal of this study is to evaluate COVID-19's ability to spread by determining the amount of the virus within an organism, known as the viral load, over time.
translation1.3: Health care personnel at Cleveland Clinic diagnosed with COVID-19, who recovered without needing hospitalization, were identified.
translation1.4: The viral load within the personnel was calculated.
translation1.5: The link between the viral load within the patient and the first day of symptoms was evaluated.
translation1.6: The viral load per day since the beginning of symptom onset within the patient were predicted using statistical models.
translation1.7: Over six weeks, 230 health care personnel had 528 tests performed.
translation1.8: The viral load within patients decreased within a few days of the beginning of virus-related symptoms.
translation1.9: The viral load within the patient was significantly linked to time since onset of symptoms.
translation1.10: The majority of the participants had peak viral load within the first 7 to 10 days.
translation1.11: Findings were similar when other statistical tests were run.
translation1.12: The authors concluded that among patients with no mild to moderate COVID-19, viral loads peaked by 2 or 3 days from symptom onset and decreased rapidly thereafter.
translation1.13: The largest amount of viral load was on average within 10 days of symptom onset.

27.question: How safe is the covid vaccine?

33301246.Title: Safety and Efficacy of the BNT162b2 mRNA Covid-19 Vaccine

abstract.1: Background: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection and the resulting coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) have afflicted tens of millions of people in a worldwide pandemic.
abstract.2: Safe and effective vaccines are needed urgently.
abstract.3: Methods: In an ongoing multinational, placebo-controlled, observer-blinded, pivotal efficacy trial, we randomly assigned persons 16 years of age or older in a 1:1 ratio to receive two doses, 21 days apart, of either placebo or the BNT162b2 vaccine candidate (30 μg per dose).
abstract.4: BNT162b2 is a lipid nanoparticle-formulated, nucleoside-modified RNA vaccine that encodes a prefusion stabilized, membrane-anchored SARS-CoV-2 full-length spike protein.
abstract.5: The primary end points were efficacy of the vaccine against laboratory-confirmed Covid-19 and safety.
abstract.6: Results: A total of 43,548 participants underwent randomization, of whom 43,448 received injections: 21,720 with BNT162b2 and 21,728 with placebo.
abstract.7: There were 8 cases of Covid-19 with onset at least 7 days after the second dose among participants assigned to receive BNT162b2 and 162 cases among those assigned to placebo; BNT162b2 was 95% effective in preventing Covid-19 (95% credible interval, 90.3 to 97.6).
abstract.8: Similar vaccine efficacy (generally 90 to 100%) was observed across subgroups defined by age, sex, race, ethnicity, baseline body-mass index, and the presence of coexisting conditions.
abstract.9: Among 10 cases of severe Covid-19 with onset after the first dose, 9 occurred in placebo recipients and 1 in a BNT162b2 recipient.
abstract.10: The safety profile of BNT162b2 was characterized by short-term, mild-to-moderate pain at the injection site, fatigue, and headache.
abstract.11: The incidence of serious adverse events was low and was similar in the vaccine and placebo groups.
abstract.12: Conclusions: A two-dose regimen of BNT162b2 conferred 95% protection against Covid-19 in persons 16 years of age or older.
abstract.13: Safety over a median of 2 months was similar to that of other viral vaccines.
abstract.14: (Funded by BioNTech and Pfizer; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT04368728.).

translation1.1: The coronavirus and the resulting Covid-19 disease (a viral, breathing-related disease) has impacted tens of millions of people around the world.
translation1.2: Vaccines that are safe and work well are urgently needed.
translation1.3: In a clinical study that is in progress, people who are at least 16 years old are randomly placed in a group to receive two doses of either a placebo (a shot that does not have medicine) or the BNT162b2 vaccine.
translation1.4: The BNT162b2 vaccine works by increasing proteins that help the immune system.
translation1.5: The main study outcomes are how well the vaccine works against Covid-19 and its safety.
translation1.6: A total of 43,548 participants are randomly put into two groups. Among this group, 43,448 received shots: 21,720 with the BNT162b2 vaccine and 21,728 with the placebo.
translation1.7: Among people who received the BNT162b2 vaccine, 8 got Covid-19 at least 7 days after they received the second dose. Among people who received the placebo, 162 got Covid-19. The BNT162b2 vaccine was 95% effective in preventing Covid-19.
translation1.8: Similar results are observed across smaller groups of participants when looking at age, sex, race, ethnicity, weight, and the presence of other conditions.
translation1.9: Among 10 cases of serious Covid-19 starting after the first dose, 9 cases happened in people who received the placebo and 1 in someone who received the BNT162b2 vaccine.
translation1.10: The safety of the BNT162b2 vaccine is described as having short-term, mild-to-moderate pain on the arm where the shot was given, tiredness, and a headache.
translation1.11: The number of serious side effects is low and is similar in the vaccine and placebo groups.
translation1.12: In conclusion, receiving two doses of the BNT162b2 vaccine provided 95% protection against Covid-19 in people 16 years or older.
translation1.13: Safety over an average of 2 months is similar to those of other vaccines.

33378609.Title: Efficacy and Safety of the mRNA-1273 SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine

abstract.1: Background: Vaccines are needed to prevent coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) and to protect persons who are at high risk for complications.
abstract.2: The mRNA-1273 vaccine is a lipid nanoparticle-encapsulated mRNA-based vaccine that encodes the prefusion stabilized full-length spike protein of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), the virus that causes Covid-19.
abstract.3: Methods: This phase 3 randomized, observer-blinded, placebo-controlled trial was conducted at 99 centers across the United States.
abstract.4: Persons at high risk for SARS-CoV-2 infection or its complications were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive two intramuscular injections of mRNA-1273 (100 μg) or placebo 28 days apart.
abstract.5: The primary end point was prevention of Covid-19 illness with onset at least 14 days after the second injection in participants who had not previously been infected with SARS-CoV-2.
abstract.6: Results: The trial enrolled 30,420 volunteers who were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive either vaccine or placebo (15,210 participants in each group).
abstract.7: More than 96% of participants received both injections, and 2.2% had evidence (serologic, virologic, or both) of SARS-CoV-2 infection at baseline.
abstract.8: Symptomatic Covid-19 illness was confirmed in 185 participants in the placebo group (56.5 per 1000 person-years; 95% confidence interval [CI], 48.7 to 65.3) and in 11 participants in the mRNA-1273 group (3.3 per 1000 person-years; 95% CI, 1.7 to 6.0); vaccine efficacy was 94.1% (95% CI, 89.3 to 96.8%; P<0.001).
abstract.9: Efficacy was similar across key secondary analyses, including assessment 14 days after the first dose, analyses that included participants who had evidence of SARS-CoV-2 infection at baseline, and analyses in participants 65 years of age or older.
abstract.10: Severe Covid-19 occurred in 30 participants, with one fatality; all 30 were in the placebo group.
abstract.11: Moderate, transient reactogenicity after vaccination occurred more frequently in the mRNA-1273 group.
abstract.12: Serious adverse events were rare, and the incidence was similar in the two groups.
abstract.13: Conclusions: The mRNA-1273 vaccine showed 94.1% efficacy at preventing Covid-19 illness, including severe disease.
abstract.14: Aside from transient local and systemic reactions, no safety concerns were identified.
abstract.15: (Funded by the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases; COVE ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT04470427.).

translation1.1: Vaccines are needed to prevent Covid-19 (a viral respiratory disease) and to protect people who are at a high risk for complications or harm.
translation1.2: The mRNA-1273 vaccine helps the body make proteins that will strengthen the immune system to fight the coronavirus that causes COVID-19.
translation1.3: The 3rd phase of a clinical study is conducted in 99 centers across the United States.
translation1.4: People who are at a high risk for the coronavirus or its complications are randomly placed in either the group to receive two shots of the mRNA-1273 vaccine or in the placebo group (people will be given a shot of an inactive substance).
translation1.5: The main result researchers are interested in is the prevention of Covid-19 starting at least 14 days after the second shot in study participants who have not already been infected with coronavirus.
translation1.6: The trial includes 30,420 volunteers who are randomly placed in a group to receive the vaccine or to receive the placebo.
translation1.7: More than 96% of volunteer participants receive both shots, and 2.2% are positive for (or have) the coronavirus at the start of the study.
translation1.8: Covid-19 is found in 185 participants in the placebo group and in 11 people in the mRNA-1273 vaccine group. The effectiveness of the vaccine is 94.1%.
translation1.9: In additional analyses, the vaccine is found to be effective during the patient evaluation 14 days after the first dose, in participants who were positive for coronavirus at the start of the study, and in participants 65 years old or older.
translation1.10: Serious Covid-19 occurs in 30 participants, with one death. All 30 are in the placebo group.
translation1.11: Moderate, short-lasting side effects after vaccination occur more often in the mRNA-1273 vaccination group.
translation1.12: Serious side effects are rare, and the number of times it occurred is similar in the two groups.
translation1.13: In conclusion, the mRNA-1273 vaccine group shows 94.1% effectiveness at preventing Covid-19, including serious cases of Covid-19.
translation1.14: Aside from short reactions to mRNA-1273, no safety concerns are found.

translation2.1: Vaccines are needed to prevent coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19), which is a breathing-related viral illness. Vaccines also protect those at high risk for issues.
translation2.3: This randomized, controlled trial was performed at 99 centers across the United States.
translation2.4: People at high risk for SARS-CoV-2, or Covid-19, infection or its effects were randomly split in a 1:1 ratio to get two injections of the new vaccine or inactive placebo 28 days apart.
translation2.5: The key measure was prevention of Covid-19 illness with onset at least 14 days after the second injection in participants who had not been infected with SARS-CoV-2 prior.
translation2.6: The trial had 30,420 volunteers randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive either the vaccine or inactive placebo (15,210 participants in each group).
translation2.7: More than 96& of participants got both injections. 2.2% had evidence (antibody and/or molecular testing) of SARS-CoV-2 infection at the start.
translation2.8: 185 participants in the inactive placebo group showed symptoms of Covid-19., while11 participants in the vaccine group showed symptoms of Covid-19.
translation2.9: Effectiveness was similar for key secondary analyses like analysis 14 days after the first dose, analysis with participants who had evidence of SARS-CoV-2 infection at the start, and analysis in participants 65 years or older.
translation2.10: Severe Covid-19 occured in 30 participants, with one death. All 30 were in the inactive placebo group.
translation2.11: Moderate, temporary body reactions after vaccination occured more often in the vaccine group.
translation2.12: Serious, harmful events were rare, and the frequency was similar in the two groups.
translation2.13: The vaccine showed 94.1% success at preventing Covid-19, including severe disease.
translation2.14: Aside from temporary local and full-body reactions, no safety concerns were found.

33629336.Title: COVID-19 vaccines: comparison of biological, pharmacological characteristics and adverse effects of Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna Vaccines

abstract.1: Objective: The "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2)" disease has caused a worldwide challenging and threatening pandemic (COVID-19), with huge health and economic losses.
abstract.2: The US Food and Drug Administration, (FDA) has granted emergency use authorization for treatment with the Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines.
abstract.3: Many people have a history of a significant allergic reaction to a specific food, medicine, or vaccine; hence, people all over the world have great concerns about these two authorized vaccines.
abstract.4: This article compares the pharmacology, indications, contraindications, and adverse effects of the Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines.
abstract.5: Materials and methods: The required documents and information were collected from the relevant databases, including Web of Science (Clarivate Analytics), PubMed, EMBASE, World Health Organization (WHO), Food and Drug Authorities (FDA) USA, Local Ministries, Health Institutes, and Google Scholar.
abstract.6: The key terms used were: Coronavirus, SARS-COV-2, COVID-19 pandemic, vaccines, Pfizer/BioN Tech vaccine, Moderna vaccine, pharmacology, benefits, allergic responses, indications, contraindications, and adverse effects.
abstract.7: The descriptive information was recorded, and we eventually included 12 documents including research articles, clinical trials, and websites to record the required information.
abstract.8: Results: Based on the currently available literature, both vaccines are beneficial to provide immunity against SARS-CoV-2 infection.
abstract.9: Pfizer/BioN Tech Vaccine has been recommended to people 16 years of age and older, with a dose of 30 μg (0.3 m) at a cost of $19.50.
abstract.10: It provides immunogenicity for at least 119 days after the first vaccination and is 95% effective in preventing the SARS-COV-2 infection.
abstract.11: However, Moderna Vaccine has been recommended to people 18 years of age and older, with a dose of 50 μg (0.5 mL) at a cost of $32-37.
abstract.12: It provides immunogenicity for at least 119 days after the first vaccination and is 94.5% effective in preventing the SARS-CoV-2 infection.
abstract.13: However, some associated allergic symptoms have been reported for both vaccines.
abstract.14: The COVID-19 vaccines can cause mild adverse effects after the first or second doses, including pain, redness or swelling at the site of vaccine shot, fever, fatigue, headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting, itching, chills, and joint pain, and can also rarely cause anaphylactic shock.
abstract.15: The occurrence of adverse effects is reported to be lower in the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine compared to the Moderna vaccine; however, the Moderna vaccine compared to the Pfizer vaccine is easier to transport and store because it is less temperature sensitive.
abstract.16: Conclusions: The FDA has granted emergency use authorization for the Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines.
abstract.17: These vaccines can protect recipients from a SARS-CoV- 2 infection by formation of antibodies and provide immunity against a SARS-CoV-2 infection.
abstract.18: Both vaccines can cause various adverse effects, but these reactions are reported to be less frequent in the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine compared to the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine; however, the Moderna vaccine compared to the Pfizer vaccine is easier to transport and store because it is less temperature sensitive.

translation1.1: The coronavirus disease has caused a global pandemic (Covid-19 - a viral breathing-related disease), with huge health and economic losses.
translation1.2: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has granted emergency use authorization, where unapproved medicines may be used, for treatment with the Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna Covid-19 vaccines.
translation1.3: Many people have a history of bad allergic reactions to specific foods, medicine, or vaccines, so people all over the world have great concerns about these two vaccines.
translation1.4: This article compares the use, reasons to take, reasons to not get, and side effects of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines.
translation1.5: The documents and information are collected from multiple databases and sources, including the FDA and World Health Organization.
translation1.6: Researchers used key search terms to collect information: Coronavirus, SARS-COV-2 (the coronavirus's name), Covid-19 pandemic, vaccines, Pfizer vaccine, Moderna vaccine, impact of drugs, benefits, allergic responses, reasons to take vaccines, reasons to not take the vaccine, and unexpected serious side effects.
translation1.7: Twelve documents including research articles, clinical studies, and websites are used to record the required information.
translation1.8: Based on available information, both vaccines are beneficial in providing immunity (resistance) against the coronavirus infection.
translation1.9: The Pfizer vaccine is recommended to people 16 years of age and older.
translation1.10: It triggers an immune response for at least 119 days after the first vaccination and is 95% effective in preventing the coronavirus infection.
translation1.11: However, the Moderna vaccine is recommended to people 18 years of age and older.
translation1.12: It triggers an immune response for at least 119 days after the first vaccination and is 94.5% effective in preventing the coronavirus infection.
translation1.13: However, some allergic reactions have been reported for both vaccines.
translation1.14: The Covid-19 vaccines can cause mild side effects after the first and second shot, including pain, redness or swelling at the site of the vaccine shot, fever, fatigue, headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting, itching, chills, and joint pain. Rarely, it can cause anaphylactic shock which is a severe allergic reaction that begins very quickly and can be life-threatening.
translation1.15: Side effects are reported to be lower in the Pfizer vaccine compared to Moderna; however, the Moderna vaccine is easier to transport and store.
translation1.16: In conclusion, the FDA has granted emergency use authorization for the Pfizer and Moderna Covid-19 vaccines.
translation1.17: These vaccines can protect people from coronavirus infection by forming antibodies (protective proteins made by the immune system to fight infections) and provide immunity against a coronavirus infection.
translation1.18: Both vaccines can cause different side effects, but these reactions are found to be less frequent in the Pfizer vaccine compared to the Moderna vaccine. However, the Moderna vaccine is easier to transport and store compared to the Pfizer vaccine.

34383735.Title: Use of COVID-19 Vaccines After Reports of Adverse Events Among Adult Recipients of Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) and mRNA COVID-19 Vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna): Update from the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices - United States, July 2021

abstract.1: In December 2020, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) issued Emergency Use Authorizations (EUAs) for Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines, and in February 2021, FDA issued an EUA for the Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) COVID-19 vaccine.
abstract.2: After each EUA, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) issued interim recommendations for vaccine use; currently Pfizer-BioNTech is authorized and recommended for persons aged ≥12 years and Moderna and Janssen for persons aged ≥18 years (1-3).
abstract.3: Both Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, administered as 2-dose series, are mRNA-based COVID-19 vaccines, whereas the Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, administered as a single dose, is a recombinant replication-incompetent adenovirus-vector vaccine.
abstract.4: As of July 22, 2021, 187 million persons in the United States had received at least 1 dose of COVID-19 vaccine (4); close monitoring of safety surveillance has demonstrated that serious adverse events after COVID-19 vaccination are rare (5,6).
abstract.5: Three medical conditions have been reported in temporal association with receipt of COVID-19 vaccines.
abstract.6: Two of these (thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome [TTS], a rare syndrome characterized by venous or arterial thrombosis and thrombocytopenia, and Guillain-Barré syndrome [GBS], a rare autoimmune neurologic disorder characterized by ascending weakness and paralysis) have been reported after Janssen COVID-19 vaccination.
abstract.7: One (myocarditis, cardiac inflammation) has been reported after Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccination or Moderna COVID-19 vaccination, particularly after the second dose; these were reviewed together and will hereafter be referred to as mRNA COVID-19 vaccination.
abstract.8: ACIP has met three times to review the data associated with these reports of serious adverse events and has comprehensively assessed the benefits and risks associated with receipt of these vaccines.
abstract.9: During the most recent meeting in July 2021, ACIP determined that, overall, the benefits of COVID-19 vaccination in preventing COVID-19 morbidity and mortality outweigh the risks for these rare serious adverse events in adults aged ≥18 years; this balance of benefits and risks varied by age and sex.
abstract.10: ACIP continues to recommend COVID-19 vaccination in all persons aged ≥12 years.
abstract.11: CDC and FDA continue to closely monitor reports of serious adverse events and will present any additional data to ACIP for consideration.
abstract.12: Information regarding risks and how they vary by age and sex and type of vaccine should be disseminated to providers, vaccine recipients, and the public.

translation1.1: In December 2020, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) issued Emergency Use Authorizations (when unapproved medicines may be used) for Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna Covid-19 vaccines (vaccines for the viral, respiratory disease). In February 2021, the FDA issued an emergency authorization for the Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) Covid-19 vaccine.
translation1.2: After each emergency authorization was issued, short-term recommendations for vaccine use were issued. Currently, Pfizer is authorized and recommended for persons aged 12 years or older and Moderna and Janssen for persons aged 18 years and older.
translation1.3: The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines require two shots and use a strand of genetic code that the body uses to build a protein that’s found in the coronavirus. The Janssen vaccine requires one shot and delivers instructions by DNA that the virus cannot replicate.
translation1.4: As of July 22, 2021, 187 million people in the United States received at least one shot of the Covid-19 vaccine, and it has been demonstrated that serious side effects are rare.
translation1.5: Three medical conditions have been reported after getting the Covid-19 vaccine, but the association between these conditions and the vaccine is mainly based on timing, in which the condition and vaccine occur around the same time.
translation1.6: Two of these conditions are reported after getting the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. They are 1) thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome [TTS], a rare condition with blood clots in the veins and arteries and low blood platelet counts (platelets help the body form blood clots to stop bleeding from injury), and 2) Guillain-Barré syndrome [GBS], a rare disorder characterized by muscle weakness and paralysis.
translation1.7: One condition (myocarditis, cardiac inflammation or heart-related swelling from an infection) has been reported after the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine, usually after the second dose. These two vaccines will be referred to as mRNA Covid-19 vaccination.
translation1.8: Data associated with these reports of serious side effects, in addition to the benefits and risks associated with vaccination, have been reviewed by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP).
translation1.9: During the most recent meeting in July 2021, ACIP determined that, overall, the benefits of Covid-19 vaccination in preventing Covid-19 illness and death outweigh the risks for these rare serious side effects in adults aged 18 years or older. This balance of benefits and risks was different by age and sex.
translation1.10: ACIP continues to recommend Covid-19 vaccination in all people aged 12 years and older.
translation1.11: CDC and FDA continue to closely monitor reports of serious side effects and will present any additional data to ACIP for review.
translation1.12: Information on risks and how they vary by age, sex, and type of vaccine should be shared with providers, people who receive the vaccine, and the public.

33444297.Title: Allergic Reactions Including Anaphylaxis After Receipt of the First Dose of Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine - United States, December 14-23, 2020

abstract.1: As of January 3, 2021, a total of 20,346,372 cases of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and 349,246 associated deaths have been reported in the United States.
abstract.2: Long-term sequalae of COVID-19 over the course of a lifetime currently are unknown; however, persistent symptoms and serious complications are being reported among COVID-19 survivors, including persons who initially experience a mild acute illness.*
abstract.3: On December 11, 2020, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) issued an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) for Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine to prevent COVID-19, administered as 2 doses separated by 21 days.
abstract.4: On December 12, 2020, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) issued an interim recommendation for use of Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine (1); initial doses were recommended for health care personnel and long-term care facility residents (2).
abstract.5: As of December 23, 2020, a reported 1,893,360 first doses of Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine had been administered in the United States, and reports of 4,393 (0.2%) adverse events after receipt of Pfizer BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine had been submitted to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS).
abstract.6: Among these, 175 case reports were identified for further review as possible cases of severe allergic reaction, including anaphylaxis.
abstract.7: Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening allergic reaction that does occur rarely after vaccination, with onset typically within minutes to hours (3).
abstract.8: Twenty-one cases were determined to be anaphylaxis (a rate of 11.1 per million doses administered), including 17 in persons with a documented history of allergies or allergic reactions, seven of whom had a history of anaphylaxis.
abstract.9: The median interval from vaccine receipt to symptom onset was 13 minutes (range = 2-150 minutes).
abstract.10: Among 20 persons with follow-up information available, all had recovered or been discharged home.
abstract.11: Of the remaining case reports that were determined not to be anaphylaxis, 86 were judged to be nonanaphylaxis allergic reactions, and 61 were considered nonallergic adverse events.
abstract.12: Seven case reports were still under investigation.
abstract.13: This report summarizes the clinical and epidemiologic characteristics of case reports of allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis and nonanaphylaxis allergic reactions, after receipt of the first dose of Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine during December 14-23, 2020, in the United States.
abstract.14: CDC has issued updated interim clinical considerations for use of mRNA COVID-19 vaccines currently authorized in the United States (4) and interim considerations for preparing for the potential management of anaphylaxis (5).
abstract.15: In addition to screening for contraindications and precautions before administering COVID-19 vaccines, vaccine locations should have the necessary supplies available to manage anaphylaxis, should implement postvaccination observation periods, and should immediately treat persons experiencing anaphylaxis signs and symptoms with intramuscular injection of epinephrine (4,5).

33507892.Title: Allergic Reactions Including Anaphylaxis After Receipt of the First Dose of Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine - United States, December 21, 2020-January 10, 2021

abstract.1: As of January 20, 2021, a total of 24,135,690 cases of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and 400,306 associated deaths had been reported in the United States (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#cases_casesper100klast7days).

abstract.3: On December 19, 2020, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) issued an interim recommendation for use of Moderna COVID-19 vaccine (1).
abstract.4: As of January 10, 2021, a reported 4,041,396 first doses of Moderna COVID-19 vaccine had been administered in the United States, and reports of 1,266 (0.03%) adverse events after receipt of Moderna COVID-19 vaccine were submitted to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS).
abstract.5: Among these, 108 case reports were identified for further review as possible cases of severe allergic reaction, including anaphylaxis.
abstract.6: Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs rarely after vaccination, with onset typically within minutes to hours (2).
abstract.7: Among these case reports, 10 cases were determined to be anaphylaxis (a rate of 2.5 anaphylaxis cases per million Moderna COVID-19 vaccine doses administered), including nine in persons with a documented history of allergies or allergic reactions, five of whom had a previous history of anaphylaxis.

abstract.10: Among the remaining case reports that were determined not to be anaphylaxis, 47 were assessed to be nonanaphylaxis allergic reactions, and 47 were considered nonallergic adverse events.

abstract.12: This report summarizes the clinical and epidemiologic characteristics of case reports of allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis and nonanaphylaxis allergic reactions, after receipt of the first dose of Moderna COVID-19 vaccine during December 21, 2020-January 10, 2021, in the United States.
abstract.13: CDC has issued updated interim clinical considerations for use of mRNA COVID-19 vaccines currently authorized in the United States (3) and interim considerations for preparing for the potential management of anaphylaxis (4).

34541483.Title: COVID-19 vaccines: Current evidence and considerations

abstract.1: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic is a global crisis, with devastating health, business and social impacts.
abstract.2: Vaccination is a safe, simple, and effective way of protecting a person against COVID-19.
abstract.3: By the end of August 2021, only 24.6% of the world population has received two doses of a COVID-19 vaccine.
abstract.4: Since the emergence of COVID-19, several COVID-19 vaccines have been developed and approved for emergency use.
abstract.5: Current vaccines have shown efficacy with low risk of adverse effects.
abstract.6: However, COVID-19 vaccines have been related to a relatively small number of cases of heart inflammation, anaphylaxis (allergic reactions), and blood clots formation.
abstract.7: On the other hand, COVID-19 vaccination is not recommended for children less than 12 years of age.
abstract.8: Furthermore, It has been proposed that some new variants (e.g., Lambda and Delta) are proficient in escaping from the antiviral immunity elicited by vaccination.
abstract.9: Herein we present current considerations regarding the COVID-19 vaccines including: efficacy against new variants, challenges in distribution, disparities in availability, dosage gender and race difference, COVID-19 vaccine transport and storage, limitations in children and pregnant women.
abstract.10: Long-time monitoring is essential in order to find vaccine efficacy and to rule out related side effects.

translation1.1: The Covid-19 (a breathing-related, viral disease) pandemic is a global crisis, with devastating health, business and social impacts.
translation1.2: Vaccination is a safe, simple, and effective way of protecting a person against Covid-19.
translation1.3: By the end of August 2021, only 24.6% of the world population has received two doses of a Covid-19 vaccine.
translation1.4: Several Covid-19 vaccines have been developed and approved for emergency use, which is when medicines not yet approved are allowed to be used.
translation1.5: Current vaccines are shown to be effective with a low risk of unexpected serious side effects, also called adverse effects.
translation1.6: However, Covid-19 vaccines are related to a relatively small number of cases of heart inflammation that can cause damage to the heart muscle via redness and swelling from an infection, anaphylaxis (severe allergic reactions that may be life-threatening), and blood clot formation.
translation1.7: On the other hand, Covid-19 vaccination is not recommended for children less than 12 years of age.
translation1.8: Also, it is proposed that some new variants (e.g., Lambda and Delta) are able to escape the immune response from vaccinations.
translation1.9: This paper presents current considerations on the Covid-19 vaccines including: effectiveness against new variants, challenges in distribution of the vaccines, differences in availability to groups, differences in doses by gender and race, how to transport and store the vaccines, and limitations in children and pregnant women.
translation1.10: Long-time monitoring is key in order to find vaccine effectiveness and to rule out related side effects.

34535317.Title: Myocarditis following COVID-19 vaccination - A case series

abstract.1: There have been reports of myocarditis following COVID-19 vaccination.
abstract.2: We surveyed all hospitalized military personnel in the Isareli Defense Forces during the period of the COVID-19 vaccination operation (12/28/2021-3/7/2021) for diagnosed myocarditis.
abstract.3: We identified 7 cases of myocarditis with symptoms starting in the first week after the second dose of COVID-19 Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.
abstract.4: One case of myocarditis diagnosed 10 days after the second dose of the vaccine was not included.
abstract.5: These 8 cases comprise of all events of myocarditis diagnosed in military personnel during this time period.
abstract.6: All patients were young and generally healthy.
abstract.7: All had mild disease with no sequalae.
abstract.8: The incidence of myocarditis in the week following a second dose of the vaccine was 5.07/100,000 people vaccinated.
abstract.9: Due to the nature of this report no causality could be established.
abstract.10: Clinicians should be aware of the possibility of myocarditis following Pfizer-BioNTech vaccination.
abstract.11: True incidence rates should be further investigated.

translation1.3: Researchers found 7 cases of myocarditis with symptoms starting in the first week after the second dose of Covid-19 Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.
translation1.4: One case of myocarditis diagnosed 10 days after the second dose of the vaccine is not included.
translation1.5: These 8 cases are all events of myocarditis diagnosed in military personnel during this time period.
translation1.6: All patients are young and generally healthy.
translation1.7: All have a mild case of the disease with no long-lasting effects.
translation1.8: The number of myocarditis in the week following a second dose of the vaccine is 5.07 out of 100,000 people vaccinated.
translation1.9: Due to the nature of this report, no deaths can be established.
translation1.10: Medical providers should be aware of the possibility of myocarditis following Pfizer vaccination.
translation1.11: The true number of occurrence of myocarditis among people receiving the vaccine should be further investigated.

34581763.Title: Characteristics and Outcomes of Patients With Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis in SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine-Induced Immune Thrombotic Thrombocytopenia

abstract.1: Importance: Thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS) has been reported after vaccination with the SARS-CoV-2 vaccines ChAdOx1 nCov-19 (Oxford-AstraZeneca) and Ad26.COV2.S (Janssen/Johnson & Johnson).
abstract.2: Objective: To describe the clinical characteristics and outcome of patients with cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) after SARS-CoV-2 vaccination with and without TTS.
abstract.3: Design, setting, and participants: This cohort study used data from an international registry of consecutive patients with CVST within 28 days of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination included between March 29 and June 18, 2021, from 81 hospitals in 19 countries.
abstract.4: For reference, data from patients with CVST between 2015 and 2018 were derived from an existing international registry.
abstract.5: Clinical characteristics and mortality rate were described for adults with (1) CVST in the setting of SARS-CoV-2 vaccine-induced immune thrombotic thrombocytopenia, (2) CVST after SARS-CoV-2 vaccination not fulling criteria for TTS, and (3) CVST unrelated to SARS-CoV-2 vaccination.
abstract.6: Exposures: Patients were classified as having TTS if they had new-onset thrombocytopenia without recent exposure to heparin, in accordance with the Brighton Collaboration interim criteria.
abstract.7: Main outcomes and measures: Clinical characteristics and mortality rate.
abstract.8: Results: Of 116 patients with postvaccination CVST, 78 (67.2%) had TTS, of whom 76 had been vaccinated with ChAdOx1 nCov-19; 38 (32.8%) had no indication of TTS.
abstract.9: The control group included 207 patients with CVST before the COVID-19 pandemic.
abstract.10: A total of 63 of 78 (81%), 30 of 38 (79%), and 145 of 207 (70.0%) patients, respectively, were female, and the mean (SD) age was 45 (14), 55 (20), and 42 (16) years, respectively.
abstract.11: Concomitant thromboembolism occurred in 25 of 70 patients (36%) in the TTS group, 2 of 35 (6%) in the no TTS group, and 10 of 206 (4.9%) in the control group, and in-hospital mortality rates were 47% (36 of 76; 95% CI, 37-58), 5% (2 of 37; 95% CI, 1-18), and 3.9% (8 of 207; 95% CI, 2.0-7.4), respectively.
abstract.12: The mortality rate was 61% (14 of 23) among patients in the TTS group diagnosed before the condition garnered attention in the scientific community and 42% (22 of 53) among patients diagnosed later.
abstract.13: Conclusions and relevance: In this cohort study of patients with CVST, a distinct clinical profile and high mortality rate was observed in patients meeting criteria for TTS after SARS-CoV-2 vaccination.

translation1.1: Thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS) is a rare condition of blood clots in the veins and arteries and low blood platelet counts. TTS has been reported in some people after they receive the AstraZeneca and Janssen/Johnson & Johnson vaccines. These vaccines provide immunity or resistance to the coronavirus, which causes COVID-19 (a viral, respiratory disease).
translation1.2: The objective of this study is to describe the clinical traits and outcomes of patients with cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) (blood clot in the brain) after receiving the coronavirus vaccine among people with and without TTS.
translation1.3: This study uses data from patients who have CVST within 28 days of vaccination in March-June 2021. Data came from 81 hospitals in 19 countries.
translation1.4: Existing data from patients with CVST between 2015 and 2018 are used to compare.
translation1.5: Clinical traits and death are described for adults with (1) CVST in the case of coronavirus vaccine-induced immune thrombotic thrombocytopenia, (2) CVST after coronavirus vaccination not meeting all parts for TTS, and (3) CVST unrelated to the coronavirus vaccination.
translation1.6: Patients are classified as having TTS (thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome) if they have new thrombocytopenia (low blood platelets) without recent exposure to heparin, a medicine that prevents blood clots.
translation1.7: Clinical traits and deaths are the main measures in this study.
translation1.8: Of the 116 patients with CVST after being vaccinated, 78 (67.2%) have TTS. Of those, 76 people had been vaccinated with AstraZeneca and 38 (32.8%) have no indication of TTS.
translation1.9: The comparison group included 207 patients with CVST before the Covid-19 pandemic.
translation1.10: A total of 63 out of 78 (81%) are female with an average age of 45, 30 out of of 38 (79%) are female with an average age of 55, and 145 of 207 (70.0%) patients are female and have an average age of 42 years.
translation1.11: Thromboembolism, which is a blood clot in the vein that has been dislodged from another part of the body, occurred in 25 out of 70 patients (36%) in the TTS group, 2 out of 35 (6%) in the no TTS group, and 10 out of 206 (4.9%) in the comparison group. Deaths in the hospital are at 47% in the TTS group, 5% in the no TTS group, and 3.9% in the comparison group.
translation1.12: The rate of deaths is 61% among patients with TTS diagnosed before the condition got the attention of scientists and 42% among patients diagnosed later.
translation1.13: In this study of patients with cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, a detailed clinical description and high death rate is observed in patients who have thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome after vaccination.

34559576.Title: Ocular Adverse Events After COVID-19 Vaccination

abstract.1: Purpose: The COVID-19 pandemic has galvanized the development of new vaccines at an unprecedented pace.
abstract.2: Since the widespread implementation of vaccination campaigns, reports of ocular adverse effects after COVID-19 vaccinations have emerged.
abstract.3: This review summarizes ocular adverse effects possibly associated with COVID-19 vaccination, and discusses their clinical characteristics and management.
abstract.4: Results: Ocular adverse effects of COVID-19 vaccinations include facial nerve palsy, abducens nerve palsy, acute macular neuroretinopathy, central serous retinopathy, thrombosis, uveitis, multiple evanescent white dot syndrome, Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease reactivation, and new-onset Graves' Disease.
abstract.5: Studies in current literature are primarily retrospective case series or isolated case reports - these are inherently weak in establishing association or causality.
abstract.6: Nevertheless, the described presentations resemble the reported ocular manifestations of the COVID-19 disease itself.
abstract.7: Hence, we hypothesize that the human body's immune response to COVID-19 vaccinations may be involved in the pathogenesis of the ocular adverse effects post-COVID-19 vaccination.
abstract.8: Conclusion: Ophthalmologists and generalists should be aware of the possible, albeit rare, ocular adverse effects after COVID-19 vaccination.

translation1.1: The pandemic of Covid-19 (a viral, breathing-related disease) has led to the development of new vaccines at an very fast pace.
translation1.2: Since the start of major efforts to promote vaccination, reports of ocular adverse effects, which are side effects that impact the eyes or the face near the eyes, after Covid-19 vaccinations have emerged.
translation1.3: This review summarizes these ocular adverse effects that are possibly associated with Covid-19 vaccines and discusses their medical traits and how to care for these effects.
translation1.4: Ocular adverse effects of Covid-19 vaccinations include weakness or paralysis in the facial muscles, problems with eye movement, blind or blurry spots, distorted vision due to fluid build up in the eye, blood clots in the veins or arteries, inflammation (redness or swelling from fighting an infection) inside the eye, inflammation in the retina of the eye, rapid vision loss from previous diseases, and newly-contracted Graves' Disease, a condition that increases thyroid (metabolism-regulating) hormones and can impact the skin and eyes.
translation1.5: Published studies mainly use existing information from previous cases or isolated reports; these are weak studies in establishing association or cause and effect.
translation1.6: However, the described cases are similar, regarding the impact on the eyes or vision, to the Covid-19 disease itself.
translation1.7: Researchers have a theory that the body's immune response to Covid-19 vaccinations may be involved in the development of the ocular adverse effects that occur after receiving the Covid-19 vaccine.
translation1.8: Eye surgeons and doctors should be aware of the possible, although rare, ocular adverse effects that impact the eyes after a Covid-19 vaccine.

34571039.Title: Manifestations and mechanisms of central nervous system damage caused by SARS-CoV-2

abstract.1: The global pandemic caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and its threat to humans have drawn worldwide attention.
abstract.2: The acute and long-term effects of SARS-CoV-2 on the nervous system pose major public health challenges.
abstract.3: Patients with SARS-CoV-2 present diverse symptoms of the central nervous system.
abstract.4: Exploring the mechanism of coronavirus damage to the nervous system is essential for reducing the long-term neurological complications of COVID-19.
abstract.5: Despite rapid progress in characterizing SARS-CoV-2, the long-term effects of COVID-19 on the brain remain unclear.
abstract.6: The possible mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2 injury to the central nervous system include: 1) direct injury of nerve cells, 2) activation of the immune system and inflammatory cytokines caused by systemic infection, 3) a high affinity of the SARS-CoV-2 spike glycoprotein for the angiotensin-converting enzyme ACE2, 4) cerebrovascular disease caused by hypoxia and coagulation dysfunction, and 5) a systemic inflammatory response that promotes cognitive impairment and neurodegenerative diseases.
abstract.7: Although we do not fully understand the mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2 causes nerve injury, we hope to provide a framework by reviewing the clinical manifestations, complications, and possible mechanisms of neurological damage caused by SARS-CoV-2.
abstract.8: With hope, this will facilitate the early identification, diagnosis, and treatment of possible neurological sequelae, which could contribute toward improving patient prognosis and preventing transmission.

translation1.1: The ongoing global pandemic is caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), also known COVID-19 (a viral, breathing-related disease). It has threatened public health and drawn worldwide attention.
translation1.2: The short- and long-term effects of COVID-19 on the nervous system pose major public health challenges.
translation1.3: Patients with COVID-19 present a wide range of symptoms of the central nervous system (the brain and spinal cord).
translation1.4: It is essential to better understand how COVID-19 affects the nervous system. Increasing current understanding will reduce the long-term effects COVID-19 may cause within the brain.
translation1.5: Despite rapid progress in better understanding how COVID-19 hurts the human body, the long-term effects of the virus on the brain are still unclear.
translation1.6: There are several possible ways COVID-19 affects the central nervous system. One of these ways is by potentially hurting nerve cells. Second, the virus may cause body-wide inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) that may activate the immune system. Third, COVID-19 may be highly attracted to a specific pathway into cells and can then rapidly distribute throughout the body. Fourth, the virus may cause disease by decreasing oxygen and increase blood clotting within the body. And lastly, COVID-19 may cause body-wide inflammation that decreases brain function.
translation1.7: Despite not fully understanding how COVID-19 causes nerve injury, the authors hoped to provide a review of clinical reports, documented human health effects, and potential pathways of COVID-19-caused brain damage.
translation1.8: The aim of this paper was to assist in early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of COVID-19-caused brain damage. Additionally, the authors hope this can help predict COVID-19 related effects before they occur and decrease viral spread in general.

translation2.1: The global pandemic caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), a breathing-related viral illness, and its threat to humans have drawn worldwide attention.
translation2.2: The immediate and long-term effects of SARS-CoV-2 on the nervous system present major public health challenges.
translation2.3: Patients with SARS-CoV-2 have diverse symptoms of the brain and spinal cord.
translation2.4: Exploring how coronavirus damages the nervous system is essential to reduce the long-term damage from COVID-19, or SARS-CoV-2 illness, to the nervous system.
translation2.5: Despite rapid progress in describing SARS-CoV-2, the long-term effects of COVID-19 on the brain is unclear.
translation2.6: Some ways SARS-CoV-2 may injure the brain and spinal cord are: 1) directly harming nerve cells, 2) activating the immune system and inflammatory molecules from full-body infection, 3) binding of the virus to a specific molecule, 4) damaged blood flow in the brain due to reduced oxygen and blood clotting, and 5) full-body inflammation leading to cognitive damage and harmful nervous system diseases.
translation2.7: While we do not fully know how SARS-CoV-2 causes nerve injury, we hope to lay the groundwork by reviewing clinical symptoms, issues, and possible methods for nerve damage caused by SARS-CoV-2.
translation2.8: This review will hopefully aid early identification and treatment of possible nerve-related consequences, which may improve patient recovery and prevent transmission.

34549987.Title: Direct activation of endothelial cells by SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein is blocked by Simvastatin

abstract.1: Emerging evidence suggests that endothelial activation plays a central role in the pathogenesis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and multi-organ failure in patients with COVID-19.
abstract.2: However, the molecular mechanisms underlying endothelial activation in COVID-19 patients remain unclear.
abstract.3: In this study, the SARS-CoV-2 viral proteins that potently activate human endothelial cells were screened to elucidate the molecular mechanisms involved in endothelial activation.
abstract.4: It was found that nucleocapsid protein (NP) of SARS-CoV-2 significantly activated human endothelial cells through TLR2/NF-κB and MAPK signaling pathways.
abstract.5: Moreover, by screening a natural microbial compound library containing 154 natural compounds, simvastatin was identified as a potent inhibitor of NP-induced endothelial activation.
abstract.6: Remarkablely, though the protein sequences of N proteins from coronaviruses are highly conserved, only NP from SARS-CoV-2 induced endothelial activation.
abstract.7: The NPs from other coronaviruses such as SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV, HUB1-CoV and influenza virus H1N1 did not activate endothelial cells.
abstract.8: These findings are well consistent with the results from clinical investigations showing broad endotheliitis and organ injury in severe COVID-19 patients.
abstract.9: In conclusion, the study provides insights on SARS-CoV-2-induced vasculopathy and coagulopathy, and suggests that simvastatin, an FDA-approved lipid-lowering drug, may benefit to prevent the pathogenesis and improve the outcome of COVID-19 patients.
abstract.10: IMPORTANCE Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by the betacoronavirus SARS-CoV-2, is a worldwide challenge for health-care systems.
abstract.11: The leading cause of mortality in patients with COVID-19 is hypoxic respiratory failure from acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
abstract.12: To date, pulmonary endothelial cells (ECs) have been largely overlooked as a therapeutic target in COVID-19, yet emerging evidence suggests that these cells contribute to the initiation and propagation of ARDS by altering vessel barrier integrity, promoting a pro-coagulative state, inducing vascular inflammation and mediating inflammatory cell infiltration.
abstract.13: Therefore, a better mechanistic understanding of the vasculature is of utmost importance.
abstract.14: In this study, we screened the SARS-CoV-2 viral proteins that potently activate human endothelial cells and found that nucleocapsid protein (NP) significantly activated human endothelial cells through TLR2/NF-κB and MAPK signaling pathways.
abstract.15: Moreover, by screening a natural microbial compound library containing 154 natural compounds, simvastatin was identified as a potent inhibitor of NP-induced endothelial activation.
abstract.16: Our results provide insights on SARS-CoV-2-induced vasculopathy and coagulopathy, and suggests that simvastatin, an FDA-approved lipid-lowering drug, may benefit to prevent the pathogenesis and improve the outcome of COVID-19 patients.

translation1.1: Recent scientific reports suggest that increased endothelial activation plays a key role in the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and multi-organ failure seen within patients of COVID-19 (a viral, breathing-related disease). Endothelial cells line our organs within our body, especially blood vessels. When these cells become activated, they encourage inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) and blood clotting or scabbing.
translation1.2: However, how COVID-19 causes this endothelial cell activation is unclear.
translation1.3: In this study, COVID-19 virus proteins (small molecules within the virus that help it function) were analyzed. The goal of analyzing the proteins was to determine how they might activate endothelial cells.
translation1.4: This study found a specific protein of COVID-19 that highly activated endothelial cells through two specific bodily pathways.
translation1.5: Secondly, the authors identified a prescription medication, known as Simvastatin, that can reduce the identified endothelial activation.
translation1.6: The authors also noted that the identified protein only caused endothelial activation in COVID-19 illness.
translation1.7: This protein in other illnesses, such as SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV, HUB1-CoV and influenza virus H1N1, did not activate endothelial cells.
translation1.8: These scientific findings match with results from clinical research (research within patients). Clinical research has shown broad endothelial cell inflammation and organ injury within COVID-19 patients.
translation1.9: The authors concluded this paper increases current knowledge surrounding how COVID-19 impacts blood vessels and blood flow within patients. Additionally, this paper suggested simvastatin may help prevent damage and improve overall health within COVID-19 patients.
translation1.10: COVID-19, caused by a coronavirus, is a worldwide challenge for health-care.
translation1.11: The leading cause of death in those with COVID-19 is lack of oxygen in the blood from a breathing-related illness.
translation1.12: To date, cells that line the lungs and its blood vessels have been overlooked as a therapy target in COVID-19, yet new evidence suggests these cells contribute to the start and spread of breathing-related illnesses by changing blood vessel structures, promoting clotting, causing inflammation, and influencing inflammatory cell reactions.
translation1.13: Therefore, a better understanding of the blood vessels Is of great importance.
translation1.14: In this study, we tested COVID-19 virus proteins that activate these blood-vessel lining cells and found that viral proteins activate these cells through phosphate-related pathways.
translation1.15: Also, by testing a natural microorganism library with 154 natural compounds, simvastatin was found to be a powerful blocker of the viral-caused lining cell activation.
translation1.16: Our results give insights on the viral-caused blood- and blood vessel-related diseases, and suggests that simvastatin, an FDA-approved fat-lowering drug, may help prevent these diseases and improve outcomes for COVID-19 patients.

34517257.Title: Dehydrozingerone ameliorates Lipopolysaccharide induced acute respiratory distress syndrome by inhibiting cytokine storm, oxidative stress via modulating the MAPK/NF-κB pathway

abstract.1: Background: Inflammation-mediated lung injury is a major cause of health problems in many countries and has been the leading cause of morbidity/mortality in intensive care units.
abstract.2: In the current COVID-19 pandemic, the majority of the patients experienced serious pneumonia resulting from inflammation (Acute respiratory distress syndrome/ARDS).
abstract.3: Pathogenic infections cause cytokine release syndrome (CRS) by hyperactivation of immune cells, which in turn release excessive cytokines causing ARDS.
abstract.4: Currently, there are no standard therapies for viral, bacterial or pathogen-mediated CRS.
abstract.5: Purpose: This study aimed to investigate and validate the protective effects of Dehydrozingerone (DHZ) against LPS induced lung cell injury by in-vitro and in-vivo models and to gain insights into the molecular mechanisms that mediate these therapeutic effects.
abstract.6: Methods: The therapeutic activity of DHZ was determined in in-vitro models by pre-treating the cells with DHZ and exposed to LPS to stimulate the inflammatory cascade of events.
abstract.7: We analysed the effect of DHZ on LPS induced inflammatory cytokines, chemokines and cell damage markers expression/levels using various cell lines.
abstract.8: We performed gene expression, ELISA, and western blot analysis to elucidate the effect of DHZ on inflammation and its modulation of MAPK and NF-κB pathways.
abstract.9: Further, the prophylactic and therapeutic effect of DHZ was evaluated against the LPS induced ARDS model in rats.
abstract.10: Results: DHZ significantly (p < 0.01) attenuated the LPS induced ROS, inflammatory cytokine, chemokine gene expression and protein release in macrophages.
abstract.11: Similarly, DHZ treatment protected the lung epithelial and endothelial cells by mitigating the LPS induced inflammatory events in a dose-dependent manner.
abstract.12: In vivo analysis showed that DHZ treatment significantly (p < 0.001) mitigated the LPS induced ARDS pathophysiology of increase in the inflammatory cells in BALF, inflammatory cytokine and chemokines in lung tissues.
abstract.13: LPS stimulated neutrophil-mediated events, apoptosis, alveolar wall thickening and alveolar inflammation were profoundly reduced by DHZ treatment in a rat model.
abstract.14: Conclusion: This study demonstrates for the first time that DHZ has the potential to ameliorate LPS induced ARDS by inhibiting cytokine storm and oxidative through modulating the MAPK and NF-κB pathways.
abstract.15: This data provides pre-clinical support to develop DHZ as a potential therapeutic agent against ARDS.

translation1.1: Lung injuries caused by inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) in the body is a major cause of health problems in several countries. Additionally, inflammation is a leading cause for disease and death within intensive care units (ICU) in hospitals.
translation1.2: The majority of patients of COVID-19 (a viral, breathing-related or respiratory disease) have suffered from a condition known as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) that results from inflammation. It is similar to pneumonia (lung infection).
translation1.3: Infections within the body can trigger the excess release of cytokines. Cytokines are proteins that can tell your immune system what to do. Sometimes, when we are sick, cytokines stimulate too many immune cells, causing hyperactivation, which in turn causes more cytokines to release more signals. This causes a biological loop known as cytokine release syndrome (CRS) that results in ARDS.
translation1.4: Currently, there are no medical treatments to prevent CRS that is causes by viruses, bacteria, or germs.
translation1.5: The goal of this paper was to better understand how a chemical, known as Dehydrozingerone (DHZ), can protect lung cells from damage caused by lipopolysaccharides (LPS). LPS are molecules that exist within the cell walls of bacteria and are extremely toxic.  This study used two types of studies, in vitro (in cells) and in vivo (in animals), to fully comprehend how DHZ can prevent LPS-induced lung cell injury.
translation1.6: For the in vitro study, cells were treated with DHZ before being exposed to LPS. This caused a series of inflammatory events to occur within the treated cells.
translation1.7: The authors reviewed how DHZ protected against LPS damage within several different types of cells.
translation1.8: They performed several lab tests looking at cells' internal health to better determine the effect DHZ had on inflammation and how it was protective.
translation1.9: Additionally, the authors determined how DHZ could prevent disease and protect against LPS within rats already sick with ARDS.
translation1.10: Within one type of cell, DHZ significantly decreased the negative effects caused by LPS exposure.
translation1.11: Similarly, DHZ protected lung cells by reducing LPS-induced inflammation in a dose-dependent manner. Meaning as the amount of DHZ given was increased, the symptoms from LPS treatment decreased.
translation1.12: In the rats treated with DHZ, the chemical significantly reduced LPS-caused ARDS.
translation1.13: DHZ significantly reduced several harmful effects of LPS within the rat model, including cell injury and cell death.
translation1.14: This study is the first to show that DHZ has the ability to protect against ARDS by decreasing harmful immune responses triggered by LPS.
translation1.15: This data provides support to develop DHZ as a potential human pharmaceutical prescription or drug to protect against ARDS.

34578462.Title: Myocardial Damage by SARS-CoV-2: Emerging Mechanisms and Therapies

abstract.1: Evidence is emerging that severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) can infect various organs of the body, including cardiomyocytes and cardiac endothelial cells in the heart.
abstract.2: This review focuses on the effects of SARS-CoV-2 in the heart after direct infection that can lead to myocarditis and an outline of potential treatment options.
abstract.3: The main points are: (1) Viral entry: SARS-CoV-2 uses specific receptors and proteases for docking and priming in cardiac cells.
abstract.4: Thus, different receptors or protease inhibitors might be effective in SARS-CoV-2-infected cardiac cells.
abstract.5: (2) Viral replication: SARS-CoV-2 uses RNA-dependent RNA polymerase for replication.
abstract.6: Drugs acting against ssRNA(+) viral replication for cardiac cells can be effective.
abstract.7: (3) Autophagy and double-membrane vesicles: SARS-CoV-2 manipulates autophagy to inhibit viral clearance and promote SARS-CoV-2 replication by creating double-membrane vesicles as replication sites.
abstract.8: (4) Immune response: Host immune response is manipulated to evade host cell attacks against SARS-CoV-2 and increased inflammation by dysregulating immune cells.
abstract.9: Efficiency of immunosuppressive therapy must be elucidated.
abstract.10: (5) Programmed cell death: SARS-CoV-2 inhibits programmed cell death in early stages and induces apoptosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis in later stages.
abstract.11: (6) Energy metabolism: SARS-CoV-2 infection leads to disturbed energy metabolism that in turn leads to a decrease in ATP production and ROS production.
abstract.12: (7) Viroporins: SARS-CoV-2 creates viroporins that lead to an imbalance of ion homeostasis.
abstract.13: This causes apoptosis, altered action potential, and arrhythmia.

translation1.1: New scientific research has shown that severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), or COVID-19 (a viral, breathing-related disease), can infect various parts of the body, including cells within the heart.
translation1.2: This paper reviews the effects COVID-19 has on the heart after direct infection, which can lead to myocarditis. Myocarditis is inflammation of the heart muscle.  This paper will also outline potential treatment options for this illness.
translation1.3: The authors proposed seven potential treatment options to help reduce heart injury in COVID-19 patients. First, the virus uses specific entry points to infect heart cells so that it can replicate and grow stronger.
translation1.4: Therefore, specific drugs that target these entry points might be helpful.
translation1.5: Second, COVID-19 uses a specific pathway to replicate itself. This pathway uses RNA, a chain of genetic material that helps form proteins.
translation1.6: Drugs that prevent the creation of RNA for viral replication could be helpful.
translation1.7: Third, COVID-19 decreases the body's ability to degrade infected cells. This prevents the body from decreasing the amount of virus within it. COVID-19 is able to replicate as it creates double-membrane vesicles, extra-strong chambers, as spaces safe from the body's natural defense system.
translation1.8: Fourth, COVID-19 can cause the host immune response to be changed so that the virus is not targeted for removal. It can also increase inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) which alters the function of immune cells.
translation1.9: Better understanding of drugs that suppress the immune system is needed.
translation1.10: Fifth, COVID-19 prevents cells from dying in the early stages of infection but induces cell death later, once it has replicated and moved to other cells.
translation1.11: Sixth, COVID-19 infection can disturb energy metabolism (the process in getting energy from food). This can reduce energy production and affect cell function and viability.
translation1.12: Seventh, COVID-19 creates virus proteins to lead to an imbalance within the host body.
translation1.13: This can cause cell death, abnormal heart function, and an abnormal heartbeat.

translation2.1: There is evidence that severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), a severe breathing-related virus, can infect various body organs, like heart cells.
translation2.2: This review focuses on the effects of SARS-CoV-2 in the heart after direct infection that can cause myocarditis (heart muscle inflammation) and possible treatments.
translation2.3: The main points are: (1) Viral entry: SARS-CoV-2 uses specific cell parts to attach to heart cells.
translation2.4: Thus, different blockers of specific cell parts may help with SARS-CoV-2-infected heart cells.
translation2.5: (2) Viral replication: SARS-CoV-2 uses a specific molecule for replication.
translation2.6: Drugs acting against a specific form of viral replication for heart cells can be effective.
translation2.7: (3) Cell degradation and transport molecules: SARS-COV-2 alters cell degradation to block virus removal and promote virus replication by making transport molecules as replication sites.
translation2.8: (4) Immune response: Patient immune response is altered to evade paitent cell attacks against SARS-CoV-2 and increased inflammation by impairing immune cells.
translation2.9: Efficiency of immune-system-suppressing therapy must be explained.
translation2.10: (5) Intentional cell death: SARS-CoV-2 blocks intentional cell death in early stages and causes cell death in later stages.
translation2.11: (6) Energy metabolism: SARS-CoV-2 infection leads to damaged energy metabolism that leads to a decrease in energy and reactive chemical production.
translation2.12: (7) Virus channels: SARS-CoV-2 pokes openings in the cell that leads to leaking of important cell molecules.
translation2.13: This leaking causes cell death, altered cell signals, and an irregular heart beat.

34578187.Title: Interactome Analysis of the Nucleocapsid Protein of SARS-CoV-2 Virus

abstract.1: SARS-CoV-2 infection has caused a global pandemic that has severely damaged both public health and the economy.
abstract.2: The nucleocapsid protein of SARS-CoV-2 is multifunctional and plays an important role in ribonucleocapsid formation and viral genome replication.
abstract.3: In order to elucidate its functions, interaction partners of the SARS-CoV-2 N protein in human cells were identified via affinity purification and mass spectrometry.
abstract.4: We identified 160 cellular proteins as interaction partners of the SARS-CoV-2 N protein in HEK293T and/or Calu-3 cells.
