32609390.Title: Discharged COVID-19 patients testing positive again for SARS-CoV-2 RNA: A minireview of published studies from China

abstract.1: In the ongoing coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, one potential cause of concern is that some discharged COVID-19 patients are testing positive again for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) RNA.
abstract.2: To better understand what is happening and to provide public health policy planners and clinicians timely information, we have searched and reviewed published studies about discharged patients testing positive again for the SARS-CoV-2 RNA.
abstract.3: Our search found 12 reports, all of which described patients in China.
abstract.4: Our review of these reports indicates the presence of discharged patients who remain asymptomatic but test positive.
abstract.5: However, it is unclear whether they are contagious because a positive reverse transcriptase - polymerase chain reaction (RT- PCR) test does not necessarily indicate the presence of replicating and transmissible virus.
abstract.6: Our review suggests the need for timely, parallel testing of different samples, including, for example, fecal specimens, from COVID-19 patients before and after they are discharged from hospitals.

translation1.1: In the current Covid-19 pandemic, one possible cause for concern is that some Covid-19 patients sent home from the hospital are testing positive again for (or have) coronavirus, which causes the respiratory lung infection of Covid-19.
translation1.2: To better understand what is happening and provide timely information to officials and doctors, researchers searched and reviewed completed studies about patients discharged or released from the hospital who test positive again for the coronavirus.
translation1.3: The search found 12 reports, all of which described patients in China.
translation1.4: The review of these reports suggests the presence of discharged patients who do not have any symptoms but test positive.
translation1.5: However, it is unclear whether they are contagious because a positive test for genetic traces of the virus does not necessarily indicate the presence of replicating and transmissible virus.
translation1.6: The review suggests the need for testing different samples at the same time, including, for example, fecal (poop) samples, from Covid-19 patients before and after they are sent home from hospitals.

33113040.Title: Recurrence of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA in recovered COVID-19 patients: a narrative review

abstract.1: Many studies have shown that re-positive tests for SARS-CoV-2 by RT-PCR in recovered COVID-19 patients are very common.
abstract.2: We aim to conduct this review to summarize the clinical and epidemiological characteristics of these patients and discuss the potential explanations for recurrences, the contagiousness of re-detectable positive SARS-CoV-2 virus, and the management of COVID-19 patients after discharge from hospital.
abstract.3: The proportion of re-positive tests in discharged COVID-19 patients varied from 2.4 to 69.2% and persisted from 1 to 38 days after discharge, depending on population size, age of patients, and type of specimens.
abstract.4: Currently, several causes of re-positive tests for SARS-CoV-2 in recovered COVID-19 patients are suggested, including false-negative, false-positive RT-PCR tests; reactivation; and re-infection with SARS-CoV-2, but the mechanism leading to these re-positive cases is still unclear.
abstract.5: The prevention of re-positive testing in discharged patients is a fundamental measure to control the spread of the pandemic.
abstract.6: In order to reduce the percentage of false-negative tests prior to discharge, we recommend performing more than two tests, according to the standard sampling and microbiological assay protocol.
abstract.7: In addition, specimens should be collected from multiple body parts if possible, to identify SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA before discharge.
abstract.8: Further studies should be conducted to develop novel assays that target a crucial region of the RNA genome in order to improve its sensitivity and specificity.

translation1.1: Many studies have shown that testing positive again for (or having) coronavirus in recovered Covid-19 patients (patients recovered from the serious viral, lung infection of Covid-19) is very common.
translation1.2: This study aims to summarize medical and other key characteristics of these patients. The summary will discuss explanations for the return of the virus in recovered patients, how contagious people are after they have recovered from the virus but test positive again, and the care of Covid-19 patients after going home from the hospital.
translation1.3: The percentage who re-tested as positive in discharged Covid-19 patients is between 2.4 to 69.2%. Retesting as positive continued from 1 to 38 days after discharge, or release, from the hospital, depending on population size, age, and the type of samples used to test.
translation1.4: Currently, several causes of re-positive tests for coronavirus in recovered Covid-19 patients are suggested, including incorrect negative or positive test results; reactivation (when someone appears to have recovered but still has traces of the virus in the body); and being re-infected with coronavirus, but the process leading to these re-positive tests is still unclear.
translation1.5: Preventing patients who have recovered and are sent home from testing positive again is an important step to control the spread of the pandemic.
translation1.6: To limit the number of false-negatives tests (when a person tests negative but are actually positive for the virus) before being sent home, study researchers suggest doing more than 2 tests.
translation1.7: In addition, samples should be collected from multiple body parts if possible, to identify coronavirus DNA before discharge from the hospital.
translation1.8: More studies should be done to develop new tests that target a crucial part of the genes from the virus in order to improve its accuracy.

33368332.Title: Quantitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in nasopharyngeal samples from infected patients with mild disease

abstract.1: Diagnosis of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-COV-2) cases is based on the count of real-time reverse transcription-plymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) positive people.
abstract.2: Viral load by real-time RT-PCR has been suggested as a biomarker of the SARS-CoV-2 infection.
abstract.3: However, the association of viral load and severity of the disease is not yet resolved.
abstract.4: Nasopharyngeal samples from 458 patients were tested by RT-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis.
abstract.5: Relative quantitation was made by the comparative threshold cycle (ΔΔCt ) formula between ORF1ab viral and RNase P housekeeping genes.
abstract.6: Absolute viral load was calculate using a reference positive control.
abstract.7: Most prevalent clinical signs were cough (75.8%), myalgia (66.7%), and fever (48.5%).
abstract.8: Hypertension (18.2%), neurological diseases (15.1%), and asthma and hypothyroidism (12.1%) were most frequent comorbidities.
abstract.9: Fever, either as an exclusive symptom or combined with others, was associated with high viral loads ( 2−ΔΔCt range, 35.65-155.16; 4.25-4.89 log10 RNA copies/test]).
abstract.10: During the first week after onset of symptoms in mild patients up to 60 years-old was detected the peak of viral load.
abstract.11: Children under 10 years old have a high viral load (313.84; 2.50) in the first 2 days postinfection with a sharp decline thereafter.
abstract.12: Cases between 10 and 49 years old mostly showed low and moderate viral load during the first 2 days postinfection (range, 0.03 to 17.24; -1.50 to 1.24).
abstract.13: Patients over 60 years old have high viral load up to the second week after the onset of symptoms (range, 25.32-155.42; 1.40-2.19), indicating the longer presence of the virus in them.
abstract.14: These findings suggest the viral load in nasopharyngeal swabs would help to monitor the SARS-CoV-2 infection in mild coronavirus disease 2019 cases.

translation1.1: Diagnosis of cases of coronavirus (a virus causing the lung infection known as Covid-19) is based on the count of positive RT-PCR tests, a type of test that looks for traces of DNA from the virus and signals positive if there is virus present.
translation1.2: The amount of virus in the body, called the viral load, measured by the RT-PCR test is seen as an indication of coronavirus infection.
translation1.3: However, the association of the amount of virus and the severity of the disease is not yet understood.
translation1.4: Samples from the back of the nose from 458 patients are tested by RT-PCR for coronavirus.
translation1.5: Additional tests are done to measure the viral load.
translation1.7: The most common signs are cough, muscle aches and pains, and fever.
translation1.8: High blood pressure, diseases affecting the brain and nerves, asthma, and hypothyroidism (not enough thyroid hormone in the body) were the most frequent conditions of other illnesses.
translation1.9: Fever, either as the only symptom or combined with others, is associated with high viral loads.
translation1.10: During the first week after symptoms start in mild patients up to 60 years-old is the peak of viral load.
translation1.11: Children under 10 years old have a high viral load in the first 2 days post-infection followed by a sharp decline.
translation1.12: Cases between 10 and 49 years old mostly showed low and moderate viral load during the first 2 days after infection.
translation1.13: Patients over 60 years old have high viral load up to the second week after the start of symptoms, indicating the virus stays present in them longer.
translation1.14: These findings suggest the viral load in swabs from the nose would help to monitor the coronavirus infection in mild coronavirus disease 2019 cases.

translation2.1: Detecting cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-COV-2), which causes a breathing-related viral disease, is based on the count of people which a certain molecular test (real-time RT-PCR) detects.
translation2.2: Viral amount by real-time RT-PCR may be a signal of the SARS-CoV-2 infection.
translation2.3: However, the link between viral amount and severity of the disease is unknown.
translation2.4: Nasal samples from 458 patients were tested by RT-PCR for SARS-CoV-2.
translation2.7: Most common symptoms were cough (75.8%), muscle pain (66.7%), and fever (48.5%).
translation2.8: High blood pressure (18.2%), brain-related diseases (15.1%), and asthma and reduced thyroid function, which affects metabolism, (12.1%) were the most frequent associated conditions.
translation2.9: Fever, either alone or with other symptoms, was linked with a high virus amount.
translation2.10: The peak of the virus amount was detected in the first week after symptoms started in mild patients up to 60 years-old.
translation2.11: Children under 10 years have a high virus amount in the first 2 days after infection with a sharp decline after.
translation2.12: Cases between 10 and 49 years mostly showed low to medium virus amount during the first 2 days after infection.
translation2.13: Patients over 60 years have a high virus amount up to the second week after symptoms start, indicating the longer presence of the virus in them.
translation2.14: The virus amount in nasal swabs may help monitor the SARS-CoV-2 infection in cases of mild coronavirus disease 2019, a breathing-related viral disease.

33224987.Title: Temporal Course of SARS-CoV-2 Antibody Positivity in Patients with COVID-19 following the First Clinical Presentation

abstract.1: Knowledge of the sensitivities of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) antibody tests beyond 35 days after the clinical onset of COVID-19 is insufficient.
abstract.2: We aimed to describe positivity rate of SARS-CoV-2 assays employing three different measurement principles over a prolonged period.
abstract.3: Two hundred sixty-eight samples from 180 symptomatic patients with COVID-19 and a reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test followed by serological investigation of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies were included.
abstract.4: We conducted three chemiluminescence (including electrochemiluminescence assay (ECLIA)), four enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), and one lateral flow immunoassay (LFIA) test formats.
abstract.5: Positivity rates, as well as positive (PPVs) and negative predictive values (NPVs), were calculated for each week after the first clinical presentation for COVID-19.
abstract.6: Furthermore, combinations of tests were assessed within an orthogonal testing approach employing two independent assays and predictive values were calculated.
abstract.7: Heat maps were constructed to graphically illustrate operational test characteristics.
abstract.8: During a follow-up period of more than 9 weeks, chemiluminescence assays and one ELISA IgG test showed stable positivity rates after the third week.
abstract.9: With the exception of ECLIA, the PPVs of the other chemiluminescence assays were ≥95% for COVID-19 only after the second week.
abstract.10: ELISA and LFIA had somewhat lower PPVs.
abstract.11: IgM exhibited insufficient predictive characteristics.
abstract.12: An orthogonal testing approach provided PPVs ≥ 95% for patients with a moderate pretest probability (e.g., symptomatic patients), even for tests with a low single test performance.
abstract.13: After the second week, NPVs of all but IgM assays were ≥95% for patients with low to moderate pretest probability.
abstract.14: The confirmation of negative results using an orthogonal algorithm with another assay provided lower NPVs than the single assays.
abstract.15: When interpreting results from SARS-CoV-2 tests, the pretest probability, time of blood draw, and assay characteristics must be carefully considered.
abstract.16: An orthogonal testing approach increases the accuracy of positive, but not negative, predictions.

translation1.1: There is not enough information on how well tests for coronavirus (which causes Covid-19 - a breathing-related illness) can correctly diagnose a positive case (which signals presence of the virus) beyond 35 days after the start of Covid-19.
translation1.2: This study aims to describe the percentage of positive coronavirus tests out of all tests, also called positivity rate, using three different measurements over a long period of time.
translation1.3: Researchers took 268 samples from 180 Covid-19 patients with symptoms. These samples are tested using an RT-PCR test that finds traces of genetic material of the virus and a blood test to look for antibodies (proteins used by the immune system to fight infection).
translation1.4: Researchers used 3 electrochemiluminescence assay (ECLIA) test formats that can look for multiple types of antibodies in the blood, 4 enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) tests that test for antibodies for the coronavirus and can provide information about past exposure to Covid-19, and 1 lateral flow immunoassay (LFIA) test format that can detect active coronavirus.
translation1.5: After the first clinical sign for Covid-19 starts, the positivity rate and other measures to find the percentage of positive and negative (no virus) results in tests that are true positive, called positive predictive value, and true negative results, called negative predictive value, are calculated each week.
translation1.6: Combinations of tests are measured to better understand how the primary tests are working.
translation1.7: Maps are created to show how the different tests operate.
translation1.8: During a follow-up period of more than 9 weeks, a type of ECLIA and one ELISA antibody test showed stable positivity rates after the third week.
translation1.9: Except for ECLIA, the positive predictive value (percentage of positive tests that are true positives) of the other tests similar to ECLIA are ≥95% for Covid-19 only after the second week.
translation1.10: ELISA and LFIA have somewhat lower positive predictive values.
translation1.11: The IgM antibody that suggests a recent infection did not have enough information to do predictive calculations.
translation1.12: An orthogonal testing approach is when a person who tests positive are tested again with a second test. Orthogonal testing provided a positive predictive value of  ≥ 95% for patients who probably had the disease (e.g., symptomatic patients).
translation1.13: After the second week, negative predictive values (percentage of negative test results that are true negatives) of all but the IgM antibody test are ≥95% for patients with a low or moderate chance of likely having the disease before being tested.
translation1.15: When reading results from coronavirus tests, the estimate of the chance of having the disease before confirming with a test, the time that blood is drawn, and test characteristics must be considered.
translation1.16: An orthogonal testing approach when a person with a positive results receives a second test increases the accuracy of positive, but not negative, predictions.

34206895.Title: Long-Term Longitudinal Evaluation of Six Commercial Immunoassays for the Detection of IgM and IgG Antibodies against SARS CoV-2

abstract.1: The number of serological assays for SARS-CoV-2 has skyrocketed in the past year.
abstract.2: Concerns have been raised regarding their performance characteristics, depending on the disease severity and the time of the analysis post-symptom onset (PSO).
abstract.3: Thus, independent validations using an unbiased sample selection are required for meaningful serology data interpretation.
abstract.4: We aimed to assess the clinical performance of six commercially available assays, the seroconversion, and the dynamics of the humoral response to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
abstract.5: The study included 528 serum samples from 156 patients with follow-up visits up to six months PSO and 161 serum samples from healthy people.
abstract.6: The IgG/total antibodies positive percentage increased and remained above 95% after six months when chemiluminescent immunoassay (CLIA) IgG antiS1/S2 and electro-chemiluminescent assay (ECLIA) total antiNP were used.
abstract.7: At early time points PSO, chemiluminescent microparticle immunoassay (CMIA) IgM antiS achieved the best sensitivity.
abstract.8: IgM and IgG appear simultaneously in most circumstances, and when performed in parallel the sensitivity increases.
abstract.9: The severe and the moderate clinical forms were significantly associated with higher seropositivity percentage and antibody levels.
abstract.10: High specificity was found in all evaluated assays, but the sensitivity was variable depending on the time PSO, severity of disease, detection method and targeted antigen.

translation1.1: The number of blood tests that check for antibodies (infection-fighting proteins) for the coronavirus (which causes COVID-19, the lung infection) has skyrocketed in the past year.
translation1.2: Concerns have been raised on the performance of the tests, depending on the disease severity and the time of the test after symptoms start.
translation1.3: Therefore, confirming the performance of the test using an unbiased sample is required in order to understand and describe the antibody data.
translation1.4: Researchers aim to assess the performance of six available blood tests, the seroconversion (when the body starts producing antibodies), and how the body creates antibodies in response to coronavirus infection.
translation1.5: The study included 528 blood samples from 156 patients with follow-up visits up to 6 months after the start of symptoms and 161 blood samples from healthy people.
translation1.6: The total amount of antibodies increased and remained above 95% after six months when using certain tests to identify antibodies.
translation1.7: At early times after the start of symptoms, a blood test that looks for certain antibodies that suggest recent infection has the best ability to correctly diagnose a positive (or virus-containing) case.
translation1.8: Two types of antibodies, IgM and IgG, appear at the same time in most circumstances, and when performed together, the ability to correctly diagnose a positive diagnosis increases.
translation1.9: The severe and the moderate clinical forms have major associations with a higher number of positive tests and antibody levels.
translation1.10: The ability to correctly have a negative (or no virus) test among negative people is found in all evaluated blood tests, but the ability to correctly diagnose a true positive varies depending on the time after the start of symptoms and the type of test.

33816325.Title: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 Viral RNA Load Status and Antibody Distribution Among Patients and Asymptomatic Carriers in Central China

abstract.1: This study aimed to monitor severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) viral loads and specific serum-antibodies (immunoglobulin [Ig] G and M) among confirmed patients and asymptomatic carriers from returning healthy travelers.
abstract.2: The throat swabs, sputum, and stool samples from 57 hospitalized coronavirus disease (COVID-19) patients and 8 asymptomatic carriers, among 170 returning healthy travelers were tested using reverse-transcription real-time polymerase chain reaction.
abstract.3: SARS-CoV-2 IgM/IgG antibodies were detected via serum chemiluminescence assay.
abstract.4: Sequential results showed higher viral RNA loads in the throat, sputum, and stool samples at 3-12 and 6-21 days after symptom onset among severely ill COVID-19 patients.
abstract.5: Shorter viral habitation time (1-8 days) was observed in the oropharyngeal site and intestinal tract of asymptomatic carriers.
abstract.6: The IgG and IgM response rates were 19/37 (51.4%) and 23/37 (62.6%) among the 29 confirmed patients and 8 asymptomatic carriers, respectively, within 66 days from symptom or detection onset.
abstract.7: The median duration between symptom onset and positive IgG and IgM results was 30 (n=23; interquartile range [IQR]=20-66) and 23 (n=19; IQR=12-28) days, respectively.
abstract.8: Of 170 returning healthy-travelers to China, 4.7% were asymptomatic carriers (8/170) within 2 weeks, and the IgG and IgM positivity rate was 12.8% (12/94).
abstract.9: IgM/IgG-positivity confirmed 3 suspected SARS-CoV-2 cases, despite negative results for SARS-CoV-2 RNA.
abstract.10: Compared with other respiratory viral infectious diseases, COVID-19 has fewer asymptomatic carriers, lower antibody response rates, and a longer antibody production duration in recovered patients and the contacted healthy population.
abstract.11: This is an indication of the complexity of COVID-19 transmission.

translation1.1: This study aims to monitor the amount of coronavirus (which causes COVID-19 - the breathing-related illness) in the blood, also called viral load, and the specific, infection-fighting proteins used by the immune system, called antibodies, among patients with coronavirus and healthy travelers who have the virus but no symptoms.
translation1.2: Samples from 57 hospitalized Covid-19 patients and 8 asymptomatic carriers (people who have the virus but no symptoms) are tested.
translation1.4: Among seriously ill Covid-19 patients, there is a higher viral load in the throat, sputum (lung), and stool samples at 3-12 and 6-21 days after symptoms start.
translation1.5: Among carriers with no symptoms, the viral load is found to stay for a shorter time period (1-8 days) in the throat and in the digestive system.
translation1.6: Antibodies to fight the viruses responded in 51.4% of confirmed patients and 62.6% among asymptomatic people within 66 days from symptom starting.
translation1.7: The average time between the start of symptoms and positive (or detected) antibodies is 30 days for the IgG antibody, and 23 days for the IgM antibodies, which often suggest a recent infection.
translation1.8: Of 170 returning healthy-travelers to China, 4.7% were asymptomatic carriers within 2 weeks, and the positive result among them for the IgG and IgM antibodies is 12.8%.
translation1.9: The IgM/IgG antibodies confirmed 3 suspected coronavirus cases, even though they tested negative for coronavirus using another test.
translation1.10: When compared to other viruses that impact the lungs, Covid-19 has fewer asymptotic carriers and has a lower antibody response. Covid-19 also has a longer period of time developing antibodies in recovered patients.
translation1.11: These findings highlight how complex transmission or spread is in Covid-19.

translation2.1: This study monitors virus amonts and naturally-created blood antibodies, which combat foreign viruses, of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which causes a breathing-related viral disorder, among infected patients and carries without symptoms from returning healthy travelers.
translation2.2: The throat swabs, mucus, and poop samples from 57 hospitalized patients with coronavirus disease (COVID-19), caused by SARS-CoV-2, and 8 virus carries without symptoms, among 170 returning healthy travelers, were tested with a molecular tool.
translation2.4: Results show higher virus amount in throat, mucus, and stool samples at 3-12 and 6-21 days after symptoms first showed among severely ill COVID-19 patients.
translation2.5: Shorter virus lifetime (1-8 days) was seen in the throat near the mount and digestive tract of carriers without symptoms.
translation2.6: Specific blood antibody detection rates were 18/37 (51.4%) and 23/37 (62.6%) among the 29 confirmed patients and 8 carriers without symptoms, respectively, within 66 days from start of symptoms or detection.
translation2.7: Average duration between start of symptoms and antibody results was 30 and 23 days, respectively.
translation2.8: Of the 170 returning healthy-travelers to China, 4.7% were infected showing no symptoms (8/170) within 2 weeks. Antibdoy detection rate was 12.8% (12/94).
translation2.9: Antibody detection confirmed 3 suspected SARS-CoV-2 cases, despite other test results not detecting the virus.
translation2.10: Relative to other breathing-related viral infectious diseases, COVID-19 has fewer carriers without symptoms, lower antibody response rates, and a longer antibody production duration in recovered and contacted healthy people.
translation2.11: These results show the complexity of COVID-19 spread.

31.question: What medications are used to treat tardive dyskinesia?

abstract.1: Purpose of review: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is caused by exposure to medications with dopamine antagonism, mainly antipsychotics.
abstract.2: It often distresses individuals, physically and emotionally and affects their quality of life.
abstract.3: We evaluated peer-reviewed recently published articles with a goal of providing a critically appraised update on the latest advancements in this field.
abstract.4: Recent findings: In 2017, FDA approved VMAT2 inhibitors, deutetrabenazine and valbenazine.
abstract.5: They have demonstrated efficacy in several class 1 studies.
abstract.6: Also there have been update in the evidence-based guidelines for treatment for tardive dyskinesia.
abstract.7: Various medication classes are being used for treatment of TD with VMAT2 inhibitors to be first FDA-approved medications.
abstract.8: Their use should be tailored to the individual patient.
abstract.9: Long-term studies will further guide us in how to optimize treatment, especially in the real-world setting.
abstract.10: As clinicians, we need to take into consideration all aspects of symptomatology, etiology, potential side effects of the medications, to find the best possible "match" for our patients.

translation1.1: Taking medications, mainly antipsychotics, that reduce activity of dopamine (a chemical messenger released when your brain is expecting a reward) causes tardive dyskinesia (TD) - a movement disorder.
translation1.2: TD often causes physical and emotional pain or suffering and affects the quality of life of patients.
translation1.3: We rated scientific studies to summarize the latest advancements in the area of TD.
translation1.4: We found that FDA approved vesicular monoamine transporter type 2 (VMAT2) inhibitors, drugs that reduce dopamine (a chemical messenger released when your brain is expecting a reward), deutetrabenazine and valbenazine, in 2017.
translation1.5: These drugs work in several clinical trials.
translation1.6: Best practice guidelines for doctors for treating tardive dyskinesia have also been updated.
translation1.7: Different drugs are being used to treat TD with VMAT2 inhibitors to be the first drug approved by the FDA.
translation1.8: Drugs used to treat TD should be specific to the individual patient.
translation1.9: Long-term studies will determine how best to treat patients, especially in the real world.
translation1.10: As doctors, we need to consider all symptoms, causes, and possible drug side effects to find the best possible "match" for our patients.

abstract.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is an iatrogenic condition that encompasses a wide phenomenological spectrum of movement disorders caused by exposure to dopamine receptor blocking agents (DRBAs).
abstract.2: TD may cause troublesome or disabling symptoms that impair quality of life.
abstract.3: Due to frequent, often inappropriate, use of DRBAs, TD prevalence rates among patients exposed to DRBAs continue to be high.
abstract.4: The judicious use of DRBAs is key to the prevention of TD, reduction of disease burden, and achieving lasting remission.
abstract.5: Dopamine-depleting vesicular monoamine transporter type 2 inhibitors are considered the treatment of choice of TD.

translation1.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a condition that includes a wide range of uncontrollable movement disorders caused by taking antipsychotics.
translation1.2: TD may cause physical and emotional pain or suffering that negatively affects quality of life.
translation1.3: The total number of TD cases in patients who have taken antipsychotics at a given time continues to be high due to frequent, often unnecessary, antipsychotic use.
translation1.4: Sensible use of antipsychotics is needed to prevent, reduce disability and death associated with, and end TD for good.
translation1.5: Vesicular monoamine transporter type 2 (VMAT2) inhibitors, drugs that reduce dopamine (a chemical messenger released when your brain is expecting a reward), are the best treatment for TD.

abstract.1: Background: Tardive dyskinesia is a movement disorder characterised by irregular, stereotyped, and choreiform movements associated with the use of antipsychotic medication.
abstract.2: We aim to provide recommendations on the treatment of tardive dyskinesia.
abstract.3: Results: Preventing tardive dyskinesia is of primary importance, and clinicians should follow best practice for prescribing antipsychotic medication, including limiting the prescription for specific indications, using the minimum effective dose, and minimising the duration of therapy.
abstract.4: The first-line management of tardive dyskinesia is the withdrawal of antipsychotic medication if clinically feasible.
abstract.5: Yet, for many patients with serious mental illness, the discontinuation of antipsychotics is not possible due to disease relapse.
abstract.6: Switching from a first-generation to a second-generation antipsychotic with a lower D2 affinity, such as clozapine or quetiapine, may be effective in reducing tardive dyskinesia symptoms.
abstract.7: The strongest evidence for a suitable co-intervention to treat tardive dyskinesia comes from tests with the new VMAT inhibitors, deutetrabenazine and valbenazine.
abstract.8: These medications have not been approved for use in Canada.
abstract.9: Conclusion: Data on tardive dyskinesia treatment are limited, and the best management strategy remains prevention.
abstract.10: More long-term safety and efficacy data are needed for deutetrabenazine and valbenazine, and their routine availability to patients outside of the USA remains in question.

translation1.1: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by possibly irreversible, abnormal, uncontrolled movements related to the use of antipsychotics.
translation1.2: We try to suggest ways to treat tardive dyskinesia.
translation1.3: Preventing tardive dyskinesia is very important, and doctors should prescribe antipsychotics as recommended, including only prescribing them for certain conditions, using the lowest working dose, and limiting how long patients take them.
translation1.4: The first recommended treatment of tardive dyskinesia is to have the patient stop taking antipsychotics if possible.
translation1.5: Stopping antipsychotics is not possible for many patients with serious mental illness due to the disease returning.
translation1.6: Switching from a first-generation (older) to a second-generation (newer) antipsychotic, such as clozapine or quetiapine, may help reduce tardive dyskinesia symptoms.
translation1.7: Studies show tests with new vesicular monoamine transporter (VMAT) inhibitors, drugs that reduce dopamine (a chemical messenger released when your brain is expecting a reward), deutetrabenazine and valbenazine, to be the best additional treatment for tardive dyskinesia.
translation1.8: Canada has not approved these drugs for use.
translation1.9: We conclude that information on tardive dyskinesia treatment is limited, and preventing TD is the best way to manage it.
translation1.10: More studies that look at safety and how well deutetrabenazine and valbenazine work are needed, and it is uncertain how reliably available these drugs are to patients outside of the United States.

translation2.1: Tardive duskinesia is a movement disorder of irregular, repetitive, and jerking movements linked with using antipsychotic medication for treating mental illnesses.
translation2.2: We aim to provide recommendation on treating tardive dyskinesia.
translation2.3: Preventing tardive dyskinesia is very important. Clinicians should follow the best policies for prescribing antipsychotic medication. These include limiting the amount for specific symptoms, using the minimum effective dose, and minimising the duration of treatment.
translation2.4: The first-to-try treatment of tardive dyskinesia is removing antipsychotic medication if clinically possible.
translation2.5: Yet, for many patients with serious mental illness, removing antipsychotics is not possible due to disease reappearance.
translation2.6: Switching from one class to another class of antipsychotics, like clozapine or quetiapine, may help reduce tardive dyskinesia symptoms.
translation2.7: The strongest evidence for a suitable co-treatment for tardive dyskinesia comes from tests with new VMAT inhibitors, deutetrabenazine and valbenazine, which treat movement disorders.
translation2.8: These drugs have not been approved for use in Canada.
translation2.9: Data on tardive dyskinesia treatment is limited. The best treatment remains prevention.
translation2.10: We need more long-term safety and effectiveness data for deutetrabenazine and valbenazine. Their regular availability to patients outside the USA is unknown.

abstract.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD), a condition of potentially irreversible abnormal involuntary movements that is associated with dopamine receptor blocking agents (DRBAs), produces significant impairment of functioning and quality of life for patients.
abstract.2: Contrary to expectations, TD has not vanished despite the introduction of SGAs.
abstract.3: Instead, changing prescription practices and increased off-label prescription of DRBAs have placed more patients than ever at risk of this potentially dangerous and disabling condition.
abstract.4: This activity provides an overview of treatment strategies for TD as part of an individualized management plan, including DRBA medication adjustment and antidyskinetic treatment.

translation1.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD), characterized by possibly irreversible, abnormal, uncontrolled movements related to the use of antipsychotics, negatively affects functioning and quality of life for patients.
translation1.2: Although many believed it would be different, TD has not gone away even with the use of second-generation antipsychotics (SGAs), which are less likely to cause movement side effects.
translation1.3: Instead, changes in how antipsychotics are prescribed and antipsychotics prescribed for unapproved use have increased the patients at risk of TD.
translation1.4: We describe treatment options for TD as part of an individual-specific plan, including changing antipsychotic dosing and treating dyskinesia.

abstract.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a common, iatrogenic movement disorder affecting many individuals treated with dopamine-receptor blocking agents (DRBAs).
abstract.2: Studying treatment of TD can be complex, as the symptoms can be affected by changes in either dosage or type of DRBA, as well as by the variable natural course of the disease.
abstract.3: Historically many pharmacological therapies have been studied in TD, finding varying degrees of treatment success.
abstract.4: Most recently, the VMAT2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine were rigorously studied in TD in large, phase III clinical trials, and were shown to be beneficial in this population.
abstract.5: In this article, we will review various treatments of TD, including manipulation of the offending agent, VMAT2 inhibitors, other non-VMAT2-inhibiting medications, and non-pharmacological approaches.

translation1.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a common movement disorder in many people taking antipsychotics.
translation1.2: Studying treatment of TD can be difficult, because the symptoms can change based on changes to how much or what kind of antipsychotics are used, and by the range of normal disease progression.
translation1.3: Many drugs made to treat TD have been studied with different levels of success.
translation1.4: Most recently, the vesicular monoamine transporter type 2 (VMAT2) inhibitors, drugs that reduce dopamine (a chemical messenger released when your brain is expecting a reward), valbenazine and deutetrabenazine, were studied in TD in large human trials, and were shown to work in this group.
translation1.5: In this article, we will look at different treatments of TD, including changing the drug causing TD, VMAT2 inhibitors, other non-VMAT2-inhibiting drugs, and non-drug options.

29022654.Title: Epidemiology, Prevention, and Assessment of Tardive Dyskinesia and Advances in Treatment

abstract.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a disorder characterized by involuntary movements, typically of the orofacial muscles and also of the extremities and other muscle groups.
abstract.2: The condition is associated with exposure to dopamine receptor blocking agents, including antipsychotics.
abstract.3: Because the indications and off-label uses for these agents have expanded over the last 2 decades, a larger number of patients are receiving antipsychotic medications than in the past.
abstract.4: While evidence suggests that patients being treated with second-generation antipsychotics have less risk for developing TD than those treated with first-generation antipsychotics, the decreased risk is not as great as was originally expected.
abstract.5: In addition, patients with chronic psychiatric conditions often require long-term use of antipsychotics, putting them at risk for TD.
abstract.6: This article addresses the prevalence, risk factors, and prevention of TD; assessment strategies including diagnostic criteria and rating scales; and evidence for TD treatments, including 2 newly approved medications: deutetrabenazine and valbenazine.

translation1.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is characterized by uncontrolled movements, usually of the face muscles and also of the arms, legs, and other muscles.
translation1.2: TD is related to antipsychotic use.
translation1.3: Because reasons to prescribe and unapproved uses for antipsychotics have increased, more patients are taking antipsychotic drugs than in the past.
translation1.4: Although data suggest that patients taking second-generation (newer) antipsychotics are less likely to develop TD than those taking first-generation (older) antipsychotics, the decreased risk is not as great as originally thought.
translation1.5: In addition, patients with long-term mental conditions often need long-term antipsychotics use, putting them at risk for TD.
translation1.6: This article looks at the total number of TD cases at a given time, risk factors, and prevention of TD; ways to measure TD including signs and symptoms and questionnaires; and TD treatments, including 2 newly approved drugs: deutetrabenazine and valbenazine.

translation2.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a disorder of involuntary movements, typlically of the lower face muscles, limbs, and other muscle groups.
translation2.2: The condition is linked to exposure with blocking agents, like antipsychotics used to treat mental illnesses, of the chemical messenger dopamine.
translation2.3: Since the allowed and off-label uses for these agents has increased over the last 20 years, more patients are receiving antipsychotics than before.
translation2.4: While patients treated with one class of antipsychotics may have less risk for developing TD than those treated with another class, the decreased risk is not as big as expected.
translation2.5: Also, patients with long-lasting mental illnesses often need long-term use of antipsychotics, pytting them at risk for TD.
translation2.6: This article describes the widespreadness of TD, its risk factors, its prevention, its identification strategies like medical criteria and ratings, and evidence for its treatments, including deutetrabenazine and valbenzaine used for treating movement disorders.

32459404.Title: Pharmacologic Treatment of Tardive Dyskinesia: A Meta-Analysis and Systematic Review

abstract.1: Objective: To examine the efficacy of pharmacologic treatments for tardive dyskinesia (TD).
abstract.2: Data sources: PubMed was searched on December 12, 2017, for randomized, placebo-controlled trials examining the treatment of TD using the search terms (drug-induced dyskinesia OR tardive dyskinesia) AND (psychotic disorders OR schizophrenia).
abstract.3: Study selection: Studies were included if they examined tardive dyskinesia treatment as the primary outcome and were randomized and placebo-controlled trials.
abstract.4: Data extraction: The effect size (standard mean difference) of improvement (compared to placebo) stratified by medication class is reported for each of the trials included in this systematic review.
abstract.5: A meta-analysis was conducted utilizing a fixed-effects model.
abstract.6: Results: Vitamin E was associated with significantly greater reduction in TD symptoms compared to placebo (standardized mean difference [SMD] = 0.31 ± 0.08; 95% CI, 0.16 to 0.46; z = 4.1; P < .001).
abstract.7: There was significant evidence of publication bias in vitamin E studies (Egger test: P = .02).
abstract.8: Shorter duration of treatment and lower dose of vitamin E were significantly associated with greater measured treatment benefit.
abstract.9: Vitamin B₆ was associated with significantly greater reduction in TD symptoms compared to placebo (SMD = 1.41 ± 0.22; 95% CI, 0.98 to 1.85; z = 6.4; P < .001) in 2 trials conducted by the same research group.
abstract.10: Vesicular monoamine transporter 2 (VMAT2) inhibitors demonstrated significant benefit on tardive dyskinesia symptoms compared to placebo (SMD = 0.63 ± 0.11; 95% CI, 0.41 to 0.85; z = 5.58; P < .005).
abstract.11: Amantadine was associated with significantly greater score reduction compared to placebo (SMD = 0.46 ± 0.21; 95% CI, 0.05 to 0.87; z = 2.20; P < .05).
abstract.12: Calcium channel blockers were not associated with significantly greater score reduction compared to placebo (SMD = 0.31 ± 0.33; 95% CI, -0.34 to 0.96; z = 0.93; P = .35).
abstract.13: Conclusions: Data from multiple trials suggests that VMAT2 inhibitors, vitamin E, vitamin B₆, and amantadine may be effective for the treatment of TD.
abstract.14: Evidence of publication bias and a significant negative association of dose and duration of treatment with measured efficacy suggest that the benefits of vitamin E in TD may be overstated.
abstract.15: Head-to-head trials are needed to compare the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of pharmacologic agents for TD.

translation1.1: We aim to understand how well different drugs work to treat tardive dyskinesia (TD) - a movement disorder.
translation1.2: On December 12, 2017, we searched for published scientific studies looking at the treatment of TD versus sugar pills.
translation1.3: We included studies if they looked at treatment of TD as the main result and randomly assigned participants to groups receiving TD treatment or sugar pills.
translation1.5: We used statistical methods to combine the results of multiple studies.
translation1.6: Results favored vitamin E over sugar pills in TD symptom reduction.
translation1.7: The results of the published vitamin E studies were different from results of unpublished studies.
translation1.8: Taking vitamin E for a shorter amount of time and at a lower dose was associated with greater TD symptom reduction.
translation1.9: Results favored vitamin B6 over sugar pills in TD symptom reduction.
translation1.10: Results favored vesicular monoamine transporter type 2 (VMAT2) inhibitors, drugs that reduce dopamine (a chemical messenger released when your brain is expecting a reward), over sugar pills in TD symptom reduction.
translation1.11: Results favored amantadine - a dopamine promoter - over sugar pills.
translation1.12: Results did not favor calcium channel blockers, which block transport of calcium in the body, over sugar pills.
translation1.13: We conclude that many studies show that VMAT2 inhibitors, vitamin E, vitamin B₆, and amantadine may work to treat TD.
translation1.14: Because results of the published vitamin E studies were different from results of unpublished studies and taking vitamin E for a shorter amount of time and at a lower dose was associated with greater TD symptom reduction, the benefits of vitamin E in TD might not be as great as studies suggest.
translation1.15: Studies comparing TD treatments to each other are needed to compare how well they work and how cost-effective they are.

29996156.Title: Prevention and Treatment of Antipsychotic-induced Tardive Dyskinesia

abstract.1: Tardive dyskinesias (TDs) are still common long-term sequelae of antipsychotic treatment.
abstract.2: They are generally irreversible and associated with cognitive deficits, a decrease in quality of life and increased mortality.
abstract.3: Furthermore, they potentially contribute to further stigmatization of the affected patients.
abstract.4: However due to limited treatment options, antipsychotic drugs are still one of the cornerstones in treatment of most severe mental illnesses.
abstract.5: Therefore, knowledge about risk factors and prevention of TDs is crucial.
abstract.6: If TDs occur, the immediate optimization of the antipsychotic drug regimen is required.
abstract.7: Targeted medical treatments such as VMAT - 2 inhibitors can be considered.
abstract.8: The novel VMAT-2 inhibitors are not yet approved in Germany.
abstract.9: Other drugs that are currently used to treat TDs include clonazepam and gingko biloba.
abstract.10: This review summarizes the current evidence of treatment options of TDs and seeks to formulate clinical recommendations for the prevention and management of TDs.

translation1.1: Tardive dyskinesias (TDs) - movement disorders - are still common long-term consequences of antipsychotic drugs.
translation1.2: TDs generally cannot be reversed and are linked with intellectual disabilities, decreased quality of life and increased death.
translation1.3: Furthermore, TDs possibly cause patients to be viewed more negatively by society.
translation1.4: Because of a lack of treatment options, antipsychotic drugs are still one of the main treatments for serious mental illness.
translation1.5: Therefore, knowing about TD risk factors and prevention is very important.
translation1.6: IF TDs happen, the amount of antipsychotic drugs prescribed must be changed quickly to an appropriate amount.
translation1.7: Specialized drugs such as vesicular monoamine transporter type 2 (VMAT - 2) inhibitors, drugs that reduce dopamine (a chemical messenger released when your brain is expecting a reward), can be used.
translation1.8: Germany has not yet approved the new VMAT-2 inhibitors.
translation1.9: Clonazepam and gingko biloba, used for seizures and memory problems, respectively, are other drugs that can be used to treat TDs.
translation1.10: We summarize the current data on TD treatment options and try to come up with recommendations for doctors to prevent and treat TDs.

29795977.Title: Treatment of tardive dyskinesia with VMAT-2 inhibitors: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials

abstract.1: Aim: The aim of this study was to summarize the characteristics, efficacy, and safety of vesicular monoamine transporter-2 (VMAT-2) inhibitors for treating tardive dyskinesia (TD).
abstract.2: Materials and methods: We conducted a literature search in PubMed, Cochrane Database, and ClinicalTrials.gov, screening for systematic reviews, meta-analyses or double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trials (DBRPCTs) reporting efficacy or safety data of VMAT-2 inhibitors (tetrabenazine, deutetrabenazine, and valbenazine) in patients with TD.
abstract.3: A random effects meta-analysis of efficacy and safety data from DBRPCTs was performed.
abstract.4: Results: Two acute, 12-week DBRPCTs with deutetrabenazine 12-48 mg/day (n=413) and 4 acute, 4-6-week double-blind trials with valbenazine 12.5-100 mg/day (n=488) were meta-analyzable, without meta-analyzable, high-quality data for tetrabenazine.
abstract.5: Regarding reduction in total Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale (AIMS) scores (primary outcome), both deutetrabenazine (k=2, n=413, standardized mean difference [SMD] =-0.40, 95% confidence interval [CI] =-0.19, -0.62, p<0.001; weighted mean difference (WMD) =-1.44, 95% CI =-0.67, -2.19, p<0.001) and valbenazine (k=4, n=421, SMD =-0.58, 95% CI =-0.26, -0.91, p<0.001; WMD =-2.07, 95% CI =-1.08, -3.05, p<0.001) significantly outperformed placebo.
abstract.6: Results were confirmed regarding responder rates (≥50% AIMS total score reduction; deutetrabenazine: risk ratio [RR] =2.13, 95% CI =1.10, 4.12, p=0.024, number-needed-to-treat [NNT] =7, 95% CI =3, 333, p=0.046; valbenazine: RR =3.05, 95% CI =1.81, 5.11, p<0.001, NNT =4, 95% CI =3, 6, p<0.001).
abstract.7: Less consistent results emerged from patient-rated global impression-based response (p=0.15) and clinical global impression for deutetrabenazine (p=0.088), and for clinical global impression change for valbenazine (p=0.67).
abstract.8: In an open-label extension (OLE) study of deutetrabenazine (≤54 weeks) and a dose-blinded valbenazine study (≤48 weeks), responder rates increased over time.
abstract.9: With valbenazine, discontinuation effects were studied, showing TD symptom recurrence towards baseline severity levels within 4 weeks after valbenazine withdrawal.
abstract.10: No increased cumulative or specific adverse (AEs) events versus placebo (acute trials) in extension versus acute trial data were observed.
abstract.11: Conclusion: The 2 VMAT-2 inhibitors, valbenazine and deutetrabenazine, are effective in treating TD, both acutely and long-term, without concerns about increased risk of depression or suicide in the TD population.
abstract.12: No head-to-head comparison among VMAT-2 inhibitors and no high-quality, meta-analyzable data are available for tetrabenazine in patients with TD.

translation1.1: We aimed to summarize the characteristics, how well it works, and safety of vesicular monoamine transporter type 2 (VMAT-2) inhibitors, drugs that reduce dopamine (a chemical messenger released when your brain is expecting a reward), for treating tardive dyskinesia (TD) - a movement disorder.
translation1.2: We searched for published scientific studies, including studies that summarized other studies, used statistics to combine results from other studies, or randomly assigned participants to groups receiving TD treatment or sugar pills that looked at how well treatments worked and safety of VMAT-2 inhibitors (tetrabenazine, deutetrabenazine, and valbenazine) in patients with TD.
translation1.3: We used statistical methods to determine how well treatments work and safety results across multiple studies.
translation1.4: We used statistical methods to combine results from two 12-week studies with deutetrabenazine 12-48 mg/day (413 patients) and four 4-6 week studies with valbenazine 12.5-100 mg/day (488 patients). No high-quality data were available for tetrabenazine for a similar analysis.
translation1.5: Results favored deutetrabenazine and valbenazine over sugar pills in scores on a rating scale that measures involuntary movements (AIMS).
translation1.6: The percentage of patients who had 50% reduction in scores on the same rating scale (AIMS) favored deutetrabenazine and valbenazine over sugar pills.
translation1.7: Results were less consistent using another rating scale done by patients and doctors for deutetrabenazine and by doctors for valbenazine.
translation1.8: In one study of deutetrabenazine and one study of valbenazine, the percentage of patients who had a 50% reduction in scores on the AIMS rating scale went up over time.
translation1.9: Effects of stopping valbenazine were studied, showing TD symptoms returning to levels before stopping valbenazine within 4 weeks of stopping the drug.
translation1.10: No increased unfavorable and unintended effects were observed in studies where participants continued to take the studied drug compared to sugar pills.
translation1.11: We conclude that the 2 VMAT-2 inhibitors, valbenazine and deutetrabenazine, work to treat TD, both in the short- and long-term, without causing increased risk of depression or suicide in people with TD.
translation1.12: No studies comparing VMAT-2 inhibitors or high-quality tetrabenazine data that could be compared across studies were available.

translation2.1: This study's aim was to summarize the characteristics, effect, and safety of vesicular monoamine transporter-2 (VMAT-2) inhibitors, drugs that treat movement disorders, for treating tardive dyskinesia (TD), a movement disorder of irregular, jerking movements.
translation2.2: We searched online for studies reporting the effect and safety of VMAT-2 inhibitors like tetrabenazine, deutetrabenazine, and valbenazine in patients with TD.
translation2.4: Two short, 12-week studies with deutetrabenazine12-48 mg/day (with 413 patients) and 4 short, 4-6-week studies with valbenazine 12.5-100 mg/day (with 488 patients) were analyzed. There was no high-quality data for tetrabenazine.
translation2.5: Regarding reducing irregular, involuntary movements (the primary symptom), both deutetrabenazine and valbenazine outperformed placebo or a dummy treatment.
translation2.6: Results were confirmed regarding responder rates, or the proportion of patients with a reduction in symptoms in a define period of time.
translation2.7: Patient-rated global impressions for deutetrabenazine and clinical global impressions for deutetrabenazine and valbenazine were less strong.
translation2.8: In a long-term study of deutetrabenazine (≤54 weeks) and a valbenazine study (≤48 weeks), responder rates increased.
translation2.9: With valbenazine, drug use stoppage effects were studied, showing TD symptom reappearance of initial severity 4 weeks after valbenazine stoppage.
translation2.10: No increased or specific, serious or adverse events (AEs) versus dummy treatment (acute trials) in long-term versus short-term trials were seen.
translation2.11: The 2 VMAT-2 inhibitors, valbenazine and deutetrabenazine, can treat TD, both short- and long-term, without concerns about increased risk of depression or suicide in the TD population.
translation2.12: No direct comparison between the VMAT-2 inhibitors and no high-quality data are available for tetrabenazine in patients with TD.

32991793.Title: Selecting Treatment for Patients With Tardive Dyskinesia Using Safety and Efficacy Evidence

abstract.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a condition of potentially irreversible abnormal involuntary movements associated with dopamine receptor blocking agents, such as antipsychotics.
abstract.2: While prevention is the best strategy, it is not always possible.
abstract.3: This report outlines strategies to reduce TD symptoms, including the use of the FDA-approved treatment options (valbenazine and deutetrabenazine).

translation1.1: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is characterized by possibly irreversible, abnormal, uncontrolled movements related to the use of antipsychotics.
translation1.2: While prevention is the best approach, it is not always possible.
translation1.3: This report lists approaches to reduce TD symptoms, including the use of treatments options approved by the FDA (such as the drugs valbenazine and deutetrabenazine).

32.question: What bp meds should not be taken if person has mthfr genetic variant?

18200034.Title: Effect of ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers on homocysteine levels in essential hypertension

abstract.1: Recent studies have shown that antihypertensive drugs like diuretics increase plasma homocysteine (Hcy) levels.
abstract.2: However, the effect of other antihypertensive drugs on plasma Hcy levels has not been tested extensively.
abstract.3: The aim of present study was to investigate the effect of antihypertensive therapy (AHT) on Hcy levels in essential hypertensive subjects.
abstract.4: A case-control study of 273 patients with essential hypertension (EH) and 103 normotensive controls was undertaken.
abstract.5: Plasma Hcy levels were measured before and after 6 weeks of AHT.
abstract.6: The genotyping of MTHFR C677T polymorphism was performed by polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism.
abstract.7: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and beta-blockers significantly decreased and hydrochlorothiazides significantly increased the plasma Hcy levels in hypertensive patients (P<0.05).
abstract.8: No significant association between MTHFR C677T genotypes and changes in Hcy levels in response to antihypertensive was observed in EH patients.
abstract.9: The decrease in Hcy induced by beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors observed in our study may be due to the improvement of endothelial function along with improved renal function.
abstract.10: Thus, our results suggest that ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers may provide additional beneficial therapeutic effects to the EH patients by decreasing Hcy levels.

translation1.1: Recent studies have shown that antihypertensive drugs (that treat high blood pressure), like diuretics, increase plasma or blood homocysteine (Hcy) levels. Hcy is am amino acid that creates other chemicals your body needs.
translation1.2: However, the effect of other antihypertensive drugs on plasma Hcy levels has not been tested extensively.
translation1.3: The goal of this study was to investigate the effect of antihypertensive therapy (AHT) on Hcy levels in essential hypertensive subjects. Essential hypertensive patients have high blood pressure that is not the result of a medical condition.
translation1.4: A study of 273 patients with essential hypertension (EH) and 103 patients with normal blood pressure was begun.
translation1.5: Plasma Hcy levels were measured before and after 6 weeks of AHT.
translation1.6: Patients were genotyped to analyze a specific genetic variation or gene material.
translation1.7: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are drugs that lower blood pressure by relaxing veins and arteries. Beta-blockers are drugs that lower blood pressure by blocking the effects of adrenaline. ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers significantly decrease plasms Hcy levels in hypertensive patients. Hydrochlorothiazides, or "water pills", significantly increase plasms Hcy levels in hypertensive patients.
translation1.8: There was no association between the identified genetic variation and changes in Hcy levels in response to antihypertensive within EH patients.
translation1.9: The observed decrease in Hcy caused by ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers may be due to the improvement of endothelial (tissue lining various organs and cavities in the body) and kidney function.
translation1.10: Therefore, this study suggests that ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers may provide additional, beneficial or therapeutic effects to the EH patients by decreasing Hcy levels.

15226090.Title: The C677T polymorphism of the methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase gene is associated with the level of decrease on diastolic blood pressure in essential hypertension patients treated by angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor

abstract.1: Objectives: Elevated plasma homocysteine has been implicated as a risk factor for hypertension.
abstract.2: C677T polymorphism in methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase gene (MTHFR) is a major determinant of hyperhomocysteinemia, which results in endothelial dysfunction.
abstract.3: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors appear to remedy the endothelial dysfunction and restore endothelium-dependent vasodilatation.
abstract.4: The co-existence of genetic polymorphisms in drug metabolizing enzymes, targets, receptors, and transporters may influence the drug efficacy.
abstract.5: The purpose of this study was to investigate whether short-term blood pressure control by benazepril, an ACE inhibitor, was modulated by C677T MTHFR gene polymorphism.
abstract.6: Methods and results: A total of 444 hypertensive patients, aged 27 to 65 years, without any anti hypertensive therapy within 2 weeks were included.
abstract.7: All of them were treated orally with benazepril at a single daily fixed dosage of 10 mg for 15 consecutive days.
abstract.8: Blood pressures were measured at baseline and on the 16th day of treatment.
abstract.9: Among them, the frequency of MTHFR C677T genotype CC, CT and TT was 24.3%, 51.8%, and 23.9%, respectively.
abstract.10: In a recessive model (CC+CT versus TT genotype), both baseline diastolic blood pressure (DBP) and diastolic blood pressure response (DeltaDBP) were significantly higher in patients with the TT genotype than in those with the CT or CC genotype (P value=0.0076 for DBP, and P value=0.0005 for DeltaDBP).
abstract.11: We further divided all patients into three groups based on the tertiles of the DeltaBP distribution.
abstract.12: Compared to subjects in the lowest tertile of DeltaDBP, the adjusted relative odds of having the TT genotype among subjects in the highest tertile was 2.6 (95% CI, 1.4 to 4.9).
abstract.13: However, baseline systolic blood pressure (SBP) and SBP response did not significantly associate with MTHFR C677T polymorphism.
abstract.14: Conclusions: Our finding suggests that MTHFR C667T polymorphism modulated baseline DBP and DBP responsiveness by short-term treatment of ACE inhibitor in Chinese essential hypertensive patients.

translation1.1: Increase plasma, or blood, homocysteine has been identified as a risk factor for hypertension (high blood pressure). Homocysteine is a chemical your body produces to help make proteins.
translation1.2: An identified genetic variation or gene type within the human population is a major determinant of hyperhomocysteinemia. Hyperhomocysteinemia is a condition with excess homocysteine in the blood. The condition can result in endothelial dysfunction, or a heart disease where the blood vessels narrow instead of opening.
translation1.3: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are a type of drug commonly used to treat high blood pressure. ACE Inhibitors appear to fix the endothelial (or blood vessel lining) dysfunction and allow blood vessels to open.
translation1.4: The presence of the genetic variation in specific bodily locations that metabolize or digest drugs, such as enzymes and receptors, may influence how well a drug works.
translation1.5: The goal of this study was to investigate if short-term blood pressure control by an ACE inhibitor (Benazepril) is effected by the identified genetic variation.
translation1.6: A total of 444 hypertensive patients, aged 27 to 65 years, without any anti hypertensive therapy within 2 weeks were included.
translation1.7: All patients were treated with Benazepril with a single, daily dose of 10 mg for 15 consecutive days.
translation1.8: Blood pressures were measured prior to the study beginning (baseline) and on the 16th day of treatment.
translation1.9: The unique genetic variation has three unique "versions" or genotypes, known as CC, CT, or TT. Among the patients, the frequency of the genetic variation genotype CC, CT, and TT was 24.3%, 51.8%, and 23.9%, respectively.
translation1.10: In a statistical analysis, several blood pressure measurements were higher in patients with the TT genotype than those with the CT or CC genotype.
translation1.11: The authors further divided all patients into three groups based on where their diastolic blood pressure response (DeltaDBP) fell within a population scale. Diastolic blood pressure is the lowest pressure when the heart is relaxed.
translation1.12: Patients with the highest DeltaDBP had the highest chance of having the TT genotype.
translation1.13: However, baseline systolic blood pressure (when the heart is contracting) was not significantly associated with the unique genetic variation.
translation1.14: This study suggests that the unique genetic variation altered baseline DBP by short-term treatment of ACE inhibitor in hypertensive patients.

translation2.1: Increased blood levels of homocysteine, a specific chemical, may be a risk factor for high blood pressure.
translation2.2: A specific mutation in DNA (C677T) encoding methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR), a protein that transforms homocysteine, greatly influences hyperhomocysteinemia, or high blood levels of homocysteine. This condition results in damage to cells that line the heart and blood vessels.
translation2.3: Blood pressure medication called angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors seem to repair damage to cells lining the heart and blood vessels and restore blood vessel widening.
translation2.4: The co-existence of varied DNA for drug-digesting enzymes, targets, target sites, and transporters may affect drug effect.
translation2.5: This study investigates if short-term blood pressure control by benazepril, an ACE inhibitor, was affected by variation in the DNA sequence for the C667T MTHFR gene.
translation2.6: 444 patients with high blood pressure, aged 27 to 65 years, without any high blood pressure therapy within 2 weeks were included.
translation2.7: All of them swallowed benazepril at a single daily fixed dose of 10 mg for 15 consecutive days.
translation2.8: Blood pressures were measured at start and on the 16th day of treatment.
translation2.9: Among them, the gene sequence for MTHFR C677T varied.
translation2.10: Diastolic blood pressure at the start and end were much higher for patients with a certain DNA sequence for the MTHFR C677T gene than patients with two other DNA sequences.
translation2.11: We then divided all patients into 3 groups based on the distribution of blood pressure readings at the study's end.
translation2.12: Compared to those with the lowest blood pressure measurements, the chances of having a certain DNA sequence for the MTHFR C667T gene among those with the highest blood pressure readings was 2.6 times higher.
translation2.13: However, systolic blood pressure at the start and end was not linked to DNA sequences.
translation2.14: DNA sequence variation for the MTHFR C667T gene affects diastolic blood pressure at the study's start and end in Chinese essential patients with high blood pressure.

30372582.Title: The modifying effect of the MTHFR genotype on the association between folic acid supplementation and pulse wave velocity: Findings from the CSPPT

abstract.1: Objective: In a subgroup analysis of the China Stroke Primary Prevention Trial, we aimed to explore the impact of folic acid supplementation on arterial stiffness and assess the modifying effect of the methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) gene in Chinese patients with hypertension.
abstract.2: Methods: This prospective study enrolled 2529 hypertensive Chinese patients.
abstract.3: Participants were randomized to receive treatment with either a combination of enalapril and folic acid or enalapril.
abstract.4: Brachial-ankle pulse wave velocity (PWV) was measured by trained medical staff using PWV instruments at both baseline and exit visits, approximately 5 years after enrollment.
abstract.5: This trial was registered with clinicaltrials.gov (NCT00794885).
abstract.6: Results: During the follow-up, change in folate was significantly and independently correlated with change in ba-PWV in study patients (β = -1.31, P < 0.001).
abstract.7: Individuals with CC genotype had a significantly greater PWV response to folic acid supplementation than did carriers of the T allele (β = -2.79, P < 0.001 for CC homozygotes compared with β = -0.56, P = 0.464 for TT homozygotes).
abstract.8: The positive effect of folic acid on improved PWV was modified by the MTHFR genotype (P for interaction = 0.034).
abstract.9: Conclusion: In a subgroup of Chinese hypertensive patients who had received 5-year antihypertensive therapy, increases in folate status were associated with higher reductions in PWV, and individuals with the CC genotype showed greatest PWV response to folic acid supplementation.

translation1.1: This study conducted an analysis using patients from the China Stroke Primary Prevention Trial. The goal of this study was to explore the impact of folic acid (a specific vitamin) on arterial stiffness (hardness of arteries or specific blood vessels). Additionally, this study aimed to measure the modifying or influencing effect of a specific gene (methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase-MTHFR) in Chinese patients with hypertension (high blood pressure).
translation1.2: This study enrolled 2,529 hypertensive (high blood pressure) Chinese patients.
translation1.3: Participants were randomized to receive treatment with either a combination of enalapril (common blood pressure medication) and folic acid or enalapril.
translation1.4: Brachial-ankle pulse wave velocity (PWV) is a measurement of  arterial stiffness. It is measured by looking at the brachial and tibial arteries, located within the upper arm. PWV was taken by trained medical staff using appropriate equipment during both baseline (before treatment) and exit (end of treatment) visits, approximately 5 years after enrollment.
translation1.5: This trial was registered with clinicaltrials.gov (NCT00794885).
translation1.6: During the follow-up, change in folate (vitamin in the body) was significantly and independently linked with change in PWV in patients.
translation1.7: Patients with CC genotype (a person's collection of specific genes) had a significantly greater PWV response to folic acid than those with genotype CT or TT.
translation1.8: The positive effect of folic acid on improved PWV was modified by what genotype the patient had.
translation1.9: The study concluded that within the analyzed subgroup of Chinese hypertensive patients who had received a 5-year antihypertensive therapy, increase in folate status were correlated or linked with decreased PWV. Additionally, individuals with CC genotype showed greatest PWV response to folic acid treatment.

29371246.Title: MTHFR Gene and Serum Folate Interaction on Serum Homocysteine Lowering: Prospect for Precision Folic Acid Treatment

abstract.1: Objective: This post hoc analysis of the CSPPT (China Stroke Primary Prevention Trial) assessed the individual variation in total homocysteine (tHcy)-lowering response after an average 4.5 years of 0.8 mg daily folic acid therapy in Chinese hypertensive adults and evaluated effect modification by methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) C677T genotypes and serum folate levels.
abstract.2: Approach and results: This analysis included 16 413 participants from the CSPPT, who were randomly assigned to 2 double-blind treatment groups: either 10-mg enalapril+0.8-mg folic acid or 10-mg enalapril, daily and had individual measurements of serum folate and tHcy levels at baseline and exit visits and MTHFR C677T genotypes.
abstract.3: Mean baseline tHcy levels were comparable between the 2 treatment groups (14.5±8.5 versus 14.4±8.1 μmol/L; P=0.561).
abstract.4: After 4.5 years of treatment, mean tHcy levels were reduced to 12.7±6.1 μmol/L in the enalapril+folic acid group, but almost stayed the same in the enalapril group (14.4±7.9 μmol/L, group difference: 1.61 μmol/L; 11% reduction).
abstract.5: More importantly, tHcy lowering varied by MTHFR genotypes and serum folate levels.
abstract.6: Compared with CC and CT genotypes, participants with the TT genotype had a more prominent L-shaped curve between tHcy and serum folate levels and required higher folate levels (at least 15 ng/mL) to eliminate the differences in tHcy by genotypes.
abstract.7: Conclusions: Compared with CC or CT, tHcy in the TT group manifested a heightened L-shaped curve from low to high folate levels, but this difference in tHcy by genotype was eliminated when plasma folate levels reach ≈15 ng/mL or higher.
abstract.8: Our data raised the prospect to tailor folic acid therapy according to individual MTHFR C677T genotype and folate status.

translation1.1: This study represents an analysis on the China Stroke Primary Prevention Trial (CSPPT). Individual variation in total homocysteine (tHcy)-lowering response was measured after an average of 4.5 years of 0.8 mg daily folic acid (or specific vitamin) therapy. Homocysteine is a chemical your body produces to help make proteins. This study was completed in Chinese hypertensive (high blood pressure) adults. This study evaluated effect modification by methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) C677T genotypes (a person's specific gene type for a specific protein) and serum or blood folate (derivative of folic acid) levels.
translation1.2: The study included 16,413 participants from the CSPPT study. The participants were randomly assigned to 2 double-blind treatment groups. Double-blind indicates the study participants were not told which treatment group they were apart of. The participants received either 10-mg enalapril (common blood pressure medication) +0.8-mg folic acid or 10-mg enalapril daily. The participants had individual measurements of serum folate and tHcy levels at baseline (before study) and exit (end of study) visits and MTHFR C677T genotypes.
translation1.3: Average baseline tHcy levels were similar between the 2 treatment groups.
translation1.4: After 4.5 years of treatment, mean or average tHcy levels were reduced in the enalapril+folic acid group, but almost stayed the same in the enalapril group.
translation1.5: However, tHcy lowering varied by MTHFR genotypes and serum folate levels.
translation1.6: Participants with a specific MTHFR genotype (TT) required higher folate levels to eliminate the differences in tHcy between them and the other two genotypes (CC and CT).
translation1.7: The study concluded that the TT genotype group showed that as folate levels increased, tHcy levels decreased. However, this difference in tHcy between the genotype groups was removed when plasma or blood folate levels reached ≈15 ng/mL or higher.
translation1.8: This study suggests to tailor folic acid therapy by MTHFR genotype and folate status.

33172445.Title: Impact of the common MTHFR 677C→T polymorphism on blood pressure in adulthood and role of riboflavin in modifying the genetic risk of hypertension: evidence from the JINGO project

abstract.1: Background: Genome-wide and clinical studies have linked the 677C→T polymorphism in the gene encoding methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) with hypertension, whilst limited evidence shows that intervention with riboflavin (i.e. the MTHFR co-factor) can lower blood pressure (BP) in hypertensive patients with the variant MTHFR 677TT genotype.
abstract.2: We investigated the impact of this common polymorphism on BP throughout adulthood and hypothesised that riboflavin status would modulate the genetic risk of hypertension.
abstract.3: Methods: Observational data on 6076 adults of 18-102 years were drawn from the Joint Irish Nutrigenomics Organisation project, comprising the Trinity-Ulster Department of Agriculture (TUDA; volunteer sample) and the National Adult Nutrition Survey (NANS; population-based sample) cohorts.
abstract.4: Participants were recruited from the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland (UK) in 2008-2012 using standardised methods.
abstract.5: Results: The variant MTHFR 677TT genotype was identified in 12% of adults.
abstract.6: From 18 to 70 years, this genotype was associated with an increased risk of hypertension (i.e. systolic BP ≥ 140 and/or a diastolic BP ≥ 90 mmHg): odds ratio (OR) 1.42, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.07 to 1.90; P = 0.016, after adjustment for antihypertensive drug use and other significant factors, namely, age, male sex, BMI, alcohol and total cholesterol.
abstract.7: Low or deficient biomarker status of riboflavin (observed in 30.2% and 30.0% of participants, respectively) exacerbated the genetic risk of hypertension, with a 3-fold increased risk for the TT genotype in combination with deficient riboflavin status (OR 3.00, 95% CI, 1.34-6.68; P = 0.007) relative to the CC genotype combined with normal riboflavin status.
abstract.8: Up to 65 years, we observed poorer BP control rates on antihypertensive treatment in participants with the TT genotype (30%) compared to those without this variant, CT (37%) and CC (45%) genotypes (P < 0.027).
abstract.9: Conclusions: The MTHFR 677TT genotype is associated with higher BP independently of homocysteine and predisposes adults to an increased risk of hypertension and poorer BP control with antihypertensive treatment, whilst better riboflavin status is associated with a reduced genetic risk.
abstract.10: Riboflavin intervention may thus offer a personalised approach to prevent the onset of hypertension in adults with the TT genotype; however, this requires confirmation in a randomised trial in non-hypertensive adults.

translation1.1: Research has linked a specific a genetic variation or gene change, known as 677C→T, within the gene encoding methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR - a blood-pressure-related protein) with hypertension (high blood pressure). Limited evidence has shown that taking riboflavin, which is a co-factor or helper of MTHFR, can lower blood pressure (BP) in hypertensive patients with the variant MTHFR 677TT genotype.
translation1.2: This study investigated the impact of the common genetic variation on BP throughout adulthood. They hypothesized that riboflavin status would alter the genetic risk of hypertension.
translation1.3: Observational data on 6076 adults of 18-102 years were drawn from the Joint Irish Nutrigenomics Organization project, comprising the Trinity-Ulster Department of Agriculture (TUDA; volunteer sample) and the National Adult Nutrition Survey (NANS; population-based sample) cohorts or groups.
