translation1.4: Participants were recruited from the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland (UK) in 2008-2012 using standard methods.
translation1.5: The genetic variant MTHFR 677TT genotype was identified in 12% of recruited adults.
translation1.6: In patients 18 to 70 years old, this genotype was associated with an increased risk of hypertension.
translation1.7: Low or deficient levels of riboflavin increased the genetic risk of hypertension. Participants with 677TT genotype and a riboflavin deficiency have a 3-fold higher risk of developing hypertension.
translation1.8: In participants up to 65 years, the authors observed poorer BP control rates on antihypertensive treatment in participants with the TT genotype compared to participants with other genotypes (CC or CT).
translation1.9: The study concluded the MTHFR 677TT genotype is associated with higher BP independently of homocysteine levels. Homocysteine is a chemical your body produces to help make proteins. Additionally, the MTHFR 677TT genotype makes people more likely to have an increased risk of hypertension and poorer BP control with antihypertensive treatment. Better riboflavin status was associated with a reduced genetic risk for hypertension.
translation1.10: Riboflavin administration or use may offer a personalized or unique approach to prevent the onset or start of hypertension in adults with the TT genotype. However, this requires more researched in non-hypertensive adults.

translation2.1: Genetic and clinical studies have linked variation in a specific DNA sequence for methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR), a certain protein, with high blood pressure. Some evidence shows that treatment with riboflavin (a molecule that attaches to MTHFR) can lower blood pressure (BP) in patients with high blood pressure and an altered DNA sequence for MTHFR called 677TT.
translation2.2: We tested the impact of this altered DNA sequence on BP through adulthood. We believed that riboflavin would affect the genetic risk of high blood pressure.
translation2.4: Patients were recruited from the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland in 2008-2012.
translation2.5: The altered DNA sequence of MTHFR 677TT was found in 12% of adults.
translation2.6: From 18 to 70 years, this altered DNA sequence, or genotype, was linked with increased risk of high blood pressure after adjusting for blood pressure medication use, age, sex, body mass, alcohol, total cholesterol, and other factors.
translation2.7: Low or no riboflavin (seen in 30.2% and 30.0% of participants, respectively) worsened the genetic risk of high blood pressure. Patients with a certain genotype along with no riboflavin had a 3-fold increased risk compared to patients with the standard genotype along with normal riboflavin.
translation2.8: Up to 65 years, we saw poorer BP control rates on anti-high-BP treatment in participants with a certain DNA sequence for MTHFR compared to those without this altered DNA sequence.
translation2.9: A specific gentoype for MTHFR is linked with higher BP regardless of homocysteine, a molecule that MTHFR acts on, and biases adults to increased risk of high BP and poorer BP control with anti-high-BP treatment. Better riboflavin amount is linked with reduced genetic risk.
translation2.10: Riboflavin treatment may thus give an individualized approach to prevent high BP in adults with a certain genotype for MTHFR. Still, this needs confirmation in a trial in adults without high BP.

24131523.Title: MTHFR 677TT genotype and disease risk: is there a modulating role for B-vitamins?

abstract.1: Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) is a critical folate-metabolising enzyme which requires riboflavin as its co-factor.
abstract.2: A common polymorphism (677C→T) in the MTHFR gene results in reduced MTHFR activity in vivo which in turn leads to impaired folate metabolism and elevated homocysteine concentrations.
abstract.3: Homozygosity for this polymorphism (TT genotype) is associated with an increased risk of a number of conditions including heart disease and stroke, but there is considerable variability in the extent of excess risk in various reports.
abstract.4: The present review will explore the evidence which supports a role for this polymorphism as a risk factor for a number of adverse health outcomes, and the potential modulating roles for B-vitamins in alleviating disease risk.
abstract.5: The evidence is convincing in the case which links this polymorphism with hypertension and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, particularly preeclampsia.
abstract.6: Furthermore, elevated blood pressure was found to be highly responsive to riboflavin intervention specifically in individuals with the MTHFR 677TT genotype.
abstract.7: Future intervention studies targeted at these genetically predisposed individuals are required to further investigate this novel gene-nutrient interaction.
abstract.8: This polymorphism has also been associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects (NTD) and other adverse pregnancy outcomes; however, the evidence in this area has been inconsistent.
abstract.9: Preliminary evidence has suggested that there may be a much greater need for women with the MTHFR 677TT genotype to adhere to the specific recommendation of commencing folic acid prior to conception for the prevention of NTD, but this requires further investigation.

translation1.1: Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) is a critical folate (specific vitamin)-metabolizing enzyme which requires riboflavin as its co-factor. Co-factors are needed for enzymes, catalysts for chemical reactions in the body, to complete their roles.
translation1.2: A common variation (677C→T) in the MTHFR gene results in reduced MTHFR activity. This can caused impaired folate metabolism and increased homocysteine concentrations. Homocysteine is a chemical your body produces to help make proteins.
translation1.3: Individuals can inherit the same form of a gene from both parents. When this occurs, a person has homozygosity. Homozygosity for this genetic variation (TT genotype) is associated with an increased risk of a number of conditions. These conditions include heart disease and stroke. However, there is a large amount of variability or differences in the extent of excess risk in various reports.
translation1.4: The study aimed to explore the evidence available that supports this genetic variation increasing the risk for several adverse or bad health outcomes. Additionally, the study aimed to explore the evidence of how B-vitamins can help alleviate or lessen disease risk.
translation1.5: There is strong evidence that links the genetic variation (TT genotype) with hypertension (hig blood pressure) and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, particularly preeclampsia.
translation1.6: Furthermore, high blood pressure was found to be highly responsive to or affected by riboflavin intervention or treatment specifically in individuals with the MTHFR 677TT genotype.
translation1.7: Future intervention studies aimed at genetically predisposed or genetically risky individuals are required to further understand this gene-nutrient interaction.
translation1.8: This genetic variation has also been associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects (NTD), brain-related damage, and other adverse pregnancy outcomes. However, the evidence on this subject has been inconsistent.
translation1.9: Initial evidence has suggested there may be a greater need for women with MTHFR 677TT genotype to take folic acid prior to conception (or having a baby) for the prevention of NTD. However, this idea requires further investigation.

32278343.Title: A prospective cohort study of MTHFR C677T gene polymorphism and its influence on the therapeutic effect of homocysteine in stroke patients with hyperhomocysteinemia

abstract.1: Background: Hyperhomocysteinemia (HHCY) is a risk factor for cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.
abstract.2: The C677T 5, 10-methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) gene polymorphism increases homocysteine (HCY) levels.
abstract.3: This study analyzed the relationship between C677T MTHFR polymorphism and the therapeutic effect of lowering HCY in stroke patients with HHCY.
abstract.4: Methods: Baseline data were collected from stroke patients with HHCY for this prospective cohort study.
abstract.5: The C677T MTHFR genotype was detected by polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism and the therapeutic effect to reduce HCY was compared.
abstract.6: Results: Of 200 stroke patients 162 (81.0%) completed follow-up and were evaluated.
abstract.7: Most of them responded well to treatment (103 cases, 63.5%), but 59 (36.4%) patients were in the poor efficacy group.
abstract.8: There was a significant difference in terms of age (P < 0.001), hypertension (P = 0.041), hyperuricemia (P = 0.042), HCY after treatment (P < 0.001), and MTHFR genotype (P < 0.001) between the poor efficacy and effective groups, with increased frequency of the TT genotype in the poor efficacy group.
abstract.9: Logistic regression showed that the T allele was associated with poor efficacy (OR = 0.733, 95%CI: 0.693, 0.862, P < 0.001).
abstract.10: In the codominant model the TT genotype was associated with poor outcome (OR = 0.862, 95%CI: 0.767, 0.970, P = 0.017) and this was also the case in the recessive model (OR = 0.585, 95%CI: 0.462, 0.741, P < 0.001) but there was no association between CT and TT in the dominant model.
abstract.11: Conclusions: The T allele and TT genotype of the MTHFR C677T polymorphism was associated with poor HCY reduction treatment efficacy in stroke patients with HHCY.

translation1.1: Hyperhomocysteinemia (HHCY), when there is excess homocysteine in the blood, is a risk factor for cardiovascular, or blood- and heart-related, and cerebrovascular, or blood- and brain-related, diseases. Homocysteine is an intermediate amino acid (molecule that form proteins).
translation1.2: A specific genetic variation or gene change, known as  C677T 5, 10-methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) gene polymorphism, which alters the MTHFR protein involved in blood pressure, increases homocysteine (HCY) levels.
translation1.3: This study analyzed the relationship between C677T MTHFR variation and the therapeutic, beneficial effect (response after a treatment) of lowering HCY in stroke patients with HHCY.
translation1.4: Baseline data, meaning prior to treatment, was collected from stroke patients with HHCY for this study.
translation1.5: The C677T MTHFR genotype was detected, and the therapeutic effect to reduce HCY was compared.
translation1.6: Of 200 stroke patients, 162 completed follow-up and were evaluated.
translation1.7: Most of them responded well to treatment, but 59 patients were in the poor efficacy or poor effect group.
translation1.8: There was a significant difference in terms of age, hypertension (high blood pressure), hyperuricemia (high uric acid or waste), HCY after treatment, and MTHFR genotype between the poor efficacy and effective groups. The poor efficacy group had more participated with TT genotype of the genetic variant.
translation1.9: Statistical analysis showed that the T allele (an alternative form of a gene) was associated with poor efficacy.
translation1.10: The TT genotype was associated with poor outcomes.
translation1.11: The study concluded the T allele and TT genotype of the MTHFR C677T genetic variation was associated with poor HCY reduction treatment efficacy in stroke patients with HHCY.

31932513.Title: Interaction of serum vitamin B 12 and folate with MTHFR genotypes on risk of ischemic stroke

abstract.1: Objective: We evaluated the interaction of serum folate and vitamin B12 with methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) C677T genotypes on the risk of first ischemic stroke and on the efficacy of folic acid treatment in prevention of first ischemic stroke.
abstract.2: Methods: A total of 20,702 hypertensive adults were randomized to a double-blind treatment of daily enalapril 10 mg and folic acid 0.8 mg or enalapril 10 mg alone.
abstract.3: Participants were followed up every 3 months.
abstract.4: Results: Median values of folate and B12 concentrations at baseline were 8.1 ng/mL and 280.2 pmol/L, respectively.
abstract.5: Over a median of 4.5 years, among those not receiving folic acid, participants with baseline serum B12 or serum folate above the median had a significantly lower risk of first ischemic stroke (hazard ratio [HR], 0.74; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.57-0.96), especially in those with MTHFR 677 CC genotype (wild-type) (HR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.31-0.78).
abstract.6: Folic acid treatment significantly reduced the risk of first ischemic stroke in participants with both folate and B12 below the median (2.3% in enalapril-folic acid group vs 3.6% in enalapril-only group; HR, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.46-0.86), particularly in MTHFR 677 CC carriers (1.6% vs 4.9%; HR, 0.24; 95% CI, 0.11-0.55).
abstract.7: However, TT homozygotes responded better with both folate and B12 levels above the median (HR, 0.28; 95% CI, 0.10-0.75).
abstract.8: Conclusions: The risk of first ischemic stroke was significantly higher in hypertensive patients with low levels of both folate and B12.
abstract.9: Effect of folic acid treatment was greatest in patients with low folate and B12 with the CC genotype, and with high folate and B12 with the TT genotype.

translation1.1: The aim of this study was to evaluate the interaction of serumor blood folate (a specific vitamin) and vitamin B12 with methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR- a gene) C677T genotypes, or inherited gene types for a protein involved in blood pressure, on the risk of first ischemic or brain-related stroke. Genotypes are variations of a gene. These variations are often referred to as TT, CC, or CT. Additionally, the study aimed to review the efficacy or success of folic acid treatment in prevention of first ischemic stroke.
translation1.2: A total of 20,702 hypertensive (high blood pressure) adults were randomly placed into one of two treatment groups: daily enalapril (common blood pressure medication) 10 mg and folic acid 0.8 mg or enalapril 10 mg alone.
translation1.3: Participants were followed up every 3 months.
translation1.4: Average values of folate and B12 concentrations before treatment were 8.1 ng/mL and 280.2 pmol/L, respectively.
translation1.5: Over an average of 4.5 years, participants not receiving folic acid with baseline (starting) serum or blood B12 or serum folate above the median (average) had a significantly lower risk of first ischemic stroke. This decreased risk was found especially in those with MTHFR 677 CC genotype (wild-type or normal).
translation1.6: Folic acid treatment significantly reduced the risk of first ischemic stroke in participants with both folate and B12 below the median, particularly in patients with CC genotype.
translation1.7: However, participants with TT genotype responded better with both folate and B12 levels above the median of participants.
translation1.8: The study concluded the risk of first ischemic stroke was significantly higher in hypertensive patients with low levels of both folate and B12.
translation1.9: Folic acid treatment helped the most in patients with low folate and B12 with the CC genotype, and with high folate and B12 with the TT genotype.

translation2.1: We checked the interaction of blood folate, a B-vitamin, and vitamin B12 with methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) C6677T genotypes, or specific DNA sequences in humans encoding the same protein. This was done to measure the risk of first ischemic stroke, or blood clotting that would block brain blood flow, and success of folic acid treatment to prevent this stroke.
translation2.2: 20,702 adults with high blood pressure randomly received either 10 mg of daily blood pressure medication and 0.8 mg of folic acid or 10 mg of blood pressure alone.
translation2.3: Participants were checked every 3 months.
translation2.4: Average folate and B12 levels at start were 8.1 ng/mL and 280.2 pmol/L, respectively.
translation2.5: Over around 4.5 years, among those not receiving folid acid, participants with starting blood B12 or blood folate above the average had much lower risk of first ischemic stroke, especially those with the standard MTHFR C6677T genotype.
translation2.6: Folic acid treatment reduced the risk of first ischemic stroke in participants with both folate and B12 below the average, especially in those with the altered MTHFR genotype.
translation2.7: However, those with certain MTHFR genotypes responded with both folate and B12 levels above the average.
translation2.8: The risk of first ischemic stroke was higher in patients with high blood pressure and low levels of folate and B12.
translation2.9: Folic acid treatment had the most effect in patients with low folate and B12 with a certain MTHFR genotype, and with high folate and B12 with another genotype.

27845713.Title: Novel Approaches to Investigate One-Carbon Metabolism and Related B-Vitamins in Blood Pressure

abstract.1: Hypertension, a major risk factor for heart disease and stroke, is the world's leading cause of preventable, premature death.
abstract.2: A common polymorphism (677C→T) in the gene encoding the folate metabolizing enzyme methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) is associated with increased blood pressure, and there is accumulating evidence demonstrating that this phenotype can be modulated, specifically in individuals with the MTHFR 677TT genotype, by the B-vitamin riboflavin, an essential co-factor for MTHFR.
abstract.3: The underlying mechanism that links this polymorphism, and the related gene-nutrient interaction, with hypertension is currently unknown.
abstract.4: Previous research has shown that 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, the product of the reaction catalysed by MTHFR, appears to be a positive allosteric modulator of endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) and may thus increase the production of nitric oxide, a potent vasodilator.
abstract.5: Blood pressure follows a circadian pattern, peaking shortly after wakening and falling during the night, a phenomenon known as 'dipping'.
abstract.6: Any deviation from this pattern, which can only be identified using ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM), has been associated with increased cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk.
abstract.7: This review will consider the evidence linking this polymorphism and novel gene-nutrient interaction with hypertension and the potential mechanisms that might be involved.
abstract.8: The role of ABPM in B-vitamin research and in nutrition research generally will also be reviewed.

translation1.1: Hypertension, also known as high blood pressure, is a major risk factor for heart disease and stroke. Hypertension is the world's leading cause of preventable, premature death.
translation1.2: A common genetic variation or gene change (677C→T) is found in the gene that codes the folate (specific vitamin) metabolizing (digesting) enzyme methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR). 677C→T is associated with increased blood pressure. There is accumulating evidence that shows this event can be altered, especially in people with MTHFR 677TT genotype, by the B-vitamin riboflavin. Riboflavin is an essential co-factor, meaning it is needed for a biological process to be completed, for MTHFR.
translation1.3: The underlying mechanism that links this genetic variation or gene differences, and the related gene-nutrient interaction, with hypertension is currently unknown.
translation1.4: Previous research has shown that the product produced by the biological reaction caused by MTHFR is a positive modulator (increases activity) of a specific enzyme. The enzyme is known as endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS), which helps fight blood vessel disease. The product of MTHFR, known as 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, may increase the production of nitric oxide, a potent vasodilator. Vasodilators widen blood vessels, which decreases blood pressure.
translation1.5: Blood pressure follows a circadian rhythm (a 24 hour cycle), peaking shortly after wakening and falling during the night. This process is known as 'dipping'.
translation1.6: Any change in this pattern, which can only be identified using ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM), has been associated with increased cardiovascular (or heart-related) disease (CVD) risk.
translation1.7: This review will consider the evidence linking this genetic variation and new gene-nutrient interaction with hypertension. This paper will also investigate the potential mechanisms that might be involved.
translation1.8: The role of ABPM in B-vitamin research and in nutrition research generally will also be reviewed.

23608654.Title: Blood pressure in treated hypertensive individuals with the MTHFR 677TT genotype is responsive to intervention with riboflavin: findings of a targeted randomized trial

abstract.1: Intervention with riboflavin was recently shown to produce genotype-specific lowering of blood pressure (BP) in patients with premature cardiovascular disease homozygous for the 677C→ T polymorphism (TT genotype) in the gene encoding the enzyme methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR).
abstract.2: Whether this effect is confined to patients with high-risk cardiovascular disease is unknown.
abstract.3: The aim of this randomized trial, therefore, was to investigate the responsiveness of BP to riboflavin supplementation in hypertensive individuals with the TT genotype but without overt cardiovascular disease.
abstract.4: From an available sample of 1427 patients with hypertension, we identified 157 with the MTHFR 677TT genotype, 91 of whom agreed to participate in the trial.
abstract.5: Participants were stratified by systolic BP and randomized to receive placebo or riboflavin (1.6 mg/d) for 16 weeks.
abstract.6: At baseline, despite being prescribed multiple classes of antihypertensive drugs, >60% of participants with this genotype had failed to reach goal BP (≤140/90 mm Hg).
abstract.7: A significant improvement in the biomarker status of riboflavin was observed in response to intervention (P<0.001).
abstract.8: Correspondingly, an overall treatment effect of 5.6±2.6 mm Hg (P=0.033) in systolic BP was observed, with pre- and postintervention values of 141.8±2.9 and 137.1±3.0 mm Hg (treatment group) and 143.5±3.0 and 144.3±3.1 mm Hg (placebo group), whereas the treatment effect in diastolic BP was not significant (P=0.291).
abstract.9: In conclusion, these results show that riboflavin supplementation targeted at hypertensive individuals with the MTHFR 677TT genotype can decrease BP more effectively than treatment with current antihypertensive drugs only and indicate the potential for a personalized approach to the management of hypertension in this genetically at-risk group.

translation1.1: Use of riboflavin (a B vitamin) was recently shown to have genotype-specific effects on lowering blood pressure (BP). This means a person's response was different depending on their genetic makeup. This process was shown within patients of premature (or early) cardiovascular (or heart-related) disease with a TT genotype of a specific genetic variation or gene change. This genetic variation, known as 677C, is found within the gene that encodes the enzyme methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR). MTHFR is involved in the processing of amino acids, the building blocks of proteins.
translation1.2: It is unknown if this effect is confined to patients with high-risk cardiovascular disease.
translation1.3: The goal of this study was to investigate the responsiveness of BP in hypertensive (high blood pressure) patients taking riboflavin. Specifically, these patients would have the TT genotype but no obvious cardiovascular disease.
translation1.4: Of 1427 hypertensive patients, the authors identified 157 with the MTHFR 677TT genotype. Ninety-one agreed to participate in the study.
translation1.5: Participants were ordered by systolic BP (when the heart contracts and the higher blood pressure number) and randomized to receive a placebo (harmless pill) or riboflavin (1.6 mg/d) for 16 weeks.
translation1.6: Before treatment, despite being prescribed multiple classes of antihypertensive drugs, the majority of participants with this genotype had failed to reach the goal BP.
translation1.7: A significant improvement in the level of bodily riboflavin was observed in response to intervention or treatment.
translation1.8: A significant treatment effect in systolic BP was observed. However, no significant treatment was found in diastolic (when the heart relaxes and the lower blood pressure number) BP.
translation1.9: The study concluded riboflavin supplementation within hypertensive individuals with the MTHFR 677TT genotype decreases BP more efficiently than current antihypertensive drugs only. Furthermore, this study indicates the potential for a personalized, or individualized, approach to the way high blood pressure is managed in this genetically at-risk group.

33.question: How long does it take for gabapentin to go out of the body?

33118231.Title: Population pharmacokinetics of gabapentin in patients with neuropathic pain: Lack of effect of diabetes or glycaemic control

abstract.1: Aims: Gabapentin (GBP) is widely used to treat neuropathic pain, including diabetic neuropathic pain.
abstract.2: Our objective was to evaluate the role of diabetes and glycaemic control on GBP population pharmacokinetics.
abstract.3: Methods: A clinical trial was conducted in patients with neuropathic pain (n = 29) due to type 2 diabetes (n = 19) or lumbar/cervical disc herniation (n = 10).
abstract.4: All participants were treated with a single oral dose GBP.
abstract.5: Blood was sampled up to 24 hours after GBP administration.
abstract.6: Data were analysed with a population approach using the stochastic approximation expectation maximization algorithm.
abstract.7: Weight, body mass index, sex, biomarkers of renal function and diabetes, and genotypes for the main genetic polymorphisms of SLC22A2 (rs316019) and SLC22A4 (rs1050152), the genes encoding the transporters for organic cations OCT2 and OCTN1, were tested as potential covariates.
abstract.8: Results: GBP drug disposition was described by a 1-compartment model with lag-time, first-order absorption and linear elimination.
abstract.9: The total clearance was dependent on estimated glomerular filtration rate.
abstract.10: Population estimates (between-subject variability in percentage) for lag time, first-order absorption rate, apparent volume of distribution and total clearance were 0.316 h (10.6%), 1.12 h-1 (10.7%), 140 L (7.7%) and 14.7 L/h (6.97%), respectively.
abstract.11: No significant association was observed with hyperglycaemia, glycated haemoglobin, diabetes diagnosis, age, sex, weight, body mass index, SLC22A2 or SLC22 A4 genotypes.
abstract.12: Conclusion: This population pharmacokinetics model accurately estimated GBP concentrations in patients with neuropathic pain, using estimated glomerular filtrationrate as a covariate for total clearance.
abstract.13: The distribution and excretion processes of GBP were not affected by hyperglycaemia or diabetes.

translation1.1: Neuropathic pain is caused by damage to the nervous system (like brain and spinal cord) and is often described as a shooting pain, burning sensation, or numbness. Gabapentin is a common medication used to treat neuropathic pain, including neuropathic pain caused by diabetes.
translation1.2: The objective of this study is to evaluate the role of diabetes and controlling blood sugar on people taking gabapentin.
translation1.3: A clinical trial is conducted in patients with neuropathic pain due to type 2 diabetes (19 people) or a slipped disc in the neck or spine (10 people).
translation1.4: All participants are treated with a single dose of gabapentin by mouth.
translation1.5: Blood is sampled up to 24 hours after gabapentin is given.
translation1.6: Data are analyzed using computer models.
translation1.7: Other information are included in the model including weight, sex, kidney functions and other changes in genes that impact how the medication works.
translation1.9: The total clearance of gabapentin from the body depends on how well the kidneys are able to process and filter the drug.
translation1.10: The estimated total clearance of the drug (completely removed) in the population is 14.7 liters per hour.
translation1.11: No major association is found with having high blood sugar levels, a diabetes diagnosis, or with age, sex, weight or other factors evaluated.
translation1.12: This model studying how the drug is processed in the body estimates gabapentin concentrations in patients with neuropathic pain.
translation1.13: The distribution and clearance processes of gabapentin are not affected by having high blood sugar levels or diabetes.

translation2.1: Gabapentin (GBP), an antiseizure drug, can treat neuropathic or nerve-related pain, including diabetic neuropathic pain.
translation2.2: We evaluate the role of diabetes and blood sugar control on drug activity in the GBP population.
translation2.3: A trial was done in 29 patients with neuropathic pain, 19 from type 2 diabetes and 10 from lower back/neck disc herniation or bulging.
translation2.4: All participants swallowed a single dose of GBP.
translation2.5: Blood was taken up to 24 hours after GBP treatment.
translation2.10: Measurements for lag time, absorption rate, volume of distribution, and clearance rate were 0.316 h (10.6%), 1.12 h-1 (10.7%), 140 L (7.7%) and 14.7 L/h (6.97%), respectively.
translation2.11: No link was seen with high blood sugar, blood sugar levels, diabetes diagnosis, age, sex, weight, body mass index, or certain DNA sequences.
translation2.12: This model measuring drug activity accurately estimated GBP concentrations in those with neuropathic pain, using kidney drug filtration rate for total drug clearance.
translation2.13: The distribution and removal processes of GBP were not affected by high blood sugar or diabetes.

32149389.Title: Cetirizine Reduces Gabapentin Plasma Concentrations and Effect: Role of Renal Drug Transporters for Organic Cations

abstract.1: Gabapentin (GBP) is an organic cation mainly eliminated unchanged in urine, and active drug secretion has been suggested to contribute to its renal excretion.
abstract.2: Our objective was to evaluate the potential drug-drug interaction between GBP and cetirizine (CTZ), an inhibitor of transporters for organic cations.
abstract.3: An open-label, 2-period, crossover, nonrandomized clinical trial was conducted in patients with neuropathic pain to evaluate the effect of CTZ on GBP pharmacokinetics.
abstract.4: Twelve participants were treated with a single dose of 300 mg GBP (treatment A) or with 20 mg/d of CTZ for 5 days and 300 mg GBP on the last day of CTZ treatment (treatment B).
abstract.5: Blood sampling and pain intensity evaluation were performed up to 36 hours after GBP administration.
abstract.6: The interaction of GBP and CTZ with transporters for organic cations was studied in human embryonic kidney (HEK) cells expressing the organic cation transporters (OCTs), multidrug and toxin extrusion proteins (MATEs), and OCTN1.
abstract.7: CTZ treatment resulted in reduced area under the concentration-time curve and peak concentration compared with treatment A.
abstract.8: In treatment B, the lower plasma concentrations of GBP resulted in reduced pain attenuation.
abstract.9: GBP renal clearance was similar between treatments.
abstract.10: GBP has low apparent affinity for OCT2 (concentration of an inhibitor where the response [or binding] is reduced by half [IC50 ] 237 µmol/L) and a high apparent affinity for hMATE1 (IC50 1.1 nmol/L), hMATE2-K (IC50 39 nmol/L), and hOCTN1 (IC50 2.1 nmol/L) in HEK cells.
abstract.11: At therapeutic concentrations, CTZ interacts with hMATE1 and OCTN1.
abstract.12: In summary, CTZ reduced the systemic exposure to GBP and its effect on neuropathic pain attenuation.
abstract.13: However, CTZ × GBP interaction is not mediated by the renal transporters.

translation1.1: Gabapentin (GBP) is a nerve-related pain medication that is mainly removed from the body in urine, and is also processed by the kidneys.
translation1.2: The objective of this study is to evaluate how gabapentin may interact with another medicine called cetirizine (CTZ) that is used to temporarily relieve allergies.
translation1.3: A clinical trial in patients with a shooting or burning pain caused by damage to the nervous system called neuropathic pain is conducted to understand the effect of cetirizine on how gabapentin is processed in the body.
translation1.4: In this study, 12 patients are treated with either one dose of gabapentin (called Treatment A) or with cetirizine for 5 days and gabapentin given on the last day of cetirizine (Treatment B).
translation1.5: Blood samples are taken and the level of pain is measured up to 36 hours after gabapentin is taken.
translation1.6: The interaction of gabapentin and cetirizine is analyzed.
translation1.7: Cetirizine treatment resulted a reduced time the body is exposed to the medication and reduced peak amount when compared with Treatment A (one dose of gabapentin).
translation1.8: In treatment B, the lower concentrations of gabapentin or GBP in the blood results in reduced pain.
translation1.9: GBP clearance from the kidneys is similar between treatments A and B.
translation1.10: GBP appears to bind less to some receptors or kidney target sites such as OCT2 and attach more towards others such as hMATE1 in certain human kidney cells.
translation1.11: At certain concentrations, CTZ interacts with transporters in the body that move materials across cells.
translation1.12: In summary, cetirizine  (CTZ) reduces the exposure to gabapentin (GBP) and its effect on neuropathic pain.
translation1.13: However, CTZ × GBP interaction is not influenced by the transporters in the kidney.

29018999.Title: Population pharmacokinetics of gabapentin in healthy Korean subjects with influence of genetic polymorphisms of ABCB1

abstract.1: The objective of this study was to perform population pharmacokinetic (PK) analysis of gabapentin in healthy Korean subjects and to investigate the possible effect of genetic polymorphisms (1236C > T, 2677G > T/A, and 3435C > T) of ABCB1 gene on PK parameters of gabapentin.
abstract.2: Data were collected from bioequivalence studies, in which 173 subjects orally received three different doses of gabapentin (300, 400, and 800 mg).
abstract.3: Only data from reference formulation were used.
abstract.4: Population pharmacokinetics (PKs) of gabapentin was estimated using a nonlinear mixed-effects model (NONMEM).
abstract.5: Gabapentin showed considerable inter-individual variability (from 5.2- to 8.7-fold) in PK parameters.
abstract.6: Serum concentration of gabapentin was well fitted by a one-compartment model with first-order absorption and lag time.
abstract.7: An inhibitory Emax model was applied to describe the effect of dose on bioavailability.
abstract.8: The oral clearance was estimated to be 11.1 L/h.
abstract.9: The volume of distribution was characterized as 81.0 L.
abstract.10: The absorption rate constant was estimated at 0.860 h-1, and the lag time was predicted at 0.311 h.
abstract.11: Oral bioavailability was estimated to be 68.8% at dose of 300 mg, 62.7% at dose of 400 mg, and 47.1% at dose of 800 mg.
abstract.12: The creatinine clearance significantly influenced on the oral clearance (P < 0.005) and ABCB1 2677G > T/A genotypes significantly influenced on the absorption rate constant (P < 0.05) of gabapentin.
abstract.13: However, ABCB1 1236C > T and 3435C > T genotypes showed no significant effect on gabapentin PK parameters.
abstract.14: The results of the present study indicate that the oral bioavailability of gabapentin is decreased when its dosage is increased.
abstract.15: In addition, ABCB1 2677G > T/A polymorphism can explain the substantial inter-individual variability in the absorption of gabapentin.

translation1.1: The objective of this study is to perform an analysis on how the nerve-related pain medication gabapentin performs in healthy Korean participants and to investigate the possible effect of genetic changes in the drug-resistant ABCB1 gene on how gabapentin is absorbed and distributed in the body.
translation1.2: Data are collected from other studies where 173 people received three different doses by mouth (orally) of gabapentin.
translation1.3: Only data on the drug design and performance are used.
translation1.4: How the body handles and uses gabapentin is measured.
translation1.5: Gabapentin shows a lot of variation or differences between people in how it is absorbed, distributed and released from the body.
translation1.6: Blood concentration of gabapentin is used to understand the process of distributing and eliminating the medication from the body.
translation1.7: How the dose amount impacts availability in the body is measured.
translation1.8: The oral clearance is estimated to be 11.1 liters per hour.
translation1.9: The volume of distribution was characterized as 81.0 L.
translation1.10: How quickly the medication enters the body remains steady.
translation1.11: Availability of the drug from the oral dose is estimated to be 68.8% at a dose of 300 mg, 62.7% at a dose of 400 mg, and 47.1% at a dose of 800 mg.
translation1.12: Clearing creatinine (a waste product that comes from wear and tear of the muscles) influences the oral clearance, and ABCB1 genes influence how quickly gabapentin is absorbed by the body.
translation1.13: However, genes showed no significant effect on gabapentin drug activity parameters.
translation1.14: The results of this study suggest that the availability of gabapentin to the body when taken by mouth is decreased when the dosage is increased.
translation1.15: In addition, changes in the ABCB1 gene can explain the major differences in how gabapentin is absorbed by the body between people.

28070716.Title: Pharmacokinetics and Saturable Absorption of Gabapentin in Nursing Home Elderly Patients

abstract.1: Pharmacokinetic data of gabapentin (GBP) in community-dwelling elderly patients show a significant effect of advanced age on GBP pharmacokinetics due to altered renal function.
abstract.2: However, there are no data in elderly nursing home (NH) patients to evaluate gabapentin absorption and elimination.
abstract.3: Our objective was to characterize the pharmacokinetics of GBP in elderly nursing home patients maintained on GBP therapy.
abstract.4: This was a prospective pharmacokinetic study in elderly nursing home patients (≥60 years) receiving GBP for the management of chronic pain or epilepsy from seven nursing homes.
abstract.5: Pharmacokinetic parameters were estimated by nonlinear mixed-effects modeling.
abstract.6: A one-compartment model described the data and clearance (CL) was associated with estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) (p < 0.0001).
abstract.7: The GBP CL in elderly nursing home patients was 2.93 L/h.
abstract.8: After adjusting for the effect of GFR, GBP CL was not affected by age, sex, body weight, or comorbidity scores.
abstract.9: No significant effects of body size measures, age, and sex were detected on volume of distribution.
abstract.10: Dose-dependent bioavailability of GBP was demonstrated, and the saturable absorption profile was described by a nonlinear hyperbolic function.
abstract.11: Prediction-corrected visual predictive check (pc-VPC) suggests adequate fixed- and random-effects models that successfully simulated the mean trend and variability in gabapentin concentration-time profiles.
abstract.12: In this analysis, the parameters of the hyperbolic nonlinearity appear to be similar between elderly and younger adults.

translation1.1: Data on how gabapentin (GBP -a nerve-related pain medication) is used in the body in elderly patients show a major effect of older age on how the drug works due to changes in kidney function.
translation1.2: However, there are no data in elderly nursing home patients to evaluate how the body absorbs and removes gabapentin.
translation1.3: The objective of this study is to describe how the body uses and processes gabapentin in elderly nursing home patients who are on gabapentin.
translation1.4: This study observed elderly nursing home patients (≥60 years) receiving gabapentin for chronic (ongoing) pain or epilepsy (seizure disorders) from 7 nursing homes.
translation1.6: Data on gabapentin and the clearance of the drug are associated with the rate that measures how well the kidneys are working.
translation1.7: The gabapentin clearance in elderly nursing home patients was 2.93 liters per hour.
translation1.8: After accounting for the rate that measures how well the kidneys are working, GBP clearance is not affected by age, sex, body weight, or other illnesses and their medications.
translation1.9: No significant effects of body size measures, age, and sex are detected on volume of distribution, the ability of various drugs to distribute through the body fluids.
translation1.10: The availability of the drug being dependent on dosage is shown, and how it is absorbed is calculated.
translation1.11: Additional calculations are done on the entire group to evaluate the performance of the drug and identify other individual factors that may impact the effect.
translation1.12: In this analysis, the patterns of the drug appear to be similar between elderly and younger adults.

translation2.1: Drug activity data of gabapentin (GBP) in community-dwelling elderly patients show a great effect of advanced age on GVP drug activity due to altered kidney function.
translation2.2: However, there are no data in elderly nursing home (NH) patients to measure gabapentin absorption and elimination.
translation2.3: We characterize the drug activity of GBP in elderly nursing home patients that are on GBP therapy.
translation2.4: This is a drug actvity study in elderly nursing home patients (≥60 years) given GBP for long-term pain or epilepsy (brain disorder causing seizures) from seven nursing homes.
translation2.6: A mathematical model showed the data and clearance (CL) was linked with estimated kidney filtration rate.
translation2.7: The GBP clearance in elderly nursing home patients was 2.93 liters/hour.
translation2.8: After adjusting for kidney filtration, GBP clearance was not affected by age, sex, body weight, or associated diseases.
translation2.9: No effects of body size, age, and sex were detected on amount of distribution.
translation2.10: Functional or active GBP amount is linked to dose amount.
translation2.11: Analysis suggests certain mathematical models successfully tracked the trend and variation in gabapentin amount over time.
translation2.12: In this analysis, certain measures seem similar between elderly and young adults.

15584938.Title: Pharmacokinetics of gabapentin in paediatric patients with uncontrolled seizures

abstract.1: Purpose: The pharmacokinetics of gabapentin in paediatric patients with uncontrolled seizures was studied.
abstract.2: Methods: Thirteen paediatric patients (mean age: 9.4 years) with uncontrolled partial seizures were included.
abstract.3: Patients received gabapentin orally until doses were individualized to 9.6-39.8 mg/kg/day.
abstract.4: Blood samples were obtained just prior to the dose and over 8 h after gabapentin was administered in the fasting state.
abstract.5: The plasma concentration of gabapentin was measured by a high-performance liquid chromatography assay.
abstract.6: Pharmacokinetic parameters for gabapentin were determined by non-compartment methods using multivariate regression analysis.
abstract.7: Results: Data from nine patients were suitable for pharmacokinetic analysis.
abstract.8: The C(max) from 0.9 to 5.8 microg/mL (mean: 2.6 +/- 1.7 microg/mL) and T(max) from 0.5 to 2.0 h (mean: 1.6 +/- 1.0 h).
abstract.9: The apparent clearance (Cl/F) ranged from 0.12 to 1.12 L/h/kg (mean: 0.50 +/- 0.29 L/h/kg), and the elimination half-life from 3.2 to 12.2 h (mean: 5.5 +/- 0.8 h).
abstract.10: Five patients experienced moderate (n = 4) to severe (n = 1) aggressive behaviour and another gained weight on gabapentin.
abstract.11: Conclusions: Our data suggests that gabapentin pharmacokinetics can vary substantially among paediatric patients.
abstract.12: Gabapentin was well tolerated in patients with uncontrolled partial seizures up to 6 months of therapy.

translation1.1: How the pediatric or child patients with uncontrolled seizures are able to handle gabapentin (a nerve-related pain medication) and the processes of absorbing, distributing, using, and removing it is studied.
translation1.2: In this study, 13 pediatric patients (less the 21 years old) with an average age of about 9 years with uncontrolled partial seizures are included.
translation1.3: Patients received gabapentin orally (by mouth) until doses are changed for each patient.
translation1.4: Blood samples are obtained just before the dose and over 8 hours after gabapentin is given during fasting, when all foods have been completely digested.
translation1.5: Blood concentrations of gabapentin is measured by blood tests.
translation1.6: Absorption, distribution, use, and removal of gabapentin in the body is analyzed.
translation1.7: Data from 9 patients are able to be used for analysis.
translation1.8: The maximum concentration of the drug and the time it takes to reach maximum concentration are estimated.
translation1.10: Five patients experience moderate (4 patients) to severe (1 patient) aggressive behavior, and another gained weight on gabapentin.
translation1.11: In conclusion, the data in this study suggests that how the body processes gabapentin can vary a lot among pediatric patients.
translation1.12: In this study, patients with uncontrolled partial seizures were able to handle gabapentin well up to 6 months of therapy.

10219274.Title: Effects of age and gender on single-dose pharmacokinetics of gabapentin

abstract.1: Purpose: This study was conducted to evaluate the effect of age, age-related changes in renal function, and gender on the single-dose pharmacokinetics of orally administered gabapentin (GBP).
abstract.2: Methods: The pharmacokinetics of a single 400-mg oral dose of GBP were studied in 36 healthy subjects (18 men and 18 women) aged 20-78 years.
abstract.3: Serial blood samples and total urine output were collected for 48 h after the dose.
abstract.4: GBP concentrations in plasma and urine were measured by high-performance liquid chromatography, and pharmacokinetic parameters were calculated by noncompartmental methods.
abstract.5: Results: All subjects tolerated the drug well, with only mild symptoms reported.
abstract.6: No change in maximal GBP plasma concentration (Cmax), time at which Cmax occurred (tmax), or apparent volume of distribution (V/F) with age was noted.
abstract.7: A significant linear decline in apparent oral clearance (CL/F), elimination-rate constant (lambda z), and renal clearance (CLR) with increasing age was observed (p < 0.005).
abstract.8: Because total urinary recovery of unchanged drug (an estimate of F for GBP) did not change with age, the decline in CL/F and lambda z can be explained by the decline in CLR.
abstract.9: The only pharmacokinetic parameter that was significantly different between genders was Cmax, which was approximately 25% higher for women than for men (p = 0.016), consistent with gender differences in body size.
abstract.10: Conclusions: The results of this study suggest that changes in renal function are responsible for age-related changes in GBP pharmacokinetics.
abstract.11: Reduction of GBP dosage may be required in elderly patients with reduced renal function.
abstract.12: The pharmacokinetics of GBP are similar in men and women.

translation1.1: This study is conducted to evaluate the effect of age, age-related changes in renal or kidney function, and gender on the single-dose pharmacokinetics (or drug activity) of orally (by mouth) administered gabapentin (GBP).
translation1.2: The body's process of absorbing, distributing, using, and removing a single oral dose (by mouth) of gabapentin is studied in 36 healthy patients (18 men and 18 women) aged 20-78 years.
translation1.3: Blood and urine samples are continuously collected for 48 hours after the dose of gabapentin.
translation1.4: The amount of Gabapentin in plasma (or blood) and urine samples are measured, and other tests are done to understand how the body processes gabapentin.
translation1.5: All patients are able to handle the drug well, with only mild symptoms reported.
translation1.6: No change in the highest (peak) gabapentin amount, the time at which the highest gabapentin amount occurred, or apparent volume of distribution (the ability of various drugs to distribute through the body fluids) with age was noted.
translation1.7: A major decline in clearance of gabapentin that is taken orally, the rate of removal from the body, and clearing it through the kidneys with increasing age is observed.
translation1.8: The decline of oral clearance and rate of removal of gabapentin from the body can be explained by the decline in clearance by the kidneys.
translation1.9: The only measure that is very different between genders is the highest (peak) gabapentin amount, which is approximately 25% higher for women than for men, consistent with gender differences in body size.
translation1.10: In conclusion, the results of this study suggest that changes in kidney function are responsible for age-related changes in how the body processes gabapentin.
translation1.11: Giving a lesser dose of gabapentin may be required in elderly patients who have weaker kidney functions.
translation1.12: How the body processes gabapentin is similar in men and women.

7665723.Title: Disposition of gabapentin in anuric subjects on hemodialysis

abstract.1: Gabapentin is an anticonvulsant drug, which in man is cleared solely by renal excretion and is not bound to plasma proteins.
abstract.2: Because the clearance of gabapentin is dependent on renal function, the pharmacokinetics of gabapentin were investigated in anuric subjects maintained on hemodialysis.
abstract.3: Plasma samples were obtained over an 8-day period after administration of single oral 400-mg doses of gabapentin.
abstract.4: Pre- and post-dialyzer plasma samples and dialysate samples from quantitative collection of dialyzer effluent were obtained during hemodialysis sessions performed 2, 4, and 7 days after dosing.
abstract.5: A mean (SD) maximum gabapentin plasma concentration of 6.0 (2.4) micrograms/mL was achieved at 4.7 (2.1) hours post-dose.
abstract.6: The elimination half-life of gabapentin on non-hemodialysis days averaged 132 hours.
abstract.7: Approximately 35% of the gabapentin dose was recovered in dialysate, and mean hemodialysis clearance of gabapentin was 142 (26) mL/min; approximately 93% of the dialyzer creatinine clearance.
abstract.8: Gabapentin elimination half-life during hemodialysis was approximately 4 hours.
abstract.9: Systemic plasma gabapentin concentrations increased approximately 30% during the first 2 hours after hemodialysis as a result of drug redistribution in the body.
abstract.10: It is recommended that patients with end-stage renal disease maintained on hemodialysis receive an initial 300-mg to 400-mg gabapentin loading dose.
abstract.11: Plasma gabapentin concentrations can be maintained by giving 200 to 300 mg of gabapentin after every 4 hours of hemodialysis.

translation1.1: Gabapentin is a nerve-related pain drug, which in humans is cleared from the body solely by the kidneys and is not attached to proteins in plasma (the liquid part of blood).
translation1.2: Because the clearance of gabapentin depends on the kidneys, how the body processes gabapentin is investigated in patients who do not make enough urine and who are on dialysis, a process of cleaning the blood of a person whose kidneys are not working normally.
translation1.3: Plasma samples are collected over an 8-day period after a single oral (by mouth) dose of gabapentin is given.
translation1.4: Plasma samples before and after being filtered, as well as dialysis fluid, are collected during dialysis sessions performed 2, 4, and 7 days after receiving the gabapentin dose.
translation1.5: An average maximum amount of gabapentin in plasma is achieved at 4.7 hours after the dose.
translation1.6: The time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma to be reduced by half on non-dialysis days averages 132 hours.
translation1.7: About 35% of gabapentin dose is recovered in dialysis fluid, and the average clearance of gabapentin in dialysis was 142 milliliters per minute.
translation1.8: The time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma to be reduced by half during dialysis is about 4 hours.
translation1.9: Gabapentin concentrations in the plasma increased about 30% during the first 2 hours after dialysis as a result of the drug being sent to other parts of the body.
translation1.10: It is recommended that patients with end-stage kidney disease who are on dialysis receive a starting 300-mg to 400-mg gabapentin dose.
translation1.11: Plasma gabapentin concentrations can remain stable by giving 200 to 300 mg of gabapentin after every 4 hours of dialysis.

translation2.1: Gabapentin is an antiseizure drug, which in man is cleared just by kidney removal and is not bound to blood proteins.
translation2.2: Because gabapentin clearance is dependent on kidney function, the drug activity of gabapentin was investigated in patients unable to make urine and maintained on artifical kidney machines or hemodialysis.
translation2.3: We took blood samples over an 8-day period after treatment of single 400-mg swallowed doses of gabapentin.
translation2.4: Blood and kidney solution samples were obtained during treatment sessions performed 2, 4, and 7 days after dosing.
translation2.5: An average maximum gabapentin blood level of 6.0 micrograms/mL was measured at 4.7 hours after the dose.
translation2.6: The time for half of gabapentin to clear on non-hemodialysis days was 132 hours.
translation2.7: Around 35% of the gabapentin dose was recovered in the fluid of the artificial kidney machine. The average hemodialysis clearance of gabapentin was 142 mL/min; around 93% of the standard dialyzer clearance.
translation2.8: The time for half of gabapentin to clear during hemodialysis was around 4 hours.
translation2.9: Blood gabapentin levels increased around 30% during the first 2 hours after hemodialysis due to drug redistribution in the body.
translation2.10: It is recommended that patients with kidney failure and on hemodialysis get an initial 300-mg to 400-mg gabapentin starting dose.
translation2.11: Blood gabapentin levels can be maintained by giving 200 to 300 mg of gabapentin after every 4 hours of hemodialysis.

abstract.1: The amino acid antiepileptic drug (AED) gabapentin (GBP) is indicated for adjunctive use in the treatment of partial seizures with or without becoming secondarily generalized in individuals older than 12 years.
abstract.2: GBP was about as potent as phenytoin in the maximal electroshock test, but had a different profile of efficacy than standard antiepileptics in a range of animal models.
abstract.3: Possible mechanisms of action include biochemical effects enhancing the ratio of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to glutamate, ion-channel actions (direct or indirect), and/ or enhancement of nonsynaptic GABA release.
abstract.4: The anticonvulsant effect appears to depend on concentration of gabapentin in neurons, presumably by the L-system amino acid transporter that has been implicated in absorption from the gut.
abstract.5: Data from studies for U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval suggested a direct relationship of clinical response to dose and efficacy did not plateau at the doses used.
abstract.6: The maximally effective dose, relationship of efficacy to blood level, and maximum tolerable dose are not yet known conclusively.
abstract.7: Lack of significant binding to plasma proteins and lack of liver metabolism contribute to the absence of known limiting drug-drug interactions, particularly with other AEDs.
abstract.8: Excretion intact in the urine affords dose adjustment on the basis of creatinine clearance.
abstract.9: A half-life of approximately 7 h necessitates multiple doses daily for many individuals.
abstract.10: The medication is well tolerated, in general.
abstract.11: Side effects tend to be mild to moderate in intensity, most frequently affect the central nervous system, and resolve with time in many individuals.
abstract.12: GBP has been prescribed for approximately 70,000 individuals worldwide without untoward incidence of severe systemic toxicity to date.
abstract.13: Safety data continue to accumulate.
abstract.14: GBP has been labeled category C on the basis of effects on rodent fetuses.
abstract.15: Experience with use in pregnant women is limited and human teratogenic effects have not been reported.
abstract.16: Data from ongoing monotherapy trials will help to clarify the range of clinical utility of gabapentin.

translation1.1: The drug gabapentin (GBP) is an addition to the regular treatment of partial seizures with or without becoming generalized seizures in the entire brain in people older than 12 years.
translation1.2: Gabapentin has performed differently than other standard drugs that are used to prevent seizures in a number of animal experiments.
translation1.3: Possible processes that lead the drug to have an effect include the response of increasing the development of neurotransmitters (signaling molecules in the brain) and other cell functions.
translation1.4: The act of stopping or slowing the excessive rapid firing of neurons (brain cells) during seizures seems to depend on the concentration of gabapentin in neurons.
translation1.5: Data from studies for U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval suggest a direct relationship of medical response to the dose and success did not level-off at the doses used.
translation1.6: The maximally effective dose (the dose at which any higher dose would not lead to improvement), the relationship of its performance to blood level, and the maximum tolerable dose (the highest dose most people can handle) are not completely known.
translation1.7: Lack of attachment to plasma (or blood) proteins and lack of liver energy contribute to the absence of known interactions between drugs, particularly with other drugs that are used to prevent seizures.
translation1.8: Doses can be adjusted based on the amount of the drug found in the urine.
translation1.9: The time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma or in the body to be reduced by half is about 7 hours, requiring multiple doses daily for many people.
translation1.10: In general, people are able to handle the medication and its side effects.
translation1.11: Side effects tend to be mild to moderate in intensity, most frequently affect the central nervous system (spinal cord and brain), and resolve with time in many individuals.
translation1.12: Gabapentin (GBP) is prescribed for about 70,000 people around the world without unexpected incidence of severe toxic effects so far.
translation1.13: Safety data continues to be collected.
translation1.14: Gabapentin has shown to have adverse effects on rodent fetuses.
translation1.15: Experience with use in pregnant women is limited, and adverse (or bad) effects or abnormalities in human fetuses have not been reported.
translation1.16: Data from ongoing single drug trials will help to clarify the range of the clinical use of gabapentin.

28676198.Title: Treatment of Gabapentin Toxicity With Peritoneal Dialysis: Assessment of Gabapentin Clearance

abstract.1: Gabapentin is almost exclusively cleared by the kidney and thus presents challenges in patients with kidney failure.
abstract.2: Gabapentin is known to be effectively cleared by hemodialysis, but the efficiency of clearance by peritoneal dialysis (PD) has not been previously described.
abstract.3: We report a case of gabapentin toxicity in a patient on long-term PD who was treated with continuous automated cycling PD.
abstract.4: We find that continuous PD provides significant clearance of gabapentin.
abstract.5: With 2-L exchanges every 2 hours, we document an apparent elimination half-life of 41.33 hours, which is substantially shorter than the reported elimination half-life of 132 hours in the absence of kidney function.
abstract.6: Further, our patient's symptoms of gabapentin toxicity gradually improved and had fully resolved after about 36 hours of dialysis.
abstract.7: Gabapentin clearance by PD was estimated at 94% of urea clearance.
abstract.8: We conclude that intensive PD provides gabapentin clearance that approximates that of urea and is an effective but slow method to treat gabapentin overdose and toxicity.

translation1.1: The nerve-related pain medication gabapentin is cleared from the body almost entirely by the kidney. Because of this, patients with kidney failure face a challenge.
translation1.2: Gabapentin is known to be effectively cleared by hemodialysis, a process of using machines to clean the blood of a person whose kidneys are not working normally, but how well peritoneal dialysis (PD), a process that filters blood using the inside lining of the stomach, clears the drug has not been previously described.
translation1.3: Researchers describe a case of too much gabapentin in a patient with long-term peritoneal dialysis who is treated with continuous automated cycling peritoneal dialysis, which is when a mechanical device filters the blood at night while sleeping.
translation1.4: Researchers find that continuous peritoneal dialysis provides significant clearance of gabapentin.
translation1.5: The documented elimination half-life (the time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma or body to be reduced by half) is 41.33 hours, which is much shorter than the 132 hours reported in other studies in the absence of kidney function.
translation1.6: In addition, the patient's symptoms of gabapentin toxicity (often muscle weakness, drowsiness, and drooping eyelids) improved and fully resolved after about 36 hours of dialysis.
translation1.7: Gabapentin clearance in the body by peritoneal dialysis is estimated at 94% of urea (or waste protein) clearance.
translation1.8: In conclusion, intensive peritoneal dialysis provides gabapentin clearance and is an effective but slow method to treat gabapentin overdose and toxicity.

abstract.1: Gabapentin is a new antiepileptic drug (AED) with an attractive pharmacokinetic profile.
abstract.2: It is absorbed by an active and saturable transport system, and has a high volume of distribution.
abstract.3: Gabapentin is not bound to plasma proteins, does not induce hepatic enzymes and is not metabolized.
abstract.4: At steady state, it has a half-life of 6-8 h, and is eliminated unchanged by renal route with a plasma clearance proportional to the creatinine clearance.
abstract.5: It is devoid of significant drug-drug interactions when administered with the established AEDs or with oral contraceptives.
abstract.6: Gabapentin used as an add-on AED significantly reduced the frequency of partial seizures and secondarily generalized tonic-clonic seizures in three large double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group clinical trails.
abstract.7: It is well tolerated, with transient somnolence and dizziness being the most frequent adverse effects.
abstract.8: Although the mechanism of action of gabapentin is not fully established, there is strong evidence to suggest a novel mechanism of action.
abstract.9: Gabapentin is a unique and promising drug that could improve the quality of life of patients with epilepsy and is a welcome addition to the armamentarium of currently available AEDs for the treatment of patients with seizures of partial onset.

translation1.1: Gabapentin is a new drug to treat seizures that appears to work well for patients.
translation1.2: It is absorbed into the body by an active and fluid-filled transport system, and is able to be distributed to tissues in the body.
translation1.3: Gabapentin is not attached to proteins in the blood, does not create liver enzymes that can speed up chemical reactions in the body, and is not broken down.
translation1.4: When the amount of the drug in the body is the same amount that is being cleared, the time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma or body to be reduced by half is 6-8 hours and is eliminated through the kidneys.
translation1.5: Gabapentin does not have any major interactions with other drugs when given with other standard drugs that treat seizures or with oral (by mouth) birth control.
translation1.6: In 3 clinical studies, gabapentin used as an add-on anti-seizure drug to assist the main treatment reduces the frequency of partial seizures (impacting half the brain) and seizures (impacting both halves of the brain).
translation1.7: The medicine is handled well by patients, with drowsiness and dizziness being the most common side effects.
translation1.8: Although the exact process of how gabapentin can lead to an effect is not fully understood, there is strong evidence that suggests a new process in the body.
translation1.9: Gabapentin is a unique and promising drug that could improve the quality of life of patients with epilepsy (seizure disorders) and is a welcome addition to currently available drugs for the treatment of patients with seizures that start in one part of the brain.

translation2.1: Gabapentin is a new antiseizure or antiepileptic drug (AED) with attractive drug activity.
translation2.2: Gabapentin is absorbed by an active transport system. The drug has a large distribution.
translation2.3: Gabapentin is not bound to blood proteins, does not activate liver enzymes and is not broken down.
translation2.4: Normally, half of the drug is eliminated in 6-8 hours. It is cleared unchanged by the kidney with a blood clearance similar to standard kidney substance clearance.
translation2.5: The drug does not have major drug-drug interactions when used with other AEDs or swallowed birth control drugs.
translation2.6: Gabapentin used as an add-on AED greatly reduces the amount of partial seizures and partial seizures developing into standard serizures in three clinical trials.
translation2.7: The drug is well tolerated, with temporary drowsiness and dizziness as the most common side effects.
translation2.8: Although how gabapentin works is unknown, there is evidence for a new mechanism of its biological action.
translation2.9: Gabapentin is a unique and promising drug that could improve life for patients with epilepsy (a brain disorder causing seizures). The drug is a welcome addition to current AEDs for treating patients with seizures of partial onset.

33439824.Title: The Management of Non-Dialysis-Dependent Chronic Kidney Disease in Primary Care

abstract.1: Background: Approximately 10% of adults in Germany have chronic kidney disease (CKD).
abstract.2: The prevalence of CKD among patients being cared for by general practitioners is approximately 30%, and its prevalence in nursing homes is over 50%.
abstract.3: An S3 guideline has been developed for the management of CKD in primary care.
abstract.4: Methods: The guideline is based on publications retrieved by a systematic search of the literature for international guidelines published in the period 2013-2017, and additional searches on specific questions.
abstract.5: It was created by the German College of General Practitioners and Family Physicians (Deutsche Gesellschaft für Allgemeinmedizin und Familienmedizin, DEGAM) and consented with the German Societies of Nephrology and Internal Medicine (DGfN, DGIM) and patient representation.
abstract.6: Results: Upon the initial diagnosis of CKD (glomerular filtration rate [GFR] <60 mL/ min), the patient's blood pressure and urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (ACR) should be measured, and the urine should be examined for hematuria.
abstract.7: Monitoring intervals are determined on an individual basis depending on the stage of disease and the patient's general state of health and personal preferences.
abstract.8: Nephrological consultation should be obtained if the GFR is less than 30 mL/min, if CKD is initially diagnosed (GFR 30-59 mL/min) in the presence of persistent hematuria without any urological explanation or of albinuria in stage A2 or higher, if the patient has refractory hypertension requiring three or more antihypertensive drugs, or if the renal disease is rapidly progressive.
abstract.9: The threshold for referring a patient should be kept low for persons under age 50; persons over age 70 should be referred only if warranted in consideration of their comorbidities and individual health goals.
abstract.10: Conclusion: The main elements of the treatment of CKD are the treatment of hypertension and diabetes and the modification of lifestyle factors.
abstract.11: An innovation from the primary care practioner's perspective is the assessment of albuminuria with the albumin-to-creatinine ratio.

translation1.1: About 10% of adults in Germany have chronic kidney disease, which is when the kidneys are damaged and can't filter waste and extra fluid from the blood.
translation1.2: The percentage of chronic kidney disease among patients being cared for by primary care doctors (family doctors) is about 30% and is over 50% in nursing homes.
translation1.3: A guideline has been developed for the care of chronic kidney disease in primary (family) care offices.
translation1.4: This guideline is based on existing, available data in articles published during 2013 - 2017 and also on additional searches of data on specific questions.
translation1.5: It is created by the German College of General Practitioners and Family Physicians and agreed with by the German Societies of Nephrology and Internal Medicine and patient representation.
translation1.6: At the first diagnosis of chronic kidney disease, the patient's blood pressure, as well as a urine sample that may indicate a kidney complication from high proteins, should be measured. The urine should also be checked for the presence of blood.
translation1.7: How often the patient should be monitored is based on the individual and depends on the stage of disease, the patient's overall health, and personal preferences.
translation1.8: A doctor who specializes in kidney disease should be consulted based on tests that check how well the kidneys are working, if there is blood in the urine, if the patient's blood pressure requires 3 or more drugs, and if the kidney disease is quickly getting worse.
translation1.9: The requirements and test levels to refer a patient under the age of 50 years for specialty care should be kept low. People over 70 should be referred only if necessary due to other illnesses and individual health goals.
translation1.10: The main parts of treating chronic kidney disease are the treatment of high blood pressure and diabetes and changing lifestyle.
translation1.11: A new assessment from the family doctor is a sign of kidney disease due to too much of a protein called albumin in the urine.

22421952.Title: Use of methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta in stage 3, 4 or 5 non-dialysis chronic kidney disease

abstract.1: Background: Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta (PEG-EPO) is indicated for the treatment of anaemia due to chronic kidney disease.
abstract.2: Its long half-life allows it to be administered once per month in maintenance therapy.
abstract.3: Objective: To evaluate the use, effectiveness and cost of PEG-EPO in a group of pre-dialysis chronic renal failure patients.
abstract.4: Method: Retrospective observational study in pre-dialysis patients who began treatment with PEG-EPO between May 2008 and February 2009.
abstract.5: The following data were gathered: age, sex, haemoglobin levels (Hb) and erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA) dose and frequency.
abstract.6: The follow-up period was 12 months.
abstract.7: Results: We included 198 patients.
abstract.8: Mean Hb upon starting PEG-EPO in patients who had received no prior treatment was 10.8g/l, and 11.6g/l at 90 days (P<.0001).
abstract.9: In patients previously treated with ESA, mean Hb before starting PEG-EPO treatment was 11.2g/l, and 11.4g/l at 12 months (P=.846).
abstract.10: Hb values were higher than 12g/l (P<.0001) after 12 months of treatment in 25% of patients; of these, 45% had values above 13g/l.
abstract.11: We observed doses 39% lower than those indicated on the drug leaflet, resulting in a reduction in the originally expected theoretical costs.
abstract.12: Conclusions: The doses of PEG-EPO administered to patients with a prior history of ESA treatment were lower than those indicated by the drug leaflet, and Hb remained stable after 12 months of treatment.
abstract.13: A large portion of the patients had levels above the 13g/l threshold.

translation1.1: Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta (PEG-EPO) is an injection that is often used to treat anemia (low red blood cells) due to chronic kidney disease.
translation1.2: It stays in the body long enough to be given once per month.
translation1.3: The objective of this study is to evaluate the use, effectiveness and cost of PEG-EPO in a group of chronic kidney failure patients who have not started dialysis, a process of using a machine to clean the blood of a person whose kidneys are not working normally.
translation1.4: This study uses data from pre-dialysis patients who started treatment with Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta (PEG-EPO) between May 2008 and February 2009.
translation1.5: The following data are gathered: age, sex, hemoglobin levels (count of proteins that carry oxygen in the blood) and the dose and frequency of medication called erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA) to help make red blood cells.
translation1.6: The follow-up period is 12 months.
translation1.7: The study included 198 patients.
translation1.8: The average hemoglobin levels when patients start PEG-EPO who had received no prior treatment is 10.8 grams/liter, and is 11.6 grams/liter at 90 days.
translation1.9: In patients who are previously treated with ESA medications to help make red blood cells, the average hemoglobin levels before starting PEG-EPO treatment is 11.2 grams/liter, and is 11.4 grams/liter at 12 months.
translation1.10: Hemoglobin levels are higher than 12 grams/liter after 12 months of treatment in 25% of patients. Among these patients, 45% have levels above 13 grams/liter.
translation1.11: Researchers observed doses 39% lower than those listed on the drug leaflet or description, resulting in less cost than originally expected.
translation1.12: In conclusion, the doses of PEG-EPO given to patients with a prior history of erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA) treatment are lower than those noted in the drug leaflet. Also, hemoglobin levels remained stable after 12 months of treatment.
translation1.13: A large portion of the patients had levels above the 13 grams/liter threshold.

26391748.Title: Practical Approach to Detection and Management of Chronic Kidney Disease for the Primary Care Clinician

abstract.1: A panel of internists and nephrologists developed this practical approach for the Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative to guide assessment and care of chronic kidney disease (CKD) by primary care clinicians.
abstract.2: Chronic kidney disease is defined as a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) <60 mL/min/1.73m  and/or markers of kidney damage for at least 3 months.
abstract.3: In clinical practice the most common tests for CKD include GFR estimated from the serum creatinine concentration (eGFR) and albuminuria from the urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio.
abstract.4: Assessment of eGFR and albuminuria should be performed for persons with diabetes and/or hypertension but is not recommended for the general population.
abstract.5: Management of CKD includes reducing the patient's risk of CKD progression and risk of associated complications, such as acute kidney injury and cardiovascular disease, anemia, and metabolic acidosis, as well as mineral and bone disorder.
abstract.6: Prevention of CKD progression requires blood pressure <140/90 mm Hg, use of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers for patients with albuminuria and hypertension, hemoglobin A1c ≤7% for patients with diabetes, and correction of CKD-associated metabolic acidosis.
abstract.7: To reduce patient safety hazards from medications, the level of eGFR should be considered when prescribing, and nephrotoxins should be avoided, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
abstract.8: The main reasons to refer to nephrology specialists are eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73 m(2), severe albuminuria, and acute kidney injury.
abstract.9: The ultimate goal of CKD management is to prevent disease progression, minimize complications, and promote quality of life.

translation1.1: A group of internal medicine and kidney doctors developed a practical approach to guide the assessment (diagnosis) and care of chronic kidney disease by primary care doctors.
translation1.2: Chronic kidney disease is defined by using a glomerular filtration rate, a blood test that checks how well your kidneys are working, and/or other measurements or conditions that are a sign of kidney damage for at least 3 months.
translation1.3: The most common tests for chronic kidney disease include the glomerular filtration rate that is estimated from the amount of creatinine (a waste product from the normal wear and tear on muscles) in the blood and too much albumin (a blood protein) in the urine which is called albuminuria.
translation1.4: These tests for creatinine levels and albumin proteins should be done for people with diabetes and/or high blood pressure but are not recommended for the general population.
translation1.5: Managing chronic kidney disease includes reducing the patient's risk of the disease getting worse and risk of related complications, such as acute or immediate kidney injury or heart disease.
translation1.6: To prevent chronic kidney disease from worsening, managing blood pressure, using medications to treat high albumin levels and high blood pressure, measuring hemoglobin levels (red blood cells) for patients with diabetes, and correcting when there is too much acid in the body's fluids is needed.
translation1.7: To reduce the negative effect of medications on patients, the level of creatinine should be noted when prescribing drugs, and nephrotoxins which can damage the kidneys should be avoided.
translation1.8: The main reasons to send a patient to a kidney specialist are based on creatinine levels, severe albuminuria (too much protein in urine), and acute kidney injury (a sudden episode of kidney failure).
translation1.9: The main goal of managing chronic kidney disease is to prevent the disease from getting worse, to minimize complications, and to promote quality of life.

translation2.1: A group of specialists created this practical approach for Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative to guide analysis and care of long-lasting or chronic kidney disease (CKD) by primary care workers.
translation2.2: Long-lasting kidney disease is a low kidney filtration rate and/or markers of kidney damage for at least 3 months.
