abstract.9: Results: In the percutaneous nephrolithotripsy group, postoperative infectious and inflammatory complications occurred in 34.1% of cases, in the percutaneous nephrolithoextraction group - in 24.6%, in the contact ureterolithotripsy group - in 7.8%, in the ureterolithoextraction group - in 2.5%.
abstract.10: The analysis made it possible to identify factors promoting the development of infectious and inflammatory complications.
abstract.11: For the first time in clinical practice, there were successfully performed ten operations of stone fragmentation using a continuous-wave diode laser with a hot-spot effect.
abstract.12: Controlled coarse fragmentation of stones providing the possibility to reduce the number of infectious and inflammatory complications was performed in the bladder as a model for testing the method.
abstract.13: Conclusion: The method of laser-induced controlled coarse fragmentation of stones with a hot-spot effect, developed and tested in clinical practice, is promising for the prevention of infectious and inflammatory complications in patients with potentially infected stones since their fine fragmentation and, consequently, spread of stone-associated toxins and microflora within the urinary system is avoided.

translation1.1: Introducing lithotripsy, a non-surgical method to break masses like kidney stones into pieces, into medical practice changes the type of complications that may occur after operations.
translation1.2: The main complications are inflammatory infections that may result in pain, redness, or swelling.
translation1.3: New and improved methods of breaking down stones, avoiding small stone fragments and sending them through the kidneys to be released through urine are searched.
translation1.4: The authors develop a method to break stones using a continuous-wave diode laser, which is a constant stream of laser light that can also reduce the scattering of stones by using a hot-spot or energy-focused effect.
translation1.5: The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of controlling the fragmenting of urinary stones (hard masses of minerals in the bladder), using a continuous-wave diode laser as a method of preventing inflammatory infections.
translation1.6: Researchers analyzed 1666 cases of patients with kidney stones who underwent different methods to remove kidney stones. These methods include percutaneous nephrolithotripsy/nephrolithoextraction (removal of stones by a small incision through the skin and stones pulled out of the incision) and ureterolithotripsy/ureteroextraction (when a flexible tube is inserted through the bladder and the ureter which connects the kidneys and bladder and stones are found with a camera and removed). An additional analysis on 90 patients is also done on patients with stones that were fragmented into tiny pieces using different lithotripters, non-surgical devices that crush stones using shock waves.
translation1.7: The method of controlled stone fragmentation by a diode laser with a hot-spot effect is tested on samples of 26 kidney stones during or after operations.
translation1.8: For the first time in clinical practice, this method is tested in the bladder (with 10 patients).
translation1.9: In the group that underwent a small incision to remove the stone, infections and inflammation complications after the procedure occurred in 34.1% of cases. In the group that had stones removed from the incision (nephrolithoextraction) had complications in 24.6%, and in the ureterolithotripsy group where a tube and camera are used, there are 7.8% cases with complications. In the ureterolithoextraction group, there are complications in 2.5%.
translation1.10: The analysis makes it possible to find things that lead to the development of infectious or inflammatory complications.
translation1.11: For the first time, there are successfully performed ten operations of stone fragmentation using a continuous-wave diode laser with a hot-spot effect.
translation1.12: Controlling the scattering of fragments of stones makes it possible to reduce the number of infectious and inflammatory complications and is done in the bladder as an example for testing this method.
translation1.13: In conclusion, using a laser to control fragmented stones with the hot spot effect is a promising way to prevent infection and inflammation complications in patients with possibly infected stones since small pieces of stones and their spread within the urinary system is avoided.

translation2.1: New advanced technology for breaking up stones in the kidney and the tube to the bladder changes the nature of issues after operation.
translation2.2: Among them, the main issues are inflammatory infections.
translation2.3: This influences the search for new, improved ways of breaking up stones to avoid small fragments and spreading stone-associated infection in the kidney and bladder system.
translation2.4: We have created a method for controlled breaking up of stones with a special laser with a hot-spot at one end.
translation2.5: This study evaluates the effectiveness of controlled breaking up of stones in urine using a special laser with a hot-spot at one end to prevent inflammatory infections in clinics.
translation2.6: We analyzed 1666 patient cases of patients with kidney stones who had operations to remove the stones in the kidney and urine. We also analyzed any complications in 90 patients who had treatment with various devices to break up stones: sound waves, pressurized air, and lasers.
translation2.7: The method of controlled breaking up of stones with a special laser with a hot-spot was tested on 26 kidney stone samples collected after surgery.
translation2.8: For the first time in clinical practice, this method was tested in the hole in the bladder of 10 patients.
translation2.9: In the group that had a small cut to remove kidney stones, infections and inflammatory issues after surgery occured in 34.1% of cases. In the group that had a cut and small tube to remove stones, infections and issues occured in 24.6%. In the group that had a small cut to remove stones in the urine, infections and issues occured in 7.8%. In the group that had a cut and tube to remove stones, infections and issues occured in 2.5%.
translation2.10: The analysis helped identify factors that promoted infectious and inflammatory issues.
translation2.11: For the first time in clinical practice, there were 10 successful operations of breaking up stones with a special laser with a hot-spot.
translation2.12: Controlled breaking up of stones, which may reduce the number of infectious and inflammatory effects, was done in the bladder to test the method.
translation2.13: The method of using a laser with a hot-spot to break up stones, developed and tested in clinical practice, may prevent infectious and inflammatory effects in patients with possibly infected stones since their previous stone fragmentation. This method may also prevent spread of stone-associated toxins and bacteria in the urinary system.

34540217.Title: The effect of stone and patient characteristics in predicting extra-corporal shock wave lithotripsy success rate: A cross sectional study

abstract.1: Introduction: We determine the effect of patient characteristics (age, sex, and body mass index BMI) and stone characteristics (density, location, and size) by non-contrast computed tomography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (CT-KUB) in predicting the success of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) in the treatment of kidney and ureteric stones.
abstract.2: We present this study to further enrich the knowledge of physicians towards the effect of different patient characteristics upon predicting extra-corporal shock wave lithotripsy success rates.
abstract.3: Methods: We evaluated 155 patients who received ESWL for renal and ureteric stone measuring 3-20 mm (mm), over a 3-month period.
abstract.4: The stone size in millimeters, density in Hounsfield units (HU) and its location was determined on pre-treatment CT-KUB.
abstract.5: ESWL was successful if post-treatment residual renal stone fragments were ≤3 mm and for ureteric stones should be totally cleared.
abstract.6: Results: The overall success of ESWL treatment was observed in 65.8% of the 155 patients.
abstract.7: There was no significant difference seen when the effect of patients age, sex and BMI were studied with ESWL outcome with P values were 0.155, 0.101 and 0.415 respectively.
abstract.8: Also, stone location either in the kidney or ureter has no statistically significant effect on ESWL response rate.
abstract.9: while stone density and size determined on CT KUB have statistically significant effect on the success rate of ESWL with a P-value of 0.002 and 0.000 respectively.
abstract.10: Conclusions: This study shows that determination of stone density and stone size on CT KUB pre ESWL can help to predict the outcome of ESWL.
abstract.11: We propose that stone density <500 HU and stone size < 5 mm are highly likely to result in successful ESWL.

translation1.1: Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a procedure to break up stones in the body by using shock waves and an X-ray to target the stones. Researchers search for the effects of patient characteristics (age, sex, and body mass index or BMI) and stone characteristics (density, location, and size) on how successful ESWL procedure is on stones in the kidneys, ureters (tubes that carry urine from the kidney to the urinary bladder), and bladder.
translation1.2: This study is intended to increase the knowledge of doctors on the effect of different patient characteristics on predicting how successful using extra-corporal shock wave lithotripsy is.
translation1.3: Researchers evaluate 155 patients who receive ESWL for stones in the kidney and ureter (tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder) over a 3-month period.
translation1.4: The stone size in millimeters (mm), density, and its location is determined using an x-ray scan before patients received treatment.
translation1.5: ESWL is considered to be successful if the size of remaining kidney stone fragments after the procedure are ≤3 mm and if ureteric stones are totally cleared.
translation1.6: The overall success of ESWL treatment was observed in 65.8% of the 155 patients.
translation1.7: There is no major difference seen when the effect of age, sex, and BMI of patients are studied with ESWL outcomes.
translation1.8: Also, stone location either in the kidney or ureter (the tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder) has no statistically significant effect (not likely to happen randomly or by chance) on the success of ESWL.
translation1.9: Stone density and size based on the scanned images have a statistically significant effect on the success rate of ESWL.
translation1.10: In conclusion, this study shows that finding out the density and size of stones using a scanned x-ray image before extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) can help predict the outcome of ESWL.
translation1.11: Researchers of this study suggest that low stone density and size are highly likely to result in successful ESWL.

34518466.Title: Flexible Ureterorenoscopy under Spinal Anesthesia: Focus on Technique, Results, Complications, and Patients' Satisfaction from a Large Series

abstract.1: Introduction: Although spinal anesthesia (SA) may reduce postoperative morbidity, most urologists perform flexible ureterorenoscopy (fURS) under general anesthesia (GA).
abstract.2: The objective of our study is to provide technical details, results, complications, and patients' satisfaction with fURS performed under exclusive SA.
abstract.3: Methods: We analyzed all consecutive fURS performed under SA to treat renal stones from March 2011 to February 2017.
abstract.4: Details of technique, operative time, outcomes, need for further treatments, complications, and patients' satisfaction were evaluated.
abstract.5: Results: Two hundred thirty-four fURS under SA were considered.
abstract.6: SA was performed through L2-L3 vertebral interspace in 64.1%.
abstract.7: Patients were discharged the same day of surgery.
abstract.8: Mean stone burden was 13.5 ± 6.6 mm and mean operative time 76.9 ± 34.6 min.
abstract.9: Single-procedure SFR was 69.7%.
abstract.10: Further treatments were performed in 22.8%. 96.6% had no anesthesia-related complications.
abstract.11: No Clavien-Dindo grade ≥ IIIb complications were noticed.
abstract.12: 99.6% of patients were satisfied with SA.
abstract.13: No cases of conversion from SA to GA occurred.
abstract.14: Conclusion: fURS can be performed safely and efficiently under SA, taking into account a few details of the technique.
abstract.15: Patients' satisfaction with SA is very high, and complications are rare.
abstract.16: Although SA is usually adopted in unfit patients for GA, it may be considered as a viable alternative in fit patients.

translation1.1: Spinal anesthesia (SA) are medicines that numbs the back of patients to reduce pain after surgery. However, most urologists (doctors who specialize in conditions of the urinary or urine-related tract) use general anesthesia that puts a patient into a heavy sleep when doing a flexible ureterorenoscopy (fURS), a procedure that uses a telescope, and occasionally a laser, to break stones in the kidney into pieces.
translation1.2: The objective of this study is to provide technical details, results, complications, and patients' satisfaction with fURS when performed under only spinal anesthesia to numb only parts of the body.
translation1.3: Researchers analyzed all flexible ureterorenoscopy (fURS) done under spinal anesthesia to treat kidney stones from March 2011 to February 2017.
translation1.4: Details of the technique, how long the procedure takes, results, need for additional treatments, complications, and patients' satisfaction are evaluated.
translation1.5: There are 234 fURS procedures done under spinal anesthesia considered.
translation1.6: SA was done in a certain area of the lower spine in 64.1%.
translation1.7: Patients are sent home the same day of surgery.
translation1.8: The average stone burden was 13.5 millimeters (± 6.6 millimeters), and the average procedure time is 76.9 minutes ( ± 34.6 minutes).
translation1.9: The percentage of patients who are stone free after one procedure is 69.7%.
translation1.10: Additional treatments are done in 22.8% of patients. Overall, 96.6% had no anesthesia-related complications.
translation1.11: No complications that required general anesthesia or other major complications are noticed.
translation1.12: 99.6% of patients are satisfied with spinal anesthesia.
translation1.13: No cases of changing from spinal anesthesia to general anesthesia occurred.
translation1.14: In conclusion, flexible ureterorenoscopy (fURS)can be performed safely and efficiently under spinal anesthesia when accounting for a few details of the procedure.
translation1.15: Patients' satisfaction with spinal anesthesia is very high, and complications are rare.
translation1.16: Although spinal anesthesia is usually used in unfit patients for general anesthesia, it may be considered as a good alternative in fit patients.

34499550.Title: The Surgical Technique of Mini Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

abstract.1: The mini percutaneous nephrolithotomy (mini-PCNL) has become a versatile tool to remove kidney stones >2 cm, lower pole stones >1 cm, renal stones previously unresponsive to shockwave therapy or inaccessible by ureteroscopy (within a caliceal diverticulum), stones within complex urinary tracts (urinary diversions, transplanted kidney, and horseshoe kidneys), and large impacted proximal ureteral stones.
abstract.2: After positioning in either the supine or prone position, a cystoscopy is performed to place an open-ended catheter, occlusion balloon, or Accordian device into the collecting system.
abstract.3: A foley catheter is placed in the bladder.
abstract.4: An ultrasound with a curvilinear probe is used to survey the kidney and guide access into the collecting system with an 18 g percutaneous needle.
abstract.5: Once access is obtained, a small 0.5 cm skin incision is made and the percutaneous tract is dilated over a wire.
abstract.6: A 16.5F metallic or self-dilating suctioning access sheath is positioned with fluoroscopic guidance.
abstract.7: A 12F rigid mini-PCNL nephroscope is used to evaluate the collecting system.
abstract.8: Once a calculus is observed, options for stone fragmentation include a lithotripter with ultrasonic and ballistic energy, or laser lithotripsy using holmium or thulium laser fibers.
abstract.9: Flexible ureteroscopy can be considered to ensure clearance of the collecting system.
abstract.10: A 6F ureteral stent can be placed in either a retrograde or antegrade approach for drainage.
abstract.11: The tract is sealed using Surgiflo hemostatic matrix with thrombin.
abstract.12: Guidelines for postoperative care and troubleshooting techniques for mini-PCNL are reviewed along with the surgical steps in the accompanying video (Supplementary Video S1).
abstract.13: There are few randomized trials comparing mini-PCNL with standard PCNL and ureteroscopy.
abstract.14: There is some evidence to suggest a difference in transfusion rates comparing mini- and standard PCNL, as well as differences in stone-free rates when comparing mini-PCNL with ureteroscopy for the treatment of lower pole stones.

translation1.1: Mini percutaneous nephrolithotomy (mini-PCNL) is when a doctor makes a small incision in the patient and uses a small camera to help remove kidney stones. The mini-PNCL has become a useful tool to remove kidney stones of different sizes, stones that did not respond to other treatments, and it can also remove stones in the urinary tract, the body's drainage system to remove urine.
translation1.2: When lying either flat on the back (supine position) or on the stomach and face down (prone position), a hollow tube with a lens is inserted into the urethra tube that goes to bladder to allow another device such as a catheter (a clean tube that goes into the bladder) into the collecting system which is the series of tubes and ducts of the kidney.
translation1.3: A foley catheter (soft tube that is inserted into your bladder to drain urine) is placed in the bladder.
translation1.4: An ultrasound (a technology that uses sound waves to take images of the inside the body) is used to look at the kidney and guide access to the collecting system with a needle.
translation1.5: Once access is obtained, a small incision (cut) on the skin is made, and the tract through the skin is increased in size.
translation1.6: A device called a suctioning access sheath is positioned to act like a vacuum and absorb fragments.
translation1.7: A mini-PCNL nephroscope (telescope with camera) is used to evaluate the collecting system.
translation1.8: Once the kidney stone is seen, options to break it up include a machine that pulverizes stones with shock waves or ballistic energy, or a laser is used to break up kidney stones.
translation1.9: A flexible tube can be used to ensure removal from the collecting system.
translation1.10: A thin, flexible tube that holds ureters (tubes that carry urine from the kidney to the urinary bladder) open called a stent can be used for drainage.
translation1.11: The tract is sealed.
translation1.12: Guidelines for care after the procedure and for troubleshooting techniques for mini-PCNL are reviewed along with the surgical steps in an available video.
translation1.13: There are few clinical trials comparing mini percutaneous nephrolithotomy (mini-PNCL) with standard percutaneous nephrolithotomy and ureteroscopy, a procedure where a small telescope is inserted through the urethra and bladder and up the ureter tube to where the stone is located.
translation1.14: There is some evidence to suggest a difference in those needing blood transfusions or transfers when comparing mini- and standard PCNL, as well as differences in stone-free rates when comparing mini-PCNL with ureteroscopy for the treatment of lower pole stones, common kidney stones that are unlikely to pass on their own.

translation2.1: Mini percutaneous nephrolithotomy (mini-PCNL) is a tool to remove a variety of stones including: large kidney stones > 2 cm, lower kidney stones > 1 cm, kidney stones unaffected by shockwaves or surgical extraction, stones in complex tubes transporting urine, and large, unchanged stones causing inflammation in tubes carrying urine.
translation2.2: After lying down, an open-ended tube to collect urine, device to collect stone fragments, or device to block escape of stone framgents is inserted into the urine tube.
translation2.3: A thin tube is placed in the bladder to drain pee.
translation2.4: Guided sound waves are used to explore the kidney and reach the urine-collecting system with an 18 g surgical needle.
translation2.5: Once access is obtained, a small 0.5 cm skin cut is made and the opening is enlarged with wires.
translation2.6: A metallic or self-enlarging vacuum is placed with x-ray guidance.
translation2.7: A rigid, small tube with a lens is used to explore the urine-collecting system.
translation2.8: Once a stone is observed, options for breaking it up include using a device with sound waves and bullet energy, or special laser.
translation2.9: Using a tube with a scope can ensure full removal from the urine-collecting system.
translation2.10: A tube to keep the urine flowing can be placed against or with urine flow for drainage.
translation2.11: The opening is sealed with a special surgical sealant.
translation2.12: The accompanying video (Supplementary Video S1) shows guidelines for care after surgery and troubleshooting techniques for mini-PCNL along with the actual surgery.
translation2.13: There are a few trials comparing mini-PCNL with the standard treatment option.
translation2.14: There may be a difference in urine transfer rates between mini- and standard PCNL. There may also be differences in stone-free rates between mini-PCNL and the standard treatment of lower kidney stones.

34477130.Title: Pooled-analysis of efficacy and safety of minimally invasive versus standard percutaneous nephrolithotomy

abstract.1: Background: This study aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of minimally invasive percutaneous nephrolithotomy (MPCNL) versus standard percutaneous nephrolithotomy in patients with renal and upper ureteric stones.
abstract.2: Methods: We conducted a pooled analysis on randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
abstract.3: The eligible RCTs were selected from the following databases: MEDLINE, Embase, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Library.
abstract.4: The reference lists of retrieved studies were also investigated.
abstract.5: Results: Our analysis included 10 RCTs with 1612 patients.
abstract.6: Pooled data from 10 RCTs revealed the following: stone-free rate (odds ratio = 1.46, 95% confidence interval (CI) [1.12,1.88], P = .004), operative time (mean difference [MD] = 4.10, 95% CI [-1.37,9.56], P = .14), length of hospital stay (MD = -15.31, 95% CI [-29.43,-1.19], P = .03), hemoglobin decrease (MD = -0.86, 95% CI [-1.19,-0.53], P < .00001), postoperative fever (MD = 0.83, 95% CI [0.49,1.40], P = .49), and urine leakage (MD = 0.59, 95% CI [0.25,1.37], P = .22).
abstract.7: Besides, we performed sub-group analysis based on vacuum suction effect and multiple kidney stones.
abstract.8: For vacuum suction effect, it revealed the following: stone-free rate in vacuum suction group (P = .007) and in non-vacuum suction group (P = .19).
abstract.9: Operative time in vacuum suction group (P = .89), non-vacuum suction group (P = .16).
abstract.10: Postoperative fever in vacuum suction group (P = .49), non-vacuum suction group (P = .85).
abstract.11: Conclusion: This pooled analysis indicated that MPCNL was a safe and effective method for treating renal stones compared with standard percutaneous nephrolithotomy.
abstract.12: Besides, the vacuum suction effect in MPCNL played a more important role.
abstract.13: When it comes to multiple or staghorn stones, the longer operative time in MPCNL could not be ignored.

translation1.1: This study aims to assess the effectiveness and safety of minimally invasive percutaneous nephrolithotomy (MPCNL), when a doctor makes a small incision in the patient and uses a scope to remove kidney stones versus the standard percutaneous nephrolithotomy that uses a larger instrument to remove stones.
translation1.2: Researchers analyze data from published clinical trials.
translation1.3: Eligible trials are from the following databases: MEDLINE, Embase, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Library.
translation1.4: The articles of these clinical trials included a list of other existing studies that are also reviewed.
translation1.5: The analysis includes 10 trials with 1612 patients.
translation1.6: The data gathered and analyzed from the 10 trials found revealed information on the following: stone-free rate, how long the procedures take, length of hospital stay, red blood cells decrease, fever after the procedure, and urine leakage.
translation1.7: Researchers also analyzed additional data on the effects of vacuum suction (vacuuming up stone fragments) and multiple kidney stones.
translation1.8: For vacuum suction effect, it reveals a difference in the stone-free rate in the vacuum suction group but not in the non-vacuum suction group.
translation1.9: There is no significant difference in how long the procedure took between the vacuum suction group and the non-vacuum suction group.
translation1.10: There is no significant difference in having a fever after the procedure between the vacuum suction group and the non-vacuum suction group.
translation1.11: In conclusion, this analysis suggests that minimally invasive percutaneous nephrolithotomy (MPCNL) is a safe and effective method for treating kidney stones compared with the standard percutaneous nephrolithotomy process.
translation1.12: Additionally, the vacuum suction effect in MPCNL played a more important role.
translation1.13: When it comes to multiple or staghorn (larger) stones, the longer procedure time in MPCNL could not be ignored.

34346246.Title: Comparison of mini-PCNL and retrograde intrarenal surgery in the treatment of kidney stone over 50 years old patients

abstract.1: Mini-Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (M-PCNL) and Retrograde Intrarenal Surgery (RIRS) are commonly used methods in treatment of kidney stones.
abstract.2: The aim of our study is to compare the efficacy and safety of M-PCNL and RIRS in kidney stone treatment over 50 years old patients.
abstract.3: A total of 125 patients, 65 of whom had RIRS, and 60 of whom had M-PCNL, were included in the study.
abstract.4: Age, gender, BMI (Body-Mass Index), ASA (American Society of Anesthesiology) scores of the patients; stone size, stone location, operation side, ESWL history, HU (Hounsfield Unit) values, hospital stay durations, SFR, complication rates according to Clavien modification system, postoperative hemoglobin loss, postoperative transfusion rates, and patients who needed a secondary operation were recorded.
abstract.5: SFR values were calculated in the postoperative third and sixth months.
abstract.6: The data between the two groups had similar characteristics in terms of age, gender, BMI, HU, stone size, operation side, stone location, ESWL history, operation time, postoperative transfusion rate, postoperative Clavien complications (p > 0.05).
abstract.7: When the ASA categories were evaluated, the mean ASA scores, ASA I, and ASA II data had similar characteristics in both groups (p > 0.05).
abstract.8: When the ASA 3 scores were evaluated, the number of ASA III patients in the RIRS group was statistically significantly higher (p < 0.05).
abstract.9: When hospital stay duration and postoperative hemoglobin loss were examined, RIRS group was found to be advantageous (p < 0.05).
abstract.10: Postoperative third month SFR and Postoperative sixth month values were statistically significantly higher in M-PCNL group (p < 0.05).
abstract.11: M-PCNL and RIRS are methods that can be used safely and effectively over 50 years old patients in kidney stone surgery.
abstract.12: M-PCNL has been found to be more advantageous in terms of SFR rates and as it requires less secondary intervention.
abstract.13: RIRS is advantageous in terms of short hospital stay, postoperative hemoglobin loss, and applicability to patients who are not suitable for the prone position.

translation1.1: Two common ways to treat kidney stones are: the Mini-Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (M-PCNL), which is when a doctor makes a small incision in the patient and uses a scope to remove kidney stones, and Retrograde Intrarenal Surgery (RIRS), a procedure that uses a laser and a viewing tube to remove kidney stones and does not make an external incision.
translation1.2: The aim of this study is to compare the effectiveness and safety of M-PCNL and RIRS in kidney stone treatment in patients over 50 years old.
translation1.3: A total of 125 patients, 65 who had RIRS, and 60 who had M-PCNL, are included in the study.
translation1.4: Age, gender, BMI (Body-Mass Index), ASA (American Society of Anesthesiology) scores of the patients; stone size, stone location, operation side, having extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy or ESWL procedure in the past, HU (Hounsfield Unit) values to measure the density of stones, length of hospital stays, stone-free rates, complication rates, blood loss after the procedure, transfusions needed after the procedure, and patients who needed a second operation are recorded.
translation1.5: Stone-free rates are calculated 3 months and 6 months after the procedure.
translation1.6: The data between the RIRS and M-PCNL groups have similar characteristics in age, gender, BMI, HU, stone size, operation side, stone location, ESWL history, operation time, transfusion rates needed after the procedure, and complications after the procedure.
translation1.7: When the ASA categories are evaluated to determine the risk of surgery before the procedure, the average ASA scores, ASA I, and ASA II data had similar characteristics in both groups.
translation1.8: When the ASA 3 scores are evaluated, the number of ASA III patients in the RIRS group is statistically significantly (the result is unlikely to be random or by chance) higher.
translation1.9: When hospital stay duration and blood loss after surgery are examined, the RIRS group is found to be beneficial.
translation1.10: The stone-free rate at the 3rd and 6th months after surgery are statistically significantly higher in the M-PCNL group.
translation1.11: M-PCNL and RIRS are methods that can be used safely and effectively in patients over 50 years old who need kidney stone surgery.
translation1.12: M-PCNL is found to be more advantageous in terms of stone-free rates, and it requires less secondary interventions, such as a second procedure.
translation1.13: RIRS is beneficial in terms of short hospital stays, blood loss after surgery, and applicability to patients who are not suitable for the prone position when patients are face down on the stomach.

abstract.1: Renal stones pose a significant burden on the health care system.
abstract.2: The prevalence of renal stones has increased from 3.8% in 1970 to 8.8% in 2010 in the United States, with annual healthcare costs of USD 3.8 billion.
abstract.3: It is estimated that more than half a million people a year visit the emergency room for kidney stone problems.
abstract.4: The most common presenting symptoms include hematuria, pain in the flank, groin, or abdomen.
abstract.5: There are many treatment modalities available for managing renal stones.
abstract.6: They range from completely non-invasive outpatient procedures to invasive procedures requiring hospital admission and increased risks of complications.
abstract.7: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a truly non-invasive procedure as opposed to other surgical treatments used, such as retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS) and percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).
abstract.8: The efficacy of ESWL lies in its ability to pulverize calculi in vivo into smaller segments, which are them expelled spontaneously by the boy.
abstract.9: Shockwaves are generated and are then focused on a point within the body.
abstract.10: The shockwaves propagate through the body with minimal dissipation of energy (and therefore damage) due to minimal difference in density of the soft tissues.
abstract.11: At the stone fluid interface, a relatively significant difference in density, combined with a large concentration of multiple shockwaves in a small area, produces a significant dissipation of energy.
abstract.12: Through the different mechanisms, this energy can overcome the tensile strength of the stone resulting in fragmentation.
abstract.13: Repetition of this process leads to the pulverization of the stone into small fragments that the body then can pass painlessly and spontaneously.

translation1.1: Kidney stones are a major burden on the health care system.
translation1.2: The number of kidney stones has increased from 3.8% in 1970 to 8.8% in 2010 in the United States, and yearly healthcare costs are at $3.8 billion.
translation1.3: It is estimated that more than half a million people a year visit the emergency room for kidney stone problems.
translation1.4: The most common symptoms include blood in the urine, pain in the back and sides, groin, or stomach area (abdomen).
translation1.5: There are many treatment methods available for managing kidney stones.
translation1.6: These options range from non-invasive (non-surgical) outpatient procedures that do not require hospital stays to invasive (surgical) procedures requiring staying in the hospital and an increased risk of complications.
translation1.7: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a truly non-invasive procedure as opposed to other surgical treatments used, such as retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS) and percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) that require an incision into the skin.
translation1.8: ESWL is effective because it can crush stones inside the body into smaller parts, which are then released from the body when going to the bathroom.
translation1.9: Shockwaves are generated and focused on a point within the body.
translation1.10: The shockwaves go through the body with little damage to surrounding tissues.
translation1.11: When the stone changes, there is a big difference in the density of the stone which may produce a larger reach of energy due to a lot of shockwaves in a small area of the body.
translation1.12: This energy can overpower the strength of the stone, resulting in breaking the stone into smaller parts.
translation1.13: Repeating this process leads to the pulverizing of the stone into small fragments that the body can then pass through the body with no pain.

translation2.1: Kidney stones are a major burden on health care.
translation2.2: The proportion of cases of kidney stones has increased from 3.8% in 1970 to 8.8% in 2010 in the United States, with yearly healthcare costs of 3.8 billion US dollars.
translation2.3: More than half a million people a year visit the emergency room for kidney stone issues.
translation2.4: The most common symptoms are blood in the urine and pain at or near the abdomen.
translation2.5: There are many treatment options for kidney stones.
translation2.6: They range from non-surgical away-from-hospital treatments to surgical procedures needing hospital care and increased risks of side effects.
translation2.7: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL), or kidney stone removal with shockwaves, is a truly non-srugical procedure compared to other surgical treatments like kidney surgery with a camera tube and making a small skin cut to remove stones.
translation2.8: The success of ESWL comes from pulverizing stones into small stones, which are removed naturally by the body.
translation2.9: Shockwaves are created and focused on a point in the body.
translation2.10: The shockwaves spread through the body with minimal loss of energy (and therefore damage) due to small density or hardness differences of the surrounding body parts.
translation2.11: At the boundary between the stone and body fluid, a large difference in hardness, along with many shockwaves in one area, creates a large burst of energy.
translation2.12: Via different mechanisms, this energy can break up the stone.
translation2.13: Repeating this process pulverzies the stone into small fragments that the body can remove painlessly and naturally.

34314230.Title: The impact of lasers in percutaneous nephrolithotomy outcomes: results from a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized comparative trials

abstract.1: Background Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the first choice treatment of renal stones larger than 2 cm.
abstract.2: We aimed to evaluate if lasers perform as equal as non-laser devices in patients with kidney stones candidate to PCNL.
abstract.3: Materials and methods A comprehensive literature search was performed in MEDLINE via PubMed, Scopus and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) to assess the differences in the perioperative course, incidence of postoperative complications, and stone free-rate (SFR) in patients with kidney stones undergoing laser versus non-laser PCNL in randomized studies.
abstract.4: The incidences of complications were pooled using the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Method with the random effect model and expressed as Risk Ratios (RR), 95% Confidence Intervals (CI), and p-values.
abstract.5: Surgical time and length of stay were pooled using the inverse variance of the mean difference (MD) with a random effect, 95% CI, and p-values.
abstract.6: Analyses were two-tailed, with a significance set at p ≤0.05.
abstract.7: Results Six papers including 732 patients (311 patients undergoing holmium laser and 421 non-laser PCNL) were included in meta-analysis.
abstract.8: Surgical time and postoperative stay were shorter in the non-laser group (MD:11.14, 95% CI:2.32-19.96, p=0.002; MD:-0.81, 95%CI:-2.18-0.57 p=0.25, respectively).
abstract.9: SFR was significantly higher in the non-laser group (RR:1.08, 95% CI:1.01-1.15, p=0.03).
abstract.10: Patients undergoing laser PCNL had a non-significant higher risk of postoperative fever >38°C (RR:0.64, 95%CI: .31-1.30, p=0.22).
abstract.11: Transfusion rate did not differ between the two groups (RR:1.02, 95% CI:0.50-2.11 p=0.95).
abstract.12: The need for stent positioning due to urine extravasation was higher risk in the laser group but the difference did not reach significance (RR:0.49, 95% CI:0.17-1.41 p=0.19).
abstract.13: Conclusions Non-laser PCNL showed better perioperative outcomes and SFR as compared to holmium laser PCNL.

translation1.1: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is a procedure that involves making an incision in the skin, inserting a tube to reach the stone, breaking it up into small pieces - sometimes using a laser, and removing it from the body. PCNL is the first choice treatment of kidney stones larger than 2 cm.
translation1.2: This study aims to evaluate if lasers perform as well as non-laser devices in patients with kidney stones.
translation1.3: Researchers searched published studies to find the differences in the preparation before or during surgery, the number of complications after surgery, and the stone-free rate (patients that no longer have stone or stone fragments) in patients with kidney stones who had either laser or non-laser PCNL.
translation1.4: The number of complications are pooled together and analyzed.
translation1.5: How long the procedure takes and length of stay at the hospital or doctor office are also analyzed.
translation1.7: Six papers including 732 patients (311 patients underwent the procedure with a laser PCNL and 421 with a non-laser PCNL) are included in the analysis.
translation1.8: Surgical time and post-operation stay were shorter in the non-laser group.
translation1.9: The stone free rate is significantly higher in the non-laser group.
translation1.10: Patients undergoing laser PCNL had a slightly higher risk of a fever >100.4°F after the procedure.
translation1.11: The need for a blood transfusion (transfer) is not different between the laser and non-laser group.
translation1.12: There is a higher need in the laser group for a thin tube called a stent to be placed in the body to help drain urine, but it is not a major difference between the two groups on needing a stent.
translation1.13: In conclusion, non-laser percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) shows better surgical outcomes and a better stone free rate when compared to the laser PCNL.

33991399.Title: Current and emerging pharmacological targets for medical expulsive therapy

abstract.1: The primary goals of medical expulsive therapy are to increase the rate of stone expulsion along the ureter to avoid ureteral obstruction and reduce ureteral colic and thus avoid the need for surgical and more invasive interventions.
abstract.2: This review focussed on the findings from in vivo and in vitro animal and human studies that have investigated the pharmacological mechanisms controlling ureteral motility and their translation to current and potentially new clinically used drugs for increasing the rate of stone expulsion along the ureter.
abstract.3: The complicated contractility profile of the ureter, which alters with age, tissue segment region, orientation and species contributes to the difficulty of interpreting studies on ureteral pharmacology, which translates to the complexity of discovering ideal drug targets for medical expulsive therapy.
abstract.4: Nevertheless, the current drug classes clinically used for patients with stone lodgement include α1 -adrenoceptor antagonists, calcium channel blockers and NSAIDS, whilst there are promising targets for drug development that require further clinical investigations including the phosphodiesterase type 5 enzyme, β-adrenoceptors and 5-HT receptors.

translation1.1: Medical expulsive therapy uses medication to relax certain muscles in the body to release small kidney stones. The main goals of medical expulsive therapy are to increase stone release along the tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder called the ureter to avoid obstruction, reduce pain, and avoid the need for surgical and other procedures.
translation1.2: This review focuses on the findings from animal and human studies that investigate the ways drugs work in the ureter and how drugs may potentially help release stones from the body.
translation1.3: How the ureter tube, that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder, is able to contract changes over time and makes interpreting results from studies on drugs difficult and, therefore, hard to find the best drugs for medical explusive therapy.
translation1.4: However, the current types of drugs used for patients with stones include α1 -adrenoceptor antagonists and calcium channel blockers, that can increase the size of the urinary tube to allow stones to pass, as well as nonsteroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) for pain. There are promising drugs under development for study.

33987110.Title: Minimally Invasive Surgery for the Treatment of Ureteric Stones - State-of-the-Art Review

abstract.1: The landscape of managing ureteric stones has evolved over the last few decades and several treatment options exist depending on the stone size, location, and other patient and stone factors.
abstract.2: While open surgery is now rarely performed, the use of medical expulsive therapy (MET) has been controversial and perhaps only recommended for large distal ureteric stones.
abstract.3: The mainstay treatment balances between shockwave lithotripsy (SWL) and ureteroscopy (URS), with the latter usually recommended for larger stones.
abstract.4: While the principles of ureteric stone management have remained largely unchanged, the modern era has generated new methods and means to deliver it.
abstract.5: Advancements have occurred in all domains of endourology to try and refine treatment and balance it with cost, patient choice and quality of life.
abstract.6: Dissemination of technologies and demonstration of their efficacy and safety will eventually result in new recommendations among international guidelines and evolution of new gold standards.

translation1.1: Managing stones in the ureter (the tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder)  has changed over the last few decades, and several treatment options exist. These options depend on the stone size, location, and other patient and stone factors.
translation1.2: While open surgery (cutting tissues so the surgeon has a full view of the organs) is now rarely performed, the use of medications to treat stones, which is called medical expulsive therapy (MET), has been controversial and perhaps only recommended for large stones in the ureter.
translation1.3: Common treatments are either shockwave lithotripsy, where shockwaves are focused to one point in the body and used to crush kidney stones into dust, or ureteroscopy, a procedure where a small telescope is inserted through the urethra and bladder and up the ureter to where the stone is located. Ureteroscopy is recommended for larger stones.
translation1.4: The overall practice of managing stones has remained mostly unchanged, but new methods and ways to deliver treatment have surfaced in modern times.
translation1.5: Advancements have occurred in all areas of stone disease to try and refine treatment and balance it with cost, patient choice and quality of life.
translation1.6: Sharing information on technology and showing their effectiveness and safety will eventually result in new recommendations among guidelines and new gold standards for care.

translation2.1: Treating kidney stones in urine tubes has changed over the last few decades. Many treatments exist depending on stone size, location, and other factors.
translation2.2: While large-cut surgery is rarely performed, drug treatment for removing stones is controversial and perhaps only recommended for large stones away from the kidney.
translation2.3: Main treatments include using shockwaves or a flexible telescope to help remove kidney stones, with the latter usually recommended for larger stones.
translation2.4: While the general idea of how to manage kidney stones has remain largely unchanged, the modern era has made new treatments to do so.
translation2.5: Advances have occured in all areas of treating the urinary system. These advances try to improve treatment while balancing cost, patient choice, and quality of life.
translation2.6: Spreading these technologies and demonstrating their success and safety will lead to new recommendations for international guidelines and new standard treatments.

37.question: Do memory problems improve over time when taking pregabalin?

30335626.Title: Cognitive Effects of Perioperative Pregabalin: Secondary Exploratory Analysis of a Randomized Placebo-controlled Study

abstract.1: Background: Pregabalin has shown opioid sparing and analgesic effects in the early postoperative period; however, perioperative effects on cognition have not been studied.
abstract.2: A randomized, parallel group, placebo-controlled investigation in 80 donor nephrectomy patients was previously performed that evaluated the analgesic, opioid-sparing, and antihyperalgesic effects of pregabalin.
abstract.3: This article describes a secondary exploratory analysis that tested the hypothesis that pregabalin would impair cognitive function compared to placebo.
abstract.4: Methods: Eighty patients scheduled for donor nephrectomy participated in this randomized, placebo-controlled study.
abstract.5: Pregabalin (150 mg twice daily, n = 40) or placebo (n = 40) was administered on the day of surgery and the first postoperative day, in addition to a pain regimen consisting of opioids, steroids, local anesthetics, and acetaminophen.
abstract.6: Specific cognitive tests measuring inhibition, sustained attention, psychomotor speed, visual memory, and strategy were performed at baseline, 24 h, and 3 to 5 days after surgery, using tests from the Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery.
abstract.7: Results: In the spatial working memory within errors test, the number of errors increased with pregabalin compared to placebo 24 h after surgery; median (25th, 75th percentile) values were 1 (0, 6) versus 0 (0, 1; rate ratio [95% CI], 3.20 [1.55 to 6.62]; P = 0.002).
abstract.8: Furthermore, pregabalin significantly increased the number of errors in the stop-signal task stop-go test compared with placebo; median (25th, 75th percentile) values were 3 (1, 6) versus 1 (0, 2; rate ratio, 2.14 [1.13 to 4.07]; P = 0.020).
abstract.9: There were no significant differences between groups in the paired associated learning, reaction time, rapid visual processing, or spatial working memory strategy tests.
abstract.10: Conclusions: Perioperative pregabalin significantly negatively affected subdomains of executive functioning, including inhibition, and working memory compared to placebo, whereas psychomotor speed was not changed.

translation1.1: Pregabalin is a nerve pain medication. The drug has been shown to help reduce opioid use (opioid-sparing) and have pain relieving (analgesic) effects in the early period following a surgery. However, effects before, during, and after surgery on cognition (thinking ability) have not been studied.
translation1.2: A study in 80 patients that had one or both of their kidneys removed was previously conducted to evaluate the opioid-sparing, analgesic, and antihyperalgesic (reduction of pain sensitivity) effects of pregabalin.
translation1.3: This paper describes a secondary investigation that tested if pregabalin would impair cognitive function when compared to a control (no treatment) group.
translation1.4: Eighty patients scheduled for donor nephrectomy (removal of one or both kidneys) participated in this study.
translation1.5: Pregabalin (150 mg twice daily) or placebo (a harmless pill) was administered (given) on the day of surgery and the first post-operation day. This was given in addition to a pain regimen consisting of opioids, steroids, local anesthetics, and acetaminophen (pain medication).
translation1.6: Cognitive tests measuring inhibition (restraint), sustained attention, psychomotor (movement) speed, visual memory, and strategy were performed before, 24 h, and 3 to 5 days after surgery.
translation1.7: The spatial working memory test is used to determine if a participant can recall the configuration of a series of images. During the test, the number of errors increased with pregabalin treatment compared to placebo 24 h after surgery.
translation1.8: Furthermore, pregabalin significantly increased the number of errors in the stop-signal task stop-go test compared with placebo.
translation1.9: There were no significant differences between treatment groups in the paired associated learning, reaction time, rapid visual processing, or spatial working memory strategy tests.
translation1.10: Perioperative (around surgery time) pregabalin significantly negatively affected several aspects of cognitive function when compared to placebo. However, psychomotor speed or movement was not changed.

24532157.Title: Cognitive effects of pregabalin in the treatment of long-term benzodiazepine-use and dependence

abstract.1: Objective: Long-term benzodiazepine (BDZ) use and dependence affect cognitive functioning adversely and partly irreversibly.
abstract.2: Emerging evidence suggests that pregabalin (PGB) might be a safe and efficacious treatment of long-term BDZ use.
abstract.3: The aim of the present study was to investigate the changes in several core cognitive functions after successful treatment of long-term BDZ use and dependence with PGB.
abstract.4: Methods: Fourteen patients with long-term BDZ use (mean duration >15 years) underwent neuropsychological assessment with the mini-mental state examination and four tests from the Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery (CANTAB) battery before the initiation of PGB treatment and at a two months follow-up after the cessation of BDZs.
abstract.5: Patients' CANTAB percentile score distributions were compared with normative CANTAB data.
abstract.6: Results: Patients improved on cognitive measures of global cognitive functioning, time orientation, psychomotor speed, and visuospatial memory and learning with strong effect sizes.
abstract.7: By contrast, they failed to improve on measures of attentional flexibility.
abstract.8: Despite their significant improvement, patients' scores on most tests remained still at the lower percentiles of CANTAB normative scores.
abstract.9: Conclusions: Although preliminary, our findings suggest that successful treatment of long-term BDZ use with PGB is associated with a substantial, though only partial, recovery of BDZ-compromised neuropsychological functioning, at least at a 2-month follow-up.

translation1.1: Benzodiazepines (BDZ) are drugs that are often used to treat anxiety, muscle spasms, and seixures. Long-term BDZ use and dependence negatively affect cognitive functioning (thinking ability). These effects can be partially irreversible.
translation1.2: New evidence suggests that pregabalin (PGB) might be a safe and effective treatment of long-term BDZ use.
translation1.3: The goal of the study was investigate the changes in cognitive function after successful treatment of long-term BDZ use and dependence with PGB.
translation1.4: Fourteen patients with long-term BDZ use underwent several neurological (brain-related) and cognititive function tests. These evaluations were conducted before the initiation of PGB treatment and at a two months follow-up after the cessation (stopping) of BDZs.
translation1.5: Patients' scores from the tests were compared with control data.
translation1.6: Patients improved on several cognitive measures with strong effect sizes.
translation1.7: By contrast, they failed to improve on measures of attentional flexibility (the ability to shift focus).
translation1.8: Despite their significant improvement, patients' scores on most tests were low when compared to control scores.
translation1.9: The study findings suggest that successful treatment of long-term BDZ use with PGB is associated (linked) with a substantial, though only partial, recovery of BDZ-compromised brain function, at least at a 2-month follow-up.

33033779.Title: Pregabalin-associated movement disorders: A literature review

abstract.1: Central nervous system adverse effects are commonly reported with pregabalin (PGB).
abstract.2: On the other hand, movement disorders (MDs) associated with this drug were rarely described.
abstract.3: However, their occurrence could significantly affect the quality of life of PGB users.
abstract.4: This literature review aims to evaluate the clinical epidemiological profile, pathological mechanisms, and management of PGB-associated MDs.
abstract.5: Relevant reports in six databases were identified and assessed by two reviewers without language restriction.
abstract.6: A total of 46 reports containing 305 cases from 17 countries were assessed.
abstract.7: The MDs encountered were as follows: 184 individuals with ataxia, 61 with tremors, 39 with myoclonus, 8 with parkinsonism, 1 with restless legs syndrome, 1 with dystonia, 1 with dyskinesia, and 1 with akathisia.
abstract.8: The mean age was 62 years (range: 23-94).
abstract.9: The male sex was slightly predominant with 54.34%.
abstract.10: The mean PGB dose when the MD occurred was 238 mg, and neuropathic pain was the most common indication of PGB.
abstract.11: The time from PGB start to MD was < 1 month at 75%.
abstract.12: The time from PGB withdrawal to recovery was < 1 week at 77%.
abstract.13: All the individuals where the follow-up was reported had a full recovery.
abstract.14: The most common management was PGB withdrawal.
abstract.15: In the literature, the majority of the cases did not report information about timeline events, neurological examination details, or electrodiagnostic studies.
abstract.16: The best management for all MDs is probably PGB withdrawal.
abstract.17: If the patient is on dialysis program, perhaps an increased number of sessions will decrease recovery time.
abstract.18: Furthermore, the addition of a benzodiazepine could accelerate recovery.

translation1.1: Central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) adverse effects (side effects) are commonly reported with pregabalin (PGB), a drug commonly given for nerve pain.
translation1.2: However, movement disorders (MDs) associated with pregabalin were rarely described.
translation1.3: However, their occurrence could significantly affect the quality of life of PGB users.
translation1.4: This literature review aims to evaluate the clinical incidence, distribution, and control; underlying causative mechanisms; and management of PGB-associated MDs.
translation1.5: Relevant scientific papers in six databases were identified and assessed (evaluated) by two reviewers without language restriction.
translation1.6: A total of 46 reports containing 305 cases from 17 countries were assessed.
translation1.7: The MDs reported were as follows: 184 individuals with ataxia (loss of full control of body movement), 61 with tremors (shaking), 39 with myoclonus (jerky movement), 8 with Parkinson's disease, 1 with restless legs syndrome, 1 with dystonia (involuntary muscle contraction), 1 with dyskinesia (uncontrolled muscle movement), and 1 with akathisia (feeling of restlessness).
translation1.8: The average age was 62 years. The age range was 23 to 94 years old.
translation1.9: The male sex was slightly predominant at 54.34% of all cases.
translation1.10: The average PGB dose when the MD occurred was 238 mg. Nerve pain was the most common indication of PGB.
translation1.11: The time between PGB start and onset of a MD was less than one month for a majority of cases.
translation1.12: The time from PGB withdrawal to recovery was less than 1 week for a majority of cases.
translation1.13: All the individuals where the follow-up was reported had a full recovery.
translation1.14: The most common management was PGB withdrawal.
translation1.15: In the literature, the majority of the cases did not report information about timeline events, neurological (brain-related) examination details, or electrodiagnostic studies (using electrical activity to gauge health).
translation1.16: The best management for all MDs is probably PGB withdrawal.
translation1.17: If the patient is on dialysis (blood filtering and purification) program, perhaps an increased number of sessions will decrease recovery time.
translation1.18: Furthermore, the addition of a benzodiazepine (anti-anxiety drug) could speed up recovery.

translation2.1: Side effects of the brain and spine are commonly reported with pregabalin (PGB), a common nerve pain medication.
translation2.2: However, movement disorders (MDs) linked with this drug were rarely described.
translation2.3: Still, their occurence could affect the quality of life of PGB users.
translation2.4: This review evaluates the distribution, disease-causing mechanisms, and treatment of PGB-associated MDs.
translation2.5: Two reviewers without language issues identified and checked relevant reports in six databases.
translation2.6: 46 reports with 305 cases from 17 countries were assessed.
translation2.7: The reported MDs include: 184 people with ataxia (impaired coordination), 61 with tremors (shaking movements), 39 with myoclonus (muscle jerks), 8 with parkinsonism (movement abnormalities from a brain disorder), 1 with restless legs syndrome (uncontrollable urge to move legs), 1 with dystonia (repetitive, twisting movements), 1 with dyskinesia (erratic movements), and 1 with akathisia (muscle quivering).
translation2.8: Average age was 62 years.
translation2.9: Proportion of male sex was 54.34%.
translation2.10: Average PGB medication dose when MD occured was 238 mg. Nerve-related pain was the most common effect of PGB.
translation2.11: Time from PGB start to MD was <1 month at 75%.
translation2.12: Time from PGD drug use withdrawal to recovery was < 1 week at 77%.
translation2.13: All individuals with a reported follow-up or later examination had a full recovery.
translation2.14: Most common management was PGB drug withdrawal.
translation2.15: In the text, many cases did not report information about timeline events, brain-related exam details, or details about the electrical activity of the body.
translation2.16: The best treatment for all MDs is likely PGB drug use stoppage.
translation2.17: If the patient is on an artificial kidney machine, perhaps more sessions will decrease recovery time.
translation2.18: Also, adding a benzodiazepine, an anti-anxiety and anti-seizure drug, could quicken recovery.

33515658.Title: Neurotoxic effects of pregabalin dependence on the brain frontal cortex in adult male albino rats

abstract.1: Pregabalin (PGB) is an analog of the inhibitory neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid.
abstract.2: The currently available evidence favors the misuse and abuse potential of PGB.
abstract.3: However, its neurotoxicity remains unclear.
abstract.4: Therefore, this study assessed the toxic effects of chronic pregabalin dependence as well as withdrawal on the cortical neurons of the frontal lobe.
abstract.5: This study included eighty adult male albino rats which were divided into three groups.
abstract.6: Group I (Control) included 40 rats and was further subdivided into two equal subgroups (IA and IB) as negative and positive controls.
abstract.7: Group II (PGB-dependent) included 20 rats which received PGB starting with the therapeutic dose (300 mg/day), then the doses were gradually increased until they reached the dependent dose (3400 mg/day) by the end of the first month.
abstract.8: Further, the dependent dose was given daily for another 2 months.
abstract.9: Group III (PGB withdrawal) included 20 rats which received PGB as described in group II.
abstract.10: After that, administration of PGB was stopped and the rats were kept for another one month.
abstract.11: By the end of the experiment, all animals were sacrificed by cervical decapitation.
abstract.12: The specimens were taken from the frontal cortex for histologic and immunohistochemical staining as well as morphometric analysis.
abstract.13: Sections of the frontal cortex of group II showed changes in the form of disturbed architectural pattern of cortical layers, apoptotic cells, weak immunoexpression of Bcl-2 and VEGF as well as moderate-strong immunoexpression of iNOS and nestin.
abstract.14: These expressions were significantly different from the control groups, but they were non-significant in comparison with group III.
abstract.15: These findings indicate that chronic PGB dependence induces neurotoxic effects mainly in the form of neuronal apoptosis, gliosis, and oxidative stress injury of the frontal cortex.
abstract.16: The PGB- induced neurotoxic effects persisted after withdrawal.
abstract.17: The influence of these neurotoxic effects and their relevance to the cognitive or neurologic disorders in PGB-dependent individuals warrants further research.
abstract.18: Furthermore, it is recommended to quantify the behavioral changes related to PGB dependence as well as withdrawal in future studies.

translation1.1: Pregabalin (PGB) - a nerve pain medication - is an analog of the inhibitory (silencing) neurotransmitter, (chemical messenger in the brain) gamma-aminobutyric acid. Analogs are compounds that have similar structure to other compounds but are not identical.
translation1.2: The currently available evidence favors the misuse and abuse potential of PGB.
translation1.3: However, its neurotoxicity (poison to the brain) remains unclear.
translation1.4: The aim of this study was to assess (measure) the toxic effects of long term dependence on pregabalin. Additionally, the study aimed to assess how withdrawal from (removal of) PGB affects cortical neurons (brain cells) in the front lobe of the brain.
translation1.5: This study included eighty adult male albino rats which were divided into three groups.
translation1.6: Group I (Control) included 40 rats and was further subdivided into two equal subgroups (IA and IB) as negative and positive controls - groups to compare the treatment group to.
translation1.7: Group II (PGB-dependent) included 20 rats. Each rat received PGB starting with the therapeutic (beneficial) dose (300 mg/day). The doses were gradually increased until they reached the dependent (full) dose (3400 mg/day) by the end of the first month.
translation1.8: Further, the dependent dose was given daily for another 2 months.
translation1.9: Group III (PGB withdrawal) included 20 rats which received PGB as described in Group II.
translation1.10: After that, administration (use) of PGB was stopped, and the rats were kept for another one month.
translation1.11: By the end of the experiment, all animals were sacrificed by cervical decapitation.
translation1.12: Samples were taken from the frontal cortex, a section of the brain, for further analysis.
translation1.13: Brain samples showed changes in cortical layer (brain) structure, dying cells, and decreased expression of several critical factors needed for cell function.
translation1.14: These expression level changes were significantly different from the Control groups. However, they were non-significant in comparison with Group III.
translation1.15: These results indicate that long-term PGB dependence causes neurotoxic effects. These effects include brain cell death, scarring of the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord), and increased reactive oxidative species (harmful chemicals from oxygen) in the frontal cortex.
translation1.16: The PGB- induced neurotoxic effects continued after withdrawal.
translation1.17: Further research is needed to understand the impact of these neurotoxic effects and their relevance to the cognitive (memory-related) or neurologic (brain-related) disorders in PGB-dependent individuals.
translation1.18: Furthermore, it is recommended to measure the behavioral changes related to PGB dependence and withdrawal in future studies.

28922287.Title: Pregabalin Toxicity Manifesting as Reversible Encephalopathy With Continuous Triphasic Waves in Electroencephalogram

abstract.1: A 74-year-old man with peripheral neuropathy due to diabetes presented with deliberate ingestion of 450 mg of pregabalin (PBG) over a period of 8 hours followed by altered mental status.
abstract.2: A bedside electroencephalogram was performed to rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus, which showed continuous triphasic waves (TWs) with slow background activity.
abstract.3: He recovered after 48 hours of stopping PBG, and his repeat electroencephalogram after 72 hours did not show any TWs.
abstract.4: We present a rare case of PBG-induced TWs thereby highlighting the extent of the etiologic spectrum of TWs and discussing the literature related to this association.

translation1.1: A 74-year-old man showed nerve damage due to diabetes (a disease involving high blood sugar). The patient had ingested 450 mg of pregabalin (PBG - a nerve pain medication) over a period of 8 hours which was followed by altered mental status.
translation1.2: A bedside test for brain activity was performed to rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus, or a prolonged seizure. The test showed continuous triphasic waves (TWs), which is abnormal body activity, with slow background activity.
translation1.3: The patient recovered after 48 hours of stopping PBG. A repeated brain acitivty test after 72 hours did not show any TWs.
translation1.4: This study presents a rare case of PBG-induced TWs. This paper highlighting the extent of the etiologic spectrum of TWs, or how TWs promote disease. Additionally, the paper discusses the literature related to this association (or link).

32632575.Title: Pregabalin-associated stuttering and frequent blepharospasm: case report and review

abstract.1: Herpes zoster is an acute, painful, herpes skin disease caused by varicella-zoster virus, which may cause viral meningitis.
abstract.2: Pregabalin has been shown to be efficacious in the treatment of pain in patients with herpes zoster.
abstract.3: However, it has the side effects of neurotoxicity.
abstract.4: We describe a 68-year-old female patient with herpes zoster, and she was treated with pregabalin.
abstract.5: The patient presented with stuttering and frequent blepharospasm after 3 days of pregabalin treatment.
abstract.6: Pregabalin was discontinued, the symptoms of stuttering and frequent blepharospasm completely resolved without any special treatment after one week.
abstract.7: In this case, the etiology of stuttering and frequent blepharospasm may be related to pregabalin.
abstract.8: Clinicians should be alert to the rare symptoms associated with the use of pregabalin.

translation1.1: Herpes zoster is an acute, painful, herpes skin disease. It is caused by the varicella-zoster virus. The virus may cause viral meningitis or inflammation of the brain and spinal cord.
translation1.2: Pregabalin, a nerve pain medication, has been shown to be effecive in the treatment of pain in patients with herpes zoster.
translation1.3: However, it can cause neurotoxicity or alteration of the normal acitivty of the nervous system (brain and spinal cord).
translation1.4: This study describes a 68-year-old female patient with herpes zoster, and she was treated with pregabalin.
translation1.5: The patient presented with stuttering and frequent, uncontrollable movement of the eyelids after 3 days of pregabalin treatment.
translation1.6: Pregabalin was no longer given to the patient. The symptoms of stuttering and frequent eyelid movement completely resolved without any special treatment after one week.
translation1.7: In this case, the onset of stuttering and frequent eyelid movement may be related to pregabalin.
translation1.8: Clinicians should be alert to the rare symptoms associated with the use of pregabalin.

translation2.1: Herpes zoster (shingles) is an immediate, painful, skin disease involved with reactivating the chickenpox virus. It may cause viral meningitis (inflamation of the brain and spine).
translation2.2: Pregabalin, common nerve pain medication, helps treat pain from herpes zoster.
translation2.3: However, pregabalin can be toxic to the nervous system.
translation2.4: We describe a 68-year-old female with herpes zoster and treated with pregabalin.
translation2.5: The patient had stuttering and frequent eye twitching after 3 days of using pregabalin.
translation2.6: Pregabalin use was stopped. The symptoms of stuttering and eye twitching completely stopped without any special treatment after one week.
translation2.7: In this case, the cause of stuttering and eye twitching may be linked to pregabalin.
translation2.8: Clinicians should be alert to the rare symptoms linked with pregabalin use.

32377769.Title: The neurotoxic effect of long-term use of high-dose Pregabalin and the role of alpha tocopherol in amelioration: implication of MAPK signaling with oxidative stress and apoptosis

abstract.1: Pregabalin abuse has become an emerging concern; thus, the current study has been designed to study the neurotoxic hazards of prolonged high-dose of pregabalin (akin to that abused by addicts) and to evaluate the effect of alpha tocopherol as a possible ameliorating agent.
abstract.2: The current study evaluated the brain neurotransmitters; dopamine, glutamate, and norepinephrine.
abstract.3: The study also assessed the expression of the apoptosis-related markers Bax, Bcl2, and caspase 3.
abstract.4: Western-blotted analysis of the three major mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs), the c-JUN N-terminal kinase (JNK), the p38 MAPK, and the extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), has also been performed.
abstract.5: The study also evaluated oxidative stress via assessment of the cortical tissue levels of reduced glutathione and malondialdehyde and the activity of superoxide dismutase.
abstract.6: Histopathological examination and histomorphometric evaluation of the darkly degenerated cortical neurons have also been performed.
abstract.7: Pregabalin in high doses (150 mg/kg/day and 300 mg/kg/day) disrupted the ERK/JNK/p38-MAPK signaling, reversed the bax/bcl2 ratio, and induced oxidative stress.
abstract.8: It also diminished the release of dopamine, glutamate, and norepinephrine and increased the count of degenerated neurons.
abstract.9: Alpha tocopherol treatment significantly attenuated the deleterious effects induced by pregabalin.
abstract.10: The role of alpha tocopherol in ameliorating the oxidative stress injury, and apoptosis induced by pregabalin, along with its role in normalizing neurotransmitters, modulating the ERK/JNK/p38-MAPK signaling pathways and improving the histopathological cortical changes, offers alpha tocopherol as a promising adjunctive therapy in patients undergoing prolonged pregabalin therapy as those suffering from prolonged seizures and neuropathies.

translation1.1: Pregabalin, a drug often used to treat nerve damage, abuse has become an emerging concern. The current study aimed to investigate nervous system (brain and spinal cord) damage caused by prolonged high-dose of pregabalin. This dose is similar to that used by addicts. Additionally, the study aimed to evaluate the effect of alpha tocopherol, a type of Vitamin E, as a possible agent to help side effects.
translation1.2: The study evaluated the brain neurotransmitters; dopamine, glutamate, and norepinephrine. Neurotransmitters are chemical messengers in the body.
translation1.3: The study also assessed (measured) the expression of the cell death-related markers Bax, Bcl2, and caspase 3.
translation1.4: Additional tests evaluating three mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs) was completed. MAPKs are involved in biological pathways that direct cell response to mitogens, or things that induce cell division.
translation1.5: The study also evaluated oxidative stress which is an imbalance between production and accumulation of harmful oxygen reactive species.
translation1.6: Evaluations of the degenerated cortical neurons, nerve cells within the brain, were also preformed.
translation1.7: Pregabalin in high doses (150 mg/kg/day and 300 mg/kg/day) disrupted the signaling for cellular processes, reversed ratios of proteins needed for cell cycles, and induced oxidative stress.
translation1.8: It also diminished the release of neurotransmitters and increased the count of degenerated neurons.
translation1.9: Alpha tocopherol treatment significantly reduced the harmful effects induced by pregabalin.
translation1.10: Alpha tocopherol plays a role in reducing negative side effects induced by pregabalin. It also normalizes neurotransmitter levels, positively effects signaling pathways for cell function, and improves cortical (brain) structure changes. These reasons make alpha tocopherol a promising therapeutic option in patients undergoing prolonged pregabalin therapy.

20194915.Title: Cognitive effects of pregabalin in healthy volunteers: a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

abstract.1: Background: Antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) can be associated with neurotoxic side effects including cognitive dysfunction, a problem of considerable importance given the usual long-term course of treatment.
abstract.2: Pregabalin is a relatively new AED widely used for the treatment of seizures and some types of chronic pain including fibromyalgia.
abstract.3: We measured the cognitive effects of 12 weeks of pregabalin in healthy volunteers.
abstract.4: Methods: Thirty-two healthy volunteers were randomized in a double-blind parallel study to receive pregabalin or placebo (1:1).
abstract.5: Pregabalin was titrated over 8 weeks to 600 mg/d.
abstract.6: At baseline, and after 12 weeks of treatment, all subjects underwent cognitive testing.
abstract.7: Test-retest changes in all cognitive and subjective measures were Z scored against test-retest regressions previously developed from 90 healthy volunteers.
abstract.8: Z scores from the placebo and pregabalin groups were compared using Wilcoxon tests.
abstract.9: Results: Thirty subjects completed the study (94%).
abstract.10: Three of 6 target cognitive measures (Digit Symbol, Stroop, Controlled Oral Word Association) revealed significant test-retest differences between the pregabalin and placebo groups, all showing negative effects with pregabalin (p < 0.05).
abstract.11: These cognitive effects were paralleled by complaints on the Portland Neurotoxicity Scale, a subjective measure of neurotoxicity (p < 0.01).
abstract.12: Conclusion: At conventional doses and titration, pregabalin induced mild negative cognitive effects and neurotoxicity complaints in healthy volunteers.
abstract.13: These effects are one factor to be considered in the selection and monitoring of chronic AED therapy.
abstract.14: Class of Evidence: This study provides Class I evidence that pregabalin 300 mg BID negatively impacts cognition on some tasks in healthy volunteers.

translation1.1: Antiepileptic - or antiseizure - drugs (AEDs) can be associated with neurotoxic (brain damaging) side effects including cognitive dysfunction. Cognitive dysfunction or inability to think properly is a problem of considerable importance given the usual long-term course of treatment.
translation1.2: Pregabalin is a relatively new AED widely used for the treatment of seizures and some types of chronic pain, including fibromyalgia - full-body pain.
translation1.3: We measured the cognitive effects of 12 weeks of pregabalin administration (use) in healthy volunteers.
translation1.4: Thirty-two healthy volunteers were randomly assigned to one of two groups: pregabalin or sham treatment/placebo (1:1).
translation1.5: Pregabalin dose was continuously increased over 8 weeks to 600 mg/d.
translation1.6: Before treatment and after 12 weeks of treatment, all subjects underwent cognitive testing.
translation1.7: Test-retest changes in all cognitive and subjective measures were Z scored against test-retest scores taken from 90 healthy volunteers. Z scores determine how far a data point is away from a dataset average.
translation1.8: Z scores from the placebo and pregabalin groups were compared.
translation1.9: Thirty subjects completed the study (94%).
translation1.10: Three of 6 cognitive measures revealed significant test-retest differences between the pregabalin and placebo groups, all showing negative effects with pregabalin.
translation1.11: These cognitive effects were paralleled by complaints on the Portland Neurotoxicity Scale, a subjective measure of neurotoxicity.
translation1.12: At standard doses and titration, pregabalin led to mild negative cognitive effects and neurotoxicity complaints in healthy volunteers.
translation1.13: These effects are one factor to be considered in the selection and monitoring of chronic AED therapy.
translation1.14: This study provides evidence that pregabalin 300 mg negatively impacts cognition on some tasks in healthy volunteers.

30003357.Title: Cognitive and fatigue side effects of anti-epileptic drugs: an analysis of phase III add-on trials

abstract.1: We aimed to investigate the terms used to refer to cognitive and fatigue related side effects and their prevalence in phase III add-on clinical trials of anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs).
abstract.2: We extracted data from publicly available FDA documents as well as the published literature.
