translation2.1: Pimary progressive aphasia (PPA), a language and speech brain disorder, is linked with amyloid-β (Aβ), a brain protein segment associated with Alzheimer's disease.
translation2.2: However, symptoms of PPA based on Aβ presence is unclear.
translation2.3: We assess the amount of Aβ presence in patients with PPA and compare the symptoms of PPA patients with Aβ presence of Aβ-positive (A+) versus those without Aβ (A-).
translation2.4: We also classified Aβ and tau type in PPA patients with this available information.
translation2.5: We had 110 PPA patients (41 who can't understand words [svPPA], 27 who can't speak but understand words [nfvPPA], 32 who have trouble finding the right word [lvPPA], and 10 unclassified [ucPPA]) undergo Aβ imaging at multiple centers.
translation2.6: The extent of language impairment and brain damage were compared between tehe A+ and A- PPA subgroups.
translation2.7: The proportion of Aβ presence was highest in patients with lvPPA (81.3%), then ucPPA (60.0%), nfvPPA (18.5%), and svPPA (9.8%).
translation2.8: The A+ PPA subgroup had brain damage mainly on the left side in the middle regions and had worse scores compared to the A- PPA subgroup.
translation2.9: Also, over 90% (13/14) patients with A+ PPA had tau, a brain protein associated with Alzheimer's disease.
translation2.10: Our findings will help clinicians understand the patterns of language impairment and brain damage in PPA patients based on Aβ presence.
translation2.11: Since most A+ PPA patients have tau, understanding the effect of Alzheimer's disease markers on PPA may allow these patients to participate in clinical studies aimed for treating atypical Alzheimer's disease.

34654834.Title: Single-cell RNA sequencing for the identification of early-stage lung cancer biomarkers from circulating blood

abstract.1: Lung cancer accounts for more than half of the new cancers diagnosed world-wide with poor survival rates.
abstract.2: Despite the development of chemical, radiological, and immunotherapies, many patients do not benefit from these therapies, as recurrence is common.
abstract.3: We performed single-cell RNA-sequencing (scRNA-seq) analysis using Fluidigm C1 systems to characterize human lung cancer transcriptomes at single-cell resolution.
abstract.4: Validation of scRNA-seq differentially expressed genes (DEGs) through quantitative real time-polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) found a positive correlation in fold-change values between C-X-C motif chemokine ligand 1 (CXCL1) and 2 (CXCL2) compared with bulk-cell level in 34 primary lung adenocarcinomas (LUADs) from Stage I patients.
abstract.5: Furthermore, we discovered an inverse correlation between chemokine mRNAs, miR-532-5p, and miR-1266-3p in early-stage primary LUADs.
abstract.6: Specially, miR-532-5p was quantifiable in plasma from the corresponding LUADs.
abstract.7: Collectively, we identified markers of early-stage lung cancer that were validated in primary lung tumors and circulating blood.

translation1.1: Lung cancer accounts for more than half of the new cancers diagnosed world-wide. Lung cancer patients have poor survival rates.
translation1.2: Despite the development of several therapy types, many patients do not benefit from these therapies. Recurrence, or the return of lung cancer, is common.
translation1.3: The authors performed an analysis to characterize human lung cancer transcriptomes at single-cell resolution. The transcriptome is the sum total of messenger RNA within the genetic material of an organism.
translation1.4: The analysis found a positive correlation (link) between a gene and a chemokine, both with roles in a pro-inflammatory or infection-fighting response, in human lung cancer cells taken from cancer patients. Chemokines are signaling proteins that attract white blood cells to infection sites.
translation1.5: Furthermore, the authors discovered an inverse (opposite) correlation between chemokine messenger RNAs and microRNAs in human lung cancer cells taken from cancer patients. MicroRNA is RNA that is not translated into functioning proteins.
translation1.6: Specially, one microRNA (miR-532-5p) was measurable in plasma from the cells.
translation1.7: The authors identified markers of early-stage lung cancer that were validated (proven) in primary lung tumors and circulating blood.

34638664.Title: Potential Biomarkers Associated with Multiple Sclerosis Pathology

abstract.1: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a complex disease of the central nervous system (CNS) that involves an intricate and aberrant interaction of immune cells leading to inflammation, demyelination, and neurodegeneration.
abstract.2: Due to the heterogeneity of clinical subtypes, their diagnosis becomes challenging and the best treatment cannot be easily provided to patients.
abstract.3: Biomarkers have been used to simplify the diagnosis and prognosis of MS, as well as to evaluate the results of clinical treatments.
abstract.4: In recent years, research on biomarkers has advanced rapidly due to their ability to be easily and promptly measured, their specificity, and their reproducibility.
abstract.5: Biomarkers are classified into several categories depending on whether they address personal or predictive susceptibility, diagnosis, prognosis, disease activity, or response to treatment in different clinical courses of MS.
abstract.6: The identified members indicate a variety of pathological processes of MS, such as neuroaxonal damage, gliosis, demyelination, progression of disability, and remyelination, among others.
abstract.7: The present review analyzes biomarkers in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and blood serum, the most promising imaging biomarkers used in clinical practice.
abstract.8: Furthermore, it aims to shed light on the criteria and challenges that a biomarker must face to be considered as a standard in daily clinical practice.

translation1.1: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a complex disease of the central nervous system (CNS). MS involves an intricate and abnormal interaction of immune cells that leads to inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection), demyelination (destruction of nerve tissue), and neurodegeneration. Neurodegeneration is the loss of structure and/or function of neurons, cells in the brain.
translation1.2: Due to the diversity of the types of MS, their diagnosis becomes challenging, and the best treatment cannot be easily provided to patients.
translation1.3: Biomarkers, or measurable biological substances that can indicate disease, have been used to simplify the diagnosis and treatment of MS. Biomarkers have also been used to evaluate the results of clinical treatments.
translation1.4: In recent years, biomarker research has advanced rapidly due to their ability to be easily and promptly measured, their specificity, and their reproducibility.
translation1.5: Biomarkers are classified into several categories. These categories depend on whether the biomarkers address personal or predictive susceptibility (or risk), diagnosis, disease forecast (or progression), disease activity, or response to treatment in different clinical courses of MS.
translation1.6: The identified members indicate a variety of causative pathways of MS. These pathways include neuroaxonal damage (nerve degeneration), gliosis (scarring in the CNS), demyelination (nerve tissue destruction), progression of disability, and many others.
translation1.7: The present review analyzes biomarkers in cerebrospinal (brain) fluid (CSF) and blood serum. These are the most promising imaging biomarkers used in clinical practice.
translation1.8: Furthermore, this paper aims to shed light on the criteria and challenges that a biomarker faces to be routinely used daily clinical practice.

abstract.1: The detection of chemical compounds in exhaled human breath presents an opportunity to determine physiological state, diagnose disease or assess environmental exposure.
abstract.2: Recent advancements in metabolomics research have led to improved capabilities to explore human metabolic profiles in breath.
abstract.3: Despite some notable challenges in sampling and analysis, exhaled breath represents a desirable medium for metabolomics applications, foremost due to its non-invasive, convenient and practically limitless availability.
abstract.4: Several breath-based tests that target either endogenous or exogenous gas-phase compounds are currently established and are in practical and/or clinical use.
abstract.5: This review outlines the concept of breath analysis in the context of these unique tests and their applications.
abstract.6: The respective breath biomarkers targeted in each test are discussed in relation to their physiological production in the human body and the development and implementation of the associated tests.
abstract.7: The paper concludes with a brief insight into prospective tests and an outlook of the future direction of breath research.

translation1.1: Detection of chemical compounds in exhaled human breath provides an opportunity to determine several aspects about human health. These aspects include evaluating physiological state (how the body is functioning), determining any disease, and/or assessing (measuring) environmental exposures (or things in the environment that can lead to disease).
translation1.2: Recent advancements in metabolomics research have led to better opportunities to explore human metabolic profiles in depth. Metabolomics is the study of metabolites within the body. Metabolites are small substances involved in cell metabolism or energy-production.
translation1.3: Despite some test challenges, exhaled breath represents a good sample for metabolomics applications. Breath is ideal as it is non-invasive, convenient, and nearly limitless in availability.
translation1.4: There are several breath-based tests that target either internal or external chemical compounds. These tests are already established and are in practical and/or clinical use.
translation1.5: This paper reviews the concept of breath analysis used for these unique tests and their applications.
translation1.6: The breath biomarkers targeted in each test are discussed in relation to their function in the human body. Additionally, the paper evaluates the development and implementation of the associated tests.
translation1.7: The paper concludes with a brief insight into prospective (future) tests and an outlook of the future direction of breath research.

translation2.1: Detecting chemical compounds in exhaled human breath may help determine health status, identify disease, or measure environmental exposure.
translation2.2: Recent advances in research of small energy molecules (metabolomics) led to better methods to explore human health status in breath.
translation2.3: Despite some methodological challenges, exhaled breath is a desirable tool for metabolomics due to its non-surgery, convenient, and limitless availability.
translation2.4: Many breath-based tests that target internal or external gas compounds are established and used in practice.
translation2.5: This review outlines the concept of breath analysis regarding these unique breath-based tests and their applications.
translation2.6: The breath biological disease markers in each test are discussed based on their production in humans and development and use of the associated tests.
translation2.7: The paper ends with a short look into future tests and direction of breath research.

40.question: Could compression therapy with bandage raise your blood pressure?

32710511.Title: Compression therapy for leg oedema in patients with heart failure

abstract.1: The presence of chronic heart failure (CHF) results in a significant risk of leg oedema.
abstract.2: Medical compression (MC) treatment is one of the basic methods of leg oedema elimination in patients with chronic venous disease and lymphedema, but it is not routinely considered in subjects with CHF-related swelling.
abstract.3: In the study, an overview of the current knowledge related to the benefits and risk of using MC in the supportive treatment of leg oedema in CHF patients is presented.
abstract.4: The available studies dedicated the comprehensive management of leg swelling using MC in CHF patients published in the English language literature till December 2019 were evaluated in term of the treatment efficacy and safety.
abstract.5: In studies performed on CHF populations, manual lymphatic drainage, MC stocking, multilayer bandaged, as well as intermittent pneumatic compression or electric calf stimulations were used.
abstract.6: The current evidence is based on non-randomized studies, small study cohorts, as well as very heterogenous populations.
abstract.7: The use of the intermittent pneumatic compression in CHF patients significantly increases the right auricular pressure and mean pulmonary artery pressures as well as decreases systemic vascular resistance in most patients without the clinical worsening.
abstract.8: The transient and rapid increase in the human atrial natriuretic peptide, after an application of the MC stocking in New York Heart Association (NYHA) class II patients was observed without clinical exacerbation.
abstract.9: An application of the multilayer bandages in NYHA classes III and IV patients lead a significant increase in the right arterial pressure and lead to transient deterioration of the right and the left ventricular functions.
abstract.10: In the manual lymphatic drainage study, aside from expected leg circumference reduction, no clinical worsening was observed.
abstract.11: In a pilot study performed in a small cohort of CHF patients, electrical calf stimulation use resulted in a reduction in the lean mass of the legs without cardiac function worsening.
abstract.12: The use of local leg compression can be considered stable CHF patients without decompensated heart function for both CHF-related oedema treatment and for treatment of the concomitant diseases leading to leg swelling occurrence.
abstract.13: The use of MC in more severe classes of CHF (NYHA III and IV) should be the subject of future clinical studies to select the safest and most efficient compression method as well as to select the patients who benefit most from this kind of treatment.

translation1.1: Long-lasting or chronic heart failure (CHF) results in a significant risk of leg oedema. Leg oedema is swelling due to excess fluid accumulation in the body.
translation1.2: Medical compression (MC) treatment is a basic method to eliminate leg oedema in patients with chronic venous disease (abnormal veins) and lymphedema (swelling). However, it is not routinely considered in subjects with CHF-related swelling.
translation1.3: This study is an overview of evidence related to the benefits and risk of using MC in the treatment of leg oedema in CHF patients.
translation1.4: This paper reviews research published in English up until December 2019. The reviewed paper focused on the management of leg swelling through the use of MC within CHF patients. All reviewed papers were evaluated for treatment efficacy and safety.
translation1.5: In studies of CHF populations, several treatment options were used. These options include manual lymphatic drainage, MC stocking, multilayer bandaged, and electric calf stimulations.
translation1.6: The current evidence is based on non-randomized studies, small study cohorts, as well as very diverse populations.
translation1.7: Intermittent pneumatic compression is a treatment that uses a device that squeezes fluids from an infected area. The treatment in CHF patients significantly increased pressure in the lungs and heart. The treatment decreased systemic vascular resistance, or the resistance that must be overcome to push blood through veins, in most patients without the disease worsening.
translation1.8: Human atrial natriuretic peptide, a substance in the body that reduces fluid volume, increased in patients without clinical exacerbation or pain.
translation1.9: Use of multilayer bandages in patients significantly increased the right arterial (section of the heart) pressure. Use of multilayer bandages also lead to deterioration of heart chamber function.
translation1.10: In the manual lymphatic drainage study, aside from reducing leg size, no clinical worsening was observed.
translation1.11: In a trial study performed in a small cohort of CHF patients, electrical calf stimulation resulted in reduced lean mass of the legs without cardiac function worsening.
translation1.12: The use of local leg compression within CHF patients could be considered. Use of local leg compression did not decompensate heart function in patients with either CHF-related oedema or concomitant (accompanying) diseases leading to leg swelling.
translation1.13: The use of MC in more severe classes of CHF should be further studied to select the safest and most efficient compression method. The patients who would benefit most from MC treatment should also be identified.

29981730.Title: Supervised short-stretch compression therapy in mixed leg ulcers

abstract.1: Objectives: This study was conducted to determine hemodynamic and clinical tolerance under short-stretch compression therapy in elderly patients suffering from mixed-etiology leg ulcers.
abstract.2: Design: Transversal observational study conducted in 25 hospitalized patients with a moderate peripheral arterial occlusive disease defined as an ankle-brachial pressure index>0.5, an ankle pressure of> 70mm Hg and a toe cuff pressure (TP)> 50mm Hg.
abstract.3: Material and methods: Short-stretch bandages were applied daily with pressures from 20 to 30mm Hg.
abstract.4: Ankle-brachial pressure, great toe laser Doppler flowmetry (LDF) and transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPO2) on dorsum of the foot were measured at baseline and after its removal at 24hours.
abstract.5: Great toe LDF was also measured at 10minutes after bandage application.
abstract.6: Compression pressure (CP) was measured with a sub-bandage device at baseline, at 10minutes and before bandage removal at 24hours.
abstract.7: Clinical tolerance was evaluated taking into account the patient's pain and skin tolerance.
abstract.8: Results: Mean age of patients was 80±15 years.
abstract.9: Median duration of ulcers was 18 months.
abstract.10: Hypertension was highly prevalent.
abstract.11: One third of patients had diabetes.
abstract.12: Toe pressure index and TcPO2 values did not significantly change under compression therapy (P=0.51 and P=0.09, respectively) whereas CP decreased significantly during 24hours.
abstract.13: The loss of CP was significant 10minutes after bandage application (P<0.001).
abstract.14: Nearly all ulcers were painful prior to placement of compression therapy and required level 1 analgesics.
abstract.15: One patient required level 2 analgesic for pain relief.
abstract.16: No increase in pain and no ischemic skin damage occurred under compression therapy.
abstract.17: Conclusions: In elderly patients with mixed leg ulcers and with an absolute TP>50mm Hg, short-stretch compression of up to 30mm Hg does not adversely affect arterial flow and appears clinically well tolerated.
abstract.18: Such bandages with appropriate levels of compression may aid ulcer healing by treating the venous part of the disease.

translation1.1: The aim of this study was to determine how  short-stretch compression therapy affected blood flow and clinical tolerance (how much a patient could take). The study was conducted in elderly patients suffering from leg ulcers (sores) caused by various reasons.
translation1.2: This observational study was conducted in 25 hospitalized patients with moderate peripheral aterial occlusive disease, or limited blood flow to lower limbs.
translation1.3: Short-stretch bandages were applied daily with pressures ranging from 20 to 30mm Hg.
translation1.4: Several health measures were taken before the bandages were applied and after 24 hours. These measures include: ankle-brachial pressure, great toe laser Doppler flowmetry (LDF), and transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPO2) on top of the foot. LDF measures blood flow. TcPO2 measures oxygen in the skin.
translation1.5: Great toe LDF was also measured at 10 minutes after bandage application.
translation1.6: Compression pressure (CP) was measured before bandages were placed on, at 10 minutes, and before bandage removal at 24 hours.
translation1.7: Clinical tolerance was evaluated taking into account the patient's pain and skin tolerance.
translation1.8: The average age of patients was 80 ± 15 years.
translation1.9: Median (average) duration of ulcers was 18 months.
translation1.10: Hypertension (high blood pressure) was highly common.
translation1.11: One third of patients had diabetes.
translation1.12: Toe pressure index and TcPO2 values did not significantly change under compression therapy. CP decreased significantly during 24 hours.
translation1.13: The loss of CP was significant 10 minutes after bandages were put on.
translation1.14: Nearly all ulcers were painful prior to placement of compression therapy and required level 1 (minor) pain medication.
translation1.15: One patient required level 2 (more intense) pain medication for pain relief.
translation1.16: No increase in pain and no skin damage due to low blood flow occurred under compression therapy.
translation1.17: The authors conclude that elderly patients with mixed leg ulcers using short-stretch compression did not have adversely (negatively) affected blood flow to the heart. The treatment was clinically well tolerated.
translation1.18: Bandages with appropriate levels of compression may aid ulcer healing by treating the diseased veins.

translation2.1: This study aimed to find blood flow and tolerance under less-stretchable compression treatment in elderly patients with mixed-cause leg sores or open wounds (leg ulcers).
translation2.2: We studied 25 hospitalized patients with blocked blood vessels in the limbs.
translation2.3: Less-stretchable compression bandages were applied daily.
translation2.4: Ankle pressure, toe blood flow, and oxygen pressure at the skin on the top of the foot was measured at the start and after bandage removal at 24 hours.
translation2.5: Big toe blood flow was measured 10 minutes after applying the bandage.
translation2.6: Compression pressure was measured with a special device at the start, at 10 minutes, and before bandage removal at 24 hours.
translation2.7: Patient tolerance was measured while considering the patient's pain and skin tolerance.
translation2.8: Average age of patients was 80 years.
translation2.9: Average duration of sores or open wounds was 18 months.
translation2.10: High blood pressure was common.
translation2.11: One third of patients had diabetes.
translation2.12: Neither pressure nor oxygen to the toes changed with compression therapy, but compression pressure decreased over 24 hours.
translation2.13: The compression pressure loss was noticeable 10 minutes after applying the bandage.
translation2.14: Nearly all ulcers were painful before compression therapy and needed painkillers.
translation2.15: One patient needed a more powerful pain killer.
translation2.16: No increase in pain or blood-flow-related skin damage occured with compression.
translation2.17: In elderly patients with mixed leg ulcers and sufficient toe pressure, less-stretchable compression does not negatively affect blood flow and appears tolerated.
translation2.18: Bandages with appropriate compression may aid ulcer healing by treating the blood flow part of the disease.

abstract.1: Compression therapy is the basic therapy in phlebology and lymphology.
abstract.2: The pressure under the bandages has to exceed the intravenous pressure especially in standing position.
abstract.3: Different compression materials such as short stretch systems, long stretch bandages and compression garments work differently on ambulatory venous hypertension, speed of reducing edema and arterial flow.
abstract.4: Compression with high stiffness, inelastic materials is more effective than compression with low stiffness, elastic materials.
abstract.5: These materials have to be placed correctly.
abstract.6: Inelastic systems should be applied with high initial pressure because the pressure will loose at some time after walking.
abstract.7: Even after one week of wearing, inelastic bandages keep higher resting and working pressure during walking than elastic bandages.
abstract.8: However, more important is that they have lower resting pressure than elastic materials.
abstract.9: Long stretch bandages and compression garments with great extensibility ensure low working pressure and higher resting pressure than short stretch systems.

translation1.1: Compression therapy is the basic therapy when treating the circulatory (blood) or lymphatic (body drainage) system.
translation1.2: The pressure under the bandages has to exceed the intravenous pressure, especially when standing. Intravenous pressure is the pressure of blood in veins.
translation1.3: Different compression materials work differently on ambulatory venous hypertension (excess pressure in veins). The material used can affect both the rate in which swelling is reduced and blood flow. Some compression materials include short stretch systems, long stretch bandages, and compression garments.
translation1.4: Compression with very stiff materials is more effective than compression with low stiffness, elastic materials.
translation1.5: These materials have to be placed correctly.
translation1.6: Inelastic systems should be applied with high initial pressure. This is because the pressure will decrease after walking.
translation1.7: Even after one week of wearing, inelastic bandages keep higher optimal pressure during walking than elastic bandages.
translation1.8: More importantly, inelastic bandages have lower resting pressure than elastic materials.
translation1.9: Long stretch bandages and compression garments that are able to stretch ensure low working pressure and higher resting pressure than short stretch systems.

23641263.Title: Compression therapy: clinical and experimental evidence

abstract.1: Aim: A review is given on the different tools of compression therapy and their mode of action.
abstract.2: Methods: Interface pressure and stiffness of compression devices, alone or in combination can be measured in vivo.
abstract.3: Hemodynamic effects have been demonstrated by measuring venous volume and flow velocity using MRI, Duplex and radioisotopes, venous reflux and venous pumping function using plethysmography and phlebodynamometry.
abstract.4: Oedema reduction can be measured by limb volumetry.
abstract.5: Results: Compression stockings exerting a pressure of ~20 mm Hg on the distal leg are able to increase venous blood flow velocity in the supine position and to prevent leg swelling after prolonged sitting and standing.
abstract.6: In the upright position, an interface pressure of more than 50 mmHg is needed for intermittent occlusion of incompetent veins and for a reduction of ambulatory venous hypertension during walking.
abstract.7: Such high intermittent interface pressure peaks exerting a "massaging effect" may rather be achieved by short stretch multilayer bandages than by elastic stockings.
abstract.8: Conclusion: Compression is a cornerstone in the management of venous and lymphatic insufficiency.
abstract.9: However, this treatment modality is still underestimated and deserves better understanding and improved educational programs, both for patients and medical staff.

translation1.1: This study aimed to evaluate different tools used in compression therapy and assess (measure) how they work.
translation1.2: The levels of pressure and stiffness of the compression devices, alone or in combination with other materials, can be measured on living organisms.
translation1.3: Hemodynamic (blood flow) effects have been demonstrated by measuring venous (vein) volume and flow velocity using several testing methods. Venous reflux (reverse flow) and venous pumping function have been demonstrated using bodily fluid volume and pressure measurements.
translation1.4: Oedema (swelling) reduction can be measured by limb volumetry, a method of suspending a limb in water to determine the amount of water displaced.
translation1.5: Compression stockings putting pressure on the lower leg are able to increase venous blood flow velocity while patients are lying down. Compression stockings are also able to prevent leg swelling after prolonged sitting and standing.
translation1.6: In the upright position, specific pressure (>50 mmHg) is needed for intermittent (irregular) closing of abnormal veins and for pressure reduction during walking.
translation1.7: High, intermittent pressure peaks exerting a "massaging effect" may be achieved by short stretch multilayer bandages instead of elastic stockings.
translation1.8: Compression is important in the management of not fully functioning venous and lymphatic systems.
translation1.9: However, using compression as a treatment is still underestimated. Compression deserves better understanding and improved educational programs for both patients and medical staff.

20483864.Title: Is low compression pressure able to improve venous pumping function in patients with venous insufficiency?

abstract.1: Background: A too high resting pressure of compression devices is poorly tolerated and may cause skin defects, especially in patients with concomitant arterial occlusive disease.
abstract.2: Aim: To investigate whether low compression pressure will improve venous pumping function in patients with venous incompetence.
abstract.3: Material and methods: Venous pumping function was assessed in 20 patients with severe reflux in the great saphenous vein by measuring ejection fraction (EF) using strain-gauge plethysmography.
abstract.4: Measurements were repeated after application of knee-high medical compression stockings and of inelastic bandages applied with a pressure of 20, 40 and 60 mmHg in the supine position.
abstract.5: Results: EF was significantly reduced compared with healthy controls.
abstract.6: Compression stockings exerting a median pressure of 27 mmHg (interquartile range [IQR] 25-29) in the supine and 30.5 mmHg (IQR 28.25-34.25) in the standing position produced a moderate, non-significant improvement of EF of 17%.
abstract.7: Inelastic bandages with a resting pressure of 20.5 mmHg (IQR 20-22) in the supine position resulting in a standing pressure of 36 mmHg (IQR 33-40.75) led to a significant increase of EF of 61.5% (P < 0.01).
abstract.8: A further increase of the resting pressure to 40 and 60 mmHg achieved an increase of the EF of 91% and 98%, respectively (P < 0.001).
abstract.9: Conclusions: In patients with venous pumping failure, inelastic bandages produce a significant pressure-dependent increase of EF.
abstract.10: A significant improvement in venous pumping function was achieved with inelastic bandages even at a resting pressure of 20 mmHg.

translation1.1: A too high resting pressure of compression devices, or when the device is just lying on the skin, is poorly tolerated and may cause skin defects. This is especially common in patients with concomitant arterial occlusive disease, blockage of an artery.
translation1.2: The goal of this study was to investigate if low compression pressure improves vein pumping function in patients with defective veins.
translation1.3: Vein pumping function was assessed (measured) in 20 patients with severe reflux, or the backup of blood, in the great saphenous vein in the leg. This was done by measuring ejection fraction (EF; percentage of blood leaving the heart when it contracts).
translation1.4: Measurements were taken after application of knee-high medical compression stockings and of inelastic bandages applied while lying down.
translation1.5: Results showed EF was significantly reduced compared with healthy controls.
translation1.6: Compression stockings produced a moderate, non-significant improvement of EF.
translation1.7: Inelastic bandages led to a significant increase of EF.
translation1.8: Increased pressure of the inelastic bandages achieved an increase of the EF.
translation1.9: The study concluded that, in patients with venous (vein) pumping failure, inelastic bandages produce a significant pressure-dependent increase of EF. This means that as pressure increases, EF increases.
translation1.10: Significant improvement in venous pumping function was achieved with inelastic bandages, even at resting pressures.

translation2.1: A too high pressure from compression devices is poorly tolerated and may causes skin damage, espeically in those with blocked blood vessels in limbs.
translation2.2: We aim to check if low compression pressure may improve blood vessel pumping in patients with impaired blood vessels.
translation2.3: Blood vessel pumping function was measured in 20 patients with severely impaired blood flow in the body's largest vein.
translation2.4: Measurements were repeated after using knee-high compression socks and inelastic bandages applied with low, medium, and high pressure while lying down.
translation2.5: The amount of blood pumped was compared to healthy patients.
translation2.6: Compression socks exerted an average pressure of 27 mmHg while lying down and slightly higher pressure of 30.5 mmHg while standing. This led to a minor improvement in the amount of blood pumped, or ejection fraction (EF), by 17%.
translation2.7: Inelastic bandages with a pressure of 20.5 mmHg while lying down led to a standing pressure of 36 mmHg, which led to a major increase in EF by 61.5%.
translation2.8: A larger increase of pressure to 40 and 60 mmHg led to an increase in the amount of blood pumped of 91% and 98%, respectively.
translation2.9: In those with impaired blood vessel pumping, inelastic bandages lead to a pressure-dependent increase of EF.
translation2.10: Inelastic bandages even with a pressure of 20 mmHg improved blood vessel pumping.

21286870.Title: Compression therapy for treatment of venous disease and limb swelling

abstract.1: Although compression therapy was initially described over 2,000 years ago (Felty and Rooke Semin Vasc Surg Mar 18:36-40, 1), several patients with edema do not receive appropriate compression therapy.
abstract.2: Instead, most patients with edema are treated primarily with diuretics.
abstract.3: Compression therapy is the cornerstone of treatment of venous edema and lymphatic disorders.
abstract.4: Compression therapy decreases the foot and leg volume and reduces venous reflux and venous hypertension.
abstract.5: Compression can be achieved by multiple different modalities, such as inelastic bandages; multilayered wraps; short, medium, and long stretch bandages; graduated compression stockings; and pneumatic compression devices.
abstract.6: The major criticism of compression therapy is poor patient compliance.
abstract.7: Compliance can be improved by selecting appropriate compression therapy tailored to the needs of the individual patient and by providing adequate patient education.

translation1.1: Although compression therapy was first described over 2,000 years ago, many patients with edema do not receive appropriate compression therapy. Edema is swelling within the body due to excess fluid build up.
translation1.2: Instead, most patients with swelling are treated primarily with diuretics (drugs that promote urination).
translation1.3: Compression therapy is a vital treatment for venous edema (vein swelling) and lymphatic disorders (disorders of the body's drainage system).
translation1.4: Compression therapy decreases the foot and leg volume. Compression therapy also reduces venous reflux and venous hypertension. Venous reflux is abnormal back up of blood in the veins. Venous hypertension is abnormal blood pressure.
translation1.5: Compression can be achieved by multiple different methods. These methods include inelastic bandages; multilayered wraps; short, medium, and long stretch bandages; graduated (pressure-varying) compression stockings; and pneumatic (inflatable) compression devices.
translation1.6: The major criticism of compression therapy is that patients do not always comply with orders.
translation1.7: Compliance with doctor orders can be increased by selecting the right compression therapy for the individual patient. Patients should also be provided with adequate education on the treatment.

14593461.Title: Compression therapy in chronic venous insufficiency. New test procedures and therapeutic options

abstract.1: Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) has a significant socioeconomic impact.
abstract.2: The existent venous hypertension and the subsequent capillary hypertension result in trophic skin damage culminating in an ulcer.
abstract.3: Venous ulcers affect 1-3% of the adult population.
abstract.4: Compression therapy provides the basis for noninvasive treatment of CVI.
abstract.5: It can be applied alone or in combination with invasive strategies.
abstract.6: A variety of materials are available for phlebological compression therapy in the form of compression bandages and compression hosiery.
abstract.7: Knowledge of the different qualities of the compression materials and their mode of action is important in choosing the correct means of compression with regard to clinical findings and the patient's needs.
abstract.8: As far as possible, the compression method applied should be monitored for any loss of effectivity during regular follow-up examinations of the patients.
abstract.9: The following article deals with this topic.
abstract.10: A new option for compression therapy of crural ulcers is presented and the possibility for checking the effectiveness of the compression stockings during outpatient

translation1.1: Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), or malfunctioning veins, has a significant impact on a person's social and economic status.
translation1.2: Continual pressure in the circulatory system can result in skin damage before forming an ulcer (sore).
translation1.3: Venous ulcers (sores from irregular blood flow) affect 1-3% of the adult population.
translation1.4: Compression therapy provides the basis for noninvasive (nonsurgical) treatment of CVI.
translation1.5: It can be applied alone or in combination with invasive (e.g. surgery) strategies.
translation1.6: A variety of materials are available for compression therapy in the form of bandages or hosiery (legwear).
translation1.7: Knowledge of the different compression materials and how they work is important in choosing the correct compression treatment to meet health goals and patient needs.
translation1.8: The compression method applied should be monitored for any decrease in effectiveness.
translation1.9: The following article deals with this topic.
translation1.10: This paper presents a new option for compression therapy of crural (leg) ulcers. This paper also checks the effectiveness of the compression stockings during outpatient treatment.

10845240.Title: Compression therapy for venous leg ulcers

abstract.1: Venous (gravitational) leg ulcers are unsightly, sometimes painful and often difficult to heal.
abstract.2: They are associated with incompetence of valves in the deep leg veins and venous hypertension.
abstract.3: The main approaches in the management of venous leg ulcers have been to reduce the 'back pressure' in the veins by surgical removal of any varicose veins, postural drainage (elevation of the legs when the patient is lying or seated), and use of compression therapy with bandages, hosiery or intermittent pneumatic compression.
abstract.4: In this article, we review the efficacy and discuss correct use of compression therapy.

translation1.1: Venous (gravitational) leg ulcers (leg sores) are unappealing to the eye, sometimes painful, and often difficult to heal.
translation1.2: They are associated with incompetence of valves in the deep leg veins and venous hypertension (high blood pressure in veins).
translation1.3: There are several approaches used in the management of venous leg ulcers. These approaches focus on reducing the 'back pressure' or 'reverse pressure' in the veins. These approaches include surgical removal of any varicose veins (twisted, enlarged veins), postural drainage (elevation of the legs when the patient is lying or seated), and use of compression therapy with bandages, hosiery (legwear) or intermittent (periodic) pneumatic (inflatable) compression.
translation1.4: This article reviews the success and correct use of compression therapy.

translation2.1: Venous leg ulcers (leg sores from veins) are ugly, sometimes painful, and often difficult to heal.
translation2.2: Venous leg ulcers are linked to high blood pressure in impaired leg veins.
translation2.3: Main treatments of venous leg ulcers have been to reduce pressure in veins by surgical removal of enlarged veins, drainage using gravity, and compression from bandages, legwear, or inflatable leg sleeves.
translation2.4: In this article, we review the effectiveness and correct use of compression therapy.

11034749.Title: Compression for preventing recurrence of venous ulcers

abstract.1: Background: Up to 1% of adults will suffer from leg ulceration at some time.
abstract.2: The majority of leg ulcers are venous in origin and are caused by high pressure in the veins due to blockage or weakness of the valves in the veins of the leg.
abstract.3: Prevention and treatment of venous ulcers is aimed at reducing the pressure either by removing / repairing the veins, or by applying compression bandages / stockings to reduce the pressure in the veins.
abstract.4: The vast majority of venous ulcers are healed using compression bandages.
abstract.5: Once healed they often recur and so it is customary to continue applying compression in the form of bandages, tights, stockings or socks in order to prevent recurrence.
abstract.6: Compression bandages or hosiery (tights, stockings, socks) are often applied for ulcer prevention.
abstract.7: Objectives: To assess the effects of compression hosiery (socks, stockings, tights) or bandages in preventing the recurrence of venous ulcers.
abstract.8: To determine whether there is an optimum pressure/type of compression to prevent recurrence of venous ulcers.
abstract.9: Main results: No trials compared recurrence rates with and without compression.
abstract.10: One trial (300 patients) compared high (UK Class 3) compression hosiery with moderate (UK Class 2) compression hosiery.
abstract.11: A intention to treat analysis found no significant reduction in recurrence at five years follow up associated with high compression hosiery compared with moderate compression hosiery (relative risk of recurrence 0.82, 95% confidence interval 0.61 to 1.12).
abstract.12: This analysis would tend to underestimate the effectiveness of the high compression hosiery because a significant proportion of people changed from high compression to medium compression hosiery.
abstract.13: Compliance rates were significantly higher with medium compression than with high compression hosiery.
abstract.14: One trial (166 patients) found no difference in recurrence between two types of medium (UK Class 2) compression hosiery (relative risk of recurrence with Medi was 0.74, 95% confidence interval 0.45 to 1.2).
abstract.15: Both trials reported that not wearing compression hosiery was strongly associated with ulcer recurrence and this is circumstantial evidence that compression reduces ulcer recurrence.
abstract.16: No trials were found which evaluated compression bandages for preventing ulcer recurrence.
abstract.17: Reviewer's conclusions: No trials compared compression with vs no compression for prevention of ulcer recurrence.
abstract.18: Not wearing compression was associated with recurrence in both studies identified in this review.
abstract.19: This is circumstantial evidence of the benefit of compression in reducing recurrence.
abstract.20: Recurrence rates may be lower in high compression hosiery than in medium compression hosiery and therefore patients should be offered the strongest compression with which they can comply.
abstract.21: Further trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of hosiery prescribed in other settings, i.e. in the UK community, in countries other than the UK.

translation1.1: Up to 1% of adults will suffer from leg ulceration (leg sores) at some time.
translation1.2: The majority of leg ulcers come from issues within veins. They are caused by high pressure in the veins due to blockage or weakness of the valves in the veins of the leg that prevent backflow or reverse blood flow.
translation1.3: Prevention and treatment of venous ulcers is aimed at reducing the pressure. This is achieved by removing or repairing the veins. It can also be achieved by applying compression material to reduce vein pressure.
translation1.4: Most venous ulcers are healed using compression bandages.
translation1.5: Once healed, they often recur or reappear. Therefore, it is common to continue applying compression in the form of bandages, tights, stockings, or socks to prevent recurrence.
translation1.6: Compression bandages or hosiery (tights, stockings, socks) are often applied for ulcer prevention.
translation1.7: The aim of this study was to assess (measure) the effects of compression hosiery (socks, stockings, tights) or bandages in preventing the recurrence of venous ulcers.
translation1.8: The study also aimed to determine whether there is an optimum pressure/type of compression to prevent recurrence of venous ulcers.
translation1.9: None of the reviewed reports compared recurrence rates with and without compression.
translation1.10: One trial (300 patients) compared high compression hosiery with moderate compression hosiery.
translation1.11: No significant reduction in recurrence at five years follow up was associated with high compression hosiery when compared with moderate compression hosiery.
translation1.12: This may underestimate the effectiveness of the high compression hosiery as a large proportion of people changed from high compression to medium compression hosiery.
translation1.13: Compliance rates, or the amount of people who used compression consistently, were higher with medium compression than with high compression hosiery.
translation1.14: One trial found no difference in recurrence between two types of medium compression hosiery.
translation1.15: Both trials reported that not wearing compression hosiery was strongly associated with ulcer recurrence. This is circumstantial evidence that compression reduces ulcer recurrence.
translation1.16: No studies that evaluated compression bandages for preventing ulcer recurrence were found.
translation1.17: The authors concluded on several points following this evidence review. First, no trials compared compression with no compression for prevention of reoccurring ulcers.
translation1.18: Second, not wearing compression was associated with ulcer reoccurrence.
translation1.19: This is circumstantial evidence of the benefit of compression in reducing recurrence.
translation1.20: Third, recurrence rates may be lower if patients wear high compression hosiery over medium compression hosiery. Because of this, patients should be offered the strongest compression they can tolerate.
translation1.21: Lastly, further studies are needed to understand the effectiveness of hosiery utilized in alternative locations.

21944912.Title: Compression therapy in mixed ulcers increases venous output and arterial perfusion

abstract.1: Objectives: This study was conducted to define bandage pressures that are safe and effective in treating leg ulcers of mixed arterial-venous etiology.
abstract.2: Methods: In 25 patients with mixed-etiology leg ulcers who received inelastic bandages applied with pressures from 20 to 30, 31 to 40, and 41 to 50 mm Hg, the following measurements were performed before and after bandage application to ensure patient safety throughout the investigation: laser Doppler fluxmetry (LDF) close to the ulcer under the bandage and at the great toe, transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPo(2)) on the dorsum of the foot, and toe pressure.
abstract.3: Ejection fraction (EF) of the venous pump was performed to assess efficacy on venous hemodynamics.
abstract.4: Results: LDF values under the bandages increased by 33% (95% confidence interval [CI], 17-48; P < .01), 28% (95% CI, 12-45; P < .05), and 10% (95% CI, -7 to 28), respectively, under the three pressure ranges applied.
abstract.5: At toe level, a significant decrease in flux of -20% (95% CI, -48 to 9; P < .05) was seen when bandage pressure >41 mm Hg.
abstract.6: Toe pressure values and TcPo(2) showed a moderate increase, excluding a restriction to arterial perfusion induced by the bandages.
abstract.7: Inelastic bandages were highly efficient in improving venous pumping function, increasing the reduced ejection fraction by 72% (95% CI, 50%-95%; P < .001) under pressure of 21 to 30 mm Hg and by 103% (95% CI, 70%-128%; P < .001) at 31 to 40 mm Hg.
abstract.8: Conclusions: In patients with mixed ulceration, an ankle-brachial pressure index >0.5 and an absolute ankle pressure of >60 mm Hg, inelastic compression of up to 40 mm Hg does not impede arterial perfusion but may lead to a normalization of the highly reduced venous pumping function.
abstract.9: Such bandages are therefore recommended in combination with walking exercises as the basic conservative management for patients with mixed leg ulcers.

translation1.1: This study was conducted to find what bandage pressures are safe and effective in treating leg ulcers (leg sores) caused by various vein disorders.
translation1.2: The study evaluated 25 patients with leg ulcers who received inelastic bandages applied with various pressures (20 to 30, 31 to 40, and 41 to 50 mm Hg). Several measurements were performed before and after bandage application to ensure patient safety throughout the investigation. These measurements included laser Doppler fluxmetry (LDF), transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPo(2)), and toe pressure. LDF measures blood flow. TcPO2 measures oxygen in the skin.
translation1.3: Ejection fraction (EF) of the venous pump, or the blood flowing from the heart, was performed to assess blood flow from the heart every time it contracts.
translation1.4: LDF values under the bandages increased at all three pressure ranges.
translation1.5: At toe level, a significant decrease in flux (blood buildup) was seen when bandage pressure was >41 mm Hg.
translation1.6: Toe pressure values and TcPo(2) moderately increased.
translation1.7: Inelastic bandages were highly efficient in improving venous pumping function. This is when a machine compresses veins to force blood flow to the heart.
translation1.8: The study concluded that patients with mixed ulceration using inelastic compression of up to 40 mm Hg do not experience impeded (blocked) arterial perfusion. Arterial perfusion is when a patient has their blood drawn, has the blood mixed with medication, and has the blood pumped back into the host. However, this inelastic compression may lead to a regularly decreased venous pumping function.
translation1.9: These bandages are recommended in combination with walking exercises as the basic treatment for patients with mixed leg ulcers.

41.question: What could possibly cause a cyst in the lower pole of the kidney?

34508491.Title: Rare Encounter of Renal Hydatid Cyst: A Case Report

abstract.1: Cystic Echinococcosis or Hydatid disease is caused by the infection with the larval stage of long tapeworm, Echinococcus granulosus.
abstract.2: This condition often remains asymptomatic for years before the cyst grows large enough to cause symptoms in affected organs.
abstract.3: The most common organs involved are liver and lungs although the heart, brain, bone, central nervous system, and kidney may also be involved.
abstract.4: This case is about a young woman who presented with left flank pain and urinary tract infection who was later diagnosed as having left renal hydatid cyst.
abstract.5: The cyst was approximately 7.8×6.6×8cm with internal multiple septations at the lower pole cortex of the left kidney.
abstract.6: Laparoscopic pericystectomy was performed and with no postoperative complications, she was discharged on albendazole and other supportive medication.
abstract.7: With timely management using combination therapy, this condition is curable and the patient can live a healthy life with normal kidney function.

translation1.1: Cystic Echinococcosis, also called Hydatid disease, is caused by the infection of a long tapeworm called Echinococcus granulosus, after it has hatched into the larval stage.
translation1.2: A person can often have this condition without symptoms for years before the cyst (growth) grows large enough to cause symptoms in affected organs.
translation1.3: The most common organs involved are the liver and lungs although the heart, brain, bone, central nervous system (spinal cord and brain), and kidney may also be involved.
translation1.4: This case is about a young woman who presented with left back pain and urinary tract infection (UTI - bladder infection) who was later diagnosed as having left kidney hydatid cyst.
translation1.5: The cyst was about 7.8×6.6×8cm with multiple compartments at the lower pole cortex (lower part) of the left kidney.
translation1.6: A procedure that uses tiny incisions was performed to remove the cyst and some tissue around the cyst. No complications occurred after the procedure, and she was sent home with anti-worm medicine and other medications.
translation1.7: With timely management using several therapies, this condition is curable, and the patient can live a healthy life with normal kidney function.

translation2.1: Cystic Echinococcosis or Hyadtid disease is caused by infection from baby Echinococcus granulosus, long tapeworms, and leads to cysts or swellings.
translation2.2: This disease often shows no symptoms for years before the swelling grows large enough to cause symptoms in affected organs.
translation2.3: Most common organs affected are the liver and lungs although the heart, brain, bone, spinal cord, and kidney may also be involved.
translation2.4: This case is a young woman with pain on the left side of the waist and infection in the urine-collecting tube due to a left kidney cyst from Hyadtid disease.
translation2.5: The cyst was around 7.8×6.6×8cm with many internal divisions at the lower part of the left kidney.
translation2.6: Cyst removal surgery by small incisions and a camera was performed with no issues post-operation. She was released with albendazole, anti-parasite medication, and other helpful medication.
translation2.7: With proper use of multiple treatments, Hyadtid disease is curable and the patient can live a healthy life with normal kidney function.

30760828.Title: Anti-microRNA screen uncovers miR-17 family within miR-17~92 cluster as the primary driver of kidney cyst growth

abstract.1: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the leading genetic cause of renal failure.
abstract.2: We have recently shown that inhibiting miR-17~92 is a potential novel therapeutic approach for ADPKD.
abstract.3: However, miR-17~92 is a polycistronic cluster that encodes microRNAs (miRNAs) belonging to the miR-17, miR-18, miR-19 and miR-25 families, and the relative pathogenic contribution of these miRNA families to ADPKD progression is unknown.
abstract.4: Here we performed an in vivo anti-miR screen to identify the miRNA drug targets within the miR-17~92 miRNA cluster.
abstract.5: We designed anti-miRs to individually inhibit miR-17, miR-18, miR-19 or miR-25 families in an orthologous ADPKD model.
abstract.6: Treatment with anti-miRs against the miR-17 family reduced cyst proliferation, kidney-weight-to-body-weight ratio and cyst index.
abstract.7: In contrast, treatment with anti-miRs against the miR-18, 19, or 25 families did not affect cyst growth.
abstract.8: Anti-miR-17 treatment recapitulated the gene expression pattern observed after miR-17~92 genetic deletion and was associated with upregulation of mitochondrial metabolism, suppression of the mTOR pathway, and inhibition of cyst-associated inflammation.
abstract.9: Our results argue against functional cooperation between the various miR-17~92 cluster families in promoting cyst growth, and instead point to miR-17 family as the primary therapeutic target for ADPKD.

translation1.1: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is an inherited condition that causes multiple cysts (growths), usually in the liver, and is the leading genetic cause of kidney failure.
translation1.2: Researchers have shown that slowing or stopping the gene miR-17~92 that is involved in cell growth and development is a possible new therapy to help people with ADPKD.
translation1.3: However, miR-17~92 is a cluster of many cysts that influence microRNAs (miRNAs), which are RNA molecules that regulate genes and how genes make proteins. How these miRNA families contribute to the development and progression of ADPKD is unknown.
translation1.4: In this study, researchers work to identify drugs that will focus on the miRNA.
translation1.5: Researchers designed drugs called anti-miRs to individually stop or slow different types of miRNAs from functioning in a genetic model.
translation1.6: Treatment with anti-miRs against the miR-17 family reduced cyst development, kidney-weight-to-body-weight ratio and size of the cyst.
translation1.7: In contrast, treatment with anti-miRs against the miR-18, 19, or 25 families did not affect cyst growth.
translation1.8: The anti-miR-17 treatment is associated with extending the lifespan of energy from certain cells, stopping or slowing cell growth often found in tumors, and stopping or slowing inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) associated with cysts.
translation1.9: These results argue against functional cooperation between the various miRNA (miR-17~92) cluster families in promoting cyst growth, and instead point to the miR-17 family as the main therapeutic target for ADPKD.

18497742.Title: pVHL and PTEN tumour suppressor proteins cooperatively suppress kidney cyst formation

abstract.1: In patients with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, renal cysts and clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) arise from renal tubular epithelial cells containing biallelic inactivation of the VHL tumour suppressor gene.
abstract.2: However, it is presumed that formation of renal cysts and their conversion to ccRCC involve additional genetic changes at other loci.
abstract.3: Here, we show that cystic lesions in the kidneys of patients with VHL disease also demonstrate activation of the phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) pathway.
abstract.4: Strikingly, combined conditional inactivation of Vhlh and the Pten tumour suppressor gene, which normally antagonises PI3K signalling, in the mouse kidney, elicits cyst formation after short latency, whereas inactivation of either tumour suppressor gene alone failed to produce such a phenotype.
abstract.5: Interestingly, cells lining these cysts frequently lack a primary cilium, a microtubule-based cellular antenna important for suppression of uncontrolled kidney epithelial cell proliferation and cyst formation.
abstract.6: Our results support a model in which the PTEN tumour suppressor protein cooperates with pVHL to suppress cyst development in the kidney.

translation1.1: In patients with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, kidney cysts (growths) and clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC), a type of kidney cancer, come from cells in the kidneys called epithelial cells that inactivate (or turn off) the VHL gene. The VHL gene keeps cells from growing and dividing too fast.
translation1.2: However, it is believed that formation of kidney cysts and their change to the ccRCC kidney cancer involve additional genetic changes at other locations.
translation1.3: This study shows that cystic wounds in the kidneys of patients with VHL disease also show activation of the enzyme called phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) pathway, which regulates key cells processes.
translation1.4: When two genes called Vhlh and Pten that keep cells from growing too fast are turned off, this brings about cyst formation in the kidneys of mice after a short delay. However, inactivation of only one of these genes fails to produce this same effect.
translation1.5: Interestingly, cells lining these cysts frequently lack primary cilium, that acts like a cell antenna and is important for stopping or slowing kidney epithelial cells from multiplying and for stopping cyst formation.
translation1.6: These results support a model in which the PTEN tumor suppressor protein cooperates with pVHL to stop cyst development in the kidney.

17965720.Title: A critical developmental switch defines the kinetics of kidney cyst formation after loss of Pkd1

abstract.1: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is an important cause of end-stage renal disease, for which there is no proven therapy.
abstract.2: Mutations in PKD1 (the gene encoding polycystin-1) are the principal cause of this disease.
abstract.3: The disease begins in utero and is slowly progressive, but it is not known whether cystogenesis is an ongoing process during adult life.
abstract.4: We now show that inactivation of Pkd1 in mice before postnatal day 13 results in severely cystic kidneys within 3 weeks, whereas inactivation at day 14 and later results in cysts only after 5 months.
abstract.5: We found that cellular proliferation was not appreciably higher in cystic specimens than in age-matched controls, but the abrupt change in response to Pkd1 inactivation corresponded to a previously unrecognized brake point during renal growth and significant changes in gene expression.
abstract.6: These findings suggest that the effects of Pkd1 inactivation are defined by a developmental switch that signals the end of the terminal renal maturation process.
abstract.7: Our studies show that Pkd1 regulates tubular morphology in both developing and adult kidney, but the pathologic consequences of inactivation are defined by the organ's developmental status.
abstract.8: These results have important implications for clinical understanding of the disease and therapeutic approaches.

translation1.1: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is an inherited disease that causes many cysts (growths) usually in the kidneys, and is an important cause of end-stage kidney disease, for which there is no proven therapy.
translation1.2: Changes in the PKD1 gene (which creates an active kidney protein) are the main causes of this disease.
translation1.3: The disease begins before birth and develops slowly, but it is not known whether the development and growth of cysts is an ongoing process during adult life.
translation1.4: When the Pkd1 gene is not active in mice within 13 days after birth, this results in many cysts in the kidneys within 3 weeks. However, inactivation (turning off) of Pkd1 at day 14 or later results in cysts only after 5 months.
translation1.5: Researchers find that cell growth and development is not higher in samples of cysts than in comparison groups. However, the sudden change of Pkd1 becoming inactive matched a stopping point of kidney growth that is not previously recognized and matched significant changes in how the gene functions.
translation1.6: These findings suggest that the effects of inactivating the Pkd1 gene are like a switch that signals the end of the end-stage kidney process.
translation1.7: These studies show that Pkd1 regulates changes in both developing kidneys and in adult kidneys, but the process of inactivation are defined by the stage of the organ's development.
translation1.8: These results have important connections to the understanding of the disease and treatment approaches.

translation2.1: An inherited disorder of many kidney cysts (swellings) is an important cause of kidney failure, for which there is no treatment.
translation2.2: Gene sequence changes in PKD1 (a gene active in kidney cells) are the leading cause of the disease.
translation2.3: The disease begins before birth and worsens slowly, but it is not known if creation of cysts is an ongoing process during adult life.
translation2.4: We show that silencing of Pkd1 in mice younger than 13 days leads to severely cystic kidneys within 3 weeks. Silencing at day 14 or later results in cysts only after 4 months.
translation2.5: We found that cell growth is not higher in those with cysts versus similar-age healthy animals, but the sudden change in response to Pkd1 silencing was linked to a new brake point during kidney growth and changes in gene expression.
translation2.6: The effects of Pkd1 silencing may be defined by a developmental switch that signals the end of the final kidney maturation process.
translation2.7: Pkd1 monitors development of tubes in growing and adult kidneys, but the disease-related effects of silencing are defined by the organ's developmental status.
translation2.8: These results influence clinical understanding of the disease and treatment options.

34486178.Title: Polycystin-1 dependent regulation of polycystin-2 via GRP94, a member of HSP90 family that resides in the endoplasmic reticulum

abstract.1: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is a common inherited renal disorder that results from mutations in either PKD1 or PKD2, encoding polycystin-1 (PC1) and polycystin-2 (PC2), respectively.
abstract.2: Downregulation or overexpression of PKD1 or PKD2 in mouse models results in renal cyst formation, suggesting that the quantity of PC1 and PC2 needs to be maintained within a tight functional window to prevent cystogenesis.
abstract.3: Here we show that enhanced PC2 expression is a common feature of PKD1 mutant tissues, in part due to an increase in Pkd2 mRNA.
abstract.4: However, our data also suggest that more effective protein folding contributes to the augmented levels of PC2.
abstract.5: We demonstrate that the unfolded protein response is activated in Pkd1 knockout kidneys and in Pkd1 mutant cells and that this is coupled with increased levels of GRP94, an endoplasmic reticulum protein that is a member of the HSP90 family of chaperones.
abstract.6: GRP94 was found to physically interact with PC2 and depletion or chemical inhibition of GRP94 led to a decrease in PC2, suggesting that GRP94 serves as its chaperone.
abstract.7: Moreover, GRP94 is acetylated and binds to histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6), a known deacetylase and activator of HSP90 proteins.
abstract.8: Inhibition of HDAC6 decreased PC2 suggesting that HDAC6 and GRP94 work together to regulate PC2 levels.
abstract.9: Lastly, we showed that inhibition of GRP94 prevents cAMP-induced cyst formation in vitro.
abstract.10: Taken together our data uncovered a novel HDAC6-GRP94-related axis that likely participates in maintaining elevated PC2 levels in Pkd1 mutant cells.

translation1.1: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is a common inherited kidney disorder that causes many cysts (growths) and is caused by changes in either the PKD1 or PKD2 genes. These genes are used to make the proteins polycystin-1 (PC1) and polycystin-2 (PC2), which regulate cells growth, cell movement, and interaction with other cells.
translation1.2: In experiments with mice, when the PKD1 or PKD2 genes are less sensitive to other cells  or make too many proteins, it may lead to cysts forming in the kidneys. This suggests that the number of PC1 and PC2 proteins needs to be stable within a brief time period to prevent the formation of cysts.
translation1.3: In this study, researchers show that more cells and proteins from PC2 is a common feature of PKD1 changes, in part because of an increase in PKD2.
translation1.4: However, this data also suggests that more effective protein folding, which is when a protein changes from a long chain to a functional shape, contributes to more levels of PC2 proteins.
translation1.5: Researchers show that the unfolded protein response is active in the kidneys without Pkd1 and in Pkd1 mutant (changed) cells. This effect is in addition to increases in the number of an endoplasmic reticulum protein, called GRP94. The endoplasmic reticulum helps create and package proteins in cells.
translation1.6: GRP94 is found to physically interact with PC2, and reducing or slowing GRP94 can lead to a decrease in PC2, suggesting that GRP94 serves as its chaperone (plays a part in the folding of itself as a protein).
translation1.7: Also, GRP94 is acetylated (modified structurally) and attaches to histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6), an enzyme that can control several important proteins and activate other proteins.
translation1.8: Slowing or stopping HDAC6 decreases PC2 proteins, suggesting that HDAC6 and GRP94 work together to regulate PC2 levels.
translation1.9: Lastly, researchers show that the slowing of GRP94 prevents the formation of cysts in laboratory tests.
translation1.10: Together, these data uncover a new HDAC6-GRP94-related point that likely participates in maintaining higher PC2 levels in Pkd1 mutant cells.

34155062.Title: TWEAK Signaling Pathway Blockade Slows Cyst Growth and Disease Progression in Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease

abstract.1: Background: In autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), cyst development and enlargement lead to ESKD.
abstract.2: Macrophage recruitment and interstitial inflammation promote cyst growth.
abstract.3: TWEAK is a TNF superfamily (TNFSF) cytokine that regulates inflammatory responses, cell proliferation, and cell death, and its receptor Fn14 (TNFRSF12a) is expressed in macrophage and nephron epithelia.
abstract.4: Methods: To evaluate the role of the TWEAK signaling pathway in cystic disease, we evaluated Fn14 expression in human and in an orthologous murine model of ADPKD.
abstract.5: We also explored the cystic response to TWEAK signaling pathway activation and inhibition by peritoneal injection.
abstract.6: Results: Meta-analysis of published animal-model data of cystic disease reveals mRNA upregulation of several components of the TWEAK signaling pathway.
abstract.7: We also observed that TWEAK and Fn14 were overexpressed in mouse ADPKD kidney cysts, and TWEAK was significantly high in urine and cystic fluid from patients with ADPKD.
abstract.8: TWEAK administration induced cystogenesis and increased cystic growth, worsening the phenotype in a murine ADPKD model.
abstract.9: Anti-TWEAK antibodies significantly slowed the progression of ADPKD, preserved renal function, and improved survival.
abstract.10: Furthermore, the anti-TWEAK cystogenesis reduction is related to decreased cell proliferation-related MAPK signaling, decreased NF-κB pathway activation, a slight reduction of fibrosis and apoptosis, and an indirect decrease in macrophage recruitment.
abstract.11: Conclusions: This study identifies the TWEAK signaling pathway as a new disease mechanism involved in cystogenesis and cystic growth and may lead to a new therapeutic approach in ADPKD.

translation1.1: In autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), an inherited disorder that causes cysts (growths) in the kidneys, cyst development and enlargement lead to end-stage kidney disease.
translation1.2: The recruitment of macrophage cells (a type of white blood cell that surrounds and kills microorganisms, removes dead cells, and activates other immune system cells) and spaces between the kidney becoming swollen are found to promote cyst growth.
translation1.3: TWEAK is a type of cytokine (chemical messenger) that regulates inflammatory (infection-fighting) responses, cell growth and division, and cell death. Its receptor Fn14 (TNFRSF12a) that sends and receives signals is expressed in macrophages and a layer of outer lining cells in the kidney called nephron epithelia.
translation1.4: To evaluate how the TWEAK cytokine signaling plays a role in cystic disease, researchers evaluate the Fn14 gene development in humans and in experiments with animals of ADPKD.
translation1.5: Researchers also looked at the response from cysts to the activation of TWEAK signaling as well as its limited signaling by injections.
translation1.6: Data published from animal studies of cystic disease show increases in mRNA (genetic strands with instructions to build proteins) of several parts of the TWEAK signaling pathway.
translation1.7: Researchers also found that too many TWEAK and Fn14 gene-derived molecules are in made in mouse ADPKD kidney cysts, and TWEAK is very high in the urine and cystic fluid from patients with ADPKD.
translation1.8: TWEAK use started formation of cysts and increased cystic growth, worsening physical traits in an animal ADPKD model.
translation1.9: Anti-TWEAK antibodies (a protein used by the immune system to identify and neutralize foreign objects such as harmful bacteria and viruses) significantly slowed the progression of ADPKD, protected kidney function, and improved survival.
translation1.10: Additionally, the reduction of cyst formation is related to decreased cell growth and a decrease in macrophage recruitment.
translation1.11: In conclusion, this study identifies the TWEAK signaling pathway as a new disease process involved in the growth and formation of many cysts and may lead to a new treatment approach in ADPKD.

33826787.Title: Quinomycin A reduces cyst progression in polycystic kidney disease

abstract.1: Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a genetic disorder characterized by aberrant renal epithelial cell proliferation and formation and progressive growth of numerous fluid-filled cysts within the kidneys.
abstract.2: Previously, we showed that there is elevated Notch signaling compared to normal renal epithelial cells and that Notch signaling contributes to the proliferation of cystic cells.
abstract.3: Quinomycin A, a bis-intercalator peptide, has previously been shown to target the Notch signaling pathway and inhibit tumor growth in cancer.
abstract.4: Here, we show that Quinomycin A decreased cell proliferation and cyst growth of human ADPKD cyst epithelial cells cultured within a 3D collagen gel.
abstract.5: Treatment with Quinomycin A reduced kidney weight to body weight ratio and decreased renal cystic area and fibrosis in Pkd1RC/RC ; Pkd2+/- mice, an orthologous PKD mouse model.
abstract.6: This was accompanied by reduced expression of Notch pathway proteins, RBPjk and HeyL and cell proliferation in kidneys of PKD mice.
abstract.7: Quinomycin A treatments also normalized cilia length of cyst epithelial cells derived from the collecting ducts.
abstract.8: This is the first study to demonstrate that Quinomycin A effectively inhibits PKD progression and suggests that Quinomycin A has potential therapeutic value for PKD patients.

translation1.1: Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a genetic disorder that causes abnormal growth and formation of kidney epithelial cells, which are important cells for kidney function, and growth of many cysts (swellings) filled with fluid within the kidneys.
translation1.2: Previous studies show that, when compared to epithelial cells, there is an increase in cell signaling called Notch signaling that allows direct cell to cell communication. This Notch signaling contributes to the growth and division of cystic cells (cells that cluster together and form a cyst).
translation1.3: Quinomycin A is a type of antibiotic (bacteria-fighting medication), has previously shown to target the Notch signaling process, and slow or stop tumor growth in cancer.
translation1.4: In this study, researchers show that quinomycin A decreases cell development and cyst growth of cyst epithelial cells taken from humans with inherited PKD and analyzed in a lab.
translation1.5: Treatment with quinomycin A reduces kidney weight to body weight ratio and decreases the size of the kidney cysts and the development of fibrous tissues that can impact the lungs.
translation1.6: Also, there is a reduced number of proteins that develop from the Notch pathway.
translation1.7: Quinomycin A treatments also normalized the length of cilia, hairlike vibrating structures found in large numbers on the surface of cyst epithelial cells.
translation1.8: This is the first study to demonstrate that Quinomycin A effectively slows or stops polycystic kidney disease (PKD) progression and suggests that Quinomycin A is a possible therapy for PKD patients.

translation2.1: Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is an inherited disorder of abnormal kidney cell growth and development of many fluid-filled cysts or swellings in the kidneys.
translation2.2: Before, we showed there is increased signaling of a specific cell pathway (Notch) compared to normal kidney cells. This Notch signaling contributes to cystic cell growth.
translation2.3: Quinomycin A, a specific protein segment, has been shown to target the Notch cell signaling pathway and block tumor growth in cancer.
translation2.4: Here, we show that Quinomycin A decreased cell and cyst growth of human, diseased cyst cells created in an isolated environment.
translation2.5: Treatment with Quinomycin A reduced kidney weight to body weight ratio and reduced kidney cystic area and scarred tissue in mice with PKD.
translation2.6: Reduced amounts of proteins of the Notch cell signaling patway, RBPjk and HeyL, and reduced cell growth in kidneys of PKD mice also occured with the other effects.
translation2.7: Quinomycin A also controlled hairlike structions on cyst cells from kidney tubes.
translation2.8: This is the first study to show that Quinomycin A blocks PDK progression and suggests that Quinomycin A has beneficial value for PKD patients.

33549515.Title: Up-Regulation of DNA Damage Response Signaling in Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease

abstract.1: DNA damage and alterations in DNA damage response (DDR) signaling could be one of the molecular mechanisms mediating focal kidney cyst formation in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).
abstract.2: The aim of this study was to test the hypothesis that markers of DNA damage and DDR signaling are increased in human and experimental ADPKD.
abstract.3: In the human ADPKD transcriptome, the number of up-regulated DDR-related genes was increased by 16.6-fold compared with that in normal kidney, and by 2.5-fold in cystic compared with that in minimally cystic tissue (P < 0.0001).
abstract.4: In end-stage human ADPKD tissue, γ-H2A histone family member X (H2AX), phosphorylated ataxia telangiectasia and radiation-sensitive mutant 3 (Rad3)-related (pATR), and phosphorylated ataxia telangiectasia mutated (pATM) localized to cystic kidney epithelial cells.
abstract.5: In vitro, pATR and pATM were also constitutively increased in human ADPKD tubular cells (WT 9-7 and 9-12) compared with control (HK-2).
abstract.6: In addition, extrinsic oxidative DNA damage by hydrogen peroxide augmented γ-H2AX and cell survival in human ADPKD cells, and exacerbated cyst growth in the three-dimensional Madin-Darby canine kidney cyst model.
abstract.7: In contrast, DDR-related gene expression was only transiently increased on postnatal day 0 in Pkd1RC/RC mice, and not altered at later time points up to 12 months of age.
abstract.8: In conclusion, DDR signaling is dysregulated in human ADPKD and during the early phases of murine ADPKD.
abstract.9: The constitutive expression of the DDR pathway in ADPKD may promote survival of PKD1-mutated cells and contribute to kidney cyst growth.
