translation2.11: We have no confidence in the results regarding the rank order of treatments in this review (very low-quality evidence), but we report a summary of results for some comparisons of treatments compared with standard gauze.
translation2.12: We present here only results from evidence we did not consdier to be very low quality, but the reported results should be interpreted while knowing of the very low quality regarding the whole study network.
translation2.13: It is not clear if treatments with special protein-breakdown dressings increase the probability of pressure ulcer healing compared with standard gauze.
translation2.14: 102 more people were healed with special protein-breakdown dressings per 1000 people than those with standard gauze alone.
translation2.15: It is unclear if any of the other treatments examined increase the probability of healing compared with standard gauze (low-quality evidence). Some showed metrics consistent with a clinically important benefit and harm. Others had a high risk of bias and unreliability.
translation2.16: A large analysis of data from 39 studies (examining 21 dressings and skin-level agents for pressure ulcers) is scattered. The evidence is also of low or very low quality (due to risk of bias and unreliability).
translation2.17: Therefore, we are unable to determine which dressings or skin-level agents are best to heal pressure ulcers. It is unclear whether the treatments are more effective than standard gauze.
translation2.18: More research is needed to tell if certain dressings or skin-level agents improve the chance of healing for pressure ulcers.
translation2.19: This analysis is uninformative regarding which treatments may best be included in a large trial. It may that research is focused on prevention, leaving clinicians to decide which treatment to use based on wound symptoms, clinical experience, patient preference and cost.

34414933.Title: Effect of Ma Yinglong Shexiang hemorrhoids cream combined with pearl powder on the pain and complications of severe pressure ulcer patients

abstract.1: Objective: The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of Ma Yinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoids Cream combined with pearl powder on pain and complications in patients with severe pressure ulcers.
abstract.2: Methods: One hundred seventeen patients with severe pressure ulcers hospitalized and treated in our hospital (January 2019--December 2019) were divided into Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream Group (MY Group), Pearl Powder Group (PP Group), and combination with Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder Group (MP group), 39 patients in each group.
abstract.3: There was no significant difference in the general data of patients in MY group, PP group, and MP group.
abstract.4: By analyzing the differences in clinical efficacy, secondary effects, scar incidence, pain, and clinical indicators of patients in the MY group, PP group, and MP group, the effects of Mayinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoid Cream combined with pearl powder in the treatment of pain and complications in patients with severe pressure ulcers were explored.
abstract.5: Results: After treatment, compared with the MY group and the PP group, the MP group had a higher clinical efficacy than the MY group and the PP group.
abstract.6: Compared with MY group and PP group, the healing time, dressing change times, and dressing change time of MP group were better than MY group (P < .05).
abstract.7: After treatment, the VAS score and incidence of secondary effects of the MP group was significantly lower than that of the MY group and PP group (P < .05).
abstract.8: The incidence and area of scar formation in the MP group were lower than those in the MY group and the PP group (P < .05).
abstract.9: Conclusion: Compared with Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream or Pearl Powder, combination of Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder are more effective in treating severe pressure ulcer patients, and can significantly reduce the pain in the affected area and reduce the occurrence of complications.

translation1.1: We aimed to study the effect of Ma Yinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoids Cream combined with pearl powder on pain and side effects in patients with serious bedsores.
translation1.2: We divided 117 patients hospitalized with serious bedsores in our hospital (January 2019-December 2019) into the Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream Group (MY Group), Pearl Powder Group (PP Group), and combination with Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder Group (MP group), 39 patients in each group.
translation1.3: Patients in the three groups generally were similar.
translation1.4: We looked at the effects of Mayinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoid Cream combined with pearl powder in the treatment of pain and side effects in patients with serious bedsores based on differences in how well a treatment works, side effects, scar occurrence, pain, and quality of care of patients in the MY, PP, and MP groups.
translation1.5: The MP group treatment worked better than the MY and PP groups.
translation1.6: The MP group had better healing time and dressing change times than the MY group.
translation1.7: The MP group had a better score on a common scoring tool for pain and fewer side effects than the MY and PP groups.
translation1.8: The MP group had less occurrence of scars and smaller scar area than the MY and PP groups.
translation1.9: A combination of Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder worked better than either treatment by itself in treating severe bedsore patients, and can significantly reduce pain in the affected area and side effects.

34692658.Title: Zwitterionic Hydrogel Activates Autophagy to Promote Extracellular Matrix Remodeling for Improved Pressure Ulcer Healing

abstract.1: Pressure ulcer (PU) is a worldwide problem that is hard to heal because of its prolonged inflammatory response and impaired ECM deposition caused by local hypoxia and repeated ischemia/reperfusion.
abstract.2: Our previous study discovered that the non-fouling zwitterionic sulfated poly (sulfobetaine methacrylate) (SBMA) hydrogel can improve PU healing with rapid ECM rebuilding.
abstract.3: However, the mechanism of the SBMA hydrogel in promoting ECM rebuilding is unclear.
abstract.4: Therefore, in this work, the impact of the SBMA hydrogel on ECM reconstruction is comprehensively studied, and the underlying mechanism is intensively investigated in a rat PU model.
abstract.5: The in vivo data demonstrate that compared to the PEG hydrogel, the SBMA hydrogel enhances the ECM remolding by the upregulation of fibronectin and laminin expression as well as the inhibition of MMP-2.
abstract.6: Further investigation reveals that the decreased MMP-2 expression of zwitterionic SBMA hydrogel treatment is due to the activation of autophagy through the inhibited PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway and reduced inflammation.
abstract.7: The association of autophagy with ECM remodeling may provide a way in guiding the design of biomaterial-based wound dressing for chronic wound repair.

translation1.1: Bedsores are a worldwide problem that is hard to heal because it causes long-lasting inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) and harms the extracellular matrix (ECM; secreted by cells and surrounds cells in tissues) from not enough oxygen and blood flow.
translation1.2: The study we did before found that non-fouling zwitterionic (inner salts to which proteins and bacteria cannot stick) sulfated poly (sulfobetaine methacrylate) (SBMA) hydrogel can improve bedsore healing and quickly rebuild ECM.
translation1.3: However, scientists are unsure how SBMA hydrogel rebuilds ECM.
translation1.4: In this study, we look at how SBMA hydrogel rebuilds ECM using a rat bedsore model.
translation1.5: SMBA hydrogel helps remodel ECM better than PEG hydrogel, another bedsore treatment.
translation1.7: The relationship between autophagy (cleaning out of damaged cells) with ECM remodeling may influence the design of wound dressings with substances that interact with biological systems for long-term wound repair.

34408570.Title: Evaluation of the therapeutic efficacy of active specialistic medical dressings in the treatment of decubitus

abstract.1: Introduction: Treatment of decubitus ulcers is a grave medical problem.
abstract.2: In many cases, it is difficult to cure a pressure ulcer, especially when it is deep and extensive, and prognosis is usually unfavourable.
abstract.3: Treatment of decubitus ulcers requires new specialist dressings, which play an important role in the healing process.
abstract.4: Aim: To evaluate therapeutic efficacy of active specialist medical dressings in the treatment of decubitus.
abstract.5: Material and methods: Research involved 40 patients - 18 (45%) women and 22 (55%) men, suffering from decubitus ulcers of different size and depth, localized in the sacral region, lasting from 1.5 to 30 months.
abstract.6: Patients were randomly assigned to two research groups (20 people each), were treated for 4 weeks with 2 different specialist dressings.
abstract.7: ATRAUMAN Ag, which contains silver ions, was used in the first group, while paraffin gauze of BACTIGRAS type was used in the second group.
abstract.8: An assessment of pressure ulcers' healing progress was done with a planimetric method, which evaluates the wound surface area.
abstract.9: Results: The analysis results showed a significant statistical decrease in an average decubitus ulcer surface area in both research groups: in the first group by 60.2% (p = 0.001), and in the second group by 32.95% (p < 0.001), which speaks in favour of dressings with silver ions as having better therapeutic effectiveness.
abstract.10: Conclusions: Using specialist dressings results in a significant decrease in the decubitus ulcer surface area, depending on the type of dressing and active substances contained within, while silver ions support curative effectiveness of the dressing used.

translation1.1: Treatment of bedsores is a serious medical problem.
translation1.2: Often, a bedsore is hard to cure, especially when it is deep and covers a large area, and usually has a poor prognosis (plan for recovery).
translation1.3: Treating bedsores requires specialized dressings, which play an important role in the healing process.
translation1.4: We aim to rate how well active specialized dressings, which promote healing by keeping the wound moist, work to treat bedsores.
translation1.5: We looked at 40 patients, 18 (45%) women and 22 (55%) men, with bedsores differing in size and depth, located near the bottom of the spine, lasting from 1.5 to 3.0 months.
translation1.6: We randomly assigned patients to two groups of 20 people each and treated them with two different specialist dressings for 4 weeks.
translation1.7: We used ATRAUMAN ag, which contains silver ions, in the first group and paraffin (waxy) gauze of BACTIGRAS type in the second group.
translation1.8: We measured the progress of bedsore healing by measuring the wound's boundaries, which calculates the surface area.
translation1.9: Results showed average bedsore surface area significantly decreased in the first group by 60.2% and in the second group by 32.95%, suggesting dressings with silver ions worked better.
translation1.10: We conclude that specialist dressings significantly decrease bedsore surface area, and dressings with silver ions work better than those without.

translation2.1: Treating decubitus ulcers (bedsores) is a serious medical problem.
translation2.2: In many cases, it is difficult to cure a pressure ulcer or bedsore, especially when it is deep and extensive. Recovery is usually poor.
translation2.3: Treating bedsores requires new specialized dressings (e.g., ointments, gauze), which are important for healing.
translation2.4: We aim to evaluate the success of active specialized medical dressings for treating bedsores.
translation2.5: Research included 40 patients - 18 (45% women) and 22 (55%) men, suffering from bedsores of various size and depth, in the lower back, lasting from 1.5 to 30 months.
translation2.6: Patients were randomly split to two groups (20 people each) and treated for 4 weeks with either ATRAUMAN Ag, a dressing with silver, or gauze with paraffin (a waxy substance commonly used for coating and sealing candles and rubbers) from BACTIGRAS.
translation2.7: Measuring pressure ulcer healing was done by measuring the wound surface area.
translation2.8: The results showed a decrease in average bedsore area in both treatment groups: in the first group by 60.2% and in the second group by 32.95%, which speaks in favour of dressings with silver as better treatments.
translation2.9: Using specialized dressings leads to a decrease in bedsore area, depending on the dressing type and substances contained within it. Silver supports the healing properties of the dressing used.

46.question: How does cystic fibrosis affect cell membrane?

33805605.Title: Lumacaftor and Matrine: Possible Therapeutic Combination to Counteract the Inflammatory Process in Cystic Fibrosis

abstract.1: Cystic fibrosis is a monogenic, autosomal, recessive disease characterized by an alteration of chloride transport caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene.
abstract.2: The loss of Phe residue in position 508 (ΔF508-CFTR) causes an incorrect folding of the protein causing its degradation and electrolyte imbalance.
abstract.3: CF patients are extremely predisposed to the development of a chronic inflammatory process of the bronchopulmonary system.
abstract.4: When the cells of a tissue are damaged, the immune cells are activated and trigger the production of free radicals, provoking an inflammatory process.
abstract.5: In addition to routine therapies, today drugs called correctors are available for mutations such as ΔF508-CFTR as well as for others less frequent ones.
abstract.6: These active molecules are supposed to facilitate the maturation of the mutant CFTR protein, allowing it to reach the apical membrane of the epithelial cell.
abstract.7: Matrine induces ΔF508-CFTR release from the endoplasmic reticulum to cell cytosol and its localization on the cell membrane.
abstract.8: We now have evidence that Matrine and Lumacaftor not only restore the transport of mutant CFTR protein, but probably also counteract the inflammatory process by improving the course of the disease.

translation1.1: Cystic fibrosis is a deadly disease inherited from both parents characterized by changes in a compound (chloride) movement caused by genetic changes in the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator (CFTR) gene.
translation1.2: One gene change, ΔF508-CFTR, causes the resulting protein the gene creates to fold incorrectly, which leads to its destruction and mineral imbalance.
translation1.3: CF patients are at very high risk of developing long-term inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) of part of the lungs.
translation1.4: When tissue cells are damaged, immune cells are stimulated and produce unstable molecules, prompting the immune system to defend the body.
translation1.5: In addition to normal treatments, drugs called correctors are available for changes like ΔF508-CFTR and other less common changes.
translation1.6: Correctors help the CFTR protein form the right shape to move to the surface of the epithelial cell (cell that covers outer surface of the internal organs).
translation1.7: Matrine, a drug, starts ΔF508-CFTR release from the cell's transportation system through the cell liquid to the surface.
translation1.8: We now have proof that Matrine and Lumacaftor, another drug, not only allow the changed CFTR to move, but probably neutralize inflammation by improving the course of the disease.

33331662.Title: Corrector therapies (with or without potentiators) for people with cystic fibrosis with class II CFTR gene variants (most commonly F508del)

abstract.1: Background: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a common life-shortening genetic condition caused by a variant in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein.
abstract.2: A class II CFTR variant F508del (found in up to 90% of people with CF (pwCF)) is the commonest CF-causing variant.
abstract.3: The faulty protein is degraded before reaching the cell membrane, where it needs to be to effect transepithelial salt transport.
abstract.4: The F508del variant lacks meaningful CFTR function and corrective therapy could benefit many pwCF.
abstract.5: Therapies in this review include single correctors and any combination of correctors and potentiators.

translation1.1: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a common life-shortening inherited condition caused by a change in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein.
translation1.2: The most common change, F508del, is a protein processing change, and up to 90% of people with CF have this change.
translation1.3: The faulty protein is destroyed before reaching the cell membrane, where it needs to be to move salt across epithelial cells (cells that cover outer surface of the internal organs).
translation1.4: The F508del change doesn't work properly and treatment to fix this could help many people with CF.
translation1.5: We review single correctors, which help the CFTR protein form the right shape to move to the cell surface, and any combination of correctors and potentiators, which are CFTR modulators (influencers) that hold the gate to the CFTR channel open so chloride can flow through the cell membrane.

33038767.Title: Glued in lipids: Lipointoxication in cystic fibrosis

abstract.1: Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the CF transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene, which encodes a chloride channel located at the apical surface of epithelial cells.
abstract.2: Unsaturated Fatty Acid (UFA) deficiency has been a persistent observation in tissues from patients with CF.
abstract.3: However, the impacts of such deficiencies on the etiology of the disease have been the object of intense debates.
abstract.4: The aim of the present review is first to highlight the general consensus on fatty acid dysregulations that emerges from, sometimes apparently contradictory, studies.
abstract.5: In a second step, a unifying mechanism for the potential impacts of these fatty acid dysregulations in CF cells, based on alterations of membrane biophysical properties (known as lipointoxication), is proposed.
abstract.6: Finally, the contribution of lipointoxication to the progression of the CF disease and how it could affect the efficacy of current treatments is also discussed.

translation1.1: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a disease inherited from both parents caused by genetic changes in the CF transmembrane conductance Regulator (CFTR) gene, which produces a compound (chloride) channel at the surface of epithelial cells (cells that cover outer surface of the internal organs).
translation1.2: Not enough Unsaturated Fatty Acid (UFA) has continually been seen in CF patients.
translation1.3: Scientists do not agree on the role of not enough UFA in causing CF.
translation1.4: We aim to discuss current beliefs on improper functioning of UFAs that comes from studies that sometime disagree.
translation1.5: Next, we suggest a way in which possible improper functioning of UFAs impacts CF cells, based on changes in the biological and physical characteristics of the cell membrane (known as lipointoxication).
translation1.6: Finally, we discuss how lipointoxication might play a role in the progression of CF disease and how it could affect how well current treatments work.

translation2.1: Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is an inherited disease, which leads to mucus buildup in many organs, caused by mutations in a specific gene, which encodes a channel located at the surface of boundary cells.
translation2.2: Lack of Unsaturated Fatty Acid (UFA), a certain form of fat, has been a common observation for patients with CF.
translation2.3: However, the effects of such deficiencies on the causes of the disease are debated.
translation2.4: This review aims to highlight the general consensus on fatty acid impairment that comes from, sometimes contradictory, studies.
translation2.5: In a second step, how the possible effects of this fatty acid impairment occur in CF cells, based on changes in cell boundary properties, is explored.
translation2.6: Finally, how fat toxicity contribtues to progression of the CF disease and affects the success of current treatments is discussed.

32666337.Title: Sphingolipids and plasma membrane hydrolases in human primary bronchial cells during differentiation and their altered patterns in cystic fibrosis

abstract.1: Human primary bronchial epithelial cells differentiated in vitro represent a valuable tool to study lung diseases such as cystic fibrosis (CF), an inherited disorder caused by mutations in the gene coding for the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator.
abstract.2: In CF, sphingolipids, a ubiquitous class of bioactive lipids mainly associated with the outer layer of the plasma membrane, seem to play a crucial role in the establishment of the severe lung complications.
abstract.3: Nevertheless, no information on the involvement of sphingolipids and their metabolism in the differentiation of primary bronchial epithelial cells are available so far.
abstract.4: Here we show that ceramide and globotriaosylceramide increased during cell differentiation, whereas glucosylceramide and gangliosides content decreased.
abstract.5: In addition, we found that apical plasma membrane of differentiated bronchial cells is characterized by a higher content of sphingolipids in comparison to the other cell membranes and that activity of sphingolipids catabolic enzymes associated with this membrane results altered with respect to the total cell activities.
abstract.6: In particular, the apical membrane of CF cells was characterized by high levels of ceramide and glucosylceramide, known to have proinflammatory activity.
abstract.7: On this basis, our data further support the role of sphingolipids in the onset of CF lung pathology.

translation1.1: Cells on the surface of the bronchi (two tubes that carry air to your lungs) extracted from humans and grown in the lab are a valuable tool to study lung disease such as cystic fibrosis (CF), an inherited disease caused by a change in the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator (CFTR) protein which helps transport chloride.
translation1.2: In CF, sphingolipids, a common type of lipids found in cell surroundings, seem to play an important role in the onset of serious lung problems.
translation1.3: Yet information is lacking on the involvement of sphingolipids and their metabolism (digestion) in the process by which cells on the surface of the bronchi change their type.
translation1.4: Two types of sphingolipids increased and two decreased as dividing cells changed type.
translation1.5: Cells on the surface of the bronchi have more sphingolipids compared to surfaces of other cells.
translation1.6: The surface of CF cells had high levels of two sphingolipids, known to promote inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection).
translation1.7: Our results support the role of sphingolipids in the onset of CF lung problems.

32637102.Title: Epithelial vectorial ion transport in cystic fibrosis: Dysfunction, measurement, and pharmacotherapy to target the primary deficit

abstract.1: Cystic fibrosis patients display multi-organ system dysfunction (e.g. pancreas, gastrointestinal tract, and lung) with pathogenesis linked to a failure of Cl- secretion from the epithelial surfaces of these organs.
abstract.2: If unmanaged, organ dysfunction starts early and patients experience chronic respiratory infection with reduced lung function and a failure to thrive due to gastrointestinal malabsorption.
abstract.3: Early mortality is typically caused by respiratory failure.
abstract.4: In the past 40 years of newborn screening and improved disease management have driven the median survival up from the mid-teens to 43-53, with most of that improvement coming from earlier and more aggressive management of the symptoms.
abstract.5: In the last decade, promising pharmacotherapies have been developed for the correction of the underlying epithelial dysfunction, namely, Cl- secretion.
abstract.6: A new generation of systemic drugs target the mutated Cl- channels in cystic fibrosis patients and allow trafficking of the immature mutated protein to the cell membrane (correctors), restore function to the channel once in situ (potentiators), or increase protein levels in the cells (amplifiers).
abstract.7: Restoration of channel function prior to symptom development has the potential to significantly change the trajectory of disease progression and their evidence suggests that a modest restoration of Cl- secretion may delay disease progression by decades.
abstract.8: In this article, we review epithelial vectorial ion and fluid transport, its quantification and measurement as a marker for cystic fibrosis ion transport dysfunction, and highlight some of the recent therapies targeted at the dysfunctional ion transport of cystic fibrosis.

translation1.1: People with cystic fibrosis have organs that do not function correctly (e.g., pancreas, digestive system, and lung) linked to not enough CI- (chloride) production and release from epithelial cells (cells that cover outer surface of the internal organs).
translation1.2: If not treated, organs quickly stop working and patients have long-term respiratory infection with decreased lung function and a decline in health from poor absorption of food.
translation1.3: Early death usually happens when lungs can't get enough oxygen into the blood.
translation1.4: The past 40 years of newborn checks and better ways to treat disease have increased the age that half of patients are still alive from the mid-teens to 43-53, with most of the increase due to earlier and more aggressive management of the symptoms.
translation1.5: In the last 10 years, drugs have been made to correct underlying problems in epithelial cells, mainly, CI- production and release.
translation1.6: New drugs for cystic fibrosis patients that work throughout the body target the changed atom (Cl-; chloride) channels and help the changed protein to move to the cell surface (correctors), hold the gate to the channel open so chloride can flow through the cell membrane (potentiators), or increase protein levels in the cells (amplifiers).
translation1.7: Restoring channel function before symptoms develop could change the course of the disease and a small repair of Cl- production and release may delay disease worsening by decades.
translation1.8: We look at movement of ions (charged atoms) and fluids in epithelial cells, how to count and measure this movement as a sign of cystic fibrosis transport problems, and discuss recent treatments for cystic fibrosis transport problems.

31401006.Title: The role of endothelial cells in cystic fibrosis

abstract.1: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disease caused by the loss of function of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein which primarily acts as a chloride channel.
abstract.2: CFTR has mainly been studied in epithelial cells although it is also functional and expressed in other cell types including endothelial cells.
abstract.3: The present review summarizes current knowledge on the role of the endothelium in CF.
abstract.4: More specifically, this review highlights the role of endothelial cells in CF in acting as a semipermeable barrier, as a key regulator of angiogenesis, coagulation, the vascular tone and the inflammatory responses.
abstract.5: It could contribute to different aspects of the disease including cardiovascular symptoms, excessive blood vessel formation, pulmonary and portal hypertension and CF-related diabetes.
abstract.6: Despite the important role of vascular endothelium in many biological processes, it has largely been under investigated in CF.

translation1.1: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a disease inherited from both parents caused when the CF transmembrane conductance Regulator (CFTR) protein no longer functions, which acts as a compound (chloride) channel.
translation1.2: Scientists have mostly studied CFTR in epithelial cells (cells that cover outer surface of the internal organs) although it also works and is seen in other cell types including endothelial cells (cells that cover the blood vessel inner surface).
translation1.3: This review summarizes what is known on the role of endothelium in CF.
translation1.4: We summarize the role of endothelial cells in CF in acting as a barrier that allows only some things to pass through, partly controlling formation of new blood vessels, clotting, blood vessel constriction, and inflammation.
translation1.5: Endothelial cells could play a role in different parts of the disease including heart symptoms, formation of too many blood vessels, two kinds of high blood pressure and CF-related diabetes.
translation1.6: Vascular endothelium (the inner cellular lining of arteries, veins, and capillaries) is important to many processes in the body, but it has not been studied enough in CF.

translation2.1: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an inherited disease caused by loss of function of a special cell boundary channel and leads to mucus buildup in many organs.
translation2.2: This special cell boundary channel has been studied in boundary cells. However, it is also present in other cell types like endothelial cells (cells that line blood vessels and empty areas of the body).
translation2.3: This review article summarizes current knowledge on the role of the endothelium in CF.
translation2.4: More specifically, this review highlights how endothelial cells in CF act as a barrier which regulates blood vessel creation, blood clotting, vessel activity, and inflammation.
translation2.5: It could contribute to different aspects of the disease like heart-related symptoms, excessive blood vessel formation, lung and vein-related high blood pressure and CF-related diabetes.
translation2.6: Despite the important role of blood vessel boundary cells in many biological processes, it has largely been under-investigated in CF.

30825185.Title: Small molecule-facilitated anion transporters in cells for a novel therapeutic approach to cystic fibrosis

abstract.1: Background and purpose: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a lethal autosomal recessive genetic disease that originates from the defective function of the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein, a cAMP-dependent anion channel involved in fluid transport across epithelium.
abstract.2: Because small synthetic transmembrane anion transporters (anionophores) can replace the biological anion transport mechanisms, independent of genetic mutations in the CFTR, such anionophores are candidates as new potential treatments for CF.
abstract.3: Experimental approach: In order to assess their effects on cell physiology, we have analysed the transport properties of five anionophore compounds, three prodigiosines and two tambjamines.
abstract.4: Chloride efflux was measured in large uni-lamellar vesicles and in HEK293 cells with chloride-sensitive electrodes.
abstract.5: Iodide influx was evaluated in FRT cells transfected with iodide-sensitive YFP.
abstract.6: Transport of bicarbonate was assessed by changes of pH after a NH4 + pre-pulse using the BCECF fluorescent probe.
abstract.7: Assays were also carried out in FRT cells permanently transfected with wild type and mutant human CFTR.
abstract.8: Key results: All studied compounds are capable of transporting halides and bicarbonate across the cell membrane, with a higher transport capacity at acidic pH.
abstract.9: Interestingly, the presence of these anionophores did not interfere with the activation of CFTR and did not modify the action of lumacaftor (a CFTR corrector) or ivacaftor (a CFTR potentiator).
abstract.10: Conclusion and implications: These anionophores, at low concentrations, transported chloride and bicarbonate across cell membranes, without affecting CFTR function.
abstract.11: They therefore provide promising starting points for the development of novel treatments for CF.

translation1.1: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a deadly disease inherited from both parents that is caused when the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein does not work correctly, a channel involved with movement of ions (charged atoms) and fluids in epithelial cells (cells that cover the outer surface of the internal organs).
translation1.2: Anionophores, which are small human-made substances that move negative ions (anions) across membranes, can replace biological anion movement regardless of gene changes in the CFTR and are possible treatments for CF.
translation1.3: We looked at the movement properties of five anionophore substances.
translation1.4: We measured the flow of chloride out of the cell.
translation1.5: We measured the flow of iodide into the cell.
translation1.6: We measured the movement of bicarbonate (compound).
translation1.8: We saw that all five compounds are able to move halides and bicarbonate (compounds) across the cell membrane, with more moved in acidic conditions.
translation1.9: Anionophores did not change CFTR activation and did not change the effects of a lumacaftor (corrector that helps the changed protein to move to the cell surface) or ivacaftor (potentiator that holds the gate to the channel open so chloride can flow through the cell membrane).
translation1.10: We conclude that anionophores, at low concentrations, moved chloride and bicarbonate (compounds) across cell membranes, without changing CFTR function.
translation1.11: New CF treatments could be developed starting from anionophores.

30349480.Title: Emerging microRNA Therapeutic Approaches for Cystic Fibrosis

abstract.1: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene and remains the most common life-shortening diseases affecting the exocrine organs.
abstract.2: The absence of this channel results in an imbalance of ion concentrations across the cell membrane and results in more abnormal secretion and mucus plugging in the gastrointestinal tract and in the lungs of CF patients.
abstract.3: The direct introduction of fully functional CFTR by gene therapy has long been pursued as a therapeutical option to restore CFTR function independent of the specific CFTR mutation, but the different clinical trials failed to propose persuasive evidence of this strategy.
abstract.4: The last ten years has led to the development of new pharmacotherapies which can activate CFTR function in a mutation-specific manner.
abstract.5: Although approximately 2,000 different disease-associated mutations have been identified, a single codon deletion, F508del, is by far the most common and is present on at least one allele in approximately 70% of the patients in CF populations.
abstract.6: This strategy is limited by chemistry, the knowledge on CFTR and the heterogenicity of the patients.
abstract.7: New research efforts in CF aim to develop other therapeutical approaches to combine different strategies.
abstract.8: Targeting RNA appears as a new and an important opportunity to modulate dysregulated biological processes.
abstract.9: Abnormal miRNA activity has been linked to numerous diseases, and over the last decade, the critical role of miRNA in regulating biological processes has fostered interest in how miRNA binds to and interacts explicitly with the target protein.
abstract.10: Herein, this review describes the different strategies to identify dysregulated miRNA opens up a new concept and new opportunities to correct CFTR deficiency.
abstract.11: This review describes therapeutic applications of antisense techniques currently under investigation in CF.

translation1.1: Changes in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene cause cystic fibrosis (CF), one of the most common life-shortening diseases affecting organs that make and release substances into transporting ducts.
translation1.2: The absence of this protein from the CFTR gene causes an imbalance of ion (charged atom) concentrations across the cell membrane and causes release and buildup of abnormally high levels of mucus in the digestive tract and lungs of CF patients.
translation1.3: Scientists have tried transferring working CFTR into a patient's cells regardless of the specific CFTR gene change, but patient trials were not successful.
translation1.4: New drugs that can stimulate CFTR function based on the specific gene change have been made in the last ten years.
translation1.5: Of the roughly 2,000 different gene changes linked to CF, the most common change is F508del, a deletion of a sequence of three consecutive gene compounds, and about 70% of people with CF have at least one form of it.
translation1.6: Chemistry, CFTR knowledge, and genetic differences of patients limit the ability to stimulate CFTR function based on the specific gene change.
translation1.7: New CF research aims to develop other treatments that combine different approaches.
translation1.8: Looking at RNA (which changes the genetic information of DNA into proteins) is a new and important chance to fix incorrectly functioning biological processes.
translation1.9: Scientists have linked abnormal microRNA (miRNA; short type of non-coding RNA that does not encode a protein) to many diseases, and over the last decade, scientists have developed interest in how miRNA interacts with specific proteins.
translation1.10: We describe different ways to find incorrectly functioning miRNA that might help correct lack of CFTR.
translation1.11: This review describes RNA treatments currently being studied in CF.

29475947.Title: Functional organization of cytoplasmic portals controlling access to the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) chloride channel pore

abstract.1: The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a Cl- channel that apparently has evolved from an ancestral active transporter.
abstract.2: Key to the CFTR's switch from pump to channel function may have been the appearance of one or more "lateral portals."
abstract.3: Such portals connect the cytoplasm to the transmembrane channel pore, allowing a continuous pathway for the electrodiffusional movement of Cl- ions.
abstract.4: However, these portals remain the least well-characterized part of the Cl- transport pathway; even the number of functional portals is uncertain, and if multiple portals do exist, their relative functional contributions are unknown.
abstract.5: Here, we used patch-clamp recording to identify the contributions of positively charged amino acid side chains located in CFTR's cytoplasmic transmembrane extensions to portal function.
abstract.6: Mutagenesis-mediated neutralization of several charged side chains reduced single-channel Cl- conductance.
abstract.7: However, these same mutations differentially affected channel blockade by cytoplasmic suramin and Pt(NO2)42- anions.
abstract.8: We considered and tested several models by which the contribution of these positively charged side chains to one or more independent or non-independent portals to the pore could affect Cl- conductance and interactions with blockers.
abstract.9: Overall, our results suggest the existence of a single portal that is lined by several positively charged side chains that interact electrostatically with both Cl- and blocking anions.
abstract.10: We further propose that mutations at other sites indirectly alter the function of this single portal.
abstract.11: Comparison of our functional results with recent structural information on CFTR completes our picture of the overall molecular architecture of the Cl- permeation pathway.

translation1.1: The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a chloride (Cl-) channel descended from an active transporter (requiring energy for movement).
translation1.2: One or more "lateral portals" may have appeared, switching the active pump to a channel.
translation1.3: "Lateral portals" allow Cl- ions (charged atoms) to move under the influence of an electric field.
translation1.4: These portals are the least understood part of Cl- movement. Scientists do not know the number of working portals, and if more than one, which portal does what.
translation1.5: We used a cell test to find out how positively charged side chemical groups in CFTR contribute to how the portal works.
translation1.6: Neutralization of many charged side chemical groups caused by gene sequence changes reduced movement of Cl- through a single channel.
translation1.7: However, these gene sequence changes affected channel blockade by negatively charged atoms differently.
translation1.8: We used many models to look at ways these positively charged chemical groups changed one or more portals and its effect on Cl- movement and interaction with blockers.
translation1.9: Our results suggest one portal is lined by many positively charged side chemical groups that interact with both CL- and other blocking negatively charged ions.
translation1.10: We further suggest that gene sequence changes at other sides change how well the single portal works.
translation1.11: We compared our results with recent information on CFTR structure to understand the pathway of Cl- transport at a molecule level.

translation2.1: The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CTFR) is a chloride transporter that apparently has evolved from an ancestral active transporter.
translation2.2: Key to the CFTR's switch from pump to channel function may have been the appearance of one or more "lateral portals."
translation2.3: Lateral portals connect the cell's inner fluid to the channel on the cell boundary, allowing a continuous pathway for chloride ion movement.
translation2.4: However, these portals are the least studied part of the chloride transport pathway. Even the number of active portals in unknown, and if multiple portals do exists, their relative contributions are unknown.
translation2.5: Here, we use electrical recordings to identify the contributions of positively charged protein segments located in CFTR's extensions to portal function.
translation2.6: Mutation-controlled silencing of several charged protein segments reduced single-channel chloride transport.
translation2.7: However, these same mutations uniquely affected channel blocking by specific inner-cell, negatively-charged particles.
translation2.8: We considered and tested many models by which the contribution of these positive protein segments to one or more independent or non-independent portals to the channel could affect chloride transport and interactions with blockers.
translation2.9: Overall, our results suggest the existence of a single portal lined with several positively-charged protein segments that interact electrically with both chloride and negative-charged, blocking particles.
translation2.10: We propose that mutations at other sites indirectly affect the function of this one portal.
translation2.11: Comparing our results with recent structural information on CTFR completes our picture of the overall molecular architecture of the chloride transport pathway.

29402832.Title: The CFTR-Associated Ligand Arrests the Trafficking of the Mutant ΔF508 CFTR Channel in the ER Contributing to Cystic Fibrosis

abstract.1: Background/aims: The CFTR-Associated Ligand (CAL), a PDZ domain containing protein with two coiled-coil domains, reduces cell surface WT CFTR through degradation in the lysosome by a well-characterized mechanism.
abstract.2: However, CAL's regulatory effect on ΔF508 CFTR has remained almost entirely uninvestigated.
abstract.3: Methods: In this study, we describe a previously unknown pathway for CAL by which it regulates the membrane expression of ΔF508 CFTR through arrest of ΔF508 CFTR trafficking in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) using a combination of cell biology, biochemistry and electrophysiology.
abstract.4: Results: We demonstrate that CAL is an ER localized protein that binds to ΔF508 CFTR and is degraded in the 26S proteasome.
abstract.5: When CAL is inhibited, ΔF508 CFTR retention in the ER decreases and cell surface expression of mature functional ΔF508 CFTR is observed alongside of enhanced expression of plasma membrane scaffolding protein NHERF1.
abstract.6: Chaperone proteins regulate this novel process, and ΔF508 CFTR binding to HSP40, HSP90, HSP70, VCP, and Aha1 changes to improve ΔF508 CFTR cell surface trafficking.
abstract.7: Conclusion: Our results reveal a pathway in which CAL regulates the cell surface availability and intracellular retention of ΔF508 CFTR.

translation1.1: The CFTR-Associated Ligand (CAL) reduces the cell surface of normal CFTR through destroying it in a well-understood way. The CFTR protein is a channel involved with movement of ions (charged atoms) and fluids in epithelial cells (cells that cover the outer surface of the internal organs).
translation1.2: However, few scientists have studied how CAL controls ΔF508 CFTR, a specific gene sequence change seen in the CFTR gene which slightly alters the CFTR protein.
translation1.3: In this study, we describe a previously unknown way CAL controls ΔF508 CFTR through stopping ΔF508 CFTR movement in the cell's transportation system.
translation1.4: We show that CAL binds to ΔF508 CFTR in one location of the cell and is destroyed in another location of the cell.
translation1.5: When CAL is stopped, the amount of ΔF508 CFTR held within the cell decreases and working ΔF508 CFTR is seen on the cell surface.
translation1.6: The binding of ΔF508 CFTR to proteins improves the cell surface movement conducted by ΔF508 CFTR.
translation1.7: We conclude that CAL controls the cell surface availability and amount held within the cell of ΔF508 CFTR.

47.question: What causes low alkaline phosphate levels?

34711245.Title: Prevalence of low alkaline phosphatase activity in laboratory assessment: Is hypophosphatasia an underdiagnosed disease?

abstract.1: Background: Tissue-nonspecific alkaline phosphatase (TNSALP) encoded by the ALPL gene is of particular importance for bone mineralization.
abstract.2: Mutation in the ALPL gene can lead to persistent low ALP activity resulting in the rare disease Hypophosphatasia (HPP) that is characterized by disturbed bone and dental mineralization.
abstract.3: While severe forms are extremely rare with an estimated prevalence of 1/100.000, recent studies suggest that moderate form caused by heterozygous mutations are much more frequent with an estimated prevalence of 1/508.
abstract.4: The purpose of this study was to estimate the prevalence of low AP levels in the population based on laboratory measurements.
abstract.5: Methods: In this study, the prevalence of low AP activity and elevated pyridoxal-5-phosphate (PLP) levels was analyzed in 6.918.126 measurements from 2011 to 2016 at a single laboratory in northern Germany.
abstract.6: Only laboratory values of subjects older than 18 years of age were included.
abstract.7: Only the first measurement was included, all repeated values were excluded.
abstract.8: Results: In total, 8.46% of the measurements of a total of 6.918.126 values showed a value < 30 U/L. 0.59% of the subjects with an ALP activity below 30 U/L had an additional PLP measurement.
abstract.9: Here, 6.09% showed elevated pyridoxal-5-phosphate (PLP) levels.
abstract.10: This suggest that 0.52% (1:194) of subjects show laboratory signs of HPP.
abstract.11: Conclusion: These data support the genetic estimation that the prevalence of moderate forms of HPP may be significantly higher than expected.
abstract.12: Based on these data, we recommend automatically measurement of PLP in the case of low ALP activity and a notification to the ordering physician that HPP should be included in the differential diagnosis and further exploration is recommended.

translation1.1: Background: Tissue-nonspecific alkaline phosphatase (TNSALP) is an enzyme that assists in breaking down phosphate groups. Phosphate groups are important in activating proteins. TNSALP is encoded by a gene, known as ALPL, that is of particular importance for bone mineralization or when minerals deposit onto bone.
translation1.2: Mutation, or a structural change, in the ALPL gene can cause persistent low alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity. ALP is an enzyme that helps bone strength. Low ALP activity can result in the rare disease Hypophosphatasia (HPP). HPP is characterized by disturbed bone and dental or tooth mineralization.
translation1.3: Severe forms of HPP are extremely rare. However, there is an estimated prevalence of 1/100,000 people. Recent studies suggest that moderate HPP is more common with an estimated prevalence of 1/508 people.
translation1.4: The aim of this study was to estimate the prevalence of low ALP levels in the population based on laboratory measurements.
translation1.5: The prevalence of low AP activity and elevated pyridoxal-5-phosphate (PLP) levels was analyzed in 6,918,126 measurements from 2011 to 2016. PLP is a co-enzyme or helper in several body processes.
translation1.6: Only laboratory values of subjects older than 18 years of age were included.
translation1.7: Only the first measurement was included. All repeated values were excluded.
translation1.8: In total, 8.46% of the measurements showed a value < 30 U/L. 0.59% of the subjects with an ALP activity below 30 U/L had an additional PLP measurement.
translation1.9: Of the participants, 6.09% showed elevated pyridoxal-5-phosphate (PLP) levels.
translation1.10: This suggest that 0.52% of subjects show signs of HPP.
translation1.11: These data support the estimation that the prevalence of moderate forms of HPP is higher than expected.
translation1.12: The authors recommend automatic measurement of PLP in cases of low ALP activity. Physicians should be notified that HPP should be included in the diagnosis and further exploration is recommended.

26783040.Title: Clinical, biochemical and genetic spectrum of low alkaline phosphatase levels in adults

abstract.1: Background: Low serum levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) are a hallmark of hypophosphatasia.
abstract.2: However, the clinical significance and the underlying genetics of low ALP in unselected populations are unclear.
abstract.3: Methods: In order to clarify this issue, we performed a clinical, biochemical and genetic study of 42 individuals (age range 20-77yr) with unexplained low ALP levels.
abstract.4: Results: Nine had mild hyperphosphatemia and three had mild hypercalcemia.
abstract.5: ALP levels were inversely correlated with serum calcium (r=-0.38, p=0.012), pyridoxal phosphate (PLP; r=-0.51, p=0.001) and urine phosphoethanolamine (PEA; r=-0.49, p=0.001).
abstract.6: Although many subjects experienced minor complaints, such as mild musculoskeletal pain, none had major health problems.
abstract.7: Mutations in ALPL were found in 21 subjects (50%), including six novel mutations.
abstract.8: All but one, were heterozygous mutations.
abstract.9: Missense mutations were the most common (present in 18 subjects; 86%) and the majority were predicted to have a damaging effect on protein activity.
abstract.10: The presence of a mutated allele was associated with tooth loss (48% versus 12%; p=0.04), slightly lower levels of serum ALP (p=0.002), higher levels of PLP (p<0.0001) and PEA (p<0.0001), as well as mildly increased serum phosphate (p=0.03).
abstract.11: Ten individuals (24%) had PLP levels above the reference range; all carried a mutated allele.
abstract.12: Conclusion: One-half of adult individuals with unexplained low serum ALP carried an ALPL mutation.
abstract.13: Although the associated clinical manifestations are usually mild, in approximately 50% of the cases, enzyme activity is low enough to cause substrate accumulation and may predispose to defects in calcified tissues.

translation1.1: Low serum levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) are a sign of hypophosphatasia (genetic disease that affects bone and tooth development). ALP is an enzyme that helps bone strength.
translation1.2: However, the clinical significance and the underlying genetics of low ALP in unselected populations are unclear.
translation1.3: To better understand this issue, the authors performed a study of 42 individuals with unexplained low ALP levels. The participants were between 20 to 77 years old.
translation1.4: Nine had mild hyperphosphatemia (high serum phosphate) and three had mild hypercalcemia (high blood calcium).
translation1.5: ALP levels were inversely related with serum calcium, pyridoxal phosphate, and urine phosphoethanolamine. These are all compounds within the body that play a role in bone health.
translation1.6: Many subjects experienced minor complaints, such as mild muscle or bone pain. However, none had major health problems.
translation1.7: Mutations in ALPL were found in 21 subjects, including six novel mutations.
translation1.8: All but one were heterozygous mutations, which is a mutation only affecting one form of a gene.
translation1.9: Missense mutations, or mistakes in the DNA, were the most common. Most of the mutations were predicted to have a damaging effect on protein activity.
translation1.10: The presence of a mutated allele was associated with tooth loss, slightly lower levels of serum (blood) ALP, higher levels of PLP and PEA, as well as mildly increased serum phosphate.
translation1.11: Ten individuals had PLP levels above the reference range. All carried a mutated allele or gene copy.
translation1.12: One-half of adult individuals with unexplained low serum ALP carried an ALPL mutation.
translation1.13: In almost half of the cases, enzyme activity is low enough to cause substrate (cell substance) accumulation. This may make an individual more likely to experience defects in calcified tissues, such as bone.

translation2.1: Low blood levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP), a protein that influences the high-energy molecule phosphate, indicates low blood phosphate levels.
translation2.2: However, the importance and genetics of low ALP in random groups is unknown.
translation2.3: To clarify this issue, we performed a clinical, biochemical and genetic study of 42 individuals with unexplained low ALP levels.
translation2.4: Nine had mildly high blood phosphate levels. Three had mildly high blood calcium levels.
translation2.5: ALP levels trended oppositely with blood calcium, pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) or active vitamin B6, and urine phosphoethanolamine (PEA), a key molecule to build cell boundaries.
translation2.6: Although many had minor complains, like mild musculoskeletal pain, none had major health problems.
translation2.7: Gene sequence changes in ALPL, the gene encoding ALP, were found in 21 subjects (50%), including six new changes.
translation2.9: Mutations that change a protein segment were the most common (present in 18 subjects; 86%). The majority were predicted to have a harmful effect on protein activity.
translation2.10: Having a mutated gene was linked with tooth loss, slightly lower levels of blood ALP, higher levels of PLP and PEA, and mildly higher blood phosphate.
translation2.11: Ten people had above-average PLP levels. All had a mutated gene.
translation2.12: Half of the adults with unexplained low blood ALP had an ALPL mutation.
translation2.13: Although the associated physical symptoms are usually mild, in around 50% of the cases, protein enzyme activity is low enough to cause phosphate accumulation and may predispose to defects in high-calcium body parts.

34515659.Title: Bilateral atypical femoral fractures during denosumab therapy in a patient with adult-onset hypophosphatasia

abstract.1: Summary: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is a rare and under-recognised genetic defect in bone mineralisation.
abstract.2: Patients presenting with fragility fractures may be mistakenly diagnosed as having osteoporosis and prescribed antiresorptive therapy, a treatment which may increase fracture risk.
abstract.3: Adult-onset HPPhypophosphatasia was identified in a 40-year-old woman who presented with bilateral atypical femoral fractures after 4 years of denosumab therapy.
abstract.4: A low serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and increased serum vitamin B6 level signalled the diagnosis, which was later confirmed by identification of two recessive mutations of the ALPL gene.
abstract.5: The patient was treated with teriparatide given the unavailability of ALP enzyme-replacement therapy (asfotase alfa).
abstract.6: Fracture healing occurred, but impaired mobility persisted.
abstract.7: HPP predisposes to atypical femoral fracture (AFF) during antiresorptive therapy; hence, bisphosphonates and denosumab are contraindicated in this condition.
abstract.8: Screening patients with fracture or 'osteoporosis' to identify a low ALP level is recommended.
abstract.9: Learning points: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is a rare and under-recognised cause of bone fragility produced by impaired matrix mineralisation that can be misdiagnosed as a fragility fracture due to age-related bone loss.
abstract.10: Antiresorptive therapy is contraindicated in HPP.
abstract.11: Low serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) provides a clue to the diagnosis.
abstract.12: Elevated serum vitamin B6 (an ALP substrate) is indicative of HPP, while identification of a mutation in the ALPL gene is confirmatory.
abstract.13: Enzyme therapy with recombinant ALP (asfotase alfa) is currently prohibitively costly.
abstract.14: Treatment with anabolic bone agents such as teriparatide has been reported, but whether normally mineralized bone is formed requires further study.

translation1.1: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is a rare and under-recognized genetic defect in bone mineralization. Bone mineralization is when bone become calcified.
translation1.2: Patients presenting with fragility fractures may be mistakenly diagnosed as having osteoporosis (brittle bones). These patients may be prescribed antiresorptive therapy, or drugs that block the breakdown of bone. These drugs may increase fracture risk.
translation1.3: Adult-onset HPP was identified in a 40-year-old woman. She had with femur fractures after 4 years of using denosumba, a drug to treat osteoporosis.
translation1.4: A low serum (blood) alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and increased serum vitamin B6 level signaled the diagnosis. Her diagnosis of HPP was later confirmed by identification of two recessive gene mutations of the ALPL gene. ALP is an enzyme that helps bone strength. ALPL is the gene that encodes ALP.
translation1.5: The patient was treated with teriparatide (an osteoporosis drug) due to the unavailability of ALP enzyme-replacement therapy.
translation1.6: The fractures healed. However, her mobility was impaired.
translation1.7: HPP makes someone more likely to experience femur fractures during antiresorptive therapy. Because of this, bisphosphonates (drugs that limit bone density) and denosumab should not be given to people with this condition.
translation1.8: Healthcare workings should screen patients with fracture or 'osteoporosis' to identify a low ALP level.
translation1.9: HPP is a rare and under-recognized cause of bone fragility. HPP is caused by impaired mineralization that can be misdiagnosed as a fragility fracture due to age-related bone loss.
translation1.10: Antiresorptive therapy is not recommended in HPP treatment.
translation1.11: Low serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) can aid in diagnosis.
translation1.12: Elevated serum vitamin B6 (a chemical that works with ALP) is suggestive of HPP. Identifying mutations within the ALPL gene can confirm HPP status.
translation1.13: Therapy with a chemical ALP reacts with, known as asfotase alfa, is currently unmanageably expensive.
translation1.14: Treatment with anabolic (repairing) bone agents has been reported. However, if this treatment helps normally mineralized bone form needs further study.

34547524.Title: Hypophosphatasia: Vitamin B 6 status of affected children and adults

abstract.1: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is the heritable dento-osseous disease caused by loss-of-function mutation(s) of the gene ALPL that encodes the tissue-nonspecific isoenzyme of alkaline phosphatase (TNSALP).
abstract.2: TNSALP is a cell-surface homodimeric phosphomonoester phosphohydrolase expressed in healthy people especially in the skeleton, liver, kidneys, and developing teeth.
abstract.3: In HPP, diminished TNSALP activity leads to extracellular accumulation of its natural substrates including inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi), an inhibitor of mineralization, and pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP), the principal circulating form of vitamin B6 (B6).
abstract.4: Autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive inheritance involving >450 usually missense defects scattered throughout ALPL largely explains the remarkably broad-ranging severity of this inborn-error-of-metabolism.
abstract.5: In 1985 when we identified elevated plasma PLP as a biochemical hallmark of HPP, all 14 investigated affected children and adults had markedly increased PLP levels.
abstract.6: However, pyridoxal (PL), the dephosphorylated form of PLP that enters cells to cofactor many enzymatic reactions, was not low but often inexplicably elevated.
abstract.7: Levels of pyridoxic acid (PA), the B6 degradation product quantified to assess B6 sufficiency, were unremarkable.
abstract.8: Canonical signs or symptoms of B6 deficiency or toxicity were absent.
abstract.9: B6-dependent seizures in infants with life-threatening HPP were later explained by their profound deficiency of TNSALP activity blocking PLP dephosphorylation to PL and diminishing gamma-aminobutyric acid synthesis in the brain.
abstract.10: Now, there is speculation that altered B6 metabolism causes further clinical complications in HPP.
abstract.11: Herein, we assessed the plasma PL and PA levels accompanying previously reported elevated plasma PLP concentrations in 150 children and adolescents with HPP.
abstract.12: Their mean (SD) plasma PL level was nearly double the mean for our healthy pediatric controls: 66.7 (59.0) nM versus 37.1 (22.2) nM (P < 0.0001), respectively.
abstract.13: Their PA levels were broader than our pediatric control range, but their mean value was normal; 40.2 (25.1) nM versus 39.3 (9.9) nM (P = 0.7793), respectively.
abstract.14: In contrast, adults with HPP often had plasma PL and PA levels suggestive of dietary B6 insufficiency.
abstract.15: We discuss why the B6 levels of our pediatric patients with HPP would not cause B6 toxicity or deficiency, whereas in affected adults dietary B6 insufficiency can develop.

translation1.1: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is the heritable, tooth and bone disease. HPP is caused by mutations of the gene ALPL. ALPL encodes the tissue-nonspecific isoenzyme of alkaline phosphatase (TNSALP). TNSALP is an enzyme that assists in breaking down phosphate groups. Phosphate groups are important in activating proteins.
translation1.2: TNSALP is expressed in healthy people, especially in the skeleton, liver, kidneys, and developing teeth.
translation1.3: In HPP, decreased TNSALP activity leads to extracellular accumulation of its natural substrates, including pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP). PLP is the principal circulating form of vitamin B6 (B6).
translation1.4: Different mutations of ALPL largely explains the remarkably broad-ranging severity of this genetic inborn-error-of-metabolism.
translation1.5: In 1985, elevated (blood) plasma PLP was identified as hallmark of HPP. In the study, all 14 investigated affected children and adults had increased PLP levels.
translation1.6: However, pyridoxal (PL), an alternate form of PLP that enters cells to cofactor (help) many enzymatic reactions, was often unexplainably elevated.
translation1.7: Levels of pyridoxic acid (PA), a compound used to determine B6 levels in the body, were unremarkable.
translation1.8: Signs or symptoms of B6 deficiency or toxicity were absent.
translation1.9: B6-dependent seizures in infants with life-threatening HPP were later explained by their low TNSALP activity. Lack of TNSALP activity was blocking PLP dephosphorylation, removal of phosphate groups, to PL. This diminished formation of gamma-aminobutyric acid, a neurotransmitter, in the brain.
translation1.10: It is theorized that abnormal B6 metabolism causes further health complications in HPP.
translation1.11: This study assessed (measured) the blood PL and PA levels in patients with previously reported elevated plasma PLP concentrations. The evaluated patient pool consisted of 150 children and adolescents with HPP.
translation1.12: Their average plasma PL level was nearly double the average of healthy pediatric controls.
translation1.13: Their PA levels were broader than our pediatric (child) control range with a normal average value.
translation1.14: In contrast, adults with HPP often had plasma PL and PA levels that suggest a dietary B6 insufficiency.
translation1.15: This paper discusses why B6 levels of children with HPP would not cause B6 toxicity or deficiency, whereas in affected adults dietary B6 insufficiency can develop.

34258332.Title: Biochemical, clinical and genetic characteristics in adults with persistent hypophosphatasaemia; Data from an endocrinological outpatient clinic in Denmark

abstract.1: Background: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is an inborn disease caused by pathogenic variants in ALPL.
abstract.2: Low levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) are a biochemical hallmark of the disease.
abstract.3: Scarce knowledge about the prevalence of HPP in Scandinavia exists, and the variable clinical presentations make diagnostics challenging.
abstract.4: The aim of this study was to investigate the prevalence of ALPL variants as well as the clinical and biochemical features among adults with endocrinological diagnoses and persistent hypophosphatasaemia.
abstract.5: Methods: A biochemical database containing ALP measurements of 26,121 individuals was reviewed to identify adults above 18 years of age with persistently low levels of ALP beneath range (≤ 35 ± 2.7 U/L).
abstract.6: ALPL genetic testing, biochemical evaluations and assessment of clinical features by a systematic questionnaire among included patients, were performed.
abstract.7: Results: Among 24 participants, thirteen subjects (54.2%) revealed a disease-causing variant in ALPL and reported mild clinical features of HPP, of which musculoskeletal pain was the most frequently reported (n = 9).
abstract.8: The variant c. 571G > A; p.(Glu191 Lys) was identified in six subjects, and an unreported missense variant (c.1019A > C; p.(His340Pro)) as well as a deletion of exon 2 were detected by genetic screening.
abstract.9: Biochemical analyses showed no significant differences in ALP (p = 0.059), the bone specific alkaline phosphatase (BALP) (p = 0.056) and pyridoxal-5'-phosphate (PLP) (p = 0.085) between patients with an ALPL variant and negative genetic screening.
abstract.10: Patients with a variant in ALPL had significantly higher PLP levels than healthy controls (p = 0.002).
abstract.11: We observed normal ALP activity in some patients classified as mild HPP, and slightly increased levels of PLP in two subjects with normal genetic screening and four healthy controls.
abstract.12: Among 51 patients with persistent hypophosphatasaemia, fifteen subjects (29.4%) received antiresorptive treatment.
abstract.13: Two patients with unrecognized HPP were treated with bisphosphonates and did not show complications due to the treatment.
abstract.14: Conclusions: Pathogenic variants in ALPL are common among patients with endocrinological diagnoses and low ALP.
abstract.15: Regarding diagnostics, genetic testing is necessary to identify mild HPP due to fluctuating biochemical findings.
abstract.16: Antiresorptive treatment is a frequent reason for hypophosphatasaemia and effects of these agents in adults with a variant in ALPL and osteoporosis remain unclear and require further studies.

translation1.1: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is a disease caused by mutations within the gene ALPL. Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is the heritable, tooth and bone disease. The gene ALPL encodes for alkaline phosphatase (ALP), an enzyme that helps bone strength.
translation1.2: Low levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) are a hallmark of the disease.
translation1.3: There is little knowledge about the prevalence of HPP in Scandinavia. Due to the variation in HPP clinical presentations, diagnosing the disease is challenging.
translation1.4: The aim of this study was to investigate the prevalence of ALPL variants (gene types). The study also aimed to identify HPP biological identifiers among adults. This study was specifically interested in adults with HPP along with endocrine (hormonal) disorders and persistent hypophosphatasemia (low body phosphorus levels).
translation1.5: A database containing ALP measurements of 26,121 individuals was reviewed to identify adults above 18 years of age with persistently low levels of ALP.
translation1.6: ALPL genetic testing, evaluation of body compound levels, and assessment of health by a systematic questionnaire among included patients, were performed.
translation1.7: Among 24 participants, thirteen subjects revealed a disease-causing variant in ALPL and reported mild health effects of HPP. Of these mild health effects, musculoskeletal pain was the most frequently reported.
translation1.8: The same genetic variant was identified in six subjects. An unreported missense (gene-altered) variant and a genetic deletion were detected by genetic screening.
translation1.9: Analysis of compound levels within the body showed no significant differences between patients with an ALPL variant and negative (no-detection) genetic screening.
translation1.10: Patients with a variant in ALPL had significantly higher PLP levels than control patients.
translation1.11: Normal ALP activity was observed in some patients classified as mild HPP. A slightly increased level of PLP was found in two subjects with normal genetic screening and four healthy controls.
translation1.12: Among 51 patients with persistent hypophosphatasemia, 15 received treatment to increase bone strength.
translation1.13: Two patients with undiagnosed HPP were treated with bisphosphonates, drugs that slow bone loss. They did not show complications due to the treatment.
translation1.14: Genetic variations in ALPL are common among patients with endocrine disorders and low ALP.
translation1.15: Genetic testing is necessary to identify mild HPP due to fluctuating body compound level findings.
translation1.16: Treatment to increase bone strength is a frequent reason for hypophosphatasemia. Effects of these agents in adults with a variant in ALPL and osteoporosis (brittle bones) remain unclear and require further studies.

translation2.1: Low levels of blood phosphate, a high-energy molecule, or hypophosphatasia (HPP) is a from-birth disease caused by disease-causing variations in ALPL (the gene for alkaline phosphatase or a protein that influences phosphate levels).
translation2.2: Low levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) are a marker of HPP.
translation2.3: Little is known about the amount of HPP in Scandinavia. The diverse symptoms make identification challenging.
translation2.4: The study aimed to investigate the amount of ALPL variants and physical and biochemical markers among adults with hormonal diagnoses and persistant low ALP levels.
translation2.5: We reviewed a database of ALP measurements from 26,121 individuals to identify adults over 18 years with persistently low levels of ALP.
translation2.6: ALPL gene testing, biological tests, and assessment of symptoms by a questionnaire among included patients were performed.
translation2.7: Among 24 patients, thirteen (54.2%) had a disease-causing variant in ALPL and mild symptoms of HPP, of which musculoskeletal pain was the most frequent.
translation2.8: A specific gene mutation that altered a protein segment was found in six subjects. A similar gene mutation and deletion of a gene segment was detected by genetic tests.
translation2.9: Tests showed no differences in ALP, bone-specific ALP, and pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) or active vitamin B6 between patients with an ALPL mutation and no genetic diseases.
translation2.10: Patients with an ALPL mutation had much higher PLP levels than healthy patients.
translation2.11: We saw normal ALP activity in some patients with mild HPP. We also saw slightly increased PLP in two subjects with no gene diseases and four healthy patients.
translation2.12: Among 51 with persistent low ALP levels, fifteen (29.4%) had anti-bone-breakdown treatment.
translation2.13: Two patients with unrecognized HPP were treated with anti-bone-breakdown drugs and did not show side effects from treatment.
translation2.14: Disease-causing mutations in ALPL are common in patients with hormonal diagnoses and low ALP.
translation2.15: Regarding detection, gene testing is needed to identify mild HPP due to diverse biochemical findings.
translation2.16: Anti-bone-breakdown treatment is frequent reason for low ALP levels and treatment effects in adults with an ALPL mutation and bone breakdown remain unclear and need further studies.

34233724.Title: Severe hypercalcemia associated with hypophosphatemia in very premature infants: a case report

abstract.1: Background: Severe hypercalcemia is rare in newborns; even though often asymptomatic, it may have important sequelae.
abstract.2: Hypophosphatemia can occur in infants experiencing intrauterine malnutrition, sepsis and early high-energy parenteral nutrition (PN) and can cause severe hypercalcemia through an unknown mechanism.
abstract.3: Monitoring and supplementation of phosphate (PO4) and calcium (Ca) in the first week of life in preterm infants are still debated.
abstract.4: Case presentation: We report on a female baby born at 29 weeks' gestation with intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) experiencing sustained severe hypercalcemia (up to 24 mg/dl corrected Ca) due to hypophosphatemia while on phosphorus-free PN.
abstract.5: Hypercalcemia did not improve after hyperhydration and furosemide but responded to infusion of PO4.
abstract.6: Eventually, the infant experienced symptomatic hypocalcaemia (ionized Ca 3.4 mg/dl), likely exacerbated by contemporary infusion of albumin.
abstract.7: Subsequently, a normalization of both parathyroid hormone (PTH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) was observed.
abstract.8: Conclusions: Although severe hypercalcemia is extremely rare in neonates, clinicians should be aware of the possible occurrence of this life-threatening condition in infants with or at risk to develop hypophosphatemia.
abstract.9: Hypophosphatemic hypercalcemia can only be managed with infusion of PO4, with strict monitoring of Ca and PO4 concentrations.

translation1.1: Severe hypercalcemia, or too high calcium blood levels, is rare in newborns. Even though hypercalcemia often shows no symptoms, it may have important effects on overall health.
translation1.2: Hypophosphatemia is when the body has low levels of phosphorous. Hypophosphatemia can occur in infants experiencing malnutrition while in the womb, blood infection, and early high-energy parenteral nutrition (PN). PN is when a mother is given nutrients through IV. Hypophosphatemia can cause severe hypercalcemia through an unknown mechanism.
translation1.3: It is debated if phosphate (PO4) and calcium (Ca) should be given in the first week of life in preterm infants.
translation1.4: This study reports on a female baby born at 29 weeks' gestation (time in womb). The infant had intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) and long-term severe hypercalcemia due to hypophosphatemia while on phosphorus-free PN. IUGR is when a baby does not grow to normal weight during pregnancy.
translation1.5: Hypercalcemia did not improve after excess water intake but responded to infusion of PO4.
translation1.6: Eventually, the infant experienced symptoms of hypocalcemia. This was likely worsened by infusion of albumin, a blood protein.
translation1.7: Following this, parathyroid hormone (PTH), which controls calcium and phosphorus in the blood, and alkaline phosphatase (ALP), which removes phosphate groups,  returned to normal levels.
translation1.8: Severe hypercalcemia is extremely rare in newborns. However, doctors should be aware of the possible occurrence of this life-threatening condition in infants with or at risk to develop hypophosphatemia.
translation1.9: Hypophosphatemic hypercalcemia can only be managed with infusion of PO4, with strict monitoring of Ca and PO4 concentrations.

34213743.Title: Clinical, biochemical and genetic findings in adult patients with chronic hypophosphatasemia

abstract.1: Purpose: The study aimed to define the clinical, biochemical and genetic features of adult patients with osteopenia/osteoporosis and/or bone fragility and low serum alkaline phosphatase (sALP).
abstract.2: Methods: Twenty-two patients with at least two sALP values below the reference range were retrospectively enrolled after exclusion of secondary causes.
abstract.3: Data about clinical features, mineral and bone markers, serum pyridoxal-5'-phosphate (PLP), urine phosphoethanolamine (PEA), lumbar and femur bone densitometry, and column X-ray were collected.
abstract.4: Peripheral blood DNA of each participant was analyzed to detect ALPL gene anomalies.
abstract.5: Results: Pathogenic ALPL variants (pALPL) occurred in 23% and benign variants in 36% of patients (bALPL), while nine patients harbored wild-type alleles (wtALPL).
abstract.6: Fragility fractures and dental anomalies were more frequent in patients harboring pALPL and bALPL than in wtALPL patients.
abstract.7: Of note, wtALPL patients comprised women treated with tamoxifen for hormone-sensitive breast cancer.
abstract.8: Mineral and bone markers were similar in the three groups.
abstract.9: Mean urine PEA levels were significantly higher in patients harboring pALPL than those detected in patients harboring bALPL and wtALPL; by contrast, serum PLP levels were similar in the three groups.
abstract.10: A 6-points score, considering clinical and biochemical features, was predictive of pALPL detection [P = 0.060, OR 1.92 (95% CI 0.972, 3.794)], and more significantly of pALPL or bALPL [P = 0.025, OR 14.33 (95% CI 1.401, 14.605)].
abstract.11: Conclusion: In osteopenic/osteoporotic patients, single clinical or biochemical factors did not distinguish hypophosphatasemic patients harboring pALPL or bALPL from those harboring wtALPL.
abstract.12: Occurrence of multiple clinical and biochemical features is predictive of ALPL anomalies, and, therefore, they should be carefully identified.
abstract.13: Tamoxifen emerged as a hypophosphatasemic drug.

translation1.1: The study aimed to define the health, biochemical, and genetic features of adult patients with bone strength issues and low serum (blood) alkaline phosphatase (sALP), a protein that helps bone strength.
translation1.2: Twenty-two patients with at least two sALP measurements below the desired range were enrolled. Any patients with additional disease or health complications were excluded.
translation1.3: Several data points for patient health and biological indicators of disease status were collected.
translation1.4: Patient DNA was analyzed to detect ALPL gene anomalies.
translation1.5: Several types of mutations within the ALPL gene were found amongst the participant population.
