These variants include pathogenic (harmful) ALPL variants (pALPL), benign (harmless) variants (bALPL), and wild-type (normal) variants (wtALPL). pALPL are variants that increases a person's chance to get sick from a disease. bALPL are mutations that do not impact human health. wtALPL variants are genes that are not mutated or changed in form.
translation1.6: Bone and tooth damage were more frequent in patients harboring pALPL and bALPL than in wtALPL patients.
translation1.7: Of note, wtALPL patients comprised women treated with tamoxifen, a drug for breast cancer.
translation1.8: Mineral and bone markers were similar in the three groups.
translation1.9: Average urine phosphoethanolamine, a compound that can indicate bone disease, was significantly higher in patients with pALPL than the other two variant types. By contrast, serum pyridoxal-5'-phosphate, an indicator of vitamin B6 volume, was similar in the three groups.
translation1.10: Certain hospital evaluation techniques were able to predict pALPL and bALPL.
translation1.11: In patients with osteoporosis (brittle bones), visible health effects and biological compound indicators do not distinguish hypophosphatasemia (low serum ALP) patients harboring pALPL or bALPL variants from those harboring wtALPL.
translation1.12: However, visible health effects and biological compound indicators can be predictive of ALPL anomalies. Therefore, they should be carefully identified.
translation1.13: Tamoxifen emerged as a drug to treat hypophosphatasemia.

28401263.Title: Mutational and biochemical findings in adults with persistent hypophosphatasemia

abstract.1: A majority of adults with persistently low serum alkaline phosphatase values carry a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant in the ALPL gene and also have elevated alkaline phosphatase substrate values in serum and urine.
abstract.2: These adults may fall within the spectrum of the adult form of hypophosphatasia.
abstract.3: Introduction: The primary objective of this study was to determine what proportion of adults with persistently low serum alkaline phosphatase values (hypophosphatasemia) harbor mutations in the ALPL gene or have elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) substrates.
abstract.4: Some adults with persistent hypophosphatasemia share clinical and radiographic features with the adult form of hypophosphatasia (HPP).
abstract.5: In HPP, ALPL mutations result in persistent hypophosphatasemia and ALP substrate accumulation in plasma (pyridoxal-5-phosphate (PLP)) and urine (phosphoethanolamine (PEA)).
abstract.6: Methods: Biochemical analyses, including serum ALP activity, bone-specific ALP, plasma PLP, and urine PEA, were performed in adults with persistent hypophosphatasemia.
abstract.7: Mutational analyses were performed using PCR and Sanger sequencing methods.
abstract.8: Gene variants were classified as pathogenic (P), likely pathogenic (LP), variants of uncertain significance (VUS), likely benign (LB), and benign (B).
abstract.9: P and LP variants were further grouped as "Positive ALPL variants" and LB and B grouped as "Negative ALPL variants." Results: Fifty subjects completed all mutational and biochemical analyses.
abstract.10: Sixteen percent carried only Negative ALPL variants.
abstract.11: Of the remaining 42 subjects, 67% were heterozygous for a P variant, 19% for an LP variant, and 14% for a VUS.
abstract.12: Biochemical results were highly inter-correlated and consistent with the expected inverse relationship between ALP and its substrates.
abstract.13: Subjects harboring Positive ALPL variants showed lower ALP and BSAP and higher PLP and PEA values compared with subjects harboring only Negative ALPL variants.
abstract.14: Approximately half of all subjects harboring Positive ALPL variants or ALPL VUS showed elevations in plasma PLP, and three quarters showed elevations in urine PEA.
abstract.15: Conclusion: Adults with persistent hypophosphatasemia frequently harbor ALPL mutations and have elevated ALP substrates.
abstract.16: These adults may fall within the spectrum of the adult form of hypophosphatasia.
abstract.17: Clinicians should take note of persistent hypophosphatasemia in their patients and be cautious in prescribing bisphosphonates when present.
abstract.18: Clinicians should take note of persistent hypophosphatasemia in their patients and be cautious in prescribing bisphosphonates when present.

translation1.1: Most adults with persistently low serum (blood) alkaline phosphatase values have a mutation in the ALPL gene that encodes it. These adults also most likely have elevated alkaline phosphatase substrate values in serum and urine. Alkaline phosphatase can indicate bone health.
translation1.2: These adults may suffer from the adult form of hypophosphatasia, an inherited disorder that affects bone and tooth development.
translation1.3: The aim of this study was to determine what proportion of adults with hypophosphatasemia (low serum alkaline phosphatase) also have ALPL gene mutations or elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) substrates.
translation1.4: Some adults with hypophosphatasemia share observable or radiographic (seen through x-ray) features with the adult form of hypophosphatasia (HPP).
translation1.5: In HPP, ALPL mutations cause persistent hypophosphatasemia and ALP substrate (protein) accumulation in plasma (pyridoxal-5-phosphate (PLP)) and urine (phosphoethanolamine (PEA)).
translation1.6: Analyses of compounds from biological samples, including serum ALP activity, bone-specific ALP, plasma PLP, and urine PEA, were performed in adults with persistent hypophosphatasemia.
translation1.7: Analysis to determine ALPL mutations were performed.
translation1.8: Variations of the gene ALPL were classified as pathogenic (P), likely pathogenic (LP), variants of uncertain significance (VUS), likely benign (LB), and benign (B). Pathogenic mutations often make a person more susceptible to disease. Benign mutations do not affect human health.
translation1.9: P and LP variants were further grouped as "Positive ALPL variants" and LB and B grouped as "Negative ALPL variants." A total of 50 subjects completed all mutational and biochemical analyses.
translation1.10: Sixteen percent carried only Negative ALPL variants.
translation1.11: Of the remaining 42 subjects, 67% were heterozygous for a P variant, 19% for an LP variant, and 14% for a VUS.
translation1.12: Biochemical results were associated with the inverse (opposite) relationship between ALP and its substrates.
translation1.13: Subjects harboring Positive ALPL variants had lower ALP and BSAP and higher PLP and PEA values.
translation1.14: Approximately half of all subjects harboring Positive ALPL variants or ALPL VUS showed elevations in plasma PLP. Most also showed elevations in urine PEA.
translation1.15: Adults with persistent hypophosphatasemia often have ALPL mutations and have elevated ALP substrates.
translation1.16: These adults may fall within the spectrum of the adult form of hypophosphatasia.
translation1.18: Clinicians should note long-lasting hypophosphatasia in patients and be cautious in giving them anit-bone-breakdown drugs.

translation2.1: Many adults with persistently low blood levels of alkaline phosphatase, a protein that influences levels of the high-energy molecule phosphate, possibly have a mutation in the ALPL gene that encodes alkaline phosphatase. Many adults also have increased phosphate-carrying compounds in blood and urine.
translation2.2: These adults may have low blood phosphate levels (hypophosphatasia).
translation2.3: The study determines what proportion of adults with persistently low blood alkaline phosphatase levels (hypophosphatasemia) have mutations in the ALPL gene or accumulated phosphate-carrying compounds.
translation2.4: Some adults with persistent hypophosphatasemia share symptoms with the adult form of low blood phosphate levels or hypophosphatasia (HPP).
translation2.5: In HPP, ALPL mutations lead to persistent hypophosphatasemia and phosphate-carrying compounds in blood (pyridoxal-5-phosphate (PLP) or active vitamin B6) and urine (phosphoethanolamine (PEA) or a key molecule to build cell boundaries).
translation2.6: Blood ALP activity, bone-specific ALP, blood PLP, and urine PEA were measured in adults with persistently low levels of ALP.
translation2.8: Variations of the ALPL gene were classified as disease-causing or pathogenic (P), likely pathogenic (LP), variants of uncertain significance (VUS), likely harmless or benign (LB), and benign (B).
translation2.9: P and LP variants were also grouped as "Positive ALPL variants". LB and B were grouped as "Negative ALPL variants."
translation2.10: Fifty subjects completed all the tests.
translation2.11: Sixteen percent had only Negative ALPL variatns.
translation2.12: Of the remaining 42, 67% had at least one copy of the P variant, 19% for an LP variant, and 14% for a VUS.
translation2.13: Tests results agreed with each other and showed that the amount of ALP trended oppositely with the quantity of the molecules that it acts upon.
translation2.14: Those with Positive ALPL variants had lower ALP and bone-specific ALP and had higher PLP and PEA than those with Negative ALPL variants.
translation2.15: Around half of those with Positive ALPL variants or ALPL VUS had increases in blood PLP. Three quarters had increases in urine PEA.
translation2.16: Adults with persistently low ALP levels frequently had ALPL mutations and increased phosphate-carrying compounds.
translation2.17: These adults may have low blood phosphate levels.

abstract.1: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is the inborn-error-of-metabolism that features low serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity (hypophosphatasemia) caused by loss-of-function mutation(s) of the gene that encodes the tissue-nonspecific isoenzyme of ALP (TNSALP).
abstract.2: Autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant inheritance from among >300 TNSALP (ALPL) mutations largely explains HPP's remarkably broad-ranging severity.
abstract.3: TNSALP is a cell-surface homodimeric phosphohydrolase richly expressed in the skeleton, liver, kidney, and developing teeth.
abstract.4: In HPP, TNSALP substrates accumulate extracellularly.
abstract.5: Among them is inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi), a potent inhibitor of mineralization.
abstract.6: Superabundance of extracellular PPi explains the hard tissue complications of HPP that feature premature loss of deciduous teeth and often rickets or osteomalacia as well as calcific arthropathies in some affected adults.
abstract.7: In infants with severe HPP, blocked entry of minerals into the skeleton can cause hypercalcemia, and insufficient hydrolysis of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP), the major circulating form of vitamin B6, can cause pyridoxine-dependent seizures.
abstract.8: Elevated circulating PLP is a sensitive and specific biochemical marker for HPP.
abstract.9: Also, the TNSALP substrate phosphoethanolamine (PEA) is usually elevated in serum and urine in HPP, though less reliably for diagnosis.
abstract.10: Pathognomonic radiographic changes occur in pediatric HPP when the skeletal disease is severe.
abstract.11: TNSALP mutation analysis is essential for recurrence risk assessment for HPP in future pregnancies and for prenatal diagnosis.
abstract.12: HPP was the final rickets/osteomalacia to have a medical treatment.
abstract.13: Now, significant successes using asfotase alfa, a mineral-targeted recombinant TNSALP, are published concerning severely affected newborns, infants, and children.
abstract.14: Asfotase alfa was approved by regulatory agencies multinationally in 2015 typically for pediatric-onset HPP.

translation1.1: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is a genetic condition that blocks metabolic pathways. HPP features low serum (blood) alkaline phosphatase (ALP - a protein which indicates bone health) activity (hypophosphatasemia). This is caused by mutation(s) of the gene that encodes the tissue-nonspecific isoenzyme (form) of ALP (TNSALP). This mutation renders the gene unable to complete it function.
translation1.2: Variations in the type of mutations largely explains HPP's remarkably broad-ranging severity.
translation1.3: TNSALP is an enzyme expressed in the skeleton, liver, kidney, and developing teeth.
translation1.4: In HPP, TNSALP substrates (proteins altered by TNSALP) accumulate outside of cells.
translation1.5: One substrate is inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi), a potent inhibitor (blocker) of mineralization.
translation1.6: Superabundance of extracellular PPi explains the hard tissue complications of HPP. These complications include premature loss of deciduous teeth, rickets or bone softening, and joint swelling in some affected adults.
translation1.7: In infants with severe HPP, blocked entry of minerals into the skeleton can cause hypercalcemia (high calcium levels). Additionally, insufficient breakdown of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP), the major circulating form of vitamin B6, can cause seizures.
translation1.8: Elevated circulating PLP is a sensitive and specific biological marker, or a measurable compound in the body that can indicate health status, for HPP.
translation1.9: Also, the TNSALP substrate phosphoethanolamine (PEA) is usually elevated in serum and urine in HPP. However, this biological marker is less reliable for diagnosis.
translation1.10: Disease-specific changes occur in pediatric (child) HPP when the skeletal disease is severe.
translation1.11: TNSALP mutation analysis is needed to determine recurrence (reappearance) for HPP in future pregnancies and for prenatal (at or before birth) diagnosis.
translation1.12: HPP was the last bone condition to have a medical treatment.
translation1.13: Now, significant successes using asfotase alfa, a prescription drug, are published concerning severely affected newborns, infants, and children.
translation1.14: Asfotase alfa was approved by regulatory agencies around the world in 2015 typically for pediatric-onset HPP.

26893260.Title: Hypophosphatasia - aetiology, nosology, pathogenesis, diagnosis and treatment

abstract.1: Hypophosphatasia is the inborn error of metabolism characterized by low serum alkaline phosphatase activity (hypophosphatasaemia).
abstract.2: This biochemical hallmark reflects loss-of-function mutations within the gene that encodes the tissue-nonspecific isoenzyme of alkaline phosphatase (TNSALP).
abstract.3: TNSALP is a cell-surface homodimeric phosphohydrolase that is richly expressed in the skeleton, liver, kidney and developing teeth.
abstract.4: In hypophosphatasia, extracellular accumulation of TNSALP natural substrates includes inorganic pyrophosphate, an inhibitor of mineralization, which explains the dento-osseous and arthritic complications featuring tooth loss, rickets or osteomalacia, and calcific arthopathies.
abstract.5: Severely affected infants sometimes also have hypercalcaemia and hyperphosphataemia due to the blocked entry of minerals into the skeleton, and pyridoxine-dependent seizures from insufficient extracellular hydrolysis of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate, the major circulating form of vitamin B6, required for neurotransmitter synthesis.
abstract.6: Autosomal recessive or dominant inheritance from ~300 predominantly missense ALPL (also known as TNSALP) mutations largely accounts for the remarkably broad-ranging expressivity of hypophosphatasia.
abstract.7: High serum concentrations of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate represent a sensitive and specific biochemical marker for hypophosphatasia.
abstract.8: Also, phosphoethanolamine levels are usually elevated in serum and urine, though less reliably for diagnosis.
abstract.9: TNSALP mutation detection is important for recurrence risk assessment and prenatal diagnosis.
abstract.10: Diagnosing paediatric hypophosphatasia is aided by pathognomic radiographic changes when the skeletal disease is severe.
abstract.11: Hypophosphatasia was the last type of rickets or osteomalacia to await a medical treatment.
abstract.12: Now, significant successes for severely affected paediatric patients are recognized using asfotase alfa, a bone-targeted recombinant TNSALP.

translation1.1: Hypophosphatasia is genetic condition that blocks metabolic pathways. It is characterized by hypophosphatasemia or low serum (blood) levels of a protein, alkaline phosphatase, that indicates bone health.
translation1.2: This biomarker, or a measurable compound to determine health status, reflects mutations within the gene that encodes the tissue-nonspecific isoenzyme (form) of alkaline phosphatase (TNSALP).
translation1.3: TNSALP is an enzyme that is expressed in the skeleton, liver, kidney and developing teeth.
translation1.4: In hypophosphatasia, accumulation of TNSALP natural substrates (substances altered by TNSALP) occurs. These substrates include inorganic pyrophosphate, an inhibitor (blocker) of mineralization. Accumulation of inorganic pyrophosphate explains the tooth loss, rickets or bone softening, and joint swelling.
translation1.5: Severely affected infants sometimes also have hypercalcemia (high calcium levels) and hyperphosphatasemia (high alkaline phosphatase levels). This is due to the blocked entry of minerals into the skeleton and pyridoxine-dependent seizures. The seizures are cause by insufficient breakdown of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate, the major circulating form of vitamin B6.
translation1.6: The different types of possible mutations of ALPL (which encodes for alkaline phosphatase) largely accounts for the wide range of severity of hypophosphatasia (a rare, genetic bone disorder).
translation1.7: High serum concentrations of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate represent an accurate and specific biomarker for hypophosphatasia.
translation1.8: Also, levels of phosphoethanolamine (which helps construct cell boundaries) are usually elevated in serum and urine. However, these biomarkers are less reliable for diagnosis.
translation1.9: TNSALP mutation detection is important to determine is recurrence may occur and prenatal diagnosis.
translation1.10: Diagnosing pediatric (child) hypophosphatasia is aided by observing disease-specific changes when the skeletal disease is severe.
translation1.11: Hypophosphatasia was the last bone disease to receive a medical treatment.
translation1.12: Now, significant successes for severely affected child patients are recognized using asfotase alfa, a prescription drug.

48.question: I have lupus. What can i do to stop it?

34681945.Title: The Pathogenesis, Molecular Mechanisms, and Therapeutic Potential of the Interferon Pathway in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and Other Autoimmune Diseases

abstract.1: Therapeutic success in treating patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is limited by the multivariate disease etiology, multi-organ presentation, systemic involvement, and complex immunopathogenesis.
abstract.2: Agents targeting B-cell differentiation and survival are not efficacious for all patients, indicating a need to target other inflammatory mediators.
abstract.3: One such target is the type I interferon pathway.
abstract.4: Type I interferons upregulate interferon gene signatures and mediate critical antiviral responses.
abstract.5: Dysregulated type I interferon signaling is detectable in many patients with SLE and other autoimmune diseases, and the extent of this dysregulation is associated with disease severity, making type I interferons therapeutically tangible targets.
abstract.6: The recent approval of the type I interferon-blocking antibody, anifrolumab, by the US Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of patients with SLE demonstrates the value of targeting this pathway.
abstract.7: Nevertheless, the interferon pathway has pleiotropic biology, with multiple cellular targets and signaling components that are incompletely understood.
abstract.8: Deconvoluting the complexity of the type I interferon pathway and its intersection with lupus disease pathology will be valuable for further development of targeted SLE therapeutics.
abstract.9: This review summarizes the immune mediators of the interferon pathway, its association with disease pathogenesis, and therapeutic modalities targeting the dysregulated interferon pathway.

translation1.1: Successfully treating patients with systematic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells) is limited by the different causes, its presence in multiple organs and systems, and a complex immune response.
translation1.2: Treatments that target certain inflammatory (infection-fighting) processes in the body may be needed for some patients.
translation1.3: One such target is the type I interferon pathway, a specific immune system pathway.
translation1.4: Type I interferons increase the production of interferon genes (genes that allow communication between cells to activate the immune system) and brings about critical immune responses to fight viruses.
translation1.5: Problems with the signaling in type I interferons are found in patients with lupus, and the extent of the problem is connected to how serious the disease is, making type I interferons possible targets for treatment.
translation1.6: The recent approval of the type I interferon-blocking antibody medicine, anifrolumab, by the US Food and Drug Administration for treating patients with lupus shows the value of targeting this pathway.
translation1.7: Nevertheless, the interferon pathway has multiple cells and signaling parts that are not completely understood.
translation1.8: Understanding the type I interferon pathway and how it relates to lupus will be valuable for future development of lupus treatments.
translation1.9: This review summarizes the immune process of the interferon pathway, its association with disease development, and therapeutic methods that target problems interferon pathway.

translation2.1: Treatment success for patients with full-body or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an inflammatory disease in which immune cells mistakely attack joints, skin, brain cells and more, is limited by muti-factor disease causes, multi-organ damage, full-body effect, and complex causes for immune cell dysfunction.
translation2.2: Treatment targeting creation and survival of antibody-creating immune cells are not effective for all patients, indicating a need to target other inflammatory groups.
translation2.3: One target group is the type I interferon pathway, a cellular signaling pathway that affects the entire immune system.
translation2.4: Type I interferons increase the amount of certain signaling proteins and influence important antiviral responses.
translation2.5: Impaired type I interferon signaling is detectable in many with SLE and similar diseases. The extent of this impairment is linked with disease severity, making type I interferons a possible treatment target.
translation2.6: The recent approval of the type I interferon blocking molcule or antibody, anifrolumab, by a government agency for treating SLE demonstrates the value of targeting this pathway.
translation2.7: Still, the interferon pathway affects multiple targets and signaling pathways that are incompletely understood.
translation2.8: Understanding the complex type I interferon pathway and its influence on lupus disease will be valuable for further development of targeted SLE treatments.
translation2.9: This review summarizes the immune middlemen of the interferon pathway, its link with disease creation, and treatments targeting the pathway when it is impaired.

34659263.Title: Clinical Experience of Proteasome Inhibitor Bortezomib Regarding Efficacy and Safety in Severe Systemic Lupus Erythematosus: A Nationwide Study

abstract.1: As treatment options in advanced systematic lupus erythematosus (SLE) are limited, there is an urgent need for new and effective therapeutic alternatives for selected cases with severe disease.
abstract.2: Bortezomib (BTZ) is a specific, reversible, inhibitor of the 20S subunit of the proteasome.
abstract.3: Herein, we report clinical experience regarding efficacy and safety from all patients receiving BTZ as therapy for SLE in Sweden during the years 2014-2020.
abstract.4: 8 females and 4 males were included with a mean disease duration at BTZ initiation of 8.8 years (range 0.7-20 years).
abstract.5: Renal involvement was the main target for BTZ.
abstract.6: Reduction of global disease activity was recorded by decreasing SLEDAI-2K scores over time and remained significantly reduced at the 6-month (p=0.007) and the 12-month (p=0.008) follow-up visits.
abstract.7: From BTZ initiation, complement protein 3 (C3) levels increased significantly after the 2nd treatment cycle (p=0.05), the 6-month (p=0.03) and the 12-month (p=0.04) follow-up visits.
abstract.8: The urine albumin/creatinine ratio declined over time and reached significance at the 6-month (p=0.008) and the 12-month follow-up visits (p=0.004).
abstract.9: Seroconversion of anti-dsDNA (27%), anti-C1q (50%) and anti-Sm (67%) was observed.
abstract.10: 6 of 12 patients experienced at least one side-effect during follow-up, whereof the most common adverse events were infections.
abstract.11: Safety parameters (C-reactive protein, blood cell counts) mainly remained stable over time.
abstract.12: To conclude, we report favorable therapeutic effects of BTZ used in combination with corticosteroids in a majority of patients with severe SLE manifestations irresponsive to conventional immunosuppressive agents.
abstract.13: Reduction of proteinuria was observed over time as well as seroconversion of some autoantibody specificities.
abstract.14: In most patients, tolerance was acceptable but mild adverse events was not uncommon.
abstract.15: Special attention should be paid to infections and hypogammaglobinemia.

translation1.1: Because treatment options in advanced systematic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells) are limited, there is an urgent need for new and effective treatment alternatives for selected cases with severe disease.
translation1.2: Bortezomib (BTZ) is a specific, reversible drug that stops the function of the protein complex called proteasome that breaks down unneeded or damaged proteins.
translation1.3: This study reports the effectiveness and safety of all patients receiving BTZ for lupus in Sweden during 2014-2020.
translation1.4: Eight females and 4 males are included with an average disease duration of 8.8 years when BZT is started.
translation1.5: Kidney involvement was the main target for BTZ.
translation1.6: Reduction of global disease activity is recorded by decreasing scores over time of the Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Disease Activity Index (SLEDAI-2K) that tracks disease activity and remained significantly reduced at the 6-month and the 12-month follow-up visits.
translation1.7: From BTZ initiation, levels of a protein that supports the immune system called complement protein 3 (C3) increased significantly after the 2nd treatment cycle, the 6-month, and the 12-month follow-up visits.
translation1.8: The urine test showing albumin protein in urine declined over time and reduced significantly at the 6-month and the 12-month follow-up visits.
translation1.9: The presence of certain antibodies (infecting-fighting molecules) related to lupus is observed.
translation1.10: Six out of 12 patients experienced at least one side-effect during follow-up, the most common adverse events are infections.
translation1.11: Tests to measure safety, including blood cell counts, mainly remained stable over time.
translation1.12: In conclusion, researchers found beneficial effects of BTZ when used in combination with corticosteroids (an anti-inflammatory drug also known as steroids) in most patients with severe lupus who do not respond to the standard treatments.
translation1.13: Reduction of proteinuria (elevated protein in urine) was observed over time as well as changes to specific antibodies.
translation1.14: In most patients, the side effects were tolerable but mild adverse events were not uncommon.
translation1.15: Special attention should be paid to infections and low levels of antibodies.

34659214.Title: Mesenchymal Stem Cell Therapy: Hope for Patients With Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

abstract.1: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease.
abstract.2: Although previous studies have demonstrated that SLE is related to the imbalance of cells in the immune system, including B cells, T cells, and dendritic cells, etc., the mechanisms underlying SLE pathogenesis remain unclear.
abstract.3: Therefore, effective and low side-effect therapies for SLE are lacking.
abstract.4: Recently, mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) therapy for autoimmune diseases, particularly SLE, has gained increasing attention.
abstract.5: This therapy can improve the signs and symptoms of refractory SLE by promoting the proliferation of Th2 and Treg cells and inhibiting the activity of Th1, Th17, and B cells, etc.
abstract.6: However, MSC therapy is also reported ineffective in some patients with SLE, which may be related to MSC- or patient-derived factors.
abstract.7: Therefore, the therapeutic effects of MSCs should be further confirmed.
abstract.8: This review summarizes the status of MSC therapy in refractory SLE treatment and potential reasons for the ineffectiveness of MSC therapy from three perspectives.
abstract.9: We propose various MSC modification methods that may be beneficial in enhancing the immunosuppression of MSCs in SLE.
abstract.10: However, their safety and protective effects in patients with SLE still need to be confirmed by further experimental and clinical evidence.

translation1.1: Systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus) is a type of chronic autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells and tissues.
translation1.2: The mechanisms and processes of how lupus develops remain unclear.
translation1.3: Therefore, effective therapies with low side effects for lupus are lacking.
translation1.4: Recently, therapy using mesenchymal stem cells (MSC), cells that are present in adult bone marrow and umbilical cords, for diseases including lupus has gained increasing attention.
translation1.5: This therapy can improve the signs and symptoms of lupus by promoting the development of Th2 and Treg cells that are involved in activating the immune system and slowing the activity of other cells that are overactive in cases of lupus (Th1, Th17, and B cells, etc.).
translation1.6: However, MSC therapy is also reported ineffective in some patients with lupus, which may be related to the stem cells or patient's factors.
translation1.7: Therefore, the treatment effects of MSCs should be further confirmed.
translation1.8: This review summarizes the status of MSC therapy in lupus treatment and potential reasons for the ineffectiveness of MSC therapy from three perspectives.
translation1.9: Researchers suggest various changes in MSC methods that may be beneficial in slowing the immune effect of MSCs in lupus.
translation1.10: However, their safety and protective effects in patients with lupus still need to be confirmed by more evidence.

34619975.Title: Redox homeostasis involvement in the pharmacological effects of metformin in systemic lupus erythematosus

abstract.1: Significance: Metformin has been proposed as a treatment for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
abstract.2: The primary target of metformin, the electron transport chain complex I in the mitochondria, is associated with redox homeostasis in immune cells, which plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases.
abstract.3: This review addresses the evidence and knowledge gaps on whether a beneficial effect of metformin in lupus may be due to a restoration of a balanced redox state.
abstract.4: Recent Advances: Clinical trials in SLE patients with mild to moderate disease activity and preclinical studies in mice have provided encouraging results for metformin.
abstract.5: The mechanism by which this therapeutic effect was achieved is largely unknown.
abstract.6: Metformin regulates redox homeostasis in a context-specific manner.
abstract.7: Multiple cell types contribute to SLE, with evidence of increased mitochondrial oxidative stress in T cells and neutrophils.
abstract.8: Critical issues: The major knowledge gaps are whether the efficacy of metformin is linked to a restored redox homeostasis in the immune system, and if it does, in which cell types it occurs?
abstract.9: We also need to know which patients may have a better response to metformin, and whether it corresponds to a specific mechanism?
abstract.10: Finally, the identification of biomarkers to predict treatment outcomes would be of great value.

translation1.1: Metformin is a medication that has been proposed as a treatment for systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells).
translation1.2: Metformin targets certain cells in the immune system that play a critical role in development of autoimmune diseases, which are diseases where the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells and tissues.
translation1.3: This review addresses the evidence and knowledge gaps on whether a beneficial effect of metformin in lupus may be due to a restoration of redox homeostasis, a balanced level of reactive oxygen molecules that signal to other cells.
translation1.4: Clinical trials in lupus patients with mild to moderate disease activity and studies in mice have provided encouraging results for metformin.
translation1.5: The mechanism that creates this therapeutic effect is largely unknown.
translation1.6: Metformin regulates redox homeostasis in specific situations.
translation1.7: Multiple cell types contribute to lupus.
translation1.8: The major knowledge gaps are whether the effectiveness of metformin is linked to a restored redox homeostasis in the immune system, and if it is linked, in which type of cells does it occur.
translation1.9: Researchers also need to know which patients may have a better response to metformin, and whether it relates to a specific mechanism or process in the body.
translation1.10: Finally, the identification of specific biological factors to predict treatment outcomes would be of great value.

translation2.1: Metformin, an anti-diabetic medication, may treat full-body or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an inflammatory disease in which immune cells mistakely attack joints, skin, brain cells and more.
translation2.2: The primary target of metformin, a specific energy-generator in the cell, is linked with electrical balance in immune cells, which influence the creation of diseases in which immune cells mistakely attack healthy cells.
translation2.3: This article reviews the evidence and knowledge gaps on whether metformin's beneficial effects in lupus may be due to a restored, balanced electrical state.
translation2.4: Clinical trials in SLE patients with mild to moderate disease severity and mice studies show encouraging results for metformin.
translation2.5: How this beneficial effect is achieved is largely unknown.
translation2.6: Metformin monitors electrical balance depending on the situation.
translation2.7: Multiple cell types contribute to SLE, with evidence of increased cellular stress in certain immune cells called T cells and neutrophils.
translation2.8: The major knowledge gaps are whether the success of metformin is linked to a restored electrical balance in the immune system. If it does, in which cell types it occurs?
translation2.9: We also need to know which patients may have a better response to metformin, and if it corresponds to a specfic biological process?
translation2.10: Finally, identifying markers to predict treatment outcomes would be very useful.

34618348.Title: Low-Dose Interleukin-2 as an Alternative Therapy for Refractory Lupus Nephritis

abstract.1: Introduction: Low-dose interleukin-2 (IL-2) selectively restores disturbances of regulatory T cells (Treg) and conventional T cells, resulting in the induction of remission in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus.
abstract.2: However, to date no research has been carried out on the efficacy of low-dose IL-2 in the treatment of refractory lupus nephritis (LN).
abstract.3: The aim of the study reported here was to investigate the renal response to low-dose IL-2 in patients with refractory LN.
abstract.4: Methods: The study population comprised ten patients with refractory LN who failed to achieve complete response or who had relapsed while being treated with at least two conventional immunosuppressive agents.
abstract.5: One treatment cycle consisted of IL-2 at a dose of 1 million IU administered subcutaneously every other day for 2 weeks followed by a 2-week break.
abstract.6: All patients received three cycles of IL-2 and were then followed up for another 12 weeks without any increase in the dose of previous immunosuppressive agents and steroids.
abstract.7: Results: Of the ten patients enrolled in the study, seven (70%) achieved ≥ 50% improvement in proteinuria at 12 weeks after initiating treatment with IL-2.
abstract.8: Median proteinuria was significantly reduced by 50.3% at week 12, from 1.83 (interquartile range [IQR] 1.23-3.21) g/24 h at baseline to 0.91 (IQR 0.52-1.60) g/24 h at 12 weeks (P = 0.005).
abstract.9: This was accompanied by a 71% reduction in urine erythrocytes, from 64/µl (IQR 24-102/µl) at baseline to 18/µl (IQR 2-20/µl) at 12 weeks (P = 0.018).
abstract.10: Anti-ds DNA was decreased from 27.9 (IQR 7.6-40.28) IU/ml at baseline to 14.1 (IQR 7.3-20.12) IU/ml (P = 0.021) at week 12, while complements C3 and C4 were slightly increased (P = 0.445, P = 0.241, respectively).
abstract.11: A significant expansion of Treg cells, from 9.3% at baseline to 16.6% at 12 weeks, was also found (P < 0.05).
abstract.12: No serious adverse events occurred during the treatment period.
abstract.13: Conclusions: Low-dose IL-2 therapy may have a promising role in the treatment of refractory LN as an alternative and safe therapeutic approach.
abstract.14: It may be used as multi-target combination therapy in clinical practice.

translation1.1: Interleukin-2 (IL-2) is a type of protein that promotes and develops immune cells at the start of an immune response and keeps them alive. A low-dose of interleukin-2 can restore changes of immune cells called T cells and Treg cells, resulting in the start of remission (recovery) in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells).
translation1.2: However, to date, no research has been carried out on the effectiveness of low-dose IL-2 in the treatment of lupus nephritis, a type of kidney disease caused by lupus.
translation1.3: The aim of this study is to investigate the kidney response to low-dose IL-2 in patients with lupus nephritis that is not responding to standard treatment.
translation1.4: The study includes 10 patients with lupus nephritis who failed to achieve a  complete response to standard treatment or who improved and then worsened while being treated with at least two standard treatments.
translation1.5: One treatment cycle consists of IL-2 given by an injection every other day for 2 weeks followed by a 2-week break.
translation1.6: All patients receive three cycles of IL-2 and are then followed up for another 12 weeks without any increase in the dose of the previous treatments or steroids.
translation1.7: Of the 10 patients enrolled in the study, 7 (70%) achieved 50% or more improvement in proteinuria (elevated levels of protein in the urine) at 12 weeks after starting IL-2 treatment.
translation1.8: Average proteinuria is significantly reduced by 50.3% at week 12.
translation1.9: There is also a 71% decrease in red blood cells in urine at 12 weeks.
translation1.10: An antibody (infection-fighting molecule) associated with lupus called anti-ds DNA decreased from the start of the study to week 12, while protein complements C3 and C4 used to monitor the immune systems are slightly increased.
translation1.11: A significant expansion of the immune Treg cells, from 9.3% at the start of the study to 16.6% at 12 weeks, is also found.
translation1.12: No serious negative events occurred while patients receive the treatment.
translation1.13: In conclusion, low-dose IL-2 therapy may have a promising role in the treatment of refractory lupus nephritis as an alternative and safe treatment approach.
translation1.14: Low-dose IL-2 may be used in combination with other medicines in clinical practice.

34615636.Title: B-cell depletion with obinutuzumab for the treatment of proliferative lupus nephritis: a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

abstract.1: Objective: Randomised trials of type I anti-CD20 antibodies rituximab and ocrelizumab failed to show benefit in proliferative lupus nephritis (LN).
abstract.2: We compared obinutuzumab, a humanised type II anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody that induces potent B-cell depletion, with placebo for the treatment of LN in combination with standard therapies.
abstract.3: Methods: Patients with LN receiving mycophenolate and corticosteroids were randomised to obinutuzumab 1000 mg or placebo on day 1 and weeks 2, 24 and 26, and followed through week 104.
abstract.4: The primary endpoint was complete renal response (CRR) at week 52.
abstract.5: Exploratory analyses through week 104 were conducted.
abstract.6: The prespecified alpha level was 0.2. Results: A total of 125 patients were randomised and received blinded infusions.
abstract.7: Achievement of CRR was greater with obinutuzumab at week 52 (primary endpoint, 22 (35%) vs 14 (23%) with placebo; percentage difference, 12% (95% CI -3.4% to 28%), p=0.115) and at week 104 (26 (41%) vs 14 (23%); percentage difference, 19% (95% CI 2.7% to 35%), p=0.026).
abstract.8: Improvements in other renal response measures, serologies, estimated glomerular filtration rate and proteinuria were greater with obinutuzumab.
abstract.9: Obinutuzumab was not associated with increases in serious adverse events, serious infections or deaths.
abstract.10: Non-serious infusion-related reactions occurred more frequently with obinutuzumab.
abstract.11: Conclusions: Improved renal responses through week 104 were observed in patients with LN who received obinutuzumab plus standard therapies compared with standard therapies alone.
abstract.12: Obinutuzumab was well tolerated and no new safety signals were identified.

translation1.1: Clinical trials studying the infection-fighting antibodies called rituximab and ocrelizumab failed to show benefit in severe cases of lupus nephritis, a kidney disease caused by lupus (when your immune system attacks healthy cells).
translation1.2: Obinutuzumab is an antibody that reduces B-cells, a type of protein that produces antibodies but also associated with diseases such as lupus. Researchers compared obinutuzumab with a placebo (inactive substance that looks like a medicine) for the treatment of lupus nephritis in combination with standard therapies.
translation1.3: Patients with lupus nephritis receiving standard treatments such as steroids are randomly put in a group to either receive obinutuzumab or a placebo. The drug or placebo are given on day 1 and weeks 2, 24 and 26, and followed through week 104.
translation1.4: The  main result is complete kidney response at week 52.
translation1.5: Additional analyses through week 104 are also done.
translation1.6: A total of 125 patients are randomly placed into either the obinutuzumab or the placebo group and did not know which group they are in.
translation1.7: Achievement of complete kidney response is greater with obinutuzumab at week 52  and at week 104.
translation1.8: Improvements in other kidney and blood tests are greater with obinutuzumab.
translation1.9: Obinutuzumab is not associated with increases in serious negative events, serious infections or deaths.
translation1.10: Reactions related to the infusion (injection) occurred more frequently with obinutuzumab but are not serious reactions.
translation1.11: In conclusion, improved kidney responses through week 104 are observed in patients with lupus nephritis who received obinutuzumab plus standard treatment compared with standard treatments alone.
translation1.12: Patients were able to tolerate side effects of obinutuzumab, and no new safety issues were identified.

34605394.Title: Comparative effectiveness and safety of belimumab and anifrolumab in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus: A Bayesian network meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials

abstract.1: Objective: To determine the relative effectiveness and safety of belimumab and anifrolumab in patients with active systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
abstract.2: Materials and methods: A Bayesian network meta-analysis was performed from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) on the effectiveness and safety of belimumab 10 mg, anifrolumab 300 mg, and a placebo in patients with active SLE.
abstract.3: Results: Six RCTs (2,757 patients) were included in this study.
abstract.4: The response rate based on the SLE 4 Responder Index (SRI4) at 52 weeks was substantially higher in the belimumab 10-mg and anifrolumab 300-mg groups than that in the placebo group (OR 2.90, % credible intervals (CrIs) 2.37 - 3.56; OR 1.60, % CrI 1.22 - 2.08).
abstract.5: The SRI4 response rate for belimumab 10 mg was significantly higher than that for anifrolumab 300 mg (OR 1.82, 95% CrI 1.30 - 2.53).
abstract.6: Ranking probability based on surface under the cumulative ranking curve (SUCRA) indicated that belimumab 10 mg was most likely the best treatment for SRI4 response (SUCRA = 0.999), followed by anifrolumab 300 mg (SUCRA = 0.500) and placebo (SUCRA = 0.001).
abstract.7: The number of serious adverse events (SAEs) did not differ significantly among the 4 treatment groups.
abstract.8: Conclusion: Based on the SRI4 response rate, belimumab 10 mg had the best response efficacy, followed by anifrolumab 10 mg.
abstract.9: However, there was no difference in the number of SAEs among the treatment options.

translation1.1: The objective of this study is to determine the effectiveness and safety of belimumab and anifrolumab, medications that lower the strength of the body's immune system, in patients with active systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells).
translation1.2: An analysis using data from different clinical studies is performed to understand the effectiveness and safety of belimumab, anifrolumab, and a placebo (sham treatment) in patients with active SLE.
translation1.3: Researchers found 6 relevant clinical studies that together have a total of 2,757 patients.
translation1.4: Using an assessment tool to measure how disease reacts to medication and other therapy, the response rate at 52 weeks is much higher in the belimumab and anifrolumab groups than that in the placebo group.
translation1.5: The response rate for belimumab is much higher than the response for anifrolumab.
translation1.6: Using data, a ranking system suggested that belimumab is most likely the best treatment for a response rate, followed by anifrolumab, and placebo.
translation1.7: The number of serious negative events are not significantly different among the 4 treatment groups.
translation1.8: In conclusion, based on the assessment (measurement) of response rate, belimumab has the best response effectiveness, followed by anifrolumab.
translation1.9: However, there is no difference in the number of serious negative events among the treatment options.

translation2.1: The study aimed to determine the relative success and safety of belimumab and anifrolumab, common immunosuppressive drugs, for patients with full-body or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an inflammatory disease in which immune cells mistakely attack joints, skin, brain cells and more.
translation2.2: An analysis was performed on randomized controlled trials (RCTs) on the success and safety of belimumab 10 mg, anifrolumab 300 mg, and a dummy treatment in patients with active SLE.
translation2.3: Six studies (2,757 patients) were analyzed.
translation2.4: Patient health at 52 weeks was much higher in the belimumab 10-mg and anifrolumab 300-mg groups than the dummy treatment group.
translation2.5: Patient health for the belimumab 10 mg group was higher than that for the anifrolumab 300 mg group.
translation2.6: Based on the analysis, belimumab 10 mg was most likely the best treatment, followed by anifrolumab 300 mg, and the sham treatment.
translation2.7: The number of harmful side effects did not differ among the 4 treatment groups.
translation2.8: Based on patient health measures, belimumab 10 mg had the best success, followed by anifrolumab 10 mg.
translation2.9: However, there was no difference in the number of harmful side effects among treatment options.

34603289.Title: Immunomodulatory Effect of MSCs and MSCs-Derived Extracellular Vesicles in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

abstract.1: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a common autoimmune connective tissue disease with unclear etiology and pathogenesis.
abstract.2: Mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) and MSC derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) play important roles in regulating innate and adaptive immunity, which are involved in many physiological and pathological processes and contribute to the immune homeostasis in SLE.
abstract.3: The effects of MSCs and EVs on SLE have been drawing more and more attention during the past few years.
abstract.4: This article reviews the immunomodulatory effects and underlying mechanisms of MSC/MSC-EVs in SLE, which provides novel insight into understanding SLE pathogenesis and guiding the biological therapy.

translation1.1: Systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus) is a common autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissues. It is unclear how the disease develops.
translation1.2: Mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) are cells that are present in adult bone marrow and the umbilical cord, and extracellular vesicles released from MSC cells are particles that carry molecules, proteins and other substances between cells.  These play important roles in regulating natural immunity and immunity acquired after exposure to a virus or to bacteria, which are involved in many disease development processes.
translation1.3: The effects of MSC cells and extracellular vesicles on lupus have been drawing more and more attention during the past few years.
translation1.4: This article reviews the changes in the body's immune system and underlying process of MSC and extracellular vesicles in lupus, which provides new insight into understanding the disease development of lupus and guiding therapy.

abstract.1: Lupus nephritis (LN) is the most frequent severe organ manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
abstract.2: About 30% of patients are refractory to treatment.
abstract.3: The authors report a case of treatment of LN with interleukin-17-targeted therapy, demonstrating its possible benefit, after reports of T helper 17 cell involvement in SLE pathogenesis.
abstract.4: We present the case of a childbearing age woman with SLE, who developed refractory LN despite all the indicated therapeutic options.
abstract.5: During follow up, infection with human papillomavirus was detected, a possible trigger, and the following management was based on this discovery.
abstract.6: We currently know that cytokines play a major role in tissue damage and interleukin-17 (IL-17) seems to be a fundamental key in SLE and LN, having shown its expression in renal glomeruli and urinary sediment.
abstract.7: Thus, it was decided to start treatment with an anti-IL-17A antibody, secukinumab.
abstract.8: After starting secukinumab, clinical and biological features improved and complete renal response was achieved.

translation1.1: Lupus nephritis is the most common form systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells) that severely impacts organs.
translation1.2: About 30% of patients do not respond to standard treatment.
translation1.3: This report summarizes a case of treating lupus nephritis by targeting a type of protein called interleukin-17, demonstrating its possible benefit.
translation1.4: The case is of a childbearing age woman with lupus who developed lupus nephritis and did not respond to available treatment.
translation1.5: During follow up visits with the patient, infection with a common sexually transmitted disease called human papillomavirus (HPV) is detected. A possible trigger and the following care and treatment is based on this discovery.
translation1.6: Interleukin-17 (IL-17 - a chemical messenger) seems to be a basic key in lupus and lupus nephritis.
translation1.7: Therefore, it is decided to start treatment with an anti-IL-17A antibody drug called secukinumab.
translation1.8: After starting secukinumab, clinical and biological features improved, and complete kidney response was achieved.

34528084.Title: Relationship of Anifrolumab Pharmacokinetics With Efficacy and Safety in Patients With Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

abstract.1: Objectives: To characterize the relationship of anifrolumab pharmacokinetics with efficacy and safety in patients with moderate to severe SLE despite standard therapy, using pooled data from 2 phase 3 trials.
abstract.2: Methods: TULIP-1 and TULIP-2 were randomized, placebo-controlled, 52-week trials of intravenous anifrolumab (every 4 weeks for 48 weeks).
abstract.3: For the exposure-response analysis, BILAG-based Composite Lupus Assessment (BICLA) or SLE Responder Index (SRI[4]) response rates at week 52 in each quartile/tertile of average anifrolumab serum concentration (Cave) were compared for anifrolumab and placebo in all-comers, patients who completed treatment, and interferon gene signature (IFNGS)-high patients who completed treatment, using average marginal effect logistic regression.
abstract.4: Relationships between exposure and key safety events were assessed graphically.
abstract.5: Results: Of patients in TULIP-1/TULIP-2 who received anifrolumab (150 mg [n = 91], 300 mg [n = 356]) or placebo (n = 366), 574 completed treatment, of whom 470 were IFNGS high.
abstract.6: In the exposure-efficacy analyses, BICLA and SRI(4) treatment differences favoring anifrolumab 300 mg vs placebo were observed across Cave subgroups and all analysis populations.
abstract.7: Logistic regression identified Cave as a significant covariate for predicted BICLA response, as higher anifrolumab Cave predicted greater efficacy.
abstract.8: There was no evidence of exposure-driven incidence of key safety events through week 52 in patients receiving anifrolumab 150 or 300 mg.
abstract.9: Conclusion: While higher Cave predicted greater efficacy, consistent positive benefit favouring anifrolumab 300 mg vs placebo was observed in BICLA and SRI(4) responses across Cave subgroups in the TULIP trials.
abstract.10: There was no evidence of exposure-driven safety events.

translation1.1: The objective of this study is to describe the relationship of how the drug called anifrolumab works with the effectiveness and safety in patients who have moderate to severe lupus (when your immune system attacks healthy cells) despite receiving standard therapy. The study uses data gathered from clinical study trials.
translation1.2: TULIP-1 and TULIP-2 are 52-week clinical trials of anifrolumab given through a vein every 4 weeks for 48 weeks.
translation1.3: Anifrolumab and placebo are compared using different assessment tools and analyses.
translation1.4: Relationships between exposure to the medication and key safety events are assessed graphically.
translation1.5: Of patients in TULIP-1/TULIP-2 who received anifrolumab (a total of 447 patients receiving a dose amount of 150 or 300mg) or sham treatment/placebo (366 patients), 574 patients completed treatment.
translation1.6: In the exposure-effectiveness analyses, treatment differences favoring anifrolumab (at 300) vs placebo are observed across subgroups of the study participants and all analysis populations.
translation1.7: The concentration of the drug is found to be a significant factor for having a response, as higher anifrolumab in blood predicted greater effectiveness.
translation1.8: There is no evidence of key safety events from taking the drug through week 52 in patients receiving anifrolumab 150 or 300 mg.
translation1.9: In conclusion, while higher concentration of the drug in blood predicted greater effectiveness, ongoing positive benefits of anifrolumab 300 mg vs placebo is observed across subgroups in the TULIP trials.
translation1.10: There is no evidence of safety events from exposure to the drug.

translation2.1: Using data from clinical trials, the study aimed to describe how anifrolumab, an immunosuppressive drug, operates effectively and safely in patients with moderate to severe full-body or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an inflammatory disease in which immune cells mistakely attack joints, skin, brain cells and more, under standard treatment.
translation2.2: We analyzed two randomized, 52-week trials, called TULIP-1 and TULIP-2, which involved injected anifrolumab treatment (every 4 weeks for 48 weeks).
translation2.3: To track patient health, we used specific assessments along with measurements of average anifrolumab blood concetration (Cave) to compare anifrolumab-treated patients, sham-treatment patients, patients who completed treatment, and patients with increased immune-specific genetic markers.
translation2.4: Trends between health and key safety events were assessed graphically.
translation2.5: Of patients in TULIP-1/TULIP-2 who got anifrolumab (91 received 150 mg, 356 received 300 mg) or sham treatment (366 patients), 574 completed treatment, of whom 470 had high levels of immune-specific molecules.
translation2.6: Patient health favored anifrolumab 300 mg vs dummy treatment across all analuzed populations.
translation2.7: Higher anifrolumab levels were linked to greater treatment success.
translation2.8: There was no evidence of treatment-related safety events through week 52 in patients receiving anifrolumab 150 or 300 mg.
translation2.9: Whil higher anifrolumab levels predicted greater success, consistent positive benefit favouring anifrolumab 300 mg vs dummy treatment was seen across assessments in subgroups of the TULIP trials.
translation2.10: There was no evidence of treatment-related safety events.

49.question: What causes pitted edema in legs?

33958571.Title: A 41-Year-Old Woman with Excessive Fat of the Lower Body Since Puberty with Progression to Swollen Ankles and Feet Despite Caloric Restriction, Due to Lipedema and Protein-Calorie Malnutrition: A Case of Stage 3 Lipedema

abstract.1: BACKGROUND Lipedema is a common condition that presents as excessive fat deposition in the extremities, initially sparing the trunk, ankles, and feet, and is found mainly in women, usually occurring after puberty or pregnancy.
abstract.2: Lipedema can progress to include lipo-lymphedema of the ankles and feet.
abstract.3: This report is of a 41-year old woman with Stage 3 lipedema and lipo-lymphedema with excessive fat of the lower body since puberty, with progression to swollen ankles and feet despite dietary caloric restriction.
abstract.4: CASE REPORT A 41-year-old woman noticed increased fat in her legs since age 12.
abstract.5: Her weight and leg size increased until age 21, when she reached a maximum weight of 165 kg, and underwent a Roux-En-Y gastric bypass.
abstract.6: Over 12 months, she lost 74.8 kg.
abstract.7: Her trunk significantly reduced in weight, but her legs did not.
abstract.8: Fifteen years later, during recovery from hysterectomy surgery, she became progressively weaker and swollen over her entire body.
abstract.9: Laboratory test results showed hypoalbuminemia (2.0 g/dL), lymphopenia, and hypolipoproteinemia.
abstract.10: She was diagnosed with protein and calorie malnutrition with marked gut edema requiring prolonged parenteral nutrition.
abstract.11: After restoration of normal protein, her health returned and her pitting edema resolved, but her extremities remained enlarged.
abstract.12: She was subsequently diagnosed with lipedema.
abstract.13: CONCLUSIONS This report demonstrates that early and correct diagnosis of lipedema is important, as women who believe the condition is due to obesity may suffer the consequences of calorie or protein-calorie deficiency in an attempt to lose weight.

translation1.1: Lipedema is a common condition where there is too much fat in the arms and legs and is found mainly in women, usually occurring after puberty (when a child's body changes to become an adult) or pregnancy.
translation1.2: Lipedema can progress to include lipo-lymphedema, which is a build up of fluid in addition to excess fat, in the ankles and feet.
translation1.3: This report is of a 41-year old woman with Stage 3 lipedema and lipo-lymphedema with excessive fat of the lower body since puberty. The woman's condition has advanced to swollen ankles and feet despite being on a low calorie diet.
translation1.4: The 41-year-old woman noticed increased fat in her legs since age 12.
translation1.5: Her weight and leg size increased until age 21, when she reached a maximum weight of 364 pounds (165 kg), and had a procedure called gastric bypass that involves a doctor placing a small pouch in the stomach and food only goes into that pouch.
translation1.6: Over 12 months, she lost 165 pounds (74.8 kg).
translation1.7: Her trunk (chest, stomach, and back) significantly reduced in weight, but her legs did not.
translation1.8: Fifteen years later, during recovery from surgery, she became continuously weaker and swollen over her entire body.
translation1.9: Lab test results showed hypoalbuminemia (low levels of the albumin protein in the blood), making it harder to move substances in the body. Tests also show low levels of white blood cells and low levels of fat lipids in the blood.
translation1.10: She was not eating enough protein and energy (through calories) to meet nutritional needs with edema (swelling) in the stomach, requiring that more nutrition be given through the vein.
translation1.11: After restoring protein to normal levels, her health returned and her pitting edema due to excess fluid resolved, but her arms and legs remained enlarged.
translation1.12: She was later diagnosed with lipedema.
translation1.13: In conclusion, this report shows that early and correct diagnosis of lipedema is important. Women who believe the condition is due to obesity may suffer from not enough calorie or protein-calories in an attempt to lose weight.

33714971.Title: A Case of Elephantiasis Nostras Verrucosa Secondary to Lymphedema Praecox Complicated by Congestive Cardiac Failure

abstract.1: BACKGROUND In lymphedema, an imbalance in the formation and absorption of lymph causes accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitium of the most gravity-dependent parts of the body.
abstract.2: Diagnosis is usually made based on patient medical history and a physical examination showing a typical appearance of the affected body part.
abstract.3: Differential diagnosis is confirmed by imaging.
abstract.4: CASE REPORT Primary lymphedema is inherited in through an autosomal dominant pattern.
abstract.5: Congestive cardiac failure and non-filarial infections predispose patients to the secondary form of lymphedema, elephantiasis nostras verrucosa (ENV).
abstract.6: We present the case of a 65-year-old man with lymphedema praecox complicated by congestive cardiac failure.
abstract.7: The patient was experiencing worsening left leg swelling and had a prior history of unilateral leg swelling at puberty.
abstract.8: The condition was inherited through an autosomal dominant pattern, as his father, elder brother, and nephew were diagnosed with the same disease.
abstract.9: The left leg showed non-pitting edema with indurated, woody skin and lichenification.
abstract.10: The right leg had mild pitting edema.
abstract.11: There were numerous verrucous folds and cobblestone-like nodules, and plaques and a painless ulcer on the left leg.
abstract.12: Laboratory evaluation demonstrated an elevated B-type natriuretic peptide.
abstract.13: He was treated with compression stockings and inelastic multi-layer bandaging and was administered limb decongestive treatment.
abstract.14: After 1 week of therapy, his swelling had somewhat improved.
abstract.15: CONCLUSIONS Various conditions can cause ENV and it can superimpose on any form of hereditary lymphedema.
abstract.16: The most effective strategy for this condition seems to be a thorough workup of the underlying cause of the ENV and early intervention.

translation1.1: In lymphedema, an imbalance of a fluid called lymph causes a build up of protein-rich fluid, usually in the arms and legs.
translation1.2: Diagnosis is usually made based on patient medical history and a physical examination of the affected body part.
translation1.3: The diagnosis may be confirmed by imaging, such as x-rays or another scan.
translation1.4: Primary lymphedema, also called hereditary lymphedema, is inherited (passed down from parent to child) through genes.
translation1.5: Congestive heart failure (inefficient heart pumping) and infections from soil particles make it easier for patients to develop the secondary form of lymphedema, elephantiasis nostras verrucosa (ENV). ENV is a rare chronic condition caused by ongoing infections with bacteria and causes a part of the body, usually the lower part of the body, to be extremely enlarged.
translation1.6: Researchers describe the case of a 65-year-old man with lymphedema complicated by congestive heart failure.
translation1.7: The patient was experiencing worsening left leg swelling and had a prior history of leg swelling at puberty (when a child's body changes to become an adult) due to disease.
translation1.8: The condition was inherited, as his father, elder brother, and nephew were diagnosed with the same disease.
translation1.9: The left leg showed non-pitting edema (there was no indentation when the area of swelling is pressed) with woody skin due to scaring that was also thick and leathery.
translation1.10: The right leg had mild pitting edema.
translation1.11: There were numerous folds and cobblestone-like lumps, raised red patches of the skin, and a painless ulcer (sore) on the left leg.
translation1.12: Lab tests showed high levels of a hormone made by the heart called B-type natriuretic peptide.
translation1.13: He was treated with compression stockings and bandaging and given decongestive treatment in the limb which includes several techniques such as draining fluid.
translation1.14: After 1 week of therapy, his swelling had somewhat improved.
translation1.15: In conclusion, various conditions can cause elephantiasis nostras verrucosa (ENV), and it can be an additional condition on any form of hereditary lymphedema.
translation1.16: The most effective strategy for this condition seems to be a detailed workup of the underlying cause of the ENV and early treatment and management.

32431556.Title: May-Thurner Syndrome: ﻿A Neglected Cause of Unilateral Leg Swelling

abstract.1: May-Thurner syndrome (MTS) is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the left iliac vein by the right iliac artery.
abstract.2: This condition predisposes the patient to deep venous thrombosis (DVT).
abstract.3: We present the case of a 30-year﻿-old female who arrived at the emergency department of our facility with progressive left leg swelling for four weeks, with low-risk probability for DVT.
abstract.4: Examination revealed left leg swelling with pitting edema extending up to the knee.
abstract.5: Her calf muscle was tender to palpation.
abstract.6: Dorsalis pedis, anterior tibial, and posterior tibial pulsations were fairly palpable due to the edema; however, the rest of her pulsations were appropriately felt.
abstract.7: Therefore, the provisional diagnosis of possible DVT was made, and further investigations were requested.
abstract.8: We present this case intending to highlight the clinical presentation of May-Thurner syndrome, its diagnosis, and treatment.

translation1.1: May-Thurner syndrome (MTS) is a clinical condition where the left iliac vein located in the abdomen that goes into the left leg is compressed by the right iliac artery which is a vein that goes into the right leg.
translation1.2: Having this condition makes it easier for the patient to develop deep venous thrombosis (DVT), a serious condition where a blood clot forms in the vein.
translation1.3: Researchers present the case of a 30-year﻿-old female who arrived at the emergency room with gradual left leg swelling for four weeks, with low-risk for developing DVT.
translation1.4: An exam revealed left leg swelling with pitting edema up to the knee, a condition where excess fluid builds up in one part of the body and pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation.
translation1.5: Her calf muscle was tender to light touch.
translation1.6: Veins in the foot, in the leg called the anterior tibial, and in the lower leg can be fairly felt due to the edema; however, the rest of her pulses were appropriately felt.
translation1.7: Therefore, the early diagnosis of possible DVT was made, and further investigations were requested.
translation1.8: Researchers present this case intending to highlight the clinical signs and symptoms of May-Thurner syndrome, its diagnosis, and treatment.

translation2.1: May-Thurner syndrome (MTS) is a condition in which the main right leg blood vessel compresses the main left leg blood vessel.
translation2.2: MTS puts the patient at risk of deep venous thrombosis (DVT), or deep blood clotting.
translation2.3: We describe a 30-year-old female who arrived at the emergency department with worsening left leg swelling for four weeks, with low-risk chance for DVT.
translation2.4: Exams showed left leg swelling with serious swelling up to the knee.
translation2.5: Her lower leg calf muscle was tender to touch.
translation2.6: Various blood vessel pulsations in the leg were noticeable due to the swelling. However, the rest of her pulsations were examined by touch.
translation2.7: Therefore, the identification of possibly DVT was made. Further invesetigations were requested.
translation2.8: We present this case to highlight the symptoms of May-Thurner syndrome, its identification, and treatment.

27586538.Title: Leg edema with (S)-amlodipine vs conventional amlodipine given in triple therapy for hypertension: a randomized double blind controlled clinical trial

abstract.1: Background: Leg edema is a common adverse effect of dihydropyridine Calcium Channel Blockers (CCB) that may need dose reduction or drug withdrawal, adversely affecting the antihypertensive efficacy.
abstract.2: Leg edema is reported to occur less often with (S)-amlodipine compared to conventional racemic amlodipine.
abstract.3: We aimed to find the incidence of leg edema as a primary outcome and antihypertensive efficacy with (S)-amlodipine compared to conventional amlodipine.
abstract.4: Methods: This prospective, double-blind, controlled clinical trial randomized 172 hypertensive patients, not controlled on beta-blockers (BB) and angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers (ACEI/ARB), to either conventional amlodipine (5-10 mg; n = 86) or (S)-amlodipine (2.5-5 mg; n = 86), while continuing their previous anti-hypertensive medications.
abstract.5: Sample was sufficient to find a difference in edema between the interventions with 80 % power at 5 % significance level.
abstract.6: Intension to treat analysis (ITT) for safety data and per protocol analysis for efficacy data was performed.
abstract.7: Fischer's exact test was applied to observe difference between responder rates and proportions of subjects having peripheral edema in the two groups.
abstract.8: Pitting edema test scores were compared using Mann-Whitney test.
abstract.9: Results: Altogether 146 patients (amlodipine, n = 76 and (S)-amlodipine, n = 70) completed 120 days treatment.
abstract.10: Demographic variables and treatment adherence were comparable in the two groups.
abstract.11: Incidence of new edema after randomization was 31.40 % in test group and 46.51 % in control group [p = 0.03; absolute risk reduction (ARR) = 15.1 %; Number Needed to Treat (NNT) = 7, ITT analysis].
abstract.12: Pitting edema score and patient rated edema score increased significantly in the control compared to test group (p = 0.038 and 0.036 respectively) after treatment period.
abstract.13: Edema scores increased significantly in the control group from baseline (p < 0.0001).
abstract.14: Responders in blood pressure were 98.57 % in test and 98.68 % in control group.
abstract.15: Most common adverse events (AE) were pitting edema and increased urinary frequency.
abstract.16: Incidence of all AEs other than edema was similar in both groups.
abstract.17: Two serious AEs occurred unrelated to therapy.
abstract.18: Biochemical and ECG parameters in the two groups were comparable.
abstract.19: Conclusions: In hypertensive patients not controlled on prior BB and ACEI/ARB therapy, addition of (S)-amlodipine besylate at half the dose of conventional amlodipine provides better tolerability with reduced incidence of peripheral edema, and equal antihypertensive efficacy compared to amlodipine given at usual doses.

translation1.1: Leg edema is a common side effect of dihydropyridine Calcium Channel Blockers (CCB), medicines taken to control blood pressure and other conditions. The dose amount of CBB drugs may need to be reduced or stopped, negatively impacting the drugs' use to control blood pressure.
translation1.2: Leg edema (fluid swelling) is reported to occur less often with a type of CBB medicine called (S)-amlodipine compared to the regular racemic amlodipine medicine.
translation1.3: Researchers aim to find the number of times leg edema appeared and how well blood pressure is lowered with (S)-amlodipine compared to conventional amlodipine.
translation1.4: This clinical trial followed 172 patients with high blood pressure, not controlled by using beta-blockers (BB) drugs or angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers (ACEI/ARB) that keep blood vessels open. These patients are randomly placed in groups to receive either standard amlodipine (86 patients) or (S)-amlodipine (86 patients), while continuing their previous anti-hypertensive medications.
translation1.5: The number of patients in this study is sufficient to find a difference in edema between the two groups.
translation1.6: Data from both treatment groups are analyzed during the study.
translation1.7: Data are analyzed to observe the difference between the two groups on how they responded to the treatment and the number of people who develop peripheral edema (swelling in lower legs and hands).
translation1.8: Pitting edema, a condition where excess fluid builds up in one part of the body and pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation, is measured and scored.
translation1.9: Altogether 146 patients completed 120 days treatment: 76 patients in the standard amlodipine group and 70 in the (S)-amlodipine group.
translation1.10: Characteristics such as age and sex and how well patients took the medicine as directed are compared between the two groups.
translation1.11: New edema is 31.40 % in the (S)-amlodipine group and 46.51 % in the standard group.
translation1.12: Pitting edema score and patient rated edema score increase significantly in the amlodipine compared to (S)-amlodipine group after the treatment period.
translation1.13: Edema scores increase significantly in the amlodipine group from the start of the study.
translation1.14: Responders in blood pressure are 98.57 % in (S)-amlodipine and 98.68 % in amlodipine group.
translation1.15: Most common side effects are pitting edema and increase in urinary frequency.
translation1.16: Number of all side effects other than edema is similar in both groups.
translation1.17: Two serious side effects occur that are unrelated to therapy.
translation1.18: Results from other blood and heart tests in the two groups are similar.
translation1.19: In patients with high blood pressure not controlled on prior BB and ACEI/ARB therapy, adding (S)-amlodipine besylate at half the dose of standard amlodipine provides few side effects. There is also a reduced number of peripheral edema, and equal ability to lower blood pressure compared to amlodipine given at usual doses.

30524565.Title: Impact of low-dose prednisolone on refractory pitting edema manifesting remitting seronegative symmetrical synovitis with pitting edema syndrome

abstract.1: We encountered an elderly male patient who after cardiac surgery for mitral stenosis had refractory pitting edema in both legs involving painful leg joints after a 1-month history of waxing and waning arthralgia.
abstract.2: His family doctor had prescribed a combination of diuretics, 40 mg furosemide and 25 mg spironolactone; however, pitting edema in his lower legs persisted.
abstract.3: He was diagnosed with worsening of congestive heart failure because of a previous cardiac surgery and was transferred to our hospital.
abstract.4: On admission, we closely observed the patient's condition and noticed that his body temperature increased to 38.0 °C every evening.
abstract.5: Furthermore, his ankle joints felt feverish and were swollen.
abstract.6: Therefore, we suspected polyarthritis as an etiology, although we initially suspected rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
abstract.7: Antibody testing did not support RA diagnosis; therefore we concluded the association of remitting seronegative symmetrical synovitis with pitting edema (RS3PE) syndrome with his condition.
abstract.8: After daily treatment with 15 mg prednisolone, the refractory edema symptom dramatically improved.
abstract.9: The concept of RS3PE syndrome could explain such as an impressive clinical course.
abstract.10: <Learning objective: Physicians encounter patients with pitting edema of unknown etiology in daily clinical practice.
abstract.11: In particular, cardiologists usually tend to prescribe diuretics for patients with pitting edema in their legs.
abstract.12: Cardiologists should consider RS3PE syndrome as a differential diagnosis, for patients with localized pitting edema in their extremities.
abstract.13: This report cautions regarding arbitrarily prescribing diuretics for localized pitting edema.>.

translation1.1: Doctors saw an elderly male patient who after heart surgery had pitting edema in both legs, a condition where excess fluid builds up in part of the body and pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation. The man also had painful leg joints after a 1-month history of periodic changes in joint stiffness.
translation1.2: His family doctor had prescribed a combination of diuretics, medicines that help remove salt and water from the body; however, pitting edema in his lower legs continued.
translation1.3: He was diagnosed with worsening of congestive heart failure (inefficient heart pumping) because of a previous heart surgery and transferred to the hospital.
translation1.4: On admission to the hospital, doctors closely observed the patient's condition and noticed that his body temperature increased to 100.4 F (38.0 C) every evening.
translation1.5: Additionally, his ankle joints felt feverish and were swollen.
translation1.6: Therefore, doctors suspected arthritis in at least five joints (polyarthritis) as a potential cause, although doctors first thought it was rheumatoid arthritis (RA - a long-lasting arthritis from immune cells attacking healthy cells).
